content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												I'm a hard core THIEF fan, I was there when THIEF 1 hit the shelves, addicted ever since.  A complete THIEF outfit & blackjack, a real nut job over this game. I too was drooling when Theif 4 was on the horizon, but put it off till after I began reading the reviews...  Still, I bought it far later when it was on super-duper sale ($8 bucks).   So lets get to the facts that whatever you heard about this game is true: 1. THIEF 4  is an artificial soybean byproduct colored & shaped to look like the original Franchise game.  (ie: lacking)2. They did get alot of things right~such as great graphics and interesting storyline + grappling hook for climbing.3. However, they simply got far too many things wrong ~ annoyingly wrong - to the point gamers wonder if the developers even bothered testing a play-through before release.  In reality, they could have fixed some outrageously annoying bugs after-the-fact with a simple update: but did not.  So why is it there is so much UTTER HATE for this beautiful game that had such a loyal following  ?   well...3.a: Even if you never played THIEF before, you will wonder why they designed EVERY window entry as "Carpel Tunnel Syndrome" with animation ??? this was one of their top idiotic moves.  Imagine having a severe repetition compulsive disorder every time you had to open a door EVERY DOOR (but a window instead) = now you understand.  (tap key 10 times EVERY time= omg, omg omg.. stop omg why did they design it this way?... omg !)3.b: THIEF 4 has the most Frustrating map design system you will ever experience (seriously) its so aggravating to try to find your way around that you just give up.. thats right... just say "screw this!" and give up, because the place you need to get to is only a few feet away, the map flag shows it as such, but you CANNOT find a way to get to it... its flabergasting that ANYONE let alone a game developer would design such a wonky broken map.   3.c:  Do you get lost often playing THIEF 4 ?  you're not alone, it's because the mini-maps links to mini-mini-maps- even loading for a single (yes ONE TINY ROOM = mini-mini-mini map)  its so annoying that it saps the fun out of the game, your life and your own existance (its that aggravating).3.d: Forced play cut-scenes: ?  Developers, you DO NOT force people to PLAY through cutscenes where you can die and have to do so 10 - 20 times forced to watch the same damn animation over and over and over again until they either get it right (or) trash their console with a nearby broken chair leg!  The lead developer of THEIF 4 should go hide in a cave in the deepest reaches of Nepal ~ his name forever shunned.4. Garrett already had a back story ~ as the unsung hero that faded into the shadows, sacraficing far more than he had ever swiped:   Now, Garrett is but a ... well, just a lowly lame Thief: steal this - steal that - go back to the same place and steal same stuff again - or only find empty LOCKED safes ?  and who keeps relocking the grates ?  and why are there grungy weapon merchants in God forsaken holes in the ground or ruins that makes No sense whatsoever.  Reliving the Asylum and the undercity was a tad unoriginal ~ we really expected more creativity.5. Okay, so done with the rant, the point was there were alot of silly flaws with this game that could have been so easily fixed with an update (but were not for some reason) that would have made the experience alot more fun.  NOTE: forced animation and compulsive disorder on every window entry is a FAIL!  plus; the map design is an inexcusable FAIL FAIL FAIL!   Now considering this is a 20 (yes twenty) gig download and as drooling fans waited 10 years for Thief 4 we expected some meat & potatos, not the knob of a water arrow in the♥♥♥♥♥♥6. (buy it on sale) It was worth the $8, but would not pay retail: and it took 48hrs to download via DSL; replayability ?  maybe for some in Hard Mode, but I won't bother because I NOW HAVE CARPEL TUNNEL SYNDROME (thanks Eidos)  and would rather not have to take medication due to mental distress from navigating the map over again.OVERVIEW: This was a surprising fail for an Original Series that had such great promise and Loyal Gamer following; I truly hope the Taffers at Eidos Montreal didn't kill off the THIEF franchise with one to many club taps to the skull and  Garrett sulks away forever into the shadows; and hope a New Developer worth their sack of gold will continue his legacy. ...It's a Keeper !

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												This game made me take a break from PC gaming.After watching my other beloved stealth series, Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell, turn to hell, I was desperately wishing the same wasn't true for Thief. I desperately wanted to play this game and find out that all the negative reviews were inaccurate, and that the few positive reviews that claimed all the haters were just playing on the easy difficulty. I desperately wanted to believe that cranking up all the difficulty settings and removing all the visual aids would actually matter. But everything the haters said came to be the truth. In a great stealth game, patience is essential for perfection and spending 3 hours on one mission is completely acceptable if it leads to that 100% stealth rating. In a great stealth game, like the older Thiefs or Splinter Cell 1-4, the more slow and careful I am, the more fun I am having and the more immersed I am. In this game, the longer you take, the more ugly flaws you realize in the mission design and it kills the stealth experience. Guards are literally on a non-stop patrol loop, repeating the exact same actions and phrases over and over without ever throwing something new at you. Everything looks and sounds great at first glance, the lighting is undeniabely good, but at a closer look it is never that impressive. How can a master thief like Garrett not be able to do anything about a store that is "closed"? A "closed" sign should be a signal that I can go inside and steal stuff, but not in this game. The only places that are accessible have a great big orb shining on them so you'll have no problem finding where to go. It is horrible level design. I wanted to get immersed into this game with my ridiculously powerful PC but I was never able to, and because there are no good stealth titles coming anytime soon, I decided to sell my rig and take a break from gaming. All because of this garbage modern rehash of a legendary stealth series, just like what happened to Splinter Cell. It should be a crime for these AAA developers to make sh***ty games, put a coat of fancy graphics on, and than slap on the name of a legendary series just to trick people into buying!!!! Maybe one day they will get it right...

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Before I get to what I didn’t like, I suppose I should get to what I thought was alright about this reboot. Visually speaking, it sports a solid look—from the environments to the characters, lighting, shadows, and art style. That’s not to say that it holds up in every regard visually; a lot of people don’t like Garrett’s redesign with a common complaint being his black eye liner making him look “emo,” but it’s not that hard to overlook if you don’t get caught up on it and you could even come to view it as something that makes sense given his chosen profession. The change of voice actor also didn’t really bother me, which is another hangup some people have when comparing it to its predecessors—other voices are either good or mediocre.Of course, the audiovisual side of things is less important than the gameplay, and in that regard I found Thief to be underwhelming but (mostly) competent–from the mission design, to the sneaking mechanics, pacing, level design, etc. Unfortunately, a lot of what’s good about the game gets bogged down by various annoyances which include:— Lots of repetitive forced animations. Grabbing loot, opening drawers and cabinets (many of which are empty and just waste your time), opening windows, enemy takedowns, etc. There’s also a long animation of Garrett moving a wooden beam out of his way that they reuse way too many times—sometimes they want you to mash X to move it and sometimes they don’t, although unlike the windows (more on those below) these are always used to section off map areas within a map or serve as a transition to a new area.— There’s no indication as to whether or not a window leads to a lootable room within the map you’re in, or if it’s a transition to another area until after you’ve already initiated the animation; if you get the prompt to tap X it’s a lootable room, if you don’t it’s a map transition.— I don’t believe the glow on rooms that strictly serve as loot locations goes away after you’ve cleared them and left, so you might end up going back into an empty room at some point if you don’t remember all of the places you’ve been.— Somewhat clunky, limited movement. The context sensitive run/jump/mantle function screws up sometimes. There are areas you should be able to get to but can’t because the rope arrows only work at specific points. I understand the need to keep you caged to some extent, but there were times where I felt my options where limited when they shouldn’t have been.— Cutscene direction and dialog was a bit stilted, the story felt like it wasn’t fully realized and the ending was kind of a mess. The only thing notable about the “Thief-taker General” is his massive bald spot and his penchant for being a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ other than that he was just a one-dimensional filler character that never amounted to much and got too much screen time.— Awful audio mixing; sounds cut off abruptly instead of fading in and out and there are inconsistencies in how loud some sounds are compared to others.—I understand it’s a reboot and they want to do their own thing, but I wish they had kept the Order of the Hammer in as a prominent backstory element. They only ever really indirectly refer to the Hammerites when they reference “The Old Gods” and with the brief appearance of the hammer symbolism in a specific area later in the game, outside of that it’s pretty much been taken out of the lore.— Lastly, and perhaps most egregiously; the guards don’t indiscriminately call people taffers.I don’t have much attachment to the original games but this one still managed to disappoint me in various ways; however, with all that being said I didn’t necessarily dislike it, it just has some glaring faults and questionable design decisions which left me feeling like it was largely wasted potential—unfinished and average in nearly every way.

number of helpful: 217 of 385 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Just a quick first impressions of the game so far. I'm one of the people who thought this just looks like a reskinned version of Dishonored (and I don't know if they've changed anything visually since then because it no longer does look like that to me) but so far I'm happy to say it is its own game overall. (review is a bit lengthy... sorry, I tried to clean it up a bit and categorize things.tl;dr: if you want a purely stealth game with minimal combat and story elements, you may like this. If you're looking for anymore than that skip this game or wait for a price drop)Visuals/animationVisually, it's pretty fantastic and I don't have all the settings maxed out. Models and animations are very well done as well from what I can tell (random NPC animations aren't the best but whatever, they're not that important). I just wish I could play it in third person due to the character movement being really annoying (there's a lot of bobbing, too much for me). Almost all textures on max settings look great. You might run into some blurry or muddy ones but they are quite rare.The one thing that is a bit annoying to me is the character movement. Whenever you walk forward the camera zooms in a bit, when you stop, the camera zooms back out. Same with all directions, it gets annoying. It has WAY too much of a "bobbing" effect and I absolutely hate this about the movement system and the reason I wish I could just play in third person.I've now gotten to a point in the game where it goes into third person for some wall climbing/scaling sections. Animations look great, camera however... it kind of swings wildly. It's very hard to control and doesn't let you view much yourself, you're better off just letting it automatically show you the way to go.Story/gameplayIt seems to have some supernatural elements to it like Dishonored did and the story also seems to be pretty similar to Dishonored's so far. The "gloom" is a sickness and people are quarantined, just like the plague in Dishonored, everyone tries to avoid these people and they're treated quite harshly. The most obvious similarity to Dishonored is probably the "focus" vision that highlights all interactables, traps, loot, etc... This has FAR more atmosphere than Dishonored in my opinion though but unlike Dishonored I haven't run into any memorable characters (yet). They all seem pretty bland and unimportant.It has also been a bit hard to tell where you can jump and where you'll just fall to your death. Sometimes the game prevents you from walking off of ledges and sometimes the game doesn't. When it doesn't prevent you from walking off you can die or get seriously injured (kind of a minor nitpicky thing but I thought I should mention it. Also, not being able to jump AT ALL outside of predetermined locations feels a bit awkward). I wish this was more consistent.Checkpoints/autosaves seem pretty scarce so make sure you quicksave (F5 by default) often, you can go through an entire mission, instantly die to a trap and start all the way from the beginning again.The QTE events are a bit annoying to be honest... I don't feel like mashing 'E' to open windows every time. I found three of them in a pretty short distance so to have to do that gets tedious and annoying.The missions for me seemed very slow going and I'm struggling to continue playing because of that and the fact that I don't know WHY I'm playing. I feel like I'm just going around stealing crap for no good reason. Yeah I'm a Thief but what is my purpose, just survive? Why am I doing this? The game has yet to tell me. I'm assuming/hoping this will change in the future.Stealth, what can I say? It's nothing special. It works. It seems fair. There's nothing "bad" about the stealth mechanics, they seem pretty solid. I kind of wish I could see the line of sight for enemies or have some way of telling who is going to freak out when they see me (civillians sometimes freak out and start yelling, but some don't... there doesn't seem to be a way to tell who's who).Audio/musicOne small annoyance is that some of the music is very poorly implemented. Out of no where some weird, loud, techno/dubstep/electronic sounding music started playing and I had no idea what was going on since right before that started there was very soft ambient sounds and music. There was no action and I wasn't spotted or anything. It felt very out of place. I'm considering turning off the music entirely, it was jarring and unnecessary.Another very minor annoyance is that the audio seems to travel through walls unobstructed. There's no sense of distance between you and the characters speaking. This makes it kind of hard to pinpoint where people are by sound because they might sound like they're right next to you when in reality they might be outside of the building or several floors above/below you. They really need to work on this.The rest of the audio like the voice acting and ambience is very good. Especially the voice acting (lip syncing and facial expressions kind of let down the quality of the voice acting since those aren't too great, especially for random NPCs. It's a bit weird hearing someone moan in pain or complain but their face is not doing anything to express that). Sometimes there isn't even any lip syncing at all just a blank face for random NPCs, this is really disappointing to me.I've run into several audio bugs now, NPCs constantly repeating lines and getting cut off. And there is little to no variety in the random chatter. You might hear the NPCs say the same exact thing three times in a row, or every single time. It gets annoying since it doesn't add anything to the game at that point.Quality of the PC portThe PC port is great, probably one of the best. It has all of the options you would want and then some (I just wish you could disable the bobbing). Menus are great, you can navigate with your mouse, press escape to go back to the previous menu, pretty much everything you would want in terms of functionality for menus. All keys are rebindable, lots of options for toggling on/off UI elements, so that's great.The ability to have custom difficulties is absolutely fantastic for the people who really want to control every little aspect of the game. You can play it as hardcore as you want or as easy as you want.Overall thoughtsThe game is very slow paced and not action oriented at all. Do not expect this to be like Dishonored in terms of gameplay. Combat is terrible, however, I think they only added in combat to give you SOME option of survival rather than immediately losing when you get spotted. It's almost a 100% stealth based game which means it can be very very slow paced. If you are looking for action and combat, this is definitely not the game you want.The game can also be very linear (and I feel like there might be a lot of back tracking if you want to get all the stuff). The first few missions and areas there are several places you can't go and items you can't get because you don't have the tools. You buy those a bit later, then you have access to certain passages.The game kind of pushes you in the direction they want you to go while having the illusion that it's much more open. Not necessarily a bad thing and it's not extreme linearity but it's still a bit disappointing. Definitely not like Assassin's Creed and probably not even like Dishonored in most cases, it's a bit more linear than the latter.Mixed feelings about it but I am only a few hours into the game. If you are heavily into stealth based gameplay and NOT into combat, I think you will enjoy this game. There aren't many other games out there that cater to this genre.

content:
Posted: April 14
												I ended up having to borrow a copy from a friend + finish this on a console - it's terribly formatted for PC and prone to crashing - even on above recc'd settings. 8) 8) 8)I was looking forward to this game when it came out, I wanted to be optimistic about a continuation of the Thief series. The setting, the characters, the story - it was a really fun little universe and I missed having a pure stealth game to play with the kind of open, sprawling levels and dark corners you could hide in while you listened to guards and NPCs gossip and♥♥♥♥♥♥ There really wasn't any of that in this game? There are *improvements* to the detection system and some neat little gimmicks like swooping (moving quickly from one corner to the next to try and avoid being seen), but movement in general is limited and clunky. It's hard to distinguish what you can and cannot climb on initially, and once you realize what you're able to mantle up on ... it's a bit disheartening, to say the least. You cannot jump (a LOT of puzzles and simple obstacles could easily be avoided if the player could jump over them), you cannot place rope arrows in areas that would be practical, etc. Not all doors, windows, etc are accessible when you're in the City.It's a minor nitpick but I also cannot stand how clunky combat is should you actually end up in a situation where you are detected. I realize the justification behind it is ~Garrett doesn't fight / kill~ and ~you should try to ghost this game~ but ffs, you really do need to smooth out combat just a little so you can properly defend yourself enough to back out of a fight if you want to encourage your players to be nonlethal. There are other ways to motivate a player to try a ghosting / nonlethal route, annnd this is not really the way to go about it tbh.The City and levels are pretty much barren via a plague plot device and it's depressing - and not in a good way. NPC types are severely limited, lowering any challenge you could have in planning your approach to each level and client job. The story itself is incredibly short, disjointed, and reaches an unsatisfying conclusion. Levels feel repetitive and dull. I *did* enjoy the shorter client job missions you could pick up optionally from various NPCs throughout the CIty, but even then it didn't feel worthwhile.Framerate issues abound, no matter what your settings are. Cutscenes love to crash and load oddly - animation is awkward despite the use of mocap to try and (I guess?) inject realism into the characters' facial expressions and body movement. Dialogue is unnatural and - again - severely disjointed. From what I understand of the history behind this game, it's no wonder it turned out to be a mess. It's just a shame - really disappointing. It can be fun at times, and I see the potential behind it, but as it stands it's just ... Yeah.I don't really think I can recommend this game to anyone, Thief fan or not. 8(

Posted: August 6, 2016
												A game that's painful to play in several ways. It's obvious that a lot of hard work went into Thief, but the end result is so confused and poorly executed that I actually feel sorry for the developers.The game is so linear it's practicaly on-rails. Even that might have been OK if there was something to support this design choice - a great story, perhaps, or thrilling combat. Unfortunately, there isn't. The game is dull, dreary, and depressing to play due to its relentless mediocrity. This really isn't worth your time or money.If you want a great modern stealth game, I instead strongly recommend Splinter Cell: Blacklist or Dishonored.

												This game has nothing of the original Thief, which I dearly loved and still do as the best stealth games ever made.The gameplay basics are there, but the excessive linearity of most levels and the consequent lack of freedom left to the player prevents them from reaching the excellence of its venerable predecessors.Finally, the story is in itself asbolutely, cringeworthy terrible - it is poorly written, it is replete with the most shallow tropes of the genre and doesn't fit the character of Garrett at all - without mentioning Garrett's character design itself, which I find completely anachronistic, ill-fitting and poorly motivated.What an incredible let-down, and how much good programming and art wasted.

Product received for free
												Ah Thief. What nostalgic memories of games gone by. That feeling of lonely vast halls, tall-ceiling buildings, creepy abandoned (really?) houses. Those were the first three games.This last Thief is nothing like that.Linear it may be, and frustrating to have to access areas again and again and each time discover those re-spawned npcs. Damn it! And rooms that go nowhere when you're trying to get through to the other side, access points to other parts of the map that let you in but don't let you out so another way has to be found, falling down ladders until you realise on pc it's W+Space. Wha? But still, I enjoyed the game, it looks good, there's still some strategising and some difficult areas that have to be worked out. Characters don't have much dimension and the game felt short and rushed. But all in all, it was a great Christmas present and from my son at that. It's replayable as well.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Thiefs back from a long hibernation to prove its worth, is it any good? Thief is a stealth first-person stealing game set in a alternate steam punk age where poverty is strong and plauge is common, in this mess you play as Garret the master thief from the previous games and you run around stealing expensive things. I found myself loosing interest a bit in to the game and I could never realy get back to playing from where I was so I just left it as it was. This is a very slow paced game that realy tests your patiance, now you could either love this or hate it. As you are a thief, combat is not realy a viable option and as such you often find yourself doing odd choices you wouldn`t do when you have a flame arrow and a gaurd walks pass you such as lerk in a closet way to long just waiting for the gaurd to leave as he never does. Sure it can be very satisfying to sneak pass a dozen gaurds unnoticed but after a while I found myself growing tired of the same exact scheme that I had been pulling the 6 or 7 hours that I had been stealing that being acting passive. Anyways, the visuals are pretty great and there is some nice 3D tessellation going on which of course looks great! The games is I guess OK optimized with weird FPS drops here and there ( tested on R9-290 ) could  definatly need some smoothing out. Hard to recommend this game for everyone based on its extreme stealth elements. Still a great game with lots of atmosphere. I'd say go a little loud with the weaponry to spice things up at least if you cant take the slow gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I am a huge fan of the original Thief games which are in my top 10 favorite games of all time. So I was worried this new game would not live up to the original. I am about half way thru it and I think it does it justice. In many respects they improved things, such as the graphics, which is to be expected. The sneak aspect is tough in this game like it should be., They leave it optional how you want to power your character up, so he can have an easier time or not, They add some stuff like dogs and birds in cages that can react to your presence, which is great, The voice actors aren't the same but are OK. A problem with this game that the older game did not have is the characters have limited sound bytes so you hear the same dialog a lot. The old games were good about not doing that. The writing isn't as good, but its not bad. It's just that the original games were top notch. As good as Half Life games. This is solid but not quite as powerful. The original games had a creepy feel to them that was actually very effective. You always felt danger was around every corner.I just replayed all of them and they still worked on me. This game doesn't do that quite as well. But it is still very good, regardless, and it is not easy. It also has excellent puzzles and Tomb Raider style climbing skills which it needed. So I would say it's well worth the money and I want more. Thief is an awesome series.

Steampunk stealth-action with an idiotic story. I have not played the original "Thief", this is my first game I traversed in this series and I can not compare it to its predecessors. The game begins with the fact that Garrett got into the apartment what that drunken man and begins to rob him and idiocy happening immediately catches the eye. Garrett steals from the poor man all, start from spoons and purse and ending with the chandelier. In the beginning it was not annoying, and it looks very interesting thanks to good character animation action. After the protagonist leaves the house of the victim and starting with a story about the history of the master thief and his unlucky pupil. In the course of the prologue Garrett says very funny phrase Originally posted by Garret: No matter how much you steal, it is important that you steal.In this case just remember the first 5 minutes of the game where the main character stuffing their pockets with junk, just do want to bridle attention to the fact that the main character steals everything that caught his eye, and because of the passage of the locations on the 100% is a very dull and boring. Then begins the exposition of the plot, which at first seems quite intriguing. But the whole affair fades as the story progresses, because he is stupid, predictable and just boring. Rhianna Pratchett unlike her father is unable to come up with something less interesting and memorable. Sometimes it seems that the storyline made ​​only for the sake of what would at least like something to explain the appearance of Garrett on the affine or locations. In a plot full of logical holes, and some things can not be a cynic Garrett intelligible explanation. But unlike the story of the gameplay and the dark atmosphere of the game very well. There is nothing innovative, and the levels are linear and sometimes lose out in terms of design another game from the same devs - DE: HR, but they still have a variety of passing. In Thief can not play as DE: HR or Dishonored killing all in its path, as Garrett is very weak in open battles with guards. Although all the enemies you can just kill with a bow, because the AI ​​is very stupid. Another positive feature of this game is a great implementation of a bow (with a really very convenient and fun to shoot) and a large supply of various arrows, which can help in any given situation. But the city in the game feels empty and dead. Main characters in the game template and uninteresting. In general, if not pay emphasis on story and the stupidity of what is happening, you can get a decent stealth action with a great bow. But if you plan to find here a great steam-punk history that I disappoint you, there is no such.

number of helpful: 28 of 43 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												I spent a lot of time mulling over what can be said about Thief.Unfortunately, nothing in the game is particularly bad, or good. There's very little of anything actually interesting to do or to see.Gameplay is standard 1st person with stealth elements. Hiding in the shadows, breaking into buildings, stealing loot. Picking locks gets repetitive after the 100th time, like most of the content in game you will be repeating over and over. The fun part is plotting your method to break into a building, most of the missions will give you multiple ways to do so.Graphics are fine, but performance is poor. Frame-rates dip when entering new areas. Sometimes characters glitch out and start spinning in a circle or textures take on a strange rainbow-like flashing colours. The city is a gloomy, depressing place and the visuals reflect this very well.Audio is weak. Half of the time, I can't even hear what characters are telling me. The other half, I can hear people through solid walls as if they were stood right next to me. Add to this there isn't any noteworthy music or voice acting.The game is relatively bug-free. Aside from the rare graphical glitches and framerate issue I previously mentioned, I did not encounter any game-breaking bugs during my time playing.In conclusion, it's a very "meh" game. Not bad at all, but it fails to impress in any area. If you can pick it up for 50% off, I would recommend it. Again, it's hard to think of anything to say about this game because it manages to straddle the "average" line so accurately.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Growing up, the Thief games were some of my favourite. Even today I still hold them close to my heart. From the distant call of the Horn of Quintus,  to the ambient terror of the Shalebridge Cradle and everything in between, there was never a dull moment. It was a magical feeling that I rarely got with other games, that within minutes of loading the game I would be hooked for hours. So upon hearing the announcement in 2009 of 'Thi4f,' naturally I was extremely excited. So I waited...and waited...and waited.Then came the announcement that broke the hearts of many a diehard Thief fan. Stephen Russell (the voice of the original Garrett) would not be returning. It was like being 5 years old and having your favourite teddy bear torn apart in front of you. Yet I still held somewhat high hopes for the game.This hope was short lived. I bought the game, and loaded it up. The Hammers that I had grown to hate, yet love were gone. The Trickster and Builder were non-existant, the Pagans and Keepers all but vanished.I didn't even hear a single mention of the word taffer.That magical feeling I got with the original trilogy was no longer there. Thief was no longer Thief. After 3 hours of playing, I knew this wasn't the game that I'd grown to love as a young'n. Saddened, I put the game back on its digital shelf, where to this day it gathers e-dust.TL;DR, diehard Thief fan becomes saddened upon playing this taffin' piece of non-canonical nonsense.

number of helpful: 19 of 27 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												I wanted this game to be good.  Thief games are smart titles, a welcome breath of fresh air in the din of shooters and roguelikes.  Alas.  It's not just that it fails to meet expectations for a Thief-lover, it's that the game itself is littered with so many problems and poor choices that it fails to even be a great game- Thief entry or no.This game is, in a word, inconsistant.  There are great things here, but there aren't enough of them to counteract all the terrible, annoying, broken crap.  For every one good thing there's about ten bad ones weighing it down.  If you didn't preorder this game, there's really no reason to pick it up unless you are a diehard stealth gamer, and even then trust me, wait for a sale. As to fellow Thief fans, well, I am sorry this is the game we were all waiting for for so long, because not only is it easily the weakest entry in the series, it wipes away all the canon we came to love, and it ruins a beloved game character that didn't need reinventing.  In short, this is not a Thief game, nor is it a particularly good game.--absolutely insulting choices made by the dev team to constrict player freedom at nearly every turn.  This studio clearly has control issues if they don't want the players to jump or mantle on just any surface.  This game felt like someone was telling me what to do and limiting my approaches at every turn.--Levels are nothing to write home about but they work.--AI can be a challenge on master.--the audio is a completely broken mess.--The music goes to some strange places.  I could've done without the dubstep wobbles, but I like that they aren't going with straight orchestral.  The originals had a disctintly odd dark D&B thing going on that I always liked, so at least there's some throwback.--The NPC's are some of the worst in any game in history.  Forgettable, cookie cutter, constantly raving and yelling, always saying the same phrases over and over in very close bursts.  Super annoying.--Garrett.  They got Garrett so, so wrong.  I can not put into words how disappointing this is.--The story is weak and superficial.  None of the characters feel real, and I don't feel for any of them.  They don't seem like people, they seem like fictions in a made up world to serve the story.  It's the most unfortunate thing about the game IMO.  Even when things start to happen in the city it all feels very contrived and forced, I never once felt immersed in the story to the point that I forgot I was playing a video game- with the exception of some moments in Moira, which stands out as the best mission in the game.  Anyone who says the Thief games aren't about narrative haven't played them.  A single mission from the originals has more depth of content than this entire reboot.--Start a mission with a cutscene, play the mission, watch a cutscene, mission over.  It's not so far from the original thief model, it's just that the cutscenes are poorly done.  they are trying to be hollywood or something, i dunno.  it's not well done.--There are boss battles.  Someone please tell Eidos Montreal that there do not need to be boss battles in their games if they write them well and design the levels well.  It didn't work in DX:HR and it certainly doesn't work here.--The main city hub has got to be one of the most irritating things in any game in recent memory.  They should have cut the hub system from the game entirely and just made good missions.  It didn't work in T3.  In fact T3 suffered from a hub system that is fragmented and difficult to navigate.  That was a BAD thing about T3, why they saw fit not only to emulate it but to expand it and make it worse is beyond all reason and logic.--Some of the side missions show promise, but they are short.--The stealth system is servicable, but the loot placement is ridiculous and opening drawers gets old real fast.--I will play through one more time without custom master.  I may have crippled the game with not using the new items and focus.  (Not playing with focus the first time through did get a little frustrating when you can't jump over pressure plate traps, but have to look around for a single brick switch or something.){mild spoilers follow]I couldn't help but notice these things:--garret's hand gets injured and it's wrapped up for the rest of the game (bioshock infinite)--there's a plague infecting a city that is on its last legs (dishonored)--there's no jump button and the contextual edges that the gamer can jump on are painted white (tomb raider)--there's QTE's to mash a button to open things and to relocate from area to area (tomb raider, other games)--there'a  couple parkour-style sequences where you hold down sprint and hit space to vault (mirror's edge)--there's a "hold button to observe" hotkey (bioshock infinite, other games) (i despise this trend)--there's a third person climbing system (ala splinter cell blacklist/tomb raider) but it only appears a few times

They could have tried for something else to get from one area to the next. Getting to areas, you only get access to specific areas when you reach certain chapters. Making some of the side quests unacheivable because you are not on that chapter. Unnecessary runnning around just to get to the next transition. (i.e. Chap 7 where you end up within visual distance of a switch to call a elevator but can't get to it without going all the way around. You could easiliy climb down, walk accross the exposed rock and climb up the other side, but you can't climb at that spot. You HAVE to work you're way around and through guards to get there.)I could go on but I won't. I'm done with this game for now, Got other games to play and may return to Thief later this year. For now, definately a thumbs down.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												I finished Thief as the sun set, left my apartment for a walk to stretch my plague shrivelled toes. Emerging from that dark world, I reflected on the deceit of Orion, the moral quandries of our nobal thief, the cries of terror and hollow moans of a city squeezed by the plague, and the stench of rats and fecal matter in the streets. I eyed the windows I passed, assessing each based on ease of entry and likelihood of occupants, unconciously feeling for the crowbar at my hip. Total play-time: 18 hours.Thief is set in a dark world, bridging stealth gameplay with linear horror elements. The ambience was great, once you get into it. Sad to say the first 10 hours of gameplay was spread out over a number of months, as I just couldn't really get into it very quickly.Gameplay: 5/10The controls are all over the map. And the map is a murky labyrinth at best. I almost quit playing because I couldn't figure out how to drop off a dangling rope. Turns out there is a seperate key for that.Once I became comfortable with it the game became much more enjoyable, but it takes a while.A/V: 8/10Ambiance, thy name is Thief. Excellent enivronments, albeit slightly linear, but that's ok because not every game released these days is obligated to be open-world survival. The architecture and attention to detail was great. The background noises and sounds drifting through the city were haunting. The music got old after a while, so I turned it off and was still immersed by the sounds of the city.Dialogue/Storyline: 5/10The dialogue was sub-par, but the overall storyline was quite interesting. Nothing is really explained in detail as most of the characters don't mince words much, so there are some intuitive leaps in the story. Most of your journey will take place alone in the dark, if you're not prepared for that then go play Nekopara or something. You really get a sense of  stoic pessimism from most of the characters that sits quite naturally in their bleak world.Overall: 18/30I love horror games, and I do enjoy stealth, so this one was uniquely catered to my tastes. That being said I can't recommend it for everyone. If you do give it a shot, give it some time, keep it on the backburner as it moves pretty slow at times.

number of helpful: 22 of 33 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Fascinatingly bad. I made it through thirteen hours before having to bail as I just couldn't take any more.There is no fun to be had in this game. Not a single bit. No satisfaction to be gained, no immersion to accumulate, nothing worth experiencing. Joyless. Dead.It's interesting because it's a high-profile game. A lot of work has gone into it. I think it's an excellent example of what what's wrong with major title game development. This is product. It's not art, it's not designed to make a statement -- it's designed to be as bland and marketable as possible. It is completely generic. It might as well be called "Action Video Game". There isn't anything you won't have seen before many times -- it feels like took as many bits from other popular games as they could and shoved them into a machine which mushed them together and sucked all the individuality and interest out of them.Let's cover the good things first, because there aren't many. It looks nice. The Unreal engine is very competently implemented, and the Mac port which I played has many thoughtful little features (like disabling notifications).That is it. There is nothing else I say to compliment this game.The original Thief: The Dark Project is one of my all time favourite games. So much fun. Sure, it had its flaws but it was bursting with life, with personality. So much thought and care had gone into it. It was completely immersive, kinda hard and a privilege to play. It's safe to say that nothing of the original has survived.You reprise the role of Garrett: Master Thief, but you'll tire of him pretty quickly. Before, he was a likable scoundrel, a master of his craft. The sort of guy who'd sneak an apple off from the table by a guard and slink off munching it. New Garrett is insufferably banal - he'd have been much better as a silent protagonist because every time I heard him I mentally disassocaited myself. And the master thief? He's now spends his time rummaging through hovels stealing mugs and scissors from poor people. Oh good, I found a bracelet in a drain. I stole a pair of scissors from squalid flat. This goblet that the beggar sitting opposite can't even be bothered with? I'll have that. It all goes into the enormous invisible bag of loot I'm presumably lugging along with me, full of hand mirrors and picture frames. You don't even get to fence them, they turn into cash instantly. Forget eyes on the prize, Garret's going for candlesticks now.They've tried to make him into Batman, but didn't take on board that the main appeal of playing as Batman is that YOU GET TO BE BATMAN. Garrett is not Batman, no matter how gruff he is or how many time he reminds you that he's wearing leather (he will do that a lot).The game combines elements from other popular titles such as Dishonoured, Batman, Assassin's Creed, Tomb Raider & Mirror's Edge resulting in something not nearly as good as any of them.At every turn this game gives the impression that the makes had an incredibly strict script they want the player to follow. You will do this thing, now you will do this. Now you will go here. Now you will jump. Now you will climb a rope. Now you will think this thing. There's no sense of free will. There's no fun. It's horrible. Bad level design, terrible writing/story, awful acting, banal main character, frustrating gameplay, 0/10 avoid like the plague.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												The Thief series is one that's been near and dear to my heart as one of my most favorite franchises.  I still remember when the first Thief came out, it blew me away.  And then Thief 2 upped the bar.  Thief 3 had one of the scariest gaming experiences ever and it carried the franchise forward.  Thief 4 took years to come to fruition and the fan base was so eager to see the fourth installment.  When it finally did get released, excitement turned to disappointment as the game didn't meet the standards set by its predecessors.  Keep in mind, open-world games like Skyrim (which was released in 2011; Thief 4 was released in 2014) were embracing giving the gamer ultimate freedom.  Meanwhile, Thief 4 boxed the gamer into small "cells", giving more a feeling of a chlostrophobic Assassin's Creed than what we were accustomed to with Thief.  The developers shot themselves in the foot by giving us a restrictive, linear, consolitis let-down.  Now don't get me wrong, the game mechanics were enjoyable, but the knowledge that you're moving from tiny cell to tiny cell ruined the gameplay for me; that and the linear way the levels were designed.  It was disappointing, because Thief 4 should've been so much more.  I envision a world of Thief 4, much like Skyrim, a huge world where a thief could thrive and gain limitless wealth.  I hate to keep comparing Thief 4 to Skyrim, but if you look at the thief aspects available in Skyrim, it's what Thief 4 should've been.  Thief 4 is the first in the series I didn't complete, because of its flaws.  Nowadays, I get my fix with Skyrim, because it simply does everything better than Thief 4.  I still love the Thief franchise and I have high hopes that a lesson was learned and that the developers scrap the restrictive aspect of Thief and go for open world awesomeness.  It is possible, as evidenced by Skyrim.  That's what Thief players want, a large unrestricted and open world to explore, missions to complete and a game worthy of the franchise.  I can't recommend Thief 4.  Instead, I suggest you check out Thief 2 and 3, both of which should put you in the right frame of mind for the franchise.  Then, if you're still left wanting, go be a thief in Skyrim and enjoy a massive game world with gravy loot.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												I finished the game. As most people know I am a big fan of this franchise. Rather than doing a normal review, while playing the game I kept notes of the thoughts that occurred to me, and thought I'd share them for those who've been asking me what I think of the game.• No taffers, no Hammerites, no Keepers, no Pagans. No mention of the builder, one mention of the trickster in passing. The "rich vs poor" meme is not a good substitute. UPDATE: there is one reference to the Hammerites at the end.• This is not Garrett. Different voice, different face, different clothes, different personality. Same name.• Looting is fun• Sneaking mechanics are pretty solid, they fixed issues from previous games where guards never looked up and where you were always invisible in doorways. However it is annoying sometimes, you'll be sitting still they won't see you, but then they start "seeing" you more, and suddenly shout out "IS THAT SOMETHING MOVING?"• Graphics are fine. Very good performance.• No distinction is made between killing and knocking out??  There are no blackjacks, you sneak up behind someone and press an action key to perform a melee takedown.• Contextual controls are dumb. I'll decide when I want to jump, thanks.• The paintings are pretty... interesting.• I missed the old thief-style cutscenes• Lockpicking minigames are terrible in all games, this one is less terrible than others.• The city in this game is better than the one in Deadly Shadows, and I like the sidequests.• Rope arrows are limited to only specific anchor points, they seem to disappear when you reload the zone and the arrows cannot be retrieved.• Much of the humor and personality of the city is gone. The humor that does exist isn't nearly as funny or clever.• No more crate stacking, and no jumping• Hate the name, we already had a Thief. This is Thief 4.• The city lost a lot of the steampunk vibe.• I enjoy the rooftop navigation, but wish there were fewer loadscreens.• Windows are annoying. You have to go through a button mashing process to open one to get into a house, then the window immediately closes and you have to do it again to get back out. It quickly becomes tedious.• The asylum seems like a less-scary ripoff of The Shalesbridge Cradle.• If a guard sees something has changed, like a door open on their patrol route, he will investigate. This is great. I also noticed on occasion they will investigate every time they pass that open door. If the room is fairly big this can mean you add a significant delay to their patrol, which is strategically interesting, if not particularly smart AI.• On the hardest difficulty, when playing passively, Thief is more difficult than Dishonored.• Some fun puzzles for getting to loot• Why is Garrett collecting a  bunch of crap in his home now instead of selling it?• Be very careful about hiding in wardrobes as it forces the game to quicksave.• It seems like the new developers only played Deadly Shadows• The story was mostly an incoherent mix of cliches, and ends unsatisfactorily.• The Thief-Taker General is pretty ridiculous.The game is not horrible, but given the source material and what it could have been, it is very disappointing. If you want a true Thief expierience, Thief 2 and 1 (Gold) are still perfectly playable, and still the best games ever made.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												This is a qualified recommendation. 1) Only buy it when it' on sale, like 75% off. It's hard to complain when you get a game at such a low price.2) The criticisms of the game are valid, such as: 	a) The maps are small, a limitation carried over from the console versions.	b) The story seems unfinished, in particular the abrupt and inexplicable ending.	c) You can only jump, climb and use rope arrows at designated locations. In other words, it feels constrained.3) If you play the main story and scour the maps for loot, you'll get about 20 hours of gameplay. Side missions could add several more hours.4) The one redeemable aspect is the high quality graphics. This game looks great on an Nvidia GTX 970. The graphics contribute to the atmosphere of the game.5) I suggest that you put aside any comparison to the previous Thief games, and play it with the eyes of a new player.Now, comparing Thief with Dishonored, Dishonored is definitely a better game. However, Thief is still, mostly, an enjoyable game that's worth $7.49 for 20+ hours of gameplay.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												Game has a great atmosphere,art and premise, but it fails to deliver.  Each chapter feels increadably small. I don't know if they were trying to optimize the game for weaker machines(It didn't work), but I feel like there were much better ways to do it. How small is it? About two streets for an area. There are about 2 areas each chapter, and maybe a few rooms. If you were living in that gloomy city it'll take you 20 minutes to walk from one end of the city to the other. That's when you combine ALL of the areas presented to you, sans the tomb-raider level (I♥♥♥♥♥♥you not). Each level has only 1 or 2 possible ways to do it. Don't bother trying to wander off and explore - you will probably have to get back after getting yourself into a stiky situation.This feels increadblt constraining. Isn't the point of stealth is to find the optimal path best fitting your playstyle?I recall when I wandered off to loot something in a hallway, and got stuck between two guards. That's right. Neither was moving. I waited a solid TWENTY MINUTES to get an opening to slip away. and even then I alerted one of the guards and he attacked me.Not only that, but you also have a restriced set of...things to interact with. A few beams to walk on. Only some walls can be climbed. Only some beams can be shot with a rope arrow. LOTS of loading screens in the middle of a chapter. They did this clever thing where the animation of opening a window is loading time for the game. So you are trying to complete a level. You find a window and think that room will lead you to there. You wait for the loading of the room to complete. Then you open another window on the other side of the room to load another area. Or maybe it loads the area you've just left. And after getting there, you suddenly realize this is the wrong way. Or you want to pick up a quest. Now you have to go back throught TWO loading screens.I don't even know what are they loading - each area is incredably small (as I mentioned) and there aren't a lot of objects to render. They could have just as well loaded the entire thing all at once in extra 30 seconds and saved us the pain. The art direction of this game is great. I wish it was a big less dark and a bit brighter, so we could see the world better. When I got closer (really closer) to objects I could see how beatifull they were. Shame everything's covered in shadows and you can't see it. The story is the only reason I completed the game. Although it was predictable, I still enjoyed it very much. I WANTED to get to the ending and feel the world around me. Magic is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Magic is used as a cheap device to deliver plot. No I don't mean plot device. It literally, on a few occasions, delivered plot to us. It was like an exposition. With clouds. Nothing of intrest is ever done with it. I would have liked if they pulled the magic aspect all together out of the story, except the last reveal about Erin(which still can be done differantly but I accept the fact that the screen writer are lazy). Any character that Isn't Erin or Garath is a cardboard that speaks. And this is coming from someone who read Twilight and didn't want to kill themselves. There are lots of characters that have an interesting design or concept, but don't do anything and don't contrebute to the story at all. Game time is short. It says I have 17 hours in game. That is a lie. Remember I said I was stuck between two guards for 20 minutes? This is the entire game. You wait for guards to♥♥♥♥♥♥off so you could climd that wall behind them. Then After going through more guards, you relise that it's the wrong way. Shame on you - the way back isn't as easy. Better wait some more. I'd say I probably only got half of my total time on record with actual gameplay.  Side quests are boring and hard to get. In all my error prone exploring, I've only managed to complete two or three side-quests. THREE. I was TRYING to get some. But they were in the 'only one way to do it' catagory of how to get to the room that has that quest. A lot of people are complaining about combat system being ♥♥♥♥♥♥. They are right. It's so horrible it's only there to laught at you because you can't use it. But a stealth game doesn't have to have a good combat system. I respect the devs decision to make this game stealth-only. It only becomes an issue when the stealth mechanism is horrible. but the combat is even worse. And then you are left with two ♥♥♥♥♥♥ options, when one would not get you killed but will kill your patience.Ususally for games like this I'd recommend buying it on sale. But this game is so bad, that it's not even about the money anymore. If you were to recieve a one million dollar inheritance I'd still tell you to not buy this game. The time wasted on it is not worth it. tl;dr - Bad gameplay, Bad stealth. Bad characteres. Bad Level design. At least it's pretty

number of helpful: 18 of 26 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Well, to start I want to clarify one thing – the game is not bad, it’s just mediocre.While I have played all previous instalments (and The Dark Mod) I’m not going to judge Thief developers for the level of fidelity to its predecessors. I don’t mind changing the backstory and getting rid of the known and established lore, the conflict between the Pagans and Mechanist etc.The thing is – new Thief fails in creating something equally interesting on its own. It just has this generic XIX century steampunk vibe, that didn’t manage to tackle my interest.I will just try to explain why I’m rather disappointed in this game. There is no single game feature that would make it mediocre in my opinion, it’s just the sum of little things, that create this rather bland experience. I will try to explain it giving just some points as an example.Lack of the ability to jump – it’s not that limiting as I initially was led to believe, because you can mantle practically on any surface you would like to, with only few exceptions, so I’m ok with that.Contextual rope arrow – I can live with that, but implementing that solution causes the rope anchor point to stand like sore thumbs and screaming invitation – “look, here you can climb, this is the way further to something interesting”. Sound design – now this is a big letdown for me. Original Thief games had wonderful sound design that let you place characters and objects in 3D space. Judging by the sound of footsteps you were able to determine the surface someone is walking on, but also whether someone is closing up on you, or getting away further.In new Thief it’s hardly the case. Footsteps really doesn’t give you good sense of direction, and to make things worse – they are often muffled by generics speeches that persons give. About♥♥♥♥♥♥rings. From the other side of the stone wall. With audio repeated twice. And alas, that happens frequently, especially when you load new area (which also happens frequently). So often what would be a tense moment of hiding from a patrolling guard will be ruined, because you will only hear repeated generic guard chat (to loudly, even from the other side of the wall (sic!)) ad nauseam that will muffle the footsteps.As for the random chats and guard lines – they have a big variety of them, but it seems like every person you encounter has only 2-3 limited lines, that they repeat constantly. So you creep for long minutes around the guards that are having the same conversation over and over. Occasionally you will encounter a scripted exposition conversation that shed some light on the world, characters, or even gives you clues about hidden loot. But Karras forbid you raise their suspicion level, because if you interrupt them, there is no coming back (except for a load long before you encounter such situation).Staying with that – voice acting is pretty decent, albeit there are some issues with lip-sync, and Garret on liners are sometimes over the top.Speaking about conversations we go to another element – the writing. It’s not that good. I don’t know how the story was butchered and changed in its turbulent development process, but the outcome is average at most and sometimes straight out laughable (so the protagonist is a Thief – lets name his nemesis Thief- Catcher General). Conversations imply sexual things in not very subtle style, like it was written with teenage audience in mind. Plot is uninteresting and cliché-ridden, not to mention that it bears unhealthy resemblance to Dishonored (city dying of plague, you are the only saviour, your allies betray you).Going back to gameplay – City hub is divided into many districts, all separated by loading zones, and sometimes having loading zones in them. It’s painfully boring to navigate, especially if you have explored most of it on the beginning, because some side missions are available only after finishing main story “Chapters”. So, one mission requires you to go through 3 separate loading zones before you get to the mission area, and there is nothing to do on the way. You have to sneak (or fight) past the guards with, well known by that point, patrol routes, listening to the same conversations.The City itself seems lifeless.  I didn’t expect crowds on the streets by night (and the plague is a poor device to justify keeping NPC’s of the streets), but even if there is a public event, like hanging  there are 2 persons performing it, and just 2 citizens watching.Main story is divided into Chapters, but they are designed rather linearly, with multiple loading sections (cleverly disguised, I admit). They just feel like a scripted set of arenas you have to complete in order to move forward, to the next arena. And what’s worse, they feel even more limiting than Dishonored. Admittedly, there are some missions, where you can freely roam big mansions, and they gave me big enjoyment and this “Thief” vibe I was longing to feel. The plot sometimes acts as just to give you a pretext to move your character to a different setting.The graphics are nice, and lighting is especially good looking, but not always working well. For example if you hide behind a crate with only your head sticking out and the passing guard will have a lantern, the screen will flash to indicate that you are fully visible (another not good design decision), but you will still remain hidden. Or you will be spotted on the other side of the fence, even if you were hiding there (maybe the can see you through the space between planks?). But those are rare instances. Other than that, the bluish tint in everything, and the repeating window textures for rooms that you cannot get into got me bored after some time. On the other hand, interiors are sometimes exceptionally well designed, and underline the differences between mission locations.As for exploring the City – almost every breaking and entering will be proceed by a loading screen, which takes form of your hands working a crowbar animation, paired with a QTE. Also – your hands are almost constantly visible, and you can see the animations for doing almost anything – looking for a hidden switch, working a lock pick, or taking the loot. But since the most common loot is a pair of scissors laying precisely in the middle of a drawer, it quickly gets boring, and rather brakes immersion, because you know that behind every pair of golden scissors there is an 1-2 second long animation, that you can’t do anything about. I don’t know why they just didn’t go for stacks of coin here and there.The AI – while they seem competent, when alerted, it’s painfully easy to lose the chase, even by going around the corner and hiding behind a crate, or changing the climbing up or down. Other than that, the change their patrol routs on the basis of your current location. So even if they have no indication of you moving to a different area, they will go and do their routine over there, because the game says so – also a poor design decision.  Other than that they react rather properly to you dousing the lights, or making too much noise.Now for the good things. Side missions proved to give me most enjoyment so far, and some have really brilliant moments. They are well thought out, loading screens are better incorporated (talking about bank job mission here), the gave me the thief experience I was hoping to get.But, alas, those few great moments drown in the sea of mediocrity.And that is why I don’t recommend buying this game for its current price. I’m rather disappointed with the experience, and while I’ve spent around 30h, I had to fight boredom on much more occasions that I wished.So, to sum up – while not a bad game, it’s not good either, I would recommend waiting for a 50% sale before buying it.

												What a massive disappointment. Incoherent story, innumerable load-zones, broken movement mechanics, and a boring protagonist. This game butchers almost everything that made the originals great, and then adds a host of technical issues that diminish the experience even further. If you want a great stealth experience, spend your money on the original trilogy of Thief games, or even Dishonored. All of those are more satisfying than this reboot.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
How the new Thief managed to steal my enjoyment from it.What the hell, Eidos? How could this game be an abomination like this? Don't you have a little respect left for this IP? Did you guys tried to copy Dishonored but make it worse? This game was clearly in development hell and the true vision of this game got butchered.Everything wrong with Thief: many scripted moments, smaller linear levels with loading screens, rope arrows only on certain spot, no modding/custom campaigns support, no jumping and only on certain scripted spot (some traps could be easly jumped over, but nah, game says you can't!), uninteresting story and cringeworthy characters, uninteresting faction and lore, a lot of cutscenes, enemy variation and bad AI, horrible audio, designed for consoles and a younger audience.The game is so heavily scripted, streamlined and linear, that it feels like I was playing a movie instad of a game. You will not feel in control at all, the freedom of movement/action and emergent gameplay is what defines this genre. You can't lean, only if you're on the wall. The controls really feels sluggish because it plays an animation for every action you do. You will button smash or hold "E" for every little thing in the environment, so it can play every time some animation, it's clearly designed for consoles. Every little prop/scripted jump area will stop the flow of movement for a moment and it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥when you're being chased by guards. You can't even jump in this game! Only on designated scripted spots, where the devs allowed you to. There where many little obstacle throughout the game where someone could easily jump over, but naaaah! The game won't let you, you can only jump on designated spots. The same thing with the rope arrows, only on designated marked spots, while in the older games you could use the rope arrow on any wooden surface.The sounds in this game is pure trash, you can't even hear the footsteps of guards and which ground they walk on. In the old games you could hear them and locate them with sound, they could hear you too, for example when you run on a metal floor. The lips of NPCs sync not right when they talk, even in the cutscenes. Audio is so horrible and buggy, when a NPC talks, it sounds like they would be next to you, but they're actully upstairs and they didn't even bother to patch this. The AI is buggy sometimes and exploitable, not really challenging. They sometimes stuck in the wall and starting to spin around wildly. The levels are so small and linear, that the level desing feels like one small railroad compared to the older games. The new Garrett is melodramatic and they tried to portrait him for some sort of Batman, you can even see it in the offical comic, how he's posing like the Batman on the roof top, watching the streets. What disgust me the most about the new Garrett is his new appearance. He looks like a emo with all that eyeshadow and his corset, it's way too edgy and let's me wonder what they were thinking when designing the new Garrett. The old Garrett was more badass, while the new one let's me cringe when ever he said something ("It's not how much you steal—it's what you steal" RLY? Most of the loot is cheap trash like forks, scissors, ink wells , etc.), like all the dialogues in this game. And don't let me start on Erin the Super Edge Girl with her anger issues.The story feels so rushed and unfinished, even if the game is full with cutscenes. It's like it was written by an edgy highschool goth kid in the recess. Maybe they were aiming for that younger audience? They didn't even put a level editor/mod tools in, so they can sell you map DLC's (The bank heist should be in the main game but they cut it for pre-order bonus and with the current price it isn't worth it.) You would be surprised how creative the classic Thief community is, if they had the tools for mod/mapping for this game too.This game is a good example of todays bullcrap that most modern AAA games do: buggy, heavily scripted, streamlined and linear, with really small levels and bad writing. I couldn't finish it, so I watched a mate playing it. Couldn't drag myself to finish it and for my mate  it was a chore to play it. I hope Eidos takes some notes of the reaction of the long time fans of Thief and do it better next time. Edit: Oh! And in the first old game last level (Spoiler): you travel to the world of a god, so you can steal his artefact and stop him to take over the world. The level desing is bizarre, waterfalls that stream up and function as elevators etc. No bizarre world here or undead walled off cities,folks! Just boring generic victorian era city with no orginality.  4/10 for this game. Get Dishonored or any other Thief game with some fan missions or Styx: Master of Shadows and stay away from that.

number of helpful: 25 of 39 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I hated this game.  If you have played the originals you will likely hate this game too.  The main character feels fake.  He now wears a gay ninja mask over his mouth.  He talks way too much, each time reminding you that this guy is not the real Garrett.  Some how the Devs thought it would be a good thing to give their version of Garrett a Sister named Erin.  What were they thinking? They killed off the fan's favorite fanatical group "The Hammers".   The levels are badly designed and linear.  You can't play your own way; only the way the level is setup.  The player is forced into actions.  Time events and button mashing.  Some how thief has become a platformer/parkour type game, which you would think would open up more areas to the player, but no in fact when you platform its because that is where you are meant to go to progress the level.  No alternate routes at all.  The Thief series made you feel like a thief, but this new game's feel is way off base.  When you blackjack a guard you have to sit through the same wack him over the head cut-scene each time.  Taking a purse off an AI is way over used, everything starts to be repeatative fast. The Dev's had feedback before the release of this game as to what fans wanted and expected. So how did they still get it so wrong? How many thosands of people tried to warn them to use Garrett's original voice actor even having a signed petition. Did these Devs even play the originals? The story is not good, but more than that, how Garrett reacts to the unfolding of the story again reminds you that this is not the real Garrett.  Each mission sould feel in itself meaning full even if it dosn't progress the main story line. In this game you don't feel a sence of acomplishment.  I am not against alot of the new concepts introduced in this game, but they were done so poorly.  Focus can be turned off but it is the whole base for the storyline.  So you have a choice to use focus which make you feel less like a thief or turn it off and have no idea what the storyline is talking about.  This could have been a great game, and I tired so hard to like it.  In the end you just have to give up and call it what it is, TRASH.  I would like to have my money back.  I even bought a new computer just so it could play this game when it came out.  So here are my last words.  If you like Parkour try Mirrior's Edge.  If you would like a thief games try Thief Gold, Thief 2, and Thief 3: Deadly Shadows.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												The new Thief was a game that struck many right chords with me in principle. A steam-punkish world, semi-open, stealth-based and riddled with rare loot to steal. However, the game falls short on many levels.The steam punk is present but only lightly, in the form of electrical (?) lighting, occasional pipes and elevators as well as a piece of equipment you hold. But that's pretty much it. Now, this wouldn't be a big problem if the world didn't feel bland. Since you move about exclusively at night, all the colours will be washed out - everything is a shade of grey and boring. The game "Dishonored" created a compelling, brilliant world in which you played, but the world of Thief leaves a lot to be desired. Cramped quarters of narrow streets and buildings throughout most of the game leaves you wanting.Coupled with this, the semi-open nature of the game doesn't really reward you. Find a hidden vent up on a roof? Unscrew it, crawl through it and lockpick the mysterious door at the end to find a room full of junk. Where's the treasure? Ahh, a single silver spoon. I'm not kidding, a lot of such areas will make you jump through hoops to collect a single, boring item.This brings me to the point of loot. It doesn't feel like you're a master thief, but more like someone who's donned a leather suit and decided to perform petty crimes. You rummage through drawers for forks, spoons and candle-holders. I was expecting missions in the style of "Mission Impossible", where you would get tasked with stealing a priceless item from a heavily guarded and trapped building somewhere. Sorry, those moments will be few and far between.The story is nothing special, but it does get a little more interesting towards the end if you're a fan of such things (can't really spoil it).All in all, I felt playing through the similar-looking grey corridors and wooden boxes somewhat of a chore throughout the game and only felt compelled to explore further occasionally.Sorry, but this is not the Thief you're looking for.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Don't play this game as a sequel to the original Thief trilogy. I played those, really loved those and for me Dishonored feels much closer to them than this game. Apart from the occasional reference and the name of some characters, the protagonist among them, this game has not much to do with them. If you can accept that this is not a sequel, if you can somehow separate the two things, than you will find a great game. It's a different Thief, but it still do things quite well. It has a great atmosphere, nicely working stealth mechanics, less combat options (which for me in this genre was an improvement), and quite a lot of stuff to do (haven't seen much of the main plot yet, though I liked it so far, because I was sidetracking a lot). I think this game would have been much better received, if they gave it a different name, because people nowadays have crazy expectations and amazingly whiney attitude, and feeding them hype is the worst thing to do for any game, almost anything is doomed to fail this way (just look at Watch Dogs, which is also a decent game in my opinion). So if you like stealth games with great atmosphere and lots to explore, I can really recommend this one, but if you want to pick up the story of that (ok, it's true, won't deny it) better and cooler Garrett of old and see what happens after Deadly Shadows, then you will be disappointed.

												9/10+ some of the  best graphics i have seen in gaming (if you can run them on ultra settings that is), not only technically but also artistically+ sound is also fantastic, with a great soundrack, excellent voice acting+ the well known from previous games in the series atmosphere is here, especially when just exploring the city, you get that mystic feeling+ garett seems darker this time, story is also darker, some david-lynch moments in the presentation, like the visions+ gameplay wise, stealth works although the enemy's ai is not the best, still you have to play using stealth, the known accessories are there, this time garett can climb and use ropes to access higher points, nice new swoop movement+ excellent side missions- enemy ai is the biggest concern, sometimes you stand in front of them and they are not alerted or they pursue you and if you just change location they stop, you can't hide the bodies in closets etc something you could do in hitman etc- as with other square enix/eidos new releases, gameplay feels automatic sometimes, they have to invest more time and polish gameplay since everything else seems to work finei don't really understand the negative reviews and i don't really care, this is a modern thief game that i really enjoy and will replay for sure.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Let me first say I'm recommending it, but only just.In terms of the Thief series, this game doesn't hold up quite the same. Your freedom in traversal isn't plentiful, you will have more than a single path to get through areas, but these more or less come down to simply what the dev has provided in terms of following a path you have selected to its end, you will have options, but not quite open freedom. Do you like to jump? Forget that with this game, the only ascent in any form is achieved by climbing things, and you are only able to climb onto objects which the devs have allowed you to.The difficulty options are nice, in that you get to customise them more to your liking. It has the typical easy, normal, hard, etc, but on top of that, there is a custom setting where you can turn on/off various other things. This includes the infamous perma-death setting (applies to being caught, seeing as this is a stealth game), no upgrades, no kills or knockouts, no manual saves, slower movement, more expensive items from sellers, and a few others. Personally, I'm doing my first playthrough using the highest difficulty, with all these settings turned on except for the perma-death and no manual saves.A little nuisance, however, is also something that might just bother completionists, as it is impossible to get 100% on the hardest difficulty. This is because certain difficulty settings make it impossible to complete certain objectives in various missions. Just recently I have completed a mission where I did everything perfect from a stealth standpoint, found all loot, never spotted, never harmed an enemy in any way, and so on. But you couldn't count it as 100%, the reason being... one of these objectives was having exactly 1 kill or knockout, which is impossible with my difficulty settings.Ignoring the previous entries in the series, it is a pretty decent game, I find myself mostly using it to kill time, though being a stealth fanatic, I can get caught into fairly lengthy sessions despite its flaws. It can still be fun, provided you're a fan of stealth, to just get by without being caught while stealing everything, that is available, in sight.In terms of performance, it seems well-made for PCs. The only issue in terms of framerate I've encountered being during pre-rendered cut-scenes, where it was noticeably choppy, but otherwise, the game runs smoothly for me with the highest settings. The general appearance of things can also be admired, considering what they were aiming for, seeing as the scenery in this game doesn't necessarily pass for "pretty."I managed to get this game for $37 before release. I'm not exactly unhappy with that amount, but to those of you looking to purchase, I'd have to say it's more worth your money to buy it in the $20-30 range.
