content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Rather than making a solid game in the style of the old Thief titles, I feel like the developers, at some point along the way, looked at Dishonored and said "this sold well - our game should be more like that."But forgoing the dishonored comparison, the sound is somewhat broken (enemies miles away sound right next to you, and you can't hear the ones ten feet away) which kills a lot of the stealthy tension. Forced, linear, 3rd person climbing sections break immersion. Forced, linear escape sections don't make sense when you've been running a 100% ghost run all the way along.A the rest of it either doesn't make sense, feels too constricted, or is somehow... off in ways that are hard to define unless you play the game directly after just having played the older Thief games. In trying to throw a lot of "modern" mechanics and graphics into the pot, they neglected the thing that made the old games great - the level design.Oh well. Here's hoping another devloper will pick up Thief 2, 2?

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Well, fellow taffers!​I played all thiefs, so T1, T2:TMA and T3:DS. I'm still a big fan of the first three installments. Although these three are quite dated, they are all still one of the best games of the genre and out there. Especially T1 and T2 ate an *insane* amount of hours of my life.Because I do like stealth games a lot, I've played DISHONORED this year until T4 dropped to a reasonable price on Steam. Then I started T4 and went from "How it's done" to "What a crap". And now comes a list why I didn't even finish T4 and why I think it's not a good game.The Good:========- Graphics and presentation. While I never judge a game by its graphics, I did like the great, dark and gritty graphics.- The lockpicking and integration for searching hidden switches behind picture frames and book shelves. Well done!- The architecture and steampunkish flair. There is absolutely nothing to dislike about mixing magic with torches, swords and machines.- Although heard very seldon, the ambient music is beast sometimes (when caught, for example)!- While this game is QTE-invested (see next points), the character movement is very vivid. You'll always see Garrett's hands and actions, be it while lockpicking, jumping, walking, crouching, opening a window, looting, grabing a coin or breaking a safe open.- The climbing works flawlessly. It's the moments were you have to climb a gutter to get to the roof. This is were the camera changes and you're in third-person-view. I did like this very much, because the climbing is made very fail-proof and easy. Also, the camera *never* gets visually blocked by a wall or something like this. Some other games / developers could really learn from this.- The Takedown-QTEs and animations worked every single time and were very satisfying to execute / watch.The Bad, The Worse and The Ugly:===========================- The acting and enactment in the cutscenes is just plain AWFUL and probably the worst you will ever see in any game. Garrett acts like an idiot. Every time when he's being adressed he acts with an embarressing silence or a dull look on his face, which degrades him to a kind of a mentally reta--ed person who doesn't know what to say. Sometimes you just wish you could punch him in the face. Really hard. With a gauntlet made out of adamantium. They tried to make him like a cool person who has everything under control, but they failed miserably. Therefore, I couldn't identify myself with Garrett and I coulnd't care less about him or his boring story. Or the whole evolving of the story.- I didn't like the puzzling at all. I'm here to steal, loot and knock people out, not to do some boring puzzling. What am playing as, a Riddler or a Master Thief? I understand many people like puzzling and finding clues, but they should have at least make it as a voluntary thing (for finding secrets) and not mandatory.- The quick-time-events (QTE) are well done, but overdone. While I do not mind at all having QTE in a game, in THIEF4 you're feeling like you're not playing, but being played. I do leave most of the loot in its place because I'm tired of seeing the same opening-the-drawer-and-taking-random-stuff-QTE over and over again. Maybe I miss the uncomplicated *ring-ring-ring* from T1 and T2 when I'm looting.- Every loot you find is placed exactly in the middle of a drawer, a cabinet or a chest, as if the City is inhabitated by people with a massive OCD. And in what places people loose their wallet, DEAR GOD LOOK DOWN.- The QTE define the whole game. Like I said before, you don't feel free at all or in what you do, it's like your constantly on a rail. When you climb a rope you can only be released from it when a platform allows you to and you can only jump when the game allows you to. While this is good sometimes (failjumping not possible), you're getting bored after a few hours, since it feels like you're mum is always with you and helps you with everything and denies you everything else. Meaning you can only jump / climb when the game wants you to, you're very restricted to where you can go. (You can't even fall down a narrow bar or a cliff or a balcony, which is good I guess.)- "Combat". I completed some levels in Predator mode and killed nearly everyone. I'm fine when I'm firing arrows out of the dark and instantly killing a not-aware-enemy, but in a close fight against a guard is way too easy. It's like it doesn't even matter. Even WHEN it does matter, the combat is horrible. After a few hits your enemy just cowers like unconscious NPC in SKYRIM, waiting to be killed.- You have to pay some extra money for being able to carry more arrows and stuff with you. Greedy evil developers, you won't make some friends with that greedy mentality. Why not making a good game instead of such a garbage? It's an insult for every gamer. What comes next, paying extra to be able to use a save slot or having a HUD?- Freeroaming? Nope. You can enter some houses in the City, but you always have to open a window, which kinda loads a new level and is isolated. While you can explore the whole city, the different sections / segments are always blocked by some crates or stuff that has been put there for only this reasons. You can trigger another QTE which will move Garrett through that pile of wooden crates to the next section. That's not the idea of a city, folks.- Your "home" is the clocktower. Garrett hoards his collection of collectibles there. I was looking forward to explore it after seeing it in the first mission. But the clocktower is just a tiny boring level itself with nothing but your stolen collections to see. When you leave/enter the Clocktower via the only window, it asks you if you want to load a new chapter / the City or enter the Clocktower, so no exploring or fun here. AGAIN.- You can't jump. This is sometimes a good idea and not a problem, but you can't even jump over traps.- I absolutely hated those flashback-psycho-levels where you're in some kind of limbus / dreamworld. Can we maybe JUST have some cool levels where I actually can be a MASTER THIEF and steal things? Like from a well guarded museum, bank or something? Why do they always have to include some boring psycho-bull? And of course they had to include some gollum-like creatures. Because we all LOVED those strange aliencreatures from T1, right?- Customers have to pay extra for a bank heist mission. Are you serious? The only thing that could've made T4 interesting is not incluced.- You can buy arrows and other stuff from merchants.If I'm not mistaken, then I'm a Thief, oh, pardon, a MASTER Thief, why the heck to I have to pay for stuff?- You have to have some tools like a wrench (for opening vents) or a razor tool (for cutting picturesout of the frame) for a ridiculous high amount of gold.Pardon me? I'm a thief, I steal necklases and rings that are worth a s---load of money but I have to unlock / buy a razor or a wrench, which can be a) stolen from everywhere or b) bought for a nickel? Get outta here, this game got more bull by the minute.- You also can buy (BUY, like in "actually spending gold") a warm undershirt, which increases your health.Well, I don't know what to say anymore.I did not finish the game after starting Mission 7/8. Also, I don't know if they just ran out of ideas or if they are drunk in general, but this game is just plain horrible and a waste of money. This franchise and idea has (had?) so much potential, but it's completely wasted by some failures which really don't have to be. Do not buy when it costs more than 5 to 10 bucks.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												The amount of hours is how long i could stomach playing this game masquerading around as a game i once knew as Thief.  Not only is the horrible stealth system, a very integral part of the series, atrociously done, the overall game-play is just flat out bad.  After realizing that this game is really a game meant to be played on an ice rink, with it's inexplicable use of press space bar to shadow dodge and win, the game fails to capture any redeeming qualities of the series.It is such a waste too since the game itself looks great, how Garret places his hands on walls etc, is very well done and can immerse you in the character, but unfortunately when the large chunk of your game is a stealth game, and that mechanic is incredibly broken, you can only enjoy the little things so long before you give up.  I really wish i had not pre-ordered the game, if this game were under 10$ i'd say it is worth a try, but anything above you're better off with something that will actually be entertaining.Take the recommendation as you will, but overall a disappointed fan of the game, for someone new to the series it may be a great / fun little game to play around with.  To any fan of the Thief series, know that this game lacks the spirit and soul of it's successors.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												What is this? I tried to like it, I really did. This game spits in the face of the old games. I just can't believe that someone could ruin a franchise like this. The storyline is terrible and contrived. The character development is just a cut above "See Spot Run", you feel funneled and everything is crazy linear. The lack of a jump action is so incredibly limiting, the old games in the series allowed full exploration via the ability to jump and rope arrows that could attach to any material soft enough for the arrow to sink in which was very abundant. Instead you can look forward to using your rope arrows in predesignated spots so that you are more easily funneled through the Stanley Para... I mean Thief game... I can't stress enough how the sense of player agency just does not exist in this game. Everything is all quicktime, quicktime in disguise, and you feel like you're stuck on a crappy rail ride in an even crappier "amusement" park. Do yourself a favor and completely avoid this title.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Recommended BUT Only Just.What to say about this game, I had little or no expectations of this game, like so many classic PC franchises, I knew that it wouldn't be what I wanted it to be. Armed with this I started playing the game with an open mind and I have to say that the core of the game is good, it would be amazing if it wasn't for the broken and very annoying sound. The voice acting and the ambiance are good it is just the conversations between NPCs is poorly applied. Picture the scene, you are in a new part of Town looking around, avoiding the guards. You see a nice dark and cosy area to hide and observe guard movements and as soon as you arrive in the dark spot you hear a very loud conversation directly behind you, you panic and roll into the vision of the guards, grrrrrrrrrr. You reload after getting a kicking by the Guards, go to the same spot and try and find who was talking and you cannot see them anywhere the reason being they are 2 floors up and on the other side of the building, very misleading in a game where you should need to hear where your threats are. After the first hour of gameplay you give up using your ears and just go on visual clues.The graphics are very good, I can max out all setting on my rig and it shows the time the Devs took getting the lighting just right, the game engine is very good and the controls are simple, all this adds up to a very fluid and immersive world where you can make the game as challenging as you wish.If it wasn't for Garrett and the name of the game you wouldn't know that it was a "Thief" franchise. There's no Pagans, Keepers, Hammerites or Glyphs. The story is very, very bland and as for the ending.......lol, It's like the Devs realised what a turkey of a story they had and just stopped. No explanations to the Primal or anything.The so called open world really is an annoyance. This game needs well thought out, fixed, maps not a join the dots that the open world becomes. The chapter missions are however the Town that you can run around in serves no purpose to the story and really does feel like it's padding to make the games seem bigger than it is. As for padding, there is a stupid and pointless part of the game, the Clock Tower. You finish a chapter and get teleported to the Clock Tower, where a screen informs you that you have new loot to admire. After you click confirm, you are free to move about in your base of operations, LOL. Basically right in front of you is your stash, I didn't need to put a single item in my stash all through the game, just past your stash is a display cases where you can look at your special loot if you are that tiny fraction of gamers who gives a s**t about that sort of thing. After that you go up stairs where there is nothing apart from the exit to the building. Completely pointless, it ends up, Finish chapter-load screen-click confirm-run for 10secs-load screen-back in the Town heading for the next chapter.All that said I did enjoy my 62+ hours in the game,6/10 this goes to show that a great game engine cannot make up for poor application and a poor storyEdit: Nov 2016 Just to say that i replayed throught the game and it's the same as when i posted above, The sound really is broken. I'm using 7.1

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												In short, the story is missing three key ingredients:  The Keepers, the Hammers, and the Pagans.  This is an unforgivable sin, and this is why The Master Builder hath smitten thee!This is a good game when you play it deciding to forget the first three games, but if you're a veteran there's a bunch of things that are difficult to stomach.  Stealth isn't absolutely necessary.  What?  Isn't this supposed to be Thief, stealth pioneer?  I love the city, and the story isn't bad.  But not far into it, I realized that I seemed to be playing Batman.  That made it feel like a bit of a rip off.I suppose that if you’re going to do a Thief Reboot, the best way would be to start over and redo “The Dark Project” better than it has ever been done before.  There were elements of the original game that I did not like, for example the terrible character design, anything having to do with burricks, the miscarriage that was the lost city, and how it always dumped the player off in a menu screen following the successful completion of a mission.  It would be neat to start over with Garrett as a boy in the streets of the current city and do a little background on how he went from Keeper Acolyte to Thief.  I know Garrett now, and I don’t believe he simply did it out of greed.But I don’t think it ever needs to be a first-person-shooter.  Garrett, in addition to being a thief, is also an adventurer, an investigator, and an explorer.  Build him a City that allows him to be creative in his approach to getting his ill-gotten gains and discover his forbidden intel.And as for Erin, I think old Garrett is about due for a love interest, and this was a good try.  I sincerely hope that Eidos and Square-Enix doesn’t give up on the title, but I also hope they all have the humility to learn from their mistakes.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												This reboot of Thief is an "alright" game in itself, but if you are a fan of the previous games, this pretty much rips out most of the lore of Keepers, Hammerites and Pagans etc. All gone apart from small references like when you enter an old church in one of the chapters which bears the Hammerite symbol.Game mechanics are flawed and some things are just plain stupid. Prime example thats really obvious from the first hour of playing; if I jimmy (break open) a window to nick a house which requires quick-time event button mashing, I should not have to do it again when leaving! Master Thief my♥♥♥♥♥♥ Getting around the city is quite clunky and sluggish in terms of animation; although I do like the immersive first person view (you can see your body when you look down etc) you are given where Garrett physically reaches out into the 3D space and picks up the item. Hard to explain in mere text but you feel truly like you are nicking something rather than "*boop* you've stolen a candle!".Sound aesthetic can vary from well done to "why the hell can I hear conversations being held indoors three blocks away as if they were standing in front of me?" or "Okay, if I hear that 'sloop' conversation one more time I'll bludgeon that guy to death". Voice acting also ranges from good to downright woeful with Garrett somewhere in the middle of that. For some reason certain cutscenes are too low, in others some characters are too loud while others are so feint you can't hear them etc. What a mess.Performance wise, the game frequently stutters since the latest patch in order to stream in textures "better". Visual aesthetic is spot on though I'll give them that. Dark and gloomy and infested with vermin; who are not necessarily rats but of mankind too. Plague is rife, beggars line the streets, hangings are amidst and generally this is where you see a lot of effort has been made to make it authentic. What a pity that the gameplay is just lacking in every department. I'm pretty crap at reviews but take it as a someone whos played the originals; its a dissapointing "No" from me.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												The thief series have long been my favorite game series of all time. Thief - The Dark Project was a masterpiece with a wonderful engrossing story to it, that starts small but then drags you into an epic conclusion.Thief - The Metal Age deals with the aftereffects of the first game. It can be played standalone, but it is the perfect continuation of the first game, and this too drags you into an epic story.Thief - Deadly Shadows is a bit different than the first two games, but I loved it. It brings all the games together, making a full circle. Kind of Zen/taoism touch to it all, how the balance shifts due to your actions through the games.Sadly... the fourth game, this one, is a letdown. I haven't played through it yet, I admit, the story might be as good as the other games. I don't know yet.But then there's the reason I haven't played through it yet... and that's the controls for starters. It's made for consoles. you have few buttons to press, and those few buttons are supposed to do everything the keyboard did in the earlier games. If you for an example want to crouch behind some crates, your game might decide that you want to climb up on them instead. the same button is used for everything. Needless to say, if you want to hide, standing on top of well lit crates is a bad idea. I could live with that, but then there are annoying bugs aswell. I play the game as a thief not an assassin. There's a bug that requires you to kill people to move on. I hope it's a bug, because you're in a vent. someone passes below you, and you get the option to kill them. if you don't, they move on, and you can't get down from there. Ever. There are more gamebreaking bugs I've found aswell, but i've ranted enough. I want to love this game, but I can't.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												In a word: Disappointed. I didn't come from the classic thief games but I do enjoy the modern day stealth games. This is technically as advertised but it just doesn't have a good feel. You are artificially blocked from doing some things -- like climbing and you can't jump (which is freakin' weird in a modern FPS game). A point where it looks like you should be able to climb, you simply can't. Furthermore (and the bigger problem) is the further you get in the game, the bugger it gets. For example, the game just crashed on me but prior to that, I was trying to access a note from the menu but every attempt to open the note failed. it's almost like the down arrow was being held down. (It's not my keyboard as I have no problem now that I'm back in windows.) Prior to this rather large bug, I saw visual glitches, which I excused as I really, really wanted to like this game. I've been trying to convince myself for the past 2 days. But I can't. It's fine but I can't recommend it. Pick up dishonored or Spinter cell instead.. This is worth a shot if you really love those other games but wait for a sale if you can.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												I liked the prologue, the streets were alive, the introduction of the story gave me goosbumps, and the shining loot made the stealing feel fullfilling. What I disliked was, after the intro, all you get are dead streets, no factions, limited ease of movement around the city, dumb guards, and anything you do apart from the main quest feels like work.  The game just doesn't seem to have life, only a flicker of it on the main quests.If you are a fan of the franchise, you WILL be dissapointed, only stick to the main quests for any hope of getting through the whole game without feeling lost inside.  If you are not a fan of the franchise, just don't pay more than £10 for it.In conclusion, this is not a good game (being generous), the next Thief will need have something new for any hope of the continuation of the franchise.  Then again, if the Assaisns Creed can do it, so can Thief.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												While Thief 1 & 2 are prime examples of outstanding late-90's game design, Thi4f may very well be one of the genres, and certainly the series, darkest and most stupid moments. Eidos Montreal did so many mistakes in this game, both fans of the predecessors as well as new gamers are absolutely right to shun it.Why do I have to QTE so many windows and wooden bars, which look all the same? Why can't I jump, save, hit and act how and when I want to? Why must Garrett, Basso and all the other beloved characters of the franchise be either idiots or absent? Where are Garrett's trusty Sword and Blackjack? When did Looking Glass' grim and authentic world get replaced by some generic, soulless medieval-steampunk hodgepodge? Why are the story, dialogues and documents so shallow-brained? Why is the sound engine so bad? Why does the game look so medicore? Why are the Levels so small, linear and uninspired? And why does a master thief wear makeup?I can only recommend this game at a low price to witness the pure underachievement Eidos created here. Looking Glass' and Ion Storms games were certainly not perfect and they left a lot of room for improvements, but this one is simply an insult. I'd rather play "Shipping... and Receiving" for a full 20 hours than 20 minutes of this crap. Still I'm going to finish the game, because I love the series so much and somewhere deep inside, there lies the nucleus of a good stealth game. But it barely shines through.I really hope someone makes a remake of T2 in the Dark Mod.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
Dull stealth action+ great graphics (provided you have high-performing machine)+ initial missions are fun+ challenging hoarding of loot and plentiful collectibles+ guards have several level of alertness- sound is broken (overheard dialogues play with default volume no matter how far are you from the people who speak; all surfaces you step onto sound the same)- shadowplay is broken (you are either hidden or exposed, but even when hidden guards sometimes notice you, sometimes not - there is no transparent mechanic in this)- usually there is only one way to complete any objective- boring characters and absolutely ridiculous antagonist- uninteresting story (I've completed 4 out of 8 game mission and I certainly didn't feel "hooked")- motifs stolen from Dishonored (plagued city, revolution, magical queen of beggars aka "Granny Rags") and other too obvious references (kindly compare the ruins in third mission with the library in The Name of the Rose[www.imdb.com])MAIN CON: The City itself. At first it's certainly great to look at, until you find out it's irrational, non-functional maze of corridors, which only pretends sandbox. There are no fast travel points, so you have to wander through there and back again, just to end up in the same dead ends, dealing with the same guards on the same places. Map is unclear, nearly useless. Rooftops are inaccessible and there is no other way to make your strolls quicker. I don't mind relatively frequent loading screens, yet I DO mind annoying QTEs when opening windows or squeezing through crates. The City is generally empty - the "mob" observing the hanging consists of two or three people; chambers and tenements you sneak into are always abandoned. Several citizens walk back and forth on short simple paths like models on catwalk and mumble one sentence or short dialogue again and again. On the other hand, some places are so heavily guarded it makes random walks more challenging than completing some of the missions. Side-questing would be fun, but since you spend more time getting to the starting point than actually completing the mission, it feels like a disappointing waste of time.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												1- GENERAL Thief is a stealth action game that I've bought in a sale when I was playing Dishonored. I thought it was alike... well, it is, but is not as good as it could be. As the title suggests the game is based in stealing stuff, but we do it with no purpose. We are not Robin Hood, we just steal... maybe that's the purpose, but I think all this theft could have a meaning. It has not. The game goes in Victorian London, now ruled by a tyrant for some reason. After the opening scene we spend most of our gameplay trying to explained what happened then and after that. Not much of a plot, but it seems all the story is kinda weak. The voice acting and character building was not very good also.  2- GAMEPLAY But the game is about stealing and stealth, and in that aspect it's great. We are often confronted with hard sections where it seems impossible to go through without being noticed by the guards. So most of the times I just knock them or put an arrow on their heads. The game is very difficult, and even on normal it was clearly hard for me to go through. Despite that, the AI is bad, with some bugs that I've learn to exploit. That does not ruin the fun. The game is not open world though, and we have a lot of loading screens between sections. That takes some of the immersion, since some of those could take up to 10 seconds on my laptop.  The controls are just frustrating, since we never know how to do something. Sometimes we are able to do an action just jumping, others we have to press a determined button... The graphics are good, and I have no problems running the game in medium setup, that helps a lot. The score mechanism gives the game some replay ability, but I warn that I do not know how can someone go through the game unnoticed. Well, maybe I'm just bad.   3- CONCLUSION I've enjoyed the game, but I've never have that feeling of immersion. I've quit before the ending also. The problem was that I was always comparing the game to dishonored, and he always lost. If you are able to ignore the bad story and the loading screens you will have a rather good stealth game where you will love to steal everything. But I've noticed the €29.99 price tag, and even knowing that the game is on sale a lot of times, it's annoying that the producers keep it at so high prices, it's just unreal and that's the reason I thumbed it down.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Worthy notes to mention:- I bought the Master edition for £4.50 off the Square Enix Store.- Because of my useless internet speed, it took roughly 2 days to download.- I haven't played the previous thief games. Though now I think I will as I can't play this...- This issue doesn't just effect me, other people have had it too, amoungst many others.Thief is a dark, stealth/action game where you play as a thief known as Garrett. From the small portion that I played, the game features some unique thieving mechanics that may also work well for the rest of the game (I wouldn't know unfortunately). The game's visuals are very pleasing and I'm glad to say that the steam store's screenshots are pretty accurate.Unfortunately though, there is a downside... Otherwise this review wouldn't be a "not recommended" review would it? Yes, Thief (4) is riddled with issues. A quick trip to the community Hub would have told me that this game was a gamble to purchase... Well, now I don't like gambling. You see, I started thief up and was met by the menu screen. Great! I thought, all seems well. Apparently not. The game (at least for me) features a horrible jagged/laggy/stuttering bug when V-sync is enabled, causing any movement with WASD+Mouse to result in a CCTV-esque movement to everything. Disabling V-sync does reduce the issue, but it causes my GTX660ti to heat up to a concerning level.In the end, I didn't spend much time playing thief, though I would have liked to.. I've been searching google, steam, and throughout the bowels of the internet to get the issue resolved. No dice.(I tried Nvidia Inspector, messing with the ThiefEngine and BaseEngine files, Sweet FX, Nvidia Control Panel, even in-game settings (Textures low etc)... Nothing worked. It was either no-vsync or preserve my GPU... I chose the GPU). If the issue gets resolved and I can eventually play the game properly, I'd happily update the review. But for now, I just can't play it with it's current v-sync issue.**Feedback / Suggestions welcome. I don't hate this game, I'm just unhappy that I bought a game which I cannot play; I just cannot enjoy it when the movement/looking around is so jarring and uncomfortable to watch.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												    The problem with naming a game after a beloved series is that it will inevitably be compared to that series' best version. It happened with DMC: Devil May Cry, and it happened here.     On it's own this game isn't that bad. It's biggest problem is that it feels like it was made on a factory line with a checklist. Standard love interest, check. Standard villain, check. Standard gameplay, check. Standard weapons and gear, check. Nothing in this game really makes it stand out from the crowd. In Thief 2 you had huge sprawling levels you could get lost in with tons of secrets to find if you were observant and clever enough.     One thing that I really noticed was that rope arrows in this game only worked at very specific points. If you fired a rope arrow anywhere else it would just be a waste of time and arrows. In Thief 2 you could fire one of those suckers anywhere and climb up even if it led nowhere. It encouraged exploring outside the linear hallways and streets. TL:DR version. Not the worst game, but there are better stealth games out there.

The Map can be interesting but.....Everything else is half arsed. The controls are a bit off, the story feels unloved, as well as unfinished, and the game lacks atmosphere. There is so much potential in this game but it feels lifeless and unloved...  like my ambitions.With a bit more effort from Eidos Montreal, this game could have been a classic, good enough to rival the original Thief games but instead it feels like they cut corners and rushed this game out 6 to 12 months early.I'd only recommend this game to you if you are a uber fan of the Thief series,who is curious about this game but please, buy it when its on sale and heavily discounted.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I'll get this out of the way now: I have not played any of the previous games in the series. My opinion on Thief comes from Thief and Thief alone.While having potential, Thief lacks what most stealth games do: an element of stealth.The stealth aspect is virtually non-existant. Enemies will not notice you so long as you are crouched, swooping, walking, or otherwise in the shadows. Nevermind the fact that they're mere inches from your face in an ominous alleyway. When their guard is down, they are completely oblivious. When their guard should otherwise be up, they are still completely oblivious. It is entirely possible to crouch by a group of guards in plain sight with little to no reaction beyond a "What was that?"Too often are there instances where the game provides little to no ingenuity. While each map supposedly has "multiple paths" for the player to take, the paths are few and far between, with little to no deviation from a linear trajectory. The maps are set up to allow you to find your own way to get from point A to point B, but after starting your path, it's simply a matter of holding down a few keys until you arrive at your destination.On top of all else, the controls are needlessly bizzare. Let us assume you wish to hop down from a rope you're climbing. One would expect the jump key while looking downward would do so, or perhaps the crouch key. One would be wrong. Instead it's required to bind seperate keys to all of these commands. Instead of grouping together contextual keys in a sensible fashion, Thief takes the approach of "4 keys for 1 action", leaving you scrambling for the correct key when another should do the same thing. Each additional bind is purely contextual, rendering the alternative bindings useless save for specific situations, and indicating that Thief missed the simple concept of one key being able to do multiple actions in order to allow the player to respond more quickly. To top off the controls, Thief's handling of input commands is lackluster. It often requires multiple key presses before any one action is actually completed. So expect to fall to your death a couple dozen times before Garrett finally decides to hop that 2-foot gap in front of him.All in all, while Thief seems appealing, it utterly lacks in any and all expected components.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												The original Thief is, possibly, my most favorite game in all the hundreds of games I've played. To be able to immerse yourself so wholly in the experience that you can literally spend the entire day in a single level, sneaking about and accomplishing the mission so perfectly that you are seen only when the pathing of enemies makes it 100% impossible, that you never have to swing your weapon save to possibly knock out a guard or two by necessity. If nothing else, the core divide I feel is that the original Thief felt like I was actually taking things in logical places from some jerks. This game feels as hollow and forced as smalltalk with a stranger on the street waiting in line for the bus.Loot is obvious, and placed everywhere without sentiment for retaining the 4th wall - as if they all agreed that if Mario can place floating coins you jump at and feel gratified then so can we!I feel as sneaky as a rusty shopping cart, and get the sense that the character is as much a Thief as an uninformed constituent is a Voter. Achieving the action with ease, is not the same as achieving the action with sprezzatura.

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Thief (2014) is a "reboot" of the Thief franchise...& maybe could be considered a true-blue sequel to Thief: Deadly Shadows (Thief: DS). Thief (2014) feels like a sequel to Thief: DS, since this game takes place (again) in a somewhat open-world called The City for "The Master Thief" Garrett (the player) to explore + b/c this feels much more modern than the previous game. Also, some references also seem like a continuation to Thief: DS. Just like Thief: DS, there are main missions + side missions for him to take on, as well - which are often excellent, with numerous stealthy ways + directions to choose, in a mission (especially main ones). Also, Garrett can also just explore The City to enter people's houses + shops to rob them!Garrett meets up with an old friend named Erin, for whom he was a mentor to. She has been greedy, trying to find a certain object, which could make her ultra-powerful + ultra-rich. Erin disappears after an incident + Garrett awakens quite a while later. A disease called The Gloom is spreading + an over-powerful figure has taken The City by storm, imposing his will on this now poverty-stricked + disease-ridden City. This part sounds very similar to another [excellent] stealth game Dishonored (in which that game took a lot of cues from the older Thief games). There is also a resistance building-up against this person, as well - which again, sounds right out of Dishonored's book. Garrett begins taking jobs again to make money + to gain information on Erin's where-abouts.There's an interesting dynamic that goes on b/t Garrett + Erin, which I wish was further explored here. Garrett usually knocks people out, steals stuff & moves along. Of course, the player can also play deadly, if they actually feel like it & choose to do so (or not). Meanwhile, Erin's turned into the complete opposite of Garrett - willing to kill to get what she wants, without hesitation. Early on, this stuff is excellent. I do wish this was emphasized + explored a bit more, though.I do wish certain story elements + characters were explored quite a bit further here + a bit more fleshed-out; & that certain events went a different direction - instead of sometimes taking the predictable or under-developered route. This stuff is seems to be one of the few weaknesses I've seen to find with this game.Eidos Montreal has tried like hell to make this game appeal to both the hardcore, old-school Thief fans + for the modern gamer. Besides your typical difficulty levels that games usually allow the gamer to select, players can impose a Custom Difficulty Mode. Here, the gamer can decide what features they can turn off. A lot of these features that can be disabled (or left enabled) - they are the features modernizing the game. These can range from Disabling One-Hit Takedowns, Game Fails When You Are Seen, Disable Focus Mode, Disabling Shimmering Objects & numerous other things. Personally, on my first run-through - I played on Thief difficulty mode. More games should take this excellent approach of allowing such a deep customization of your difficulty + settings - which flat-out embarrasses most games that basically only have a few difficulty modes.Like Hitman: Absolution, there is a new X-Ray mode (which is similar to the Batman: Arkham games) called Focus Mode. Garrett can basically see through walls + see enemies. It goes further than that, also. Garrett can even slow-down time, be faster in this mode, do lethal blows & even see important objects be highlighted even more so than normal. A lot of this depends also on your difficulty settings + what skills you upgrade. Depending on what you turn on + off, the game scores the difficulty setting. You're scored in-game, also.The more Garrett does in the game-world, the more money he can make so he can buy Equipment from merchants & even can purchase Focus Points from a certain someone. Also, Focus Points can even be found in the game-world. This is how Garrett upgrades his skills. Skills can range from making Garrett faster; see more hidden objects in the game-world (& on the map); make him lockpick faster; be more deadly in Focus Mode; his attacks do more damage; upgrade the amount of equipment he can carry; & numerous other things. Garrett no longer carries a sword - for his main weapon. Garrett only has his blackjack, which by default can make the game played quite a bit more stealthy (as long as you don't level-up down a more action-orientated approach). Getting into fights (especially early on) is not really the best idea, until you've followed Garrett's skills down a certain path. Garrett has his usual assortment of arrows for his bow: regular arrows to hit enemies with; rope arrows so he can climb ropes + reach certain areas; fire arrows to burn objects + enemies; water arrows to put out fires; explosive arrows - to name a few arrows. Also, Garrett has a claw + can climb certain walls w/ it. While a great majority of the game is in 1st-person perspective for the camera + you're seeing through his eyes, when Garrett is platforming on pipes & rappelling down some objects (like Lara Croft would in the Tomb Raider games or Nilin in Remember Me), the game switches to a 3rd-person perspective.Thief (2014) gets the feel of being "The Master Thief" better than any other game I've seen. Besides the big things the Thief games always got right, there's also now a lot of subtle + little things that are emphasized big-time here. A new cover system has been added, as well - in which Garrett can glance, lean + look around objects. Garrett can switch from cover-to-cover. A bit similar to Blink Mode from Dishonored, Garrett can perform a "Swoop" move that moves him very quickly & hard-to-see for a moment - but, its range is very limited. While here you can't move very far + in that supernatural way like Dishonored allowed with Blink Mode - Garrett's "Swoop" seems like a way to speed-up the gameplay here a bit, making it a bit faster + more action-orientated.That's not everything on subtlties, either! When putting his hands around paintings, we see Garrett's hands close-up, moving around to try + find the switch to find hidden objects. The same goes for bookshelves, as well - when Garrett's looking for a book that actually might pull a switch to reveal a hidden area. We see Garrett react to objects he finds in the game-world, that might be worth a lot of money. We see (mostly) from the 1st-person perspective, with Garrett opening drawers to cabinets, dressers & other things - moving quick + fast like a Thief would. Garrett has a home-base, in which he stores all of the important things + trophies that he's found, stolen + taken. Not only that - you can look at your stats in-game + even store equipment there, also.Nixxes has done a good job with making the PC version look technically excellent - which seems like the norm for them, after seeing many of their recent ports for Square Enix + Eidos (Hitman: Absolution, Tomb Raider 2013, Sleeping Dogs, etc). Though, performance was all erratic on DX11 w/ most things on Normal on my PC (i7 950; 1 GB of GF GTX 560 Ti; 8 GB RAM; Win 7 64-bit) on its own - ranging from 40 frames to 60 frames per sec at any moment. Locking it down to a 40 frames maximum with EVGA Precision X certainly solved this issue.If you really liked Thief: DS w/ the direction that game took with gameplay + modernizing the series (when it did), then I'm pretty much preaching to the choir here - play Thief 2014; it does this even more so than Thief: DS. If you weren't happy w/ the direction Thief: DS took [especially when compared to the previous 2 Thief games (Thief: The Dark Project / Gold + Thief II: The Metal Age)] - it's still possible the game might be for the old-school Thief fan b/c of its new Custom Difficulty Mode. After 31 hours w/ my 1st playthrough - Thief (2014) was really good, even despite its few flaws that just rob it from reaching greatness.Grade = B+.

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												I really liked the old Thief games. I wasn't a huge fan, but I really enjoyed them. I was so stoked when this game came out, but I was very quickly disappointed. I think the old games were so good because they were a fresh style of gameplay in their time. This game felt like Wal-mart's "Great Value" brand Reduced sodium Saltine crackers taste....BLAND.The biggest sin this game commited was its storytelling. Cliche's galore! The ending was so.....bad. It felt like they wanted to keep it open for a sequel, but they made Garrett look like such a fool. There were shopkeepers to sell arrows and such in the most unusual locations. You never had to worry about conserving ammunition before an important event because. BAM, out of nowhere, a guy offering items for all your "nefarious needs." Which brings me to my next big sin. The voice acting. Zero emotion, zero talent. I got so sick of hearing the same back and forth banter that never changed or had variation throughout the whole game. I would think that at least Garrett would have a good voice actor, but it sounded like the guy the voiced Garrett did it while lying down on his couch.The AI was horrendous. They would see you kill a fellow guard in cold blood, and once you hid for about 1 minute, they would say, "whoever it was, he's gone now," and go back to their exact same patrol route. No more guards would be summoned, nothing. They either knew exactly where you were, or had no idea. There was no searching around until they found you. For the first 3 chapters, if a torch was extinguished by a water arrow, they reacted to it. After that, they must have had a memo go around the Pony Express for the guards, that ordered them to stop reacting to that nonsense.Lastly, the level design. It was probably one of the most linear games since Contra for the NES (Contra was an epic game...this, was not). You usually had ONE path you could take to get somewhere. If there were two choices, it was either, stealth path, or fight guards path. There were more doors and windows you couldnt go in, than words spoken in the game. You could only climb in very particular places. SO, SO.....SOOO BAD!!! This game is DREAFUL!!! For the love of Pete~~! Don't spend money on this game!! Pity.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I write this review on the basis that I was extremely excited for the release of this game considering it's the first Thief game I will play. A lot of talk over the internet from fans of the series suggested that from trailers and gameplay shown before the release of this game, it was considered things like not living up to the original Thief games and that this game will flop. I tried my best through my play of this game to advert my thinking of the game in such a way but by the end of it all I have to agree with what everyone is saying about this game. I wanted something good out of this game, the first big "next gen" game to be released and it did flop, so badly that by the end, I just wanted Thief to finish so I could never play it again.The game has bad design choices in many aspects from the forced animations ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to the repetive sequences such as knocking out a guard or going through a small crack inbetween areas. The story was lackluster, voice acting sub par. Music was fair in certain cases but it gets really annoying when I'm somewhat in the mood of the setting and suddenly a "clash" everytime I take down someone. Graphics was the only redeeming factor about this game but even then, it still ran like♥♥♥♥♥♥in some cases. Loading times weren't an issue as a few people had mentioned.AI is stupid as well as ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t sometimes with their ability to never miss and persistent idiocy to search forever but instantly give up.In the end, this game was a massive disappointment and I'd rather finish Dishonored 3 times over and enjoy myself than play this game again. I truely hope there ISN'T a sequel to this game because if they did make one, I'd have to triple check, no, a million check to make sure the game isn't♥♥♥♥♥♥TL:DR 6/10 playable but♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Thief, where do i start with this ?seeing the trailers of this game made me a little bit excited but at the same time i was skeptical since i haven't played any of the other Thief games, but then i found a great deal of this game on Gamecards website and i decided to take my chances and buy it.The game starts with you, Garret, the master thief, in a house full of loot and a drunk man laying on bed, u sneak around and you steal any shiny stuff, at the begining of this game i didn't think it will be that exciting to try and find each and every collectable, but as soon as Chapter 2 started, i fell in love with this game.The atmosphere this game creates is unlike any other, and the sound of your heartbeats pounding as a guard approaches is one of the amazing things about this game, it's the perfection of sound effects that gets you in the game and makes you wanna play more.I haven't finished the game yet, but the missions i played were awesome, stealth games just got a new reboot for me with this game, and what i really like is that the games rewards you based on your play style, wether you were a predator, a ghost or an oppurtunist, your rewards will be based on that, and you will get more if you were a ghost, which really motivates you to play the game the way you should, as a GHOST!At the end of the day, each game has its pros and cons, and the cons of this game were:- You have to make your way inside any home by opening a window, which is a silly way to make loading screens- Enemy AI can be stupid at times, detecting you from a distance and sometimes they don't see you even if you become very close to them- Some tools were useless, as some arrows require more than 3 shots to kill a targetBut afterall, i'm really enjoying the game and will soon finish it, and hope you try it as well :)Recommended, 9 OUT OF 10

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Graphics 6/10Gameplay 3/10Replay value 3/10Sound 2/10This game was designed for console.This will probaly turn into a rant!The lockpicking system seems to be just using the d-pad to find the spot, Which is kinda difficult on a mouse setup and no visual clues or audible ones either apart from a sphere brightening.The audio 3d positioning is one of the worst I've heard. Stood 3 feet from a ticking clock, moved another foot  and the sound faded to nothing.Might seem like nothing to some people but it destroys the immersion.The original game had audio so finely tuned you didn't need to see the guards, just hear them to know exactly where they were.The graphics, while nice, are nothing to write home about.Kinda has a comic look to things, is washed out and has no real depth.The field of view feels claustraphobic and going above the normal changes things to a fisheye lens view.Opening (jimmying) windows is another console driven gimmic designed to instill intrepidation and realism into the act, but alas, fails and only annoys when you realise that you have to do it over and over again even from withing the room you just burgled.How many people need to jimmy their own windows from the inside?Th inability to not use your tools unless in the proper place is also a detriment to this game.Take a rope arrow and try it on a wooden structure you think you may climb and NO.Predefined rope attachment areas only and also no retrieval of the rope arrow.Even the original game allowed you to do that. I remember going through a 40ft room swinging from rope arrow to rope arrow all while using just 2 arrows.The AI in the game is stupid.Two guards in a room, I open a door in plain sight and fade away again"who opened that"  "ahh twas nothing"yes, nothing happened to pick the lock and open the door.People on the street don't seem to see you, except guards because they are looking for me? With the exception of the way I am dressed I could be anybody. I haven't killed in their sight or done anything wrong.The game is almost impossible to play if you turn all the console type features off and try to play like the original game.Without focus mode you may see traps, but sometimes not all traps are equal. some may reset your progress. others may release poison or darts or set off alarms. without focus they all look the same.The lack of a sword or a knife to defend youself, should you get discovered is also missing.Yout can dodge and use a billyjack but then you also have to press a different key to finish them off, else they get back up and kill you.Consoles are killing the pc gaming scene by diluting original games into a series of button mashing mini games and QTE's.I'm done with console reboots of orginal pc games.SOD the lot of em

Why does Chapter 5 exist?First Thief game I've ever played and it was a huge let down. This game is riddled with bad AI, bugs, and overall ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game design. This bad stealth game all of a sudden took on the visage of a horror game, like Outlast. The sad part? That was the first piece of solid game design I'd seen! It was so good for what it shouldn't have been. If Thief had been a horror game, this review would be positive, and I would have loved it. Sure, the horror was weak, and predictable, but they established atmosphere, and that's what they lack in most AAA horror games nowadays.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												I really wanted to recommend this game, but I just can't do it. There are plenty of other games out that are far more engaging than Thief. And while I'm not on the "the original Thief games r the BEST!" bandwagon, those games were simply much more fun to play. I still had fun with the new Thief - the game tries hard to be engaging. Stealth is required the minute Garrett steps out of his hideout, interacting with the environment is key to success, and there are multiple ways to accomplish a given task. Sounds good, right? Except the actual game-play of Thief - thieving and strategizing - happens the same way too many times for the game to carry my interest through to the end (I did get there eventually on my third attempt). The story could have been engaging, but characters are under-developed (some only appear in cut-scenes), show up for no reason, and are blessed with campy B-movie dialogue. The cutscene at the end of the game, while complete, made me think there might have been more to the story, but it was trimmed or cut. Who knows. The mechanics of the game work well, but as before, there's little variation: put out fires to create shadows, throw a bottle to distract guards, and swoop to the objective. What should have been a thrilling exploration of an open world Steampunk city is instead reduced to a grind-fest for loot in a lot of close alleys. Some of the level designs are great - the house with the moving walls was one of my favorites - but the novelty passed quickly once I realized that most loot would be acquired (yet again) by rifling through the desks and closets for pens, ashtrays, golden saucers, scroll holders...In a sense, Thief really is Kleptomania Simulator. You scamper around the City, stealing random sh*t. But to me, Thief should be about “the job,” not about stealing random sh*t. There are three kinds of jobs in Thief: Main (story) jobs, client jobs that an NPC will provide, and Basso's side jobs. Story jobs advance the story; yes, there's theft along the way, but even with the massive amount of loot in the Baron's mansion, thieving still feels like an afterthought because there's literally no reason to do it. Client jobs have a minor story of their own, but there are only two clients (each provides three missions). Jobs from Basso are side-quests that give some gold and a notice on screen that it's completed. Even though they're acquired from different sources, they all have a similar feel and execution. Thief has great graphics and fun mechanics - the archery is especially good - but these positives are betrayed by a very average use just about all other game elements. The setting needed to be opened up. The music creates tension without being memorable. Enemies only come in three varieties. The enemies' AI all behaves the same (extremely predictable). And boss battles - what a joke they are! Grab Thief on sale if it interests you, and hope you finish it before your patience is exhausted and you start just killing all the guards so you can loot in peace. On challenge mode: There are three maps (one of which is DLC): the Asylum, the Baron's mansion, and the House of Blossoms (all excerpted from the main game). Collect loot before the time runs out. Every time you gather loot, the count-down resets. It's an arcade-y addition that might help refine your thieving technique (there are enemies present), but with only three maps it's little more than a distraction. And if you don't purchase The Forgotten DLC (the Asylum map), there are actually only two maps...On the Master Thief edition:The Master Thief edition is b*llsh*t. You get: the Opportunist Booster Pack, a digital comic book, and the digital soundtrack. The Opportunist booster Pack contains items that can be acquired in-game, you just get them at the start. To get the comic book, you have to take the code provided and enter it into an external website. To get the soundtrack, you have to enter the code you receive into a different external website. BUT THE SOUNDTRACK IS NOT COMPLETE. I only received 10 tracks of the soundtrack this way. The full album on Amazon is 20 tracks. A straight-up cheat, plain and simple. Don't get the Master Thief edition.On DLC:Of the DLC, the Booster packs are not pay-to-win, but they are pay-for-an-advantage. The Bank Heist is fun if short. If feels like a left-over level for content that was cut from the game. It's fun, but the value of the loot is disappointing, and it can be beaten in 30-60 minutes. If Challenge mode is something you enjoyed, the The Forsaken challenge map is worth the price - on sale at 80% off, of course.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												Against all odds, the game is actually a lot of fun!I am a hardcore classic Thief fan, having played the original two games to death, including tons of fan missions. I had sub-zero expectaitons and was growing increasingly horrified by the reboot with each new trailer and gameplay video. Having now played a reasonable amount of the game, I can say that despite all the complaints oldschool Thief fans have, it's actually a solid experience that feels satisfying and thiefy at its core.Despite the lack of Hammerites / Mechanists / Stephen Russell / etc, the game provides enough tweaks to turn it into an experience very close to the originals. Even if story missions are smaller, the city hub is a lot of fun to explore and loot. You can strip the on-screen feedback to just the light gem and explore using your brains and your senses, which is actually what Thief is all about.I hated and laughed at this game before I played it. However, at the end of the day all that matters is whether you have fun with your purchase and I am actually having a lot of fun with this reboot.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												A reboot of a well-loved series is always a gamble. Even if developers manage to completely recreate everything right about the original games, you're still never going to recapture that nostalgia. I feel for fans of the original games who are disappointed with the reboot, I really do. As a Silent Hill fan, I know what it's like to see a series you love change in ways you hoped it never would.  But as I've never played the original Thief games, I can only base my review on this one, and despite a lot of problems such as the muddled story, linear missions, and inability to climb absolutely everywhere due to contextual climbing and jumping, I found this game wildly fun. In the end, my biggest complaint is that there just isn't any more. The story could be explored so much better with a slower-moving pace and more, less hectic missions that let the narrative slowly unfold through small details rather than bombastic action sequences. At any rate, despite it's flaws, this game made it to my ultimate top 10, and as such, I feel as though I owe it at least a thumbs up.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												So, the new Thief game has come and a lot of people have a lot of oppinions on it. Personally, the old Thief games are some of my all time favourites and I gladly place Thief 1 & 2 at some point in my Top 10 list of best games ever. I am also a big fan of the more recent Dishonored game, really hoping for a sequel there, and I hold it as the true spiritual successor to the old Thief games. So how does this new, actual THIEF Thief game hold up?I am glad to say that I enjoyed it! When judges on it's own merrits, it is a very enjoyable experience with some great gameplay throughout. The story is a bit simplistic, especially when compared to the old games stories, but there are a lot of layers to the story and the universe that you really have to dig for to get a glimpse of. For example, there is a very interesting theory circulating that this Thief game actually takes place in the same universe as the old games, only set about 800 or so years into the future, with this games Garret being a sort of reincarnation of the old games Garret. There is a theme about the cyclical nature of time in the game, and there's a side-quest in particular that discusses the idea of all parts of time existing at the same time all the time (sorry if it sounds a bit confusing from my explanation), but it would make sense that this story could be a continuation as well as a reboot at the same time.The best part of the game is clearly the gameplay, and stealing things really takes the main stage, as is appropriate. There is almost always something to steal in any part of the environment, and sometimes you happen upon special loot that is especially valuable. A lot of it is also hidden or contained in special places where you actively need to find the loot or figure out how to unlock it in some very intricate ways, which gives a thorough player a great sense of rewarding the dedicated playstyle. The addition of the "swooping" mechanic to Garrets moveset is also really enjoyable, and it works as a sort of counter to the "Blink" ability that was the absolute best part of the stealth system in Dishonored.It is very interesting to observe the evolution of the first person stealth genre visible here, as the original Thief games so strongly influenced the development of Dishonored, where they borrowed elements very hevily and used them to an extremely good extent, whereupon the developers here for the new Thief game were very heavily inspired by the style and development of Dishonored in turn. A great example is the three-part introduction to the world of the game that both Dishonored used (Tales from Dunwall) as well as Thief (Stories from The City).There are some aspects that detract from the overall experience of Thief, however. There are a couple of times when bugs can ruin the immersion, however they were fairly infrequent and none of them were really game-breaking. The worst one I ran into was durring a chapter where you ride in an evelvator and at the end of the ride have to climb out through a hatch in the top of the elevator. Upon trying to climb up, Garret got caught in a hanging-animation from the hatch and refused to climb up. After trying to climb, and then letting go and trying again, I was finally able to get on top of the elevator on my third or fourth try, so the problem solved itself after all. Problems like this, however, are rather frustrating to run into, even if they never ruin the experience completely.The navigation system can also be somewhat frustrating at times, due mainly to the fact that there is no real "jump" button in the game. The player can only perform a leap of some kind at certain points, like near an edge to jump accross to another platform. At times this jump can behave unexpectedly, however, and sometimes even gets the player killed. An example is any situation where you need to jump to a hanging rope, where you need to be perfectly aligned with the rope and do the exact kind of jump the game asks you for. If you don't, Garret won't aim for the rope and can sometimes instead just jump of the platform and throw himself to his death. This happened a couple of times durring my playthrough and it got very frustrating at some points.Overall, however, I would possitively recommend this game to everyone. If you're an old Thief player, or if you enjoyed Dishonored, you will be able to get a lot of enjoyment out of this game if you are able to judge the game based on it's own merrits rather than only comparing it to how great the originals were. Even though I absolutely love the old games, as I said, I was able to accept the changes the developers had made to the mechanics and I ended up enjoying the new Thief game a whole lot. And if you're a gamer that hasn't yet experienced this type of game, I would also recommend it, as it is a pretty nice introduction to stealth mechanics with a very well designed game. However, for these types of people I would probably also suggest that you give at least Dishonored a try before hand, as it is the most well designed stealth game of the modern era. While I would also suggest the old Thief games, they can be very challenging to a newer player, but if you are brave enough (both figurativelly and litterally), you should definitely give them a try as well, you won't regrett it!As a final touch, I have to compliment Thief on being a ridiculously well ported/optimised game with some amazing graphical options on all fronts. Running the game at max settings is also a true treat for the senses as the world is strictly beautifull to behold both visually as well as through it's audio. Finally, I have to say I really enjoyed the new voice actor for Garret. While not as amazing as the originals Stephen Russell, the new voice actor manages to capture the feeling of Garrets personality and his internal monologues really well. At times, his delivery made it feel like I was playing the old games again, which is a really nice thing indeed.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Warning: flaming review.Stupid scenario that features a mix of teen emo & blatant emptiness, the more you advance, the less you like it. Absent or lame characters, world feels bare & empty. Garret is too silent compared to previous games & unable to jump (maybe he's now too old for that haha). Another bad thing: you will often see Garett's face, which shouldn't be. Tiny & boring levels and no pleasure from exploring/discovering: everything is painted/scratched for you to see the possible routes, only blind players would miss them... Level layout is really bad. Gated gameplay: go THERE, do THAT, etc. Annoying Scripted sequences that you'll have to restart several times. Knocking people is bad, M'okay? So forget about the previous games where it was the hype thing to do lol. To top it all it's rather ugly, with no colors and oddly enough no mirrors (maybe it's my settings though). The AI is ridiculous. A lot seem like stolen from Dishonored: the guards' uniforms, the illness thing and a lot of the decor stuff.In conclusion: I cannot believe what I'm going to say but the average Thief 3 is waaaaay better than this! So huh?! How come? I tried to love the game, you can see that I have put a lot of hours in it & I still have some stuff to do in it but playing more than an hour at the time is too ***ing boring. Best Thief to Worst Thief, IMO: 2, 1, 3, 4.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												As a die hard fan of Thief series, I refuse to perceive this latest remake as bad. We've been waiting 10 years for another Thief game, and although this is not the direct continuation of trilogy it is still a very good game.You can adjust the difficulty level to your liking. Don't like focus? Turn it off. As in other Thief games, you are not forced to kill anyone, you can either sneak past them or knock them out. Some loot can be tricky to find, some are in plain sight but are still out of your reach until you pull the right trigger. Though this is a remake, it's has nice touch about the original Thief's past: Hammerites cathedral, references to Trickster, cog shaped loot (hint toward the Mechanists), Keeper's Library - it is all sentimental in this new instalment. Very nice music and graphics, steam punk, dark feel about the story. The story though might be one weaker side of this game. It's not as full and reach as it was in previous trilogy games. Nevertheless I like the game and hopefully we will see Garrett again. Or his apprentice from the end of the trilogy.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												I thoroughly enjoyed this game. It is visually gorgeous, has a good story with documents and conversations which add depth, offers a range of play styles and routes through levels, and has a wide variety of collectables for those who enjoy hunting them out. I would definitely recommend it.However for OCD completionists like me there are a couple of issues which will drive you insane. [Spoilers] One of the levels has a challenge which cannot be obtained due to bugs, the statistics on challenges are bugged, several of the levels are glitchy and require counter intuitive actions or even exploits to get pure ghost along with 100% loot (one appears completely impossible), the city appears to be missing 2 loot items (I may have missed them, but given one of the smuggler's maps caches is missing I think not).

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Is the game any good?Short answer - Yes it is.BUT, the game is plagued by a long history of expectations from previous really good games in this series, and also by troubled development, which makes it much more complicated to talk about. A lot of reviews gave this game a low score, and even though I do understand that point of view partially, I also think it is unfair most of the time. Why? Well, more on that later.So what is good about it?It has very good stealth-mechanics. It has fantastic options for customizing your experience. It looks really great. Movement is smooth. It feels great to sneak, run, jump, and swoop. Good atmosphere in general. Hub-world is quite large and filled with many secrets. Many, really great side-missions. Great voice acting overall. What is not so good about it?Story feels unfinished and does not make much sense - it is also really cheesy and out of place. Audio is badly optimized at times. Frequent loading-screens in hub-world break immersion. You need quite a powerful machine to run it well. WEIRD April 1st bug, making it possible to complete the game, because of looping the chapter you are currently at. Bypassed by changing your date on the computer, but WHY???Control:Mouse and keyboard is the better experience - and it is excellent . Some controllers have fun rumble feedback, but it is not entirely worth it. So, why are some reviews unfair?Because of nostalgia: Some people have spent so much time into the older games, and they had such a good time playing those games, that they expect exactly the same experience again in later installments.Reboot-hate (stuck in the past)You simply can't repeat  an experience - it is not the same game - It is not the same you. The feeling we remember when we played a game the first time is mostly a nostalgic memory, that is probably a little warped from reality. And with that somewhat warped memory we search for the same feeling in the new game, which we never get - hence we become upset.I see so many reviewers critiquing the game from this angle, and so the critique is not objective in my mind. Instead of objectiviley looking at the game, everything gets judged as bad, because it does not fit the past. and many seemed to have decided in advance to hate the game no matter what it did. Another reason it is judged badly is partially because the game should be played slowly (I think) - Rushing through the game in order to write a quick review, and I think the essence of the game is mostly lost. Do we really want the game to be the same as the older ones?I would be really disappointed if they made Thief the same game as before with just better graphics, which I feel a lot of people are asking for. If that is what you want, I say go play the old games instead. I'm serious. Those games exist here on steam and GoG, they are still great (and MUCH cheaper), and they have tons of mods, updates, and fan made missions that make these games highly enjoyable.Devs. Damned if they do, damned if they don't.And, how do you create a game that is both enjoyable for someone who has hundreds of hours invested, and for someone totally new to the series?  It would, for example, not be commercially viable to create a game just for the SMALL devote thief-community. It is also interesting that most players who are not familiar with the older games really like this new Thief.Is this game a true thief-game?You hide in the shadows. You can sneak, you can explore, both vertically and horizontally, you have all the interesting arrows and gadgets. The game-mechanics are really good. There is lock-picking (best in the series). The AI chatter is better than ever, even though buggy at times. The atmosphere is very tense, dark and scary. You are weak and vulnerable. There is lots of loot and hidden areas - The game is quite long and re-playable. There is aspects of the supernatural, and the world is kind of steam-punk-medieval.  Sound design is really well made (a part from the bugs), and an integral part of the game. So, yes, it is absolutely a thief-game.Problems?Yes, there are quite a few. The most noticeable one is sound in general. Sure, at times the sound is really great, but it just does not seem to be mixed right. Sometimes you don't hear what you should hear, because something else is too loud. Sometimes you hear NPCs that are not in the same room as you, still as loud as they were right next to you. On occasion the music cuts out which makes you wonder if someone saw you, or something happened. The guards seem to get stuck sometimes, but there is always a way to get around them if you have your wits around. But then there is also the occasional issue of some NPCs being completely frozen, or "glitching out". None of the problems are game-breaking, a part of the April 1st bug that truly was a mystery. (You were kept in a loop and could not exit the current mission, when you reloaded a save you always started from the beginning.)What I don't like:Oh the story... In a way, it seems like they put some real effort into it, and the voice-acting and cut-scenes are nice. But, it also does not seem to head anywhere - Some cut-scenes just did not feel like they fit the situation you were in previously or after.  You get the sensation the story was quickly put together before the deadline, using various ideas all mixed together. You don't care for anyone really. Also, the occasional 3rd person wall climbing, even though not a problem at all, it just doesn't fit in the game - there is no point for this mechanic either. Also, I wished there could have been a little more space for "inventing your own path". All options on how to finish a task or path, were pretty obvious (to me). For example, you can't just use a rope arrow where you like, only at specific places. Frequent loading screens does break immersion - It becomes mostly apparent when you are trying to reach a specific location. The loading-screen times are not awful, and not too frequent, but I was hoping that it would be a little better, considering that was Deadly Shadow's biggest flaw, and I'm a little surprised it's needed with today's hardware - Aren't there ways to load stuff in the background as you progress? At least there are no loading screens during missions anymore (as in Deadly Shadows).Verdict:I say that Thief is a very good game despite its problems. The stealth mechanics, atmosphere and immersion are all fantastic, and the fact that you can highly customize your experience is just icing on the cake. Hopefully patches will come soon to correct the flaws, but the story and direction can't be patched, and it is unfortunately a real mess. But the main mechanics: thieving and sneaking is actually really well done, and the levels are atmospheric and fun, sometimes truly great. The side-missions are really worth your time as well. Then you can of course compete with your friends in terms of how fast you can complete a level, how much loot, knockdowns, ghosting etc. All this clearly makes the game very much worth it.If the other thief-games did not exist, if we did not compare with our sometimes questionable nostalgia, more would probably see this game as a really good and unique experience. But some people just decided to hate this game no matter what it is - haters are gonna hate I guess.I have played all thief games extensively (including fan missions), and I still like this game a lot. In fact, while playing Thief, I kind of forgot my other duties at times; I could not wait to get back in the world.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												This game took away everything from the original Thief games that makes it unique and a challenge.Having a hard time navigating Victorian London? Good thing Garrett has a GPS-like minimap and objective markers everywhere.Wanna jump over this pesky table and climb those boxes over there to avoid guards? Nope. Jumping and climbing only work in context sensitive areas.Ledge too high to climb and don't feel like walking to find stairs? Too bad! Rope arrows are now 500% more context sensitive!Looking for a gripping story? Go fish.Devs said in an interview ""we want you to play as a thief, but we don't want to force you to play as a thief." Quick reminder in case you forgot the series' title - THIEF. Garrett now has expert assassin/combat skills.Good thing we can see his hands moving, though, don't know how we ever survived without some visual feedback to remind us what we just did.disappointment/10

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												- Cliche, terribly written dialogue. - Boring, cardboard characters.- Awful narrative.- Terrible combat system. - Buggy AI pathing.- Awful mini-map and map system.- inversed y-axis mouse doesn't save (I need to set this every single time I boot up).I presumed I wouldn't be lost in the plot not having previously played the other Thief games, but the plot and the characters were given no history or introduction and the narrative is so spartan I have zero sense of sympathy for the main characters and the vague antagonist. I have felt completely dissociated from the plot since the game began. The cut-scenes often have awkward inexplicable pauses that scream for revision. The actions are mundane. The dialogue is trite and doused in cliches. There's no sense of urgency to continue stealing stuff - I don't even understand what's going on most of the time.Having played nearly ten hours I'm ready to give up. This game feels like a chore to play. Having had no expectations coming into this game, it's hard to be disappointed. I just wish they'd picked up a better script-writer. And...you know...made the game mechanics fun to play or something...Avoid this one
