number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												As a fan of the series I was very worried by the early footage of this game and felt pretty sure they were going to ruin the series.  Fortunately they do seem to have corrected a lot of issues such that I feel I can recommend the game, but it's definitely worth noting there are problems.Short SummaryFor those who want a brief summary, here's the short version first.  The game lacks polish, the level design isn't always up to par, dialogue gets repetitive at times and the story is just annoying and thoroughly awful.  It feels like 30 different people all want to tell their story and you get an incoherent noise where you can pick up some ideas from different stories.  That said, the game is still at its heart a Thief game.  If you want a traditional stealth game you can definitely find it here, especially with the remarkable amount of customisation available, and the actual gameplay itself is sufficient that I would recommend looking past the problems.ReviewSo this Thief game is a series reboot which means that there is no story you're missing if you're new to the series.  There are some nods to older fans but nothing particularly relevant.  There is a central hub city where routes through open up as you advance through the main missions and there is a reasonable amount of exploration and side missions to be found.  The missions, and bigger side quests, all take place in separate levels you access by finding them around the city.The design of the mission areas is hit and miss, with some fairly competent design let down by other areas clearly influenced by the earlier path the game was taking and, frustratingly, late in the game there are boss fights which is never a good thing in a stealth game.  Given they don't break character by forcing an actual altercation it isn't as terrible as it could have been, they all the same feel frustratingly out of place and should at least be a consequence of gameplay rather than something you just have to live with.Another, more significant addition to the game is focus mode.  With this you can look around your world to highlight loot, hidden buttons or things you can use.  It can also be upgraded to provide a lot of additional upgrades in pickpocketing and lock picking, combat and stealth mechanics.  Whilst I welcome the mechanic being available to help people through the game and make it less frustrating, if you're really in to stealth games you're going to find it makes things a bit easy as the game goes on, especially as you can use it when your focus meter is empty whenever you want to get a lingering highlight of the important things in the world. Fortunately it can be disabled, but only when you're selecting starting difficulty settings.Customisation is really the strongest part of the game and really sets a standard I'd like to see in more games.  First the PC port of this game has a great options menu with everything you could really want.  The options continue though in the difficulty of the game, with 3 base difficulties but also custom options you can use to tailor the game to what you want.  A few examples include disabling focus mode, no kills or knockouts, no alerts allowed and many more up to even Iron Man where failing or dying means you have to start from the beginning of the game.  The game continues though, with every single element of the HUD being able to be turned off (including loot glint and lock pick help) or being given a timed fade away for things like health bars.  You really can set this game up how you want it and it's remarkable in that sense.Several other aspects of the game are done very well; the character feels like they're really in the world, with the use of limbs and the way the character interacts with things giving a real sense of there really being a person there.  You can learn quite a bit about the world by eavesdropping, spying on people and some reasonably well written documents and it feels reasonably organic.  The swoop feature (where you quietly dash forward) also feels really good to use and actually adds rather well to some tense stealth sections.The AI in the game is sometimes quite good, noticing things on their patrol route have been opened and being reasonably consistent in its detection of you or otherwise.  Other times though it will bug out, will get stuck on doors, not notice really obvious things, or notice really unobvious things such as you, through a wall, one floor down, in the shadows.  It's usually alright but sometimes feels a bit under-polished, which is a phrase that would describe a lot of the game quite well unfortunately.The world sometimes feels a bit lifeless, people have set paths with very limited dialogue options that repeat annoyingly often - you will sometimes hear 3 or 4 guards in a row repeat the exact same thing.  Some rather useful information is hidden in loading screens, such as pressing X to let go of ropes, which leads to perfectly functioning aspects of the game feeling annoying.  Sometimes your character will drop off ledges; sometimes you need to use the drop button.  Sometimes you can leave vents; sometimes you will need to try repeatedly.  Sometimes you will loot the draw with a context sensitive button; sometimes it'll move away and look around a corner with the same context sensitive button.  These kinds of things give the game the feeling of just not quite being finished.Finally, the biggest problem with the game is the story, it damages the game.  For one thing it starts pretty bad and just gets worse every single time there is some major advancement in it.  It's so focussed on someone it's very difficult to care about that it is annoying to experience, and to make things worse because you're driven by it you're not so much going to places to steal from them, you're stealing from them on the way through.  As a result of this approach you spend a lot more time stealing cutlery than planning a big heist.  The bank heist DLC comes the closest to this ideal and really shows the potential the game really did have when unencumbered by the mess that is the story.I appreciate this review sounds quite negative; indeed there is a lot to be negative about.  It is the weakest game in the series, but with its great customisation options you can still find a Thief game in it.  It is, at its heart, a rather competent stealth game and if you're a fan of the genre you will definitely get something out of it.  You do need to look past its rough edges though.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Now I'll start off with saying I have a bias towards square enix games so I might rate this slightly higher than others, but I do believe this is a decent game. Play as Garrett, the master thief who lifts everything that isn't bolted down, but then unbolts said object and takes it. This game was the first game that ever had me play stealth in first-person which makes it more tense, but also fun. I enjoyed playing through the levels and the stealth mechanics are actually quite great making sure to hide bodies and shut cabinets and cases. I have enjoyed it so far but it of course is not without it's faults. A couple being the hub world is a terrible mess of loading screens and confusing pathways and the bow which seems like an item of paramount importance really doesn't seem to be (while playing I only ever found myself using the water arrows). The story and voice acting is rather plain, but not entirely bad and I would recommend this game only during times of steam sales where I feel the value vs. price is a bit better. 7/10

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												While my feelings are mixed with this game I will hesitantly give it a thumbs up.  There's a lot of bad but the game is worth a look just because it is a new thief game.  don't buy it unless it's on sale and save it for a rainy day.  5/10pros;Current gen thief game.Graphics are shiny.Guards etc very much like normal thief game.Secrets and collectables.Most of the game will support different play styles.cons;Focus system really draws away from the original thief.Dat space tap, same thing.Dat ending and last boss fight... really?Where's my anytime jump for making really loud noises for free?City travel is a real pita, and it all looks the same; it is easy to get lost and hard to remember.DLC: all the thief games came with a bank robbing mission right into the storyline, this one didn't because they knew you'd buy it as a dlc.Birds and Dogs.One path areas, I don’t need a developer holding my hand, or funneling me into a storyline scripted encounter.Unlike previous thief games interface you cannot have both a weapon and a secondary "equipped" at the ready.No skill required one button knockouts.Memory leak, client needs restarting every 3 hours on PC or your game starts chugging.Awkward story, with new/changed lore that tries so hard but just ends up missing the point.Missing our favorite hammer wielding hammerites and Tree Hugging pagan factions.Not the original voice actor from the previous thief games.  Some dialogue is made and added later to the original making some very awkward moments most notably right at the start when talking to his apprentice.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Opening Desk Drawers: The Game, 4/10Stealth is somewhat decent; I enjoyed actually being able to use the shadows to my advantage. But the AI tends to spot you sometimes even when you are completely hidden. Visually the game looks pretty nice. It's a tad bit too dark at times (depending on the environment, of course). Combat system is terrible, which almost forces you to sneak and stay out of sight, regardless of  your playstyle. When in combat, you can only melee and duck. Which not only is boring, but feels clunky. I found myself loading a previous save whenever I was spotted to avoid altercations. The story is very, very forgetable. There were a few times where I had no idea what was actually going on. Maybe it was just boring to me and didn't catch my interest. Voice acting was the worst/funniest I've ever experienced. It's overly exaggerated and forced and the poor writing was not in the actors favor. In conclusion, I only paid 7 dolars for the game, so I can't complain too much. I honestly wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Save your Steam monies.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Thief is a dystopian stealth game where you play as Garrett a Master Thief by his and many other's rights. However, while it may sound good as a tagline (or maybe it doesn't) it's not as good as I thought it'd be. I got an email from Steam telling me that it was on sale for 66% off I believe and I love Steam sales so I paid about $12 for it and it's about as worth that much to me.Maybe a little harsh? You would think the same if you were like me and played it yourself. The main problems I have with the game are how the map is very difficult to follow and I found myself getting lost in the Stonemarket area while trying to complete some extra jobs for clients. I also felt that the UI/HUD was a little poorly done, I'm not quite sure what it was about it I didn't like so I can't offer a better review on that aspect. I looked briefly, before the purchase, at other reviews and saw that it didn't get really good reviews and I should've known better before I decided to buy it, but I wanted to still give it a shot anyways, to try and be more fair and give the makers of the game the benefit of the doubt. But never again.I'd not suggest anyone play this game until the rebooted Thief gets a reboot itself.

												Well before i get into bashing on the game: i loved the whole series, as in up till deadly shadows, i like sneaking games, and i give major props for ignating in me the hype for the Thief series. Now on with the review. The game graphics look good, the feel of the world is there and is satisfying enough. The story has legs and feet up till a point. The constant mini loadings (we dont have loadings in our game hurr durr) or "loading events, tap e" are a bother, I tried to figure out where the game crashed for me, and i think it was at *spoilers ahead* opening the last safe in the game, the vital for the story one (without giving too much away) - it was straight up bugged and i had to look on the web for a solution, and i came back to the game (had a falling off due to the story not delievering the pase) much much later. It's one of those games that you go back into and feel that it was a waste of money. Especially if it's a triple a title.Pros:+ Graphics+ SoundCons:- Story is good but really slow- In my eyes not worth the full price

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												I think, had I not played AC 4 before I played Thief I would have enjoyed Thief a lot more. However, the game felt clunky and constrainted compared to the free running aspect of AC4. I was frequently frustrated by the fact that I could only climb certain places, and several levels felt like you were on rails, sure you had a choice of which set of rails you started on, but once you found the stealth route vs the predator route, there was little variety. I'm not sure why the present the option of Predator vs Ghost Vs Opportunist, I played through several chapters without being spotted and/or knocking someone out, only to be told I was a Predator.The "Focus" points might as well not be in the game, although I suppose they may make it easier if you decided to go the combat route, but the game is called Thief, not Fighter. I will say that the Assylum level was awesome and had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. Overall the game felt like it was building up to something awesome, only to be let down in the end. Its worth a play through, but I wish I hadn't paid full price for it. Wait for it to come down, then pick it up, I guess.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												So I got this game over the Summer Sale with high expectations.... only to be let down. Alright let me get this clear, Thief is NOT a bad game. Yes I do not recommend it but I can't trash on it either. Thief is an alright but there are a lot of things which really prevent it from being a good game. First of all is game feel. I've played a lot of stealth based games in my time so I would like to think that I know what makes a good stealth game. This game right of the bat does not have that feel which it should aim to have. A big problem for me is that the game feels too slow and clunky most of the time. It gives me a hard time believing that I'm a master thief when all of my movements are slow and incoherent. Thieves should be quick and nimble and I feel that Garrett, in this game, is not. I really wanted to give this game a try and I tried to like it but it's mechanics and controls really prevent me from doing so. Secondly the game lags quite a lot for me. My PC is not a high end PC which can run the newest Crysis with max graphics but I can confidently say that it can run a lot of games on their highest settings. Yet for some reason I get a stable 24 fps when I run Thief, even in the lower settings. Maybe it's something on my end but then again maybe it's not. Want a good stealth game? Play Dishonored. Maybe even play some of the older games in the Thief franchise, which I have not played myself but I've heard that they're fantastic. Reading the other reviews here on Steam makes me feel that my arguments are valid given that a few of my complaints were addressed by other consumers as well. However as with any review I can't guarantee that my experience with the game will be the same as yours. If I didn't convince you to not buy the game then go ahead and buy it, you might have a blast playing it. Then again you might not. I tried to compliment the game somewhere in this review but the only thing I could think of were the different types of arrows they had in the game.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Through most of the game I was wishing it was a bit more like Dishonored. Not that I would want something like the "blink" ability from Dishonored in this game but a little more freedom wouldn't go amiss. Too often did I find myself confined to the floor because an otherwise perfectly climbable crate had a wicker basket or some other easily moveable object on it. While Dishonored lets you climb almost anything that's wide enough to stand on in Thief you can rarely climb anything that's not clearly marked for the purpose.Thief is not a power fantasy like Dishonored, and it doesn't need to be, but it would benefit from being less restricted. Too often will you run up to a wall or object that looks perfectly scalable only to find that the jump button does nothing at all meaning that beating the game will be much more a matter of trial and error than planning and executing.That said the game is not terrible but it's not as good as it should have been given it's setting and production values. If you don't already have Dishonored get that instead and wait for the price to drop on this one.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Overall I think it's an okay game. What I liked:-Interesting features (blowing out candles, environment obstacles such as making noise from going through water too fast or stepping on broken glass, finding locks behind picture frames, etc.)-Charts of what type of player you are in the game (ghost, opportunist, predator) and stats (collectables, knockouts, etc.)What I disliked:-Unobservant AI (you could stand directly in front of enemies and they won't see you most of the time)-Linear missions (there was only one path to complete missions and work your way through the levels)I prefer Dishonored over this game as I found Dishonored was more open, had better AI, and was fun to play. I did play Dishonored first and am new to the Thief games.In the end I would not recommend this game.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												Thief Deadly Shadows was one of my favorite games and this was a big let down for bringing the series back. The game is extremely repetative, the voice acting is sub-par and the story hasn't really been that interesting (just finished Chapter 6). It's enjoyable when you first start the game and the graphics are very well done. But when you've snooped through the same drawers and cabinets, heard the same NPC voices complaing about sloop over and over again, and pushed the same plank of wood out of the way in another back ally for the 100th time, the joy fades fast. Pick it up when it's cheap if you can't resist another steath game. I'd highly recommend Dishonored instead if you're looking for something to fill that need now, though.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												NOTE: I've added this whole review to my blog which also includes a few bonus images. Check it here: http://opbroadcast.com/?p=144There are quite a few top negative responses to Thief, so for the benefit of my friends I thought I should drop some of my own thoughts. I'll preface though: If you're someone who's looking for Thief 4, or a true continuation of the decade-old series, you've come to the wrong place. Even so, I still enjoyed my time with Thief and I'd gladly recommend it if you're a fan of first person stealth-action games. Graphics and Style:The promotional screenshots for this game are terrible. Just look above and what do you see? Boring monochromatic vistas set in a pseudo-English, steampunk town. Even the gameplay footage above isn't that great. However, once you're in-game, the atmospheric quality is sold incredibly well. This is a dead city, filled with dust and decay. High contrast shadows draw attention to the light sources to create an incredible noir-like environment, and each location has enough unique architecture to keep you interested in exploring the space. Story:This certainly is the weakest part of Thief. The characters are laughably bad and the voice acting is delivered awkwardly (especially Garret's want-a-be noir quips). Square Enix (mostly from the Edios run studios) has always had a bizarre cast of characters.  (See Hitman's latex nuns, Dues Ex's painfully racist informant, etc.) Accents change on the fly, modern curses are thrown around like a modern rap artist, and the in-game notes are poorly written and unfocused. There are some good points though, in regards to the atmospheric storytelling. Walking through the hub town you'll hear muffled stories through the walls, some simply giving depth to the backstory of the city, while others can potentially provide you with hints on finding hidden loot throughout the world. Gameplay:The meat. The real reason you should be thinking about buying this game. I could talk about all the systems, annoyances and enjoyments, and everything else that made up the 20 or so hours I invested into this game. Many of these things you've probably already heard about elsewhere and have been written on extensively and far better than I could have, so I'll summarize first:Thief was fun.It's clear this is a game from the same studio as Dues Ex Human Revolution. Even though it's a separate team, you can't work in the same room as someone without borrowing a few of their ideas. It's also likely the development was influenced by Dishonored, as the game borrows quite a bit from its systems. (Ironic, as Dishonored was also inspired by the classic thief series.) While Dishonored was more of assassination sandbox where the game gives you a few tools, a loose objective, and tells you to have fun, Thief is directed. There's still some alternate paths and open exploration (especially in the hub city), but most of the primary missions give you a series of spaces to navigate through and it's up to you how stealthy or murderous you decide to be. This is especially prevalent in the side-quest missions, which mostly involve one self-contained zone giving you more power to plan your assault, rob your target, and attempt to make it back out in one piece. Oh, and I'll touch on movement for a moment, seeing as the lack of a "jump" key is a heated contention. When you start, it definitely feels weird not being able to jump up on things. However, the game features a surprisingly robust contextual movement system (it's a good thing they haven't invented fingerprinting yet as Garret touches damn near anything he gets close to), so you get used to the flow of movement rather quickly. There was only a few times I had trouble with jumping and most of them involved me trying to get somewhere I probably shouldn't have been anyways. "Swooping" between shadows and cover is tremendously fun though, and while I wish it didn't come with the lack of a jump key, I hope more games include it as a potential action. In Conclusion:Thief is not a fantastic game, and it certainly doesn't live up to the name it's given. But in the moments, and throughout the 20 or so hours I spent with it, I found fun even when it's issues and strange design choices emerged. I even enjoyed it enough to complete most (if not all) of the game's side-quests and collection opportunities, which is more then what I can say about the last dozen or so games I've picked up. Thief is in no way a terrible game. It could have been better, and perhaps with a future installment it might just be. For now though, it's decent, and I'd recommend it.

If you can get it on a good sale, I say, go for it but I don't think it's woth the full price.

												I've been a huge fan of the Thief series from the beginning, and while this new entry started well, for some reason my attention just wasn't held. The game is gorgeous but controls are extremely touchy with computer inputs, highly recommend a gamepad of some sort. For the current price ($15-30 depending on sales) I'd recommend it, but for full price at release I feel as though I strongly overpaid.  I'll list this as recommended because the game is enjoyable, but not heavily so.  The best I can say is that it wasn't terrible.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Brief version.- Upsides: Awesome atmosphere, good narrative style, nicely written sidemission, somewhat satisfying main plot.- Downsides in a word: Gameplay. It isn't too bad, but it's so clearly flawed that it sometimes ruins the upsides.- Evaluation: 6/10.Longer version:I played Thief's games a long time ago, and this pseudo-reboot/follow-up/whatever-it-is isn't anything close to the originals. Honestly, just the drop from 90+ metacritic score to 70 says something about a very wide gap, and that gap is real (and even bigger than 20 points out of 100).So why the hell do I recommend this game? Because it's still a decent game, and it provides for good entertainment. It is a 6/10 game coming from a 9/10 and 10/10 series, so if you played the previous Thief's titles be warned: you'll be disappointed, mainly by gameplay mechanics. I'll start with the bad to end with the ok.What is wrong about gameplay?- Sounds: you can hear YOUR footsteps even when you stay still and turn around (wtf!) but you can't hear a GUARD's footsteps if he's around a corner more than 2/3 meters away. Bad. Plus, into the houses you just hear very loud random footsteps/conversations from the other floors of the building (which you can't access). This this could be very cool if played right, but it becomes annoying since it's too frequent, and the people in the city seems like a bunch of sleep-walkers.- Random dialogues: while missions and main plot dialogues are satisfying to my taste, you keep overhearing like 6-7 exchanges over and over again while you roam the city, all from the same voices. Are those guys following you? Also, there is a chance that you overhear something useful, pointing you at thieving objectives like sub-sub-plots: cool... except it happened only 2 times in the whole game... meh...- Stealth is often awkward, mainly for two reasons: sight and sound (again). Sight - you are hidden in the shadows or you are not. In the first event, guards may also walk close to you - too close - they then look your way and they... don't detect you. What? Not very realistic, not in a *realistic* stealth game. In the second event they may see you just right and from afar: it's ok, but isn't there any middle-ground? - Sound - surfaces almost do not matter unless it's glass: you crouch if you want to move silently or you stand to move faster, except on carpets where you can move faster and still be silent: that was so cool when pace of movent and sound were so important, in previous Thief's installments, but now they introduced the swoop: if you want to move fast then just stay crouched and *swoop* around. Noise/speed trade-off doesn't exist anymore.- Swoop: sounds cool to me, and it really makes you feel a shadowy thief with great skill, but it's just too much prone to abuse. You want to go around faster? Swoop. You want to reach the back of a guard without alerting him when you WOULD alert him if you walked? Swoop. It's so abusable that it seems like a cheat rather than the cool tool it is supposed to be.- Footprints: they made you leave footprints in a 2002 game (if I remember the year right), now in 2014 you randomly walk into oil, pools of blood and such and do not leave any trail, not even for a few steps. Are you kidding me? That was very disappointing.AI is ok. Despite the many critics to that, I find the AI consistent enough, if you purge its behaviour from the effects of what's above. Only thing is: you are in a house with only 3 guards, you knock out the patrolling one: good. Wouldn't the other two notice he's missing, after a while? If so the game *realism* would have been so improved... but whatever.Let's get to the upsides!- Voice acting: some hardcore fans make themselves disgusted by the voice acting because it's different from how it was before. Why? Get over it, dudes, this one is good and well done.- Story: it's not a story of overwhelmingly epic proportions, but it's very good and entertainig. Moreover it's very well-balanced between thieving, discovering things (you won't understand half of what's happening unless you search for the documents and read them), supernatural activity, crowd madness when they revolt... a good story, well written too.- Atmosphere: awesome and very well designed, could only be better with less random-dialogues (see above) and more dialogues giving some insights on the city life. But grafically it's very good.- Overall feeling: if you are able to get over the downsides, Thief leaves a lasting feeling of... playing a dark gothic, almost satisfying stealth game, and that's why I recommend it.- Interface design: people complains a lot about it, and I wonder why. Focus makes the game like 100 times easier? Map indicators disturbs you and prevent you from feeling the exploration/orientation stuff you want? Frigging DISABLE it. I played with everything disabled and I like it, but there are many players too used to mmorpg (lost without map indicators) and some players who play to have a good time without having to pay too much attention (they are welcome to use focus). Who care? Let people play the game the way they want. Customizable difficulty/helpers are a BIG upside to this game IMO.Last thing worth mentioning, not related to the game but to its development. Many of the flaws above were highlighted during early beta stages by fans screaming in anguish. Why didn't the developers listen to the often good advise? Did they WANT to make a mediocre game? That I cannot understand but it isn't a reason to hate the game, rather to despise the developers' hybris.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												I'd love to say that this game is great. Sadly, it's a spotty stealth-em-up with where the story, mechanics and sound design often feel unfinished. There's fun to be had in here, but not at the current AAA price. The world is poorly-realised, derivative and strangely empty. If you want a good current-gen stealth game, try Dishonored instead.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												I'd love to say that this game is great. Sadly, it's a spotty stealth-em-up with where the story, mechanics and sound design often feel unfinished. There's fun to be had in here, but not at the current AAA price. The world is poorly-realised, derivative and strangely empty. If you want a good current-gen stealth game, try Dishonored instead.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												I recommend this game to all the people that liked the "Assassins Creed" games. Most people say it's like that game but in first person which it is but, they focus more on the stealth aspect. You run around trying to rob as much stuff as you can, stay in the shadows to stay out of sight. Combat in the game is quite difficult till you get the hang of it so do your best to avoid being seen. You can sneak up on unsuspecting guards and take them down silently, you can also perfrom this if the guard is below you. The game may lag a little and takes a while to load up but it's all worth it. You use the gold you get by robbing things to buy equipment such as diffrent types of arrows that assist you in diffrent ways. There is also a power you have called focus, the default keys is "F". It helps you navigate your way through the level but, it does run out you can restore this by using a flower called poppy. So Foucs is almost like "Eagle Vision" from the "Assassins Creed" Games. If you do manage to pick up a copy of this game I hope you enjoy it.

Save yourself the trouble - play one of the originals or try a different game. Not recommended.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												+ Garrett is no longer an insufferable, arrogant twatwaffle as he was in the original series.+ Even though the levels are little more than "point A to point B" navigation, there's at least some variety in how you get from point A to point B. Not as good as Deus Ex, not as bad as Call of Duty.+ Customizable difficulty to recapture the feel of previous Thief games.+ The insane asylum is extremely creepy, continuing the tradition of atmospheric scares from Thief: The Dark Project's Return to the Cathedral and Thief: Deadly Shadows' Robbing the Cradle missions.- Every cultural thing you loved about the original Thief series is gone or lampshaded. There's a single conversation between two guards about the word "taffer", and Chapter 7 has you exploring the ruins of an old cathedral where the symbols bears striking similarity to the Hammerite and Mechanist symbols. That's it.- Rope arrows are more like puzzle mechanics than actual rope arrows from the original series. They cost 600 gold apiece (at Master difficulty), can only be fired at specific hanging posts, and cannot be collected again once fired.- There's no dedicated jump button. The spacebar will allow you to swoop (think: stealth roll in Skyrim), mantle up ledges, and climb ladders and ropes, but there is no jump button. Case in point: One of the final Basso side jobs has you breaking into an aparment. Said apartment has a window out on a ledge that is two feet away from the ledge you are currently on, and would be an easy task to get to IF THE GAME HAD A JUMP BUTTON. Instead, the mission forces you to go around to the side and waste 600 gold on a rope arrow to get in.- Boss battles.- BLOODY SCREEN SO REAL when your health is low.- The windows. There are a few windows that you can open, and when you start the opening animation you are either A) given a quicktime event where you mash E for no apparent reason, or B) don't have to do a quicktime event since it's a level transition. The problem is, the game never tells you which one is which until it's too late, the minimap and map have no level transition markers. And you cant just exit out of the quicktime event, you need to go through the entire motion of the animation.- Placement of the guards means that you are going to have to exploit dumb AI and game mechanics if you want to get a Ghost rating. Similarly, it is virtually impossible to play it Lytha style (no detections, no evidence, no knockouts, you were never there).In short, save your money and just buy Dishonored. It's a much better Thief game than Thief. Alternatively, go buy the original Thief trilogy from GOG.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												It was okay, I had kind of a good time, honestly I really don't know how I feel about it, the stealth was pretty good, gadgets were fun, the speciel powers seemed out of place, but what stealth game wouldn't have see through walls vision now a days, it honestly felt more like I was playing a first person medevil Batman game, but batman was willing to kill people with arrows on top of beating them senseless. You never have to kill, but I didn't really feel a penelty or a point, to killing or not killing respectivly. I paid way too much at launch for as little fun as I had with it, but if you get it on a deal it's not bad. Aparently though for a reboot of the old series it's a travasty, I wouldn't know I never played them, and despite any roots in older popular stealth games, I would likely say it was average for a stealth game, not even on par with Dishonored. Admitedly Dishonored had actual spells, while this has one spell that lets you do stuff better while it's active, basically you have one buff spell that you have to upgrade a crazy amount to have it be more useful than just tapping the button once in awhile to see where guards are. Over all it's bland not a lot of story, it's kind of a neat story mind you, but it seems to have more far reaching implications than this game alone so it kind of never takes off beyond "Garret, save girl to make amends.", like they intended it to have a sequal at some point about another character that was I assume supposed to be cooler than Garret, which if this is the baseline for cool they intended to set then I hope they try to go leaps and bounds beyond Garret if they make a sequal. I can't say I liked it, but I didn't hate it, kind of like Call of Duty games, if you play them they are pretty fun for a while, but they never really feel satisfying to look back on, like it was all some pointless ride. Also it has an open world, and linear missions that take place in a closed world, like Super Mario 64 did, only instead of jumping in paintings you just open a door and a loading screen happens, then you do the one mission and complete all the side objectives in the closed off area and never need to come back to it ever again, unless you want to farm for money which is kind of pointless beyond the few non lethal upgrades you can get, you never need to explicitly kill anybody if you sneak well enough or quick save like a mad man, but even if you are caught you can outrun most guards and move to places they can't fallow, then they forget they saw you after a while, which is SOP so I'm no complaining really. All in all it didn't wow me enough to warnt the sixty dollars I paid for it, maybe for twenty, but personally I would have only paid five if I'd known I'd not have a minimum of as much fun as I did with Dishonored. And just to be clear in case some one reading thinks I have a hard on for Dishonored, I'd like to point out that few games have been first person stealth focused in the past several years, in fact it's bsically just those two, so comparisons were bound to be made, Dishonored was the assassination simulator where killing had concequence, and Theif was the Sticky Fingered Batman simulator where you could kill anyone if you really really wanted to and not have it bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												I was trying to decide if I should recommend or not recommend this game. It's a mixed bag. As you should know this is a reboot of the Thief series. It is by no means as good as the original 3 Thief games. Good, now that that's out of the way we can move on.This game is extremley linear but the City exploring is the most fun you will have out of this game. The missions are okay but they aren't anything special. The story is pretty damn bad as well. One of the reasons the original Thief games are praised for is the story. Just don't go into this game hoping for a good well thought out story.The gameplay is decent most of the time. Now my one of my main concers as a fan of the Thief series is Garrett's voice. If you play the other Thief games you will see what I mean. This game will probably frustrate fans more than it will people who aren't because they took away the interesting lore. Sure there is one level in the game that has one faction of the original games but that's about it.So if you really want to play this, go ahead. If you aren't sure, then don't play it. If any thing you should play Thief The Dark Project, Thief 2 The Metal Age, and Thief Deadly Shadows. So if you want to get into the Thief series, DO NOT play this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												I've only got a few words in my vocabulary to describe Thief, which concists of: underdevelopped, boring, anticlimatic and dull. But I could look past these things as I am (now was) an enthusiast of the thief franchise. But then discovering master thief Garret wearing a corset just flipped the table.This latest installment to the franchise is done on the same formula they used in the previous Thiefs, which is out-dated!The good:- the Asylum mission (I really had to think hard about what I enjoyed about this game.)The bad:-Montonous sword fighting, and there's probably someone going: "yeah, but it is a steatlh game!" and to you I say, If they're               going to put sword fighting in the game, make it exciting, but what we get is a formulated, block, slash, block slash deal.-Dull characters, at the end of it, you really don't care about anyone.-Loading times between levels and a really unhelpful map.-Everything else.Conclusion:This game sucks. Do not buy it even if it goes for $0.99, because you wouldn't be able to get back the time you play/wait this game.

												The game itself is alright, the chapters are really good, but the city which you must traverse between the chapters are horrible.Alot of loadingscreens and a "tumble or jump"-button that rarely jumps when you want it to, makes this game a not so smooth playthrough. The story is nice and I enjoyed it quite much from time to time(while playing chapters). I think it was worth the 10euro I payed for it, but I would never recommend it on fullprice.I would also not set it that high on the "to do"-list,  there are alot better games out there.Overall: A worthy buy on sale if you are out of things to play, just don't expect it to be of Tomb Raider quality.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												A middling stealth game. Graphics and scenaries are wonderfull, but need a powerfull hardware to run fine. The sound is horrible, establish distances and directions is impossible. The Mechanics and backgrounds are copies of other titles, specially Dishonored. Maps are really big, with a lot of dark places and with good transitions to one another, but main ones are lineal. Many obstacles are stupid: can not jump over a box or barrel with a little sack or basket over it. Special items are unimaginative and few, collectables are simply useless. Player can carry just one object for distract foes, but other means neither works well. Fighting is dispensable because movements are slow and clumsy, knock out by surprise is noisy even against a asleep target, only can make from backwards and carry the body is more slowly and striking yet. Bow deselects itself without warning. Lighting effects are good, but torchs require an arrow to turn them off, lamps are untouchables, and visual capacities of foes vary a lot; the ones of animals are exagerated. Only the times of freedom to prowl in obscure places are memorable.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												This game is BAD, BAD, BAD.1-Awful interface- clunky. There are multiple keys for sneaking... yet no keys to jump?2-Level design is ultra-linear; even the HUB is linear! No fast travel and it gets really boring. 3- Bad design ideas make exploration a chore. 'Rewards' rarely worth the cost of the materials you had to use to get there. "Hidden traps" are just a gimmick requiring you to repeatedly turn on Assassin's creed style "Eagle Vision" ripoff, and simply walking around them. Boring.4- Stealth mechanics horribly simplistic, overly-easy, unrealistic and unfun. Guess what happens when you walk past the guards and your shadow passes over them? Nothing. The Devs forgot to program it in.5- Gimmicky 'player punishing' gameplay (not challenging- just makes you wait and wastes time)Sometimes you follow the map, break into a house (takes ages- and then a loading screen)- to realize my entrance was surrounded by traps and I was then expected to backtrack out of the window (another loading screen) and take a back entrance (another loading screen) to just walk in.Uninstalled it. Regretted my purchase. Tried to get a refund but was refused DO NOT BUY. If you like this kind of game- buy "Dishonoured", or Assassin's Creed (either Black Flag or Rogue). They're actually fun and well designed. Avoid this game at all costs!

												Graphics issues, antialiasing are limited to poorly implimented FXAA and processing intensive SSAA, no MSAA option, low framerates. It could solve some of these issues by not being an open world game, as the stories are in fact linear.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												The struggle to enjoy this game. As a long time Thief fan this just does not feel like Theif at all and even as a stealth game its not really that good either. From the boring level design to the audio engine which pales in comparison to Thief: Deadly Shadows, and the inconsistant A.I. its just a shame to see one of my favourite franchises hit this kind of low. The story is like something out of a childs book and isnt very interesting and it doesnt do a good job of making you feel as if you are somewhere you are not meant to be unlike earlier Thief games, in this you just feel like an everyday petty thief. Though I have only played 4 hours of it so far I just cant bring myself to play in long stretches unlike the previous games were they had me glued to my screen. As of now its a no but if it gets any better the further it goes in then I will change my review.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												You'll get bored after a while of playing this game. There's not really any excitement through out the game, nor a good story in my opinion. Square Enix succeded to fulfill the genre "Stealth", but by the title "Thief"..not as much. As I said, there aren't much excitement, and when you (for example) pickpocket a guard or perhaps steal an item from someone else you won't feel ANYTHING (which you usually do when you steal something because you know it's illegal). Square Enix somehow made stealing boring/ dull which was a huge mistake, because stealing is pretty much what a thief does. (Did, almost, immediately regret paying 59.99 Euros the same day I bought it).This could very well have been a great game, but still...I admire the graphics and partially the parkour & animations ;) *4.6/10*

												Wow, I really wanted to like this game, but it is a bad mess. number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												This game, sigh. Where to start?Let's start with the good. The graphics are really good and atmospheric and, well...That's about all that's good with this game. The rest is average or terrible.The gameplay leaves tons to be desired and I'm not saying that in comparison to the old games but just as a game, it's not very good. I have played all the previous thief games and this one is definetily the worst but if I have to compare, I'd say that it's the most like thief 3 (deadly shadows). I say that because the whole game has a hub world so to say and from there you travel around to different levels in the game, just like thief 3. The greatest problem for me with this game is that I don't have the feeling of control that I'm used to. You can't jump and alot of times you feel locked to the enviroment as if you were on rails. Especially in many parts in "the city" which is the hub world. The other problems with the gameplay are numerous.Questionable level desgins, meaningless and lame side quests, lack of freedom with tools but let's talk about the other possible selling point of the game: the story.It's bad, with no likeable characters (especially Erin). Erin gets lost early in the game before we get to know her at all. The only thoughts you get before she dissapears is that she's a whining and annoying ♥♥♥♥♥. After that, the game expects you to care for the character since the whole game is basicelly about saving her. So from the start, I disliked the story but it gets worse. The game doesn't know what it wants to be. Supposedly it's a reeboot but many elements are left such as Garrets robot eye and the character Basso yet nothing else in the story connects. It makes up a bunch of questions and plot elements are presented that are never anwsered. A mayor plot point is revelead in one point and then no one ever mentions it again. The story is a joke, a complete mess.So what is there left if the gameplay is average at best and the story blows? The anwser is, there is none.The game is simply not worth buying and playing. The only time I could recommend this is if you catch it on the cheap in a sale but otherwise, stay away.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												After Dishonored (if you like the stealth genre but havent played Dishonored yet grab that one, as its one of the best game of the generation) I was really excited for Thief, the next stealth game set in a dark desperate steampunk like environment, but I was very wrong with my high ecpectations. The only thing this game excells in is the very nice graphic, all other thins are bad to medicore. So here is my breakdown:(+)Very nice looking graphics(+) good stealth engine with a nice but somewhat narrow selection of gadgets (mainly different arrow types)(-) Very limited freedom which imo is a natural expectation against a stealth game, maps are almoast entirelly linear.(-)Very very bad mimimap of the city hub which absolutelly does not aid you in getting where you want, its frustrating searching the right path to the actual quest location(-)Very very bad secondary quest design where actually the main difficulty is to get to the quest site and not the sloving of the (mainly very trivial side quests) this is largely due to the useles minimap(-)The selection of sounds and banter and chats of NPS is substandard(-)No real background story of main character and the city(-)Story is somewhat weak..(-)The gameplay revolves around thieving thins which gets dull after a while because mainly you steal pottery, forks, scissors,  small liqour flasks and the like useless junk...Althogether a quite frustrating game..J.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												I personally regret buying this game.  I was truly expecting so much more and I was left disappointed.  I watched some videos of game play and foolishly decided too quickly that this game was something incredible.  That was my mistake, and I'm simply writing a review to hopefully prevent someone else from making the same mistake.The storyline had promise, but it was very poorly put together and very difficult to follow.  This continues until the very end of the game and you're left feeling as though nothing was resolved.  By the end of the game the only thing accomplished is stopping Orion from turning everyone into monsters and saving Erin. ‘Nothing’ in the city changes. Gloom is still running rampant, people are still dying, the city is still corrupt and now it has no leaders...The side missions are a catastrophe.  They are bland and unrewarding.  You simply enter the location steal an object and your mission is complete.  There is never anyone inside the house to challenge your sneaking skills or anything at all.  You don't even have to deliver the object after you've stolen it.    You simply get a tiny description on the mission and that's it. The full map and mini map are extremely lacking with barely any detail put into them whatsoever.  Certain areas of the city are mission locked and the areas that you can explore never change. It's a very boring and bland place to explore.  All of the accessible ‘houses’ are rundown and every room looks practically the same. Really, you don’t get to explore houses as 90% of the house is always off limits and no one is ever inside either.  I also hate how you can't fast travel.  That is extremely annoying, especially when everything about the 'free roaming area' of the city is repetitive.The population of the city consists of possibly at most four generic AI faces.  There are never any events in the city other than the occasional hanging which consists of a crowd between three and four people.  The city doesn’t feel real at all.  Gossip between AI’s never change either even if you’ve stolen the loot they’re discussing they just keep looping forever.  They even follow the same path after the events of chapter six when their city is on fire burning around them! They don’t react AT ALL.There are so many features that could have been implemented into this game that would make it incredible.  But, aside from stunning visuals of the game it really has nothing else to offer.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												I haven't had the chance to play the older Thief games just yet, but I was greatly impressed by this reboot's mechanics, graphics, etc. I was once so immersed in the game during a chapter centering around the Asylum that my cat jumped on me and I screamed. :D As far as games go, I think people generally downvote this one because they've played the older games and are unimpressed by the newest addition to the series, even if it's a reboot - for someone coming into the series belatedly and playing this one first, the story was very interesting and the attention to detail for stealth missions and the chase scene over rooftops kind of threw in a little extra thrill for me. Overall, I thought it was great, but other people might not. Still happy with my purchase.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												I own every game of the Thief-series, I loved the first 3 and would put Thief 1 and 2 in my all time favorites list. But Thief 4 was such a horrible dissapointment that I felt the need to write a review for the first time, and warn others. If you have any love for the old Thief games I suggest you avoid this like the plague. The game felt as if they had removed everything that I liked about the series with surgical precision. The game reminded me of Call of Duty way too often in it's casual, linear and clichéd way. Dishonored and Amnesia: dark descent gave me more "nostalgic thief feeling" than this game did. I miss the freedom to explore, I miss the little details that made the game-world come alive for me in the old games, I don't like the cutscenes and I don't like the way Garret's character changed (or should I say "was removed", because what's left of him is so generic and lame that the old and the new Garret have little more in common than their name). I even preferred the sounddesign and ambiance in the old games. It just felt more real and the musical action cues in Thief 4 seem so out of place. When I take down an enemy with the blackjack I don't need to hear the music freak out every... single... time.... It breaks immersion more than it helps in my opinion.I have been playing the old Thief 1 when I got too frustrated with the newest installment of the series and I have to say I just have more fun with it. The gameplay is way better and more rewarding in my opinion. All the added mechanics in Thief 4 just make it feel more artificial and contrived to me. Never did I have the feeling of being in a world that I could explore or that any of my decisions mattered. Also Thief 1 on the easiest setting is in my opinion for the most part harder than Thief 4 on hardest setting. One bossfight in Thief 4 was incredibly unfair and hard though, to the point where it felt like a bad joke. I don't judge Thief 1 and 2 just from nostalgic memory, I still play such games to this day. I just picked up where I left my second playthrough of Thief 1 and I played Thief 2 again just a few years ago. I give the game credit though for coming up with what I think might be the most cliché and cheezy bad guy character that I have ever seen. From the name, to his appearance and dialogue this is pure B-Movie trash and I said out loud "are you kidding me?" multiple times throughout the game. If you have not played Dishonored yet you should buy that. It really is better in every conceivable way! If you liked the old Thief games, chances are you will hate this one as much as I do. I don't know whom I could recommend this to. I wouldn't even play it only for the stories sake, because it's just as bad as everything else.Unlike other old franchises like Tomb Raider and Deus Ex that recently got very decent new titles added to their legacy, this one should have better stayed in the shadows...TL;DRwow, such b*llsh*t, very disappoint!P.S.: It says I played for ~17 hours, that's thankfully not the case. The game was more like 12-13 hours including retries, the other time I had alt-tabbed and it kept tracking.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Go buy Thief 2. Or, if you want graphics, Thief 3. Thief 4 is basically a copy of Thief 3, only narrower and scripted;Below I'll show an example of what I mean, but besides that:Buggy game -- guard can suddenly spin around;Constantly repeated dialogue - and only ONE - which is annoying as hell;HORRIBLE sound balance, use headphones because even simple 2.0 sound system will be furiously unbalanced;Character development down the drain; I'm not comparing this game with old Thief  games right now, even by its own merit this is Dishonored meets Batman but with less style and scope;Stealing does not feel satisfying _at all_ _WHATSOEVER_. Constant points of no return within small levels and constant loading screens; THe game couldn't be more restrictive on how you do things.And now for the level design comparing:SPOILERS (!!!!!)For instance, in the asylum level in Thief 3 suspens was rising. First there was noone there but eerie atmosphere and possibility of guards caused you to sneak; Then, sudden ghost of a girl creeped you out, but she was friendly. And then step by step asylum became a horror-fest in the end denying you the way out itself; It was HORRIFYING.Now Asylum in Thief 4: Scripted crows fly out. Door opens by itself and then slams shut. A jump scare from a woman who's supposed to be dead; She tells you you sholdn't be here when she pointed towards this place earlier;SUBTLETY.In conclusion: go buy thief 3; or wait until this game is -75%or just pirate it! it is a Thief game after all ;)

How it couldn't run on a computer that was above the required graphics card level so all of the textures and graphic and resolution were turned to♥♥♥♥♥♥mode. There were also many other things that i found strange for a game that i paid about $60 for as in some of the cut scenes at the end had no sound and the judgment at the end of missions was always wrong especially at the end, only one 'thing' died and it was a creature who died by a fire that was pre lit. The first boss encounter was nearly impossible to sneak by but i defeated him by using a stupid method that suprisingly worked, by knocking him out with the gas arrows then pelting him with the explosive ones (He could take more of them than i could, and he took them to the face while i took the flames from it hitting me from the side and even then two of those would kill me). Some of the mechanics were good like the stealth mostly and the looting but if i tried to cancel going through a window i couldn't, i had to finnish going through the window and then go back through. So basicly tell me when the patches actually work and the developers actually do something and then i will consider re-installing the game again.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												This game would have been a solid 6.5/10 had it come out under it's own label. As a completely independant game with the freedom to create new ideas it may have even been a good game. However you cannot escape the inalienable fact that this is a sequel to Thief: The Dark Project and the subsequent games, therefore it should be a continuation of the story in the same narrative universe. This game fails to make use of the source material in any meaningful way. It is almost like the development team were given just the name Thief as the title, Garret as the protagonist and Basso as the fence and told to make a game about stealing stuff in early industrial revolution generic grey steampunk city. Maybe they didn't get usage rights for anything else, because thats what it feels like. Garrets character is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ised from the word go. Gone is the aloof, cynical, selfish, anti-hero that only acts on other people behalf when it suits him, when there is no other option, or for revenge. Instead we are given a flat boring character that essentially denounces all of Garrets traits that the first game made us painstakingly aware of. All within the tutorial. What ever happened to 'I only work alone'. Adding to that the Keepers taught Garret to be invisible in a crowd in order to document history, but not interfere. Garret corrupted the teachings by using them  to be a stealthy thief. But in this game everyone seems to know who you are, even the 'Thief-Take General' (*rolls eyes). If the original Garret was in this situation, he would have just left. Why take unessisary risks.The original games were setup as an unrestricted world puzzle where you felt that your own ingenuity, quick(slow) action and sensory feedback  allowed you to complete missions with a smug sense of statisfaction. This game is an pre-determined obstacle course for the player, complete with '90's sidescroller loot-that is impossible to get untill you know how-and has no earthly reason for being there'. There are points in the game where you try and not follow the pre-determined path because it is too risky, only to find it is the only way. Usually leading to a forced action cut scene where.... YOU GET CAUGHT.... In a game called... Thief. This doesn't just happen once, but all the time, followed by hell being raised as you try to scramble and escape along a new pre-determined path. I know that game designers need to up the ante, but this is just cliche at this point.All in all this game would have been great as a prequel. Garret having freshly left the Keepers in order to persue a life of burglary of the wealthy and undeserving for his own gain. Working with people he initially trusts, who then betray him or die on the job. Hell... they could have even kept the main story elements intact. Maybe then we could have seen where Garrets dark personality came from in the first game and why he is behaving like such a noob in this one. But unfortunatly the games story line is irrevocably terrible.Ultimatly game play and graphics are slightly above average. The inability to even try pay lip service to the original brings it down to a 4/10. Don't bother. Go play the originals. If you can't stand bad graphics get the story arc of Youtube.What is with the obsession with The Claw!! Seriously I had Jim Carrey in my head every time they said it.Edit: A note for Steven Gallagher. Head Narrative Director. Garret is not against killing 'without thought or good reason', he's not a conscientious assasin. Garret's rationale is that killing is messy, noisy and gets you caught. Again, would have been fine under it's own brand. The game probably would not have tanked.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Забагованная до ужаса: рассинхрон речи с анимацией, постоянные фризы. Графика на вышке то очень не очень, боюсь представить что там на минималке, лица и мимка не многим лучше Thief: Deadly Shadows (2004). Даже пререндер и тот страшненький.Сюжет скучен, высосан из пальца. Персонажи не запоминаются, нет у них ни характера, ни личности, ни мотивации.Геймплей прикольный первую первую пару часов. Уровни - пара параллельных коридоров и ответвление с бомжом-торговцем. Учитывая, что у Гаррета есть gps, а стражей обдурить проще простого (а можно просто у них за спиной пройти в тесном коридоре), прохождение - изи-бризи. Ghost стелс местами слишком замороченный, а Opportunist всегда слишком простой. В 3 их 8 уровнях мне не получилось получить Ghost исключительно из-за забагованный стражей, которые стояли на месте и теребели свой меч/арбалет, а не патрулировали местность, как им и положено.Ассортимент оружия такой не нужен вообще, из него используется веревочная, водная, да тупая стрела. Апгрейды вообще бессмысленные. К середине игры забиваешь на исследование уровней и собирание лута, т.к. тратить награбленное не на что.Короче, первые полтора часа думаешь "о, круто". Потом все эти одинковые сценки с окнами и баррикадами приедаются (особенно, учитывая, что они тормозят), все ловушки и головоломки решаются с помощью глаза. И оказывается, что это все, что есть в игре, больше ничего не будет, тебе еще 8 часов делать все то же самое, один в один.Ну и да, улицы пустые, на повешенье приходит 2 человека.

												This is a disgrace to be called Thief. Maybe I had too high expectations because of the great universe of the old Thief games. Where are the Pagans, Mages, the Machinists, Hammerites? If this a reboot, why is Garrett's eye glass/metal?Bad PC port, bad optimalisation, staggering gameplay, constant loading screens (not so nextgen, isn't it?) It's 5.1 surround, but the sound system is completly f**d up: one step forward and can hear a conversations at full volume, one step backwards and cannot hear a thing. This is also an issue with footsteps, so it's pretty hard to be a master thief. Also, play it on master difficulty, if you want anything that is one bit close to the old (and good) gameplay.All in all: Dishonored is a better Thief game then this...

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												So, I just finished Thief, in about 39 hours, or so Steam claims. So anyway, I wanna throw out my thoughts on the game.First of all, I am a fan of the old thief games. They were the first stealth games I'd ever played and it was just great going around stealing things and not killing anyone for a change. I will be making comparisons with the old games, but keep in mind my memory might be hazy and blinded by nostalgia.Overall, I was neither deeply impressed nor disappointed in this reboot. It was alirght.The Writing: The overall story just wasn't very interesting to me. It has some plot twists, but they seem borrowed from Thief: The Dark Project in some way. I think the original Thief series had much better writing, from Garret's backstory, to the setting - the three factions Garret has to deal with, manipulating the fate of the world in various ways and Garret always getting into trouble with them, getting mixed up in some crazy plot. The whole steampunk technology versus supernatural elements the original series has going is just really awesome.While both the original series and the reboot's stories might be simplified to "A loner's journey through a society where powerful factions struggle for power", the new Thief just wasn't that interesting to me as the older games. I guess it's a matter of details.That's not to say that there weren't some cool aspects to the writing/story. I did enjoy the mysterious gloomy atmosphere. There are also some spooky elements which I enjoyed. I did enjoy Garret himself as a character too.The Gameplay:I found the new lockpicking mechanic enjoyable. There's plenty of exploration and loot to find, lots of documents to read too which is really cool if you enjoy hunting around for backstory (in fact, some of the details you find in writing are a lot cooler than the main story itself). The sneaking is also solid. The guards react properly to distractions, not just going towards where you threw something but also searching around and even coming after you if they saw where the projectile came from. They alert other guards too if they are too startled and then it gets really tough to escape if you're anywhere near them. They also relight fires if they see them go out, so you can't just water arrow everything and have an easy time sneakingi around.However, there are some unwelcomed changes and additions...First of all, the rope arrow - where before you could fire it into wooden surfaces, now you can only use it on predetermined spots. One might think that in both cases you're still only using the rope arrow where the developer intended. However, there's just no denning that the old rope arrow mechanics offered more freedom. Thus you feelt like the path you made through levels was your own, you could feel proud of your solutions. Now, instead of crafting your path through the level, it feels more like you're just oppening different kind of doors all the time. You want to get into a room and you start looking at your options: I can picklock the door, or disable some trapping mechanism so I can get through the window, or use the wrench to open the basement grating, or if I have a rope arrow I can unlock the path through the second story window. I'm not saying that navigating the levels isn't fun, but it just feels like these are all toggle switches. You do this to open your path. Yay. How exciting. After a while it just becomes routine.Then there's a couple of silly action sequences. I don't want to run around on rooftops being chased by what have you. I want to sneak around all the time and never get spotted. That's why I'm playing a Thief game and not Mirror's Edge. (Although even I have to admit, there is one action sequence which looked cool the first time I saw it - but that's about it. It still felt out of place in a Thief game.)There are some stupid QTE mechanics too, though thankfuly not many. When oppening windows for some reason you have to mash the Use key. And when passing through narrow corridors you also have to mash the Use key. Why? What's the point of this? It doesn't make the game any more exciting, it doesn't add any level of challenge, it's just annoying. Even more annoying, there are sections where Window opening and Narrow corridor crawling are used to load new areas, and in these sections you don't have to mash the Use key - why couldn't they let you not mash the Use key in all the other times?!...While there are plenty of annoying things about the gameplay, luckily exploring around for loot, picking locks and avoding guards was entertaining enough for me.Other stuff:While I didn't play much of the challenge modes yet, I must say I do enjoy them a lot. In fact, they might be more enjoyable than the rest of the game.Also, the custom difficulty options are really cool. It's really cool that they let you customize your experience like that. I played on a custom Master dificulty with penalties for killing or alerting anyone, and also with focus abilities disabled because I wanted to play a thief not some magic eyes wizzard.Annoying Bugs I encountered:The sound sometimes buggered out, people ending up saying the same linie twice at the same time. (Edit: I mean, an NPC would literally say the same thing "with two voices" with a 1-2 second delay in between the two.)Quicksaving seemed to bug out guard patrol routes sometimes.In addition, the game sometimes started dropping frames like crazy, going down from my average of 40-60 fps to what felt like under 10 - just stuttering all the time until I restarted it. This seemed to happen in the hub world after loading too many new areas or something.Conclusions:So yea, overall I don't think it's anywhere near as good a game as the original thief games were in their time. Although, as I said, nostalgia might be clouding my memories. All things considered, while I did focus here more on the negative aspects of the game, it was still a solid experience for me - it wasn't as great as I hoped it would be, but not as disappointing as I feared it might be either.If you haven't played a Thief game before but enjoy stealth, you might enjoy it. If you played the old Thief games, well, you might not think as much of it as a newcomer, but if you keep an open mind you might still find it enjoyable like I did.So I guess I would recommend it, preferably at a discount. Unless the full price isn't that big of a deal for you.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Oh boy its remake time again. Remakes are always a dangerous thing I guess. Very often a remake is trying to be something completly new and so it is too far away from the original. On the other hand, if a remake does nothing new it does raise the question why you should make a remake if you did change nothing?This review is probably not very positive and some people will probably say something like: Hey you just had wrong expectations!While I will say something about the whole expectations thing later, let us just look at the plain facts.Let us start with the most obvious thing, how does thief look? Well it does look pretty well if you ask me. Well of course it is not the most colorful game, but hey it is a about sneaking in a dark city with steampunk elements. Thief is actually pretty good at this task. The city does look nice and so I can clearly say that thief is a good looking game.However trouble is easy to find, or in that case easy to hear. The sound of the game is pretty much underwhelming in all aspects. While the voice actors are okay (not great and not terrible) I do miss the old voice actor of garret. However there is more trouble ahead. The entire soundscape is underwhelming and is often schockingly silent. The attempt at a dynamic music system ranges between annoying and broken and I have to say it has been a long time since I actually actively hated the ingame music of a game.Well sound and graphics are obviously not everything so what about the gameplay and the story? Sadly those two departments show the biggest flaws. Gameplay is pretty linear and often not very interesting, of course there are some alternative routes here or there but they are neither elegant or interesting. While you can roam around the city and do some sidemissions you always feel how limited your routes and by that your options are. It does not help that the enemy AI is pretty stupid and that the guards are awful at their job. So gameplay wise the game is pretty linear and not really challenging. Of course you can raise the difficult in the settings and customize a lot of things, but that does no really make the gameplay itself more interesting and fun.The story of Thief is also sadly pretty boring and dull. Beside that it is full of logic holes. I dont expect a story to make 100% sense and of course there are things in a story that happen because the story must go somewhere. However a a story most have its own logic and if things stop making sense inside that logic, then you have problems getting engaged in a fictional story. So much about a look about what I would call the facts. Thief is not a terrible game, I think games with a big budget can hardly be completly terrible, but just having a big budget mean you produce a ace game. Thief is far from being a ace game. I spoke about expectations earlier and this game wants to be a thief game. The problem is that in nearly no aspect it is one. It may sound a bit extreme but this game could have been released under a completly different title and some people would only call it a part time rip off of the original thief.Can I recommend this game? Well not really. This game claim to be something that is is not and beside that it is only a average game.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
Mediocre game with a nostalgic titleFirstly, I'd like to say that I am no hardcore fan of the series, although I truly enjoyed Thief 3, despite its flaws. This iteration in the series is much more polished in terms of visuals (textures, models, especially animations), but far inferior story- and gameplay-wise and has a few bugs - not game-breaking, but still noticeable (I'll elaborate below). The game itself is really linear (apart from the mission hub), which stands in striking contrast to the previous games. The main character isn't memorable. Non-guard NPCs are basically placeholders - after they say their lines they walk around in silence, acknowledging Garrett's presence just by looking at him (take his appearance into account). If you block their path they simply try to walk through you with obviously poor results. To enter most interiors or to get through to another area, you have to mash the 'use' button repeatedly, to let the game load the data I suppose. Why, though? The repeated animation is useless and annoying. To me, this would be of no importance, if the core gameplay met the expectations. I played on Master difficulty (hardest) with additional crutches to enjoy the game better, but the guards were still broken. The key part of a stealth game is broken. That's unacceptable. Let me develop this topic:Guards' flaws:1. Most game-breaking bug: they stop following their normal patrol routes. I simply don't know how, but I've read that saving/loading may cause this. If the guard has a pause on his patrol route, he may somehow refuse to resume his patrol. I've noticed that many times, sometimes it helped me, but mostly it annoyed me, cause I tried to play ghost and be unnoticed at all times, even avoiding taking them down with the blackjack. That would be possible if they had their scripts/AI written well. Sometimes saving/loading again fixed this issue, but not always. This should not happen in such a big-budget game.2. Blind as hell until they acknowledge you, then they are perfect at seeing you from thrice the distance, from which you'd be unnoticed had they been not alarmed, even if looking straight at you.3. 5-second memory - if you get caught, they will go after you, but once you disappear from their sight for a couple seconds, they stand in one place, looking around or go back to their patrol routes, being mildly alarmed. After some time, they simply forget any threat was around there. Hiding in a one-entrance room was never that easy.4. Fighting - I know it's a stealth game, but bear with me - if you get into a fight with a single guard armed with a sword (not a crossbow), it's stupidly easy to avoid every hit he aims at you. The time-window to press the dodge key is so big that anyone is able to avoid each and every attack with just a single click of a button. After each attack the guard recovers his strength for a second or two and attacks again. It's so pointless. In a stealth game it should be very hard to survive a fight.5. Sleeping guards are a joke - they wake up from a bad step in glass or a failed lockpicking try (sure, I suppose Garrett makes such noise when he misses a pin), but ignore a fight two metres away, even with the other guard shouting. What?!6. Some guards are looking at loot to steal on their patrol routes, yet refuse to acknowledge the fact that at some point in time it has been stolen and they are looking at an empty counter. Come on, really?Given that the game is meant to be a reboot, a fresh start of the series, a step in the right direction, a demo of what's to come, I am afraid that's the last Thief for me. Pretty graphics on the outside, but the insides are far below expectations of a modern stealth game. Fools' gold. And this game came out AFTER Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Dishonored...
