content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Very disappointing "reboot".   The game is very banal and dull, and doesn't even have a tiny bit of the atmosphere and immersion that made the originals so wonderful.What's good:- Fantastic visuals and animations.- Barely okay gameplayWhat's bad:-- All the supernatural elements have been completely gutted from the universe, leaving it as bland and dull as any other generic medieval type atmosphere.- Can't jump where you want.  Only can jump at specific handholding points- Too much "gameplay cutscenes"   For example when you knock out a guard, you are locked into a 5 second first person cutcsene of him gently lowering the guard to the ground while his allies pound into you.   I understand this type of silliness is a child of the consolitis mindset and it makes sense that this game was made for consoles. - Idiotic story that made no sense at all in any way.  The story fails you pull you in, interest you, or even give you any sort of compulsion to follow it.   Compared to the horrific compelling work of art that was in the original two games this is complete garbage.  I even read wikis on what it was all about and I'm still scratching my head going "Huh? This is stupid."   I uninstaleld the game after the second last plot mission.  The story was so dull I couldn't be bothered playing through the finale, I just watched the ending on youtube and it was as stupid and illogical as I knew it would turn out to be.- Too much "drawer simulator" going on.  Rather than having all the loot sitting around the real world, much of it is inside drawers that you have to open and close [again those lovely minicutscenes that once you start you're stuck til it's over]- AI is worthless. It's either godlike oversensitive, or completely and totally unaware of your obvious presence. No Balance.Didn't feel like Thief.  Isn't Thief.   Felt like the whole game was phoned in and thrown together.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Thief is what I'd call a good game that was squandered by bad decisions. I, personally, found myself enjoying most of the game, but even then, I could see where it went right and where it went wrong. The relative non-linearity of the levels that encourages exploration: Good. The immersiveness of your character with simple things such as hands and feet, putting you into the shoes of Garrett: Good (great, for an immersion nut like myself). The phenominal graphics that breath life to what you would assume is a horribly dark and dank and dirty place with nothing else to offer: Good. But then you have the "bad" side of things. You have the port issues, with stuttery FPS in the hub areas. You have the inability to jump (for whatever reason), resulting in awkward moments, falls, and deaths that could rival those found in Assassin's Creed. You have the simplification of mechanics, a prime example of which being the rope arrow. What was once a creative way to both open up a level is now little more than a scripted event, or something that might as well be. And here's my biggest gripe: the fact that the player's actions can directly go against Garrett as a character. And in the most ridiculous sense, too. Early on in the game (and I suppose this is a spoiler, so...) Garrett and Erin — his trusty sidekick — have themselves a little game of "I bet I can steal more!" and shortly after they meet up again, Erin scoffs at his take. Garrett, the Master Thief himself, then replies "It's not about how much you steal, but what you steal" and she adds, "and how you steal it." And that's perfectly fine; a thrillseeker thief archetype who steals things of worth? That's kinda neat! "But hold on a second, I was just stealing forks and knives to sell for a pitiful one gold coin..." Yeah, kinda absurd, if you ask me. It's like Niko in GTA4 mourning about how he had to kill in the war, then gunning everyone down between missions. Garrett boasts about how it doesn't matter if you go around scrounging up tiny mathoms no one wants, then goes around doing exactly that. This is a problem not only because it goes against the narrative, but it devalues Garrett as a character. He's no longer the professional stealing to survive like he was in the old games, nor is he a thief stealing to both survive and because he has some thrill for the rush of it all. He's just a kleptomaniac, out to rob all of "The City" of their common household utensils. What an♥♥♥♥♥ right? Easy fix to this would be to just make it so that you can rob people of their knives, forks, and spoons. There are plenty of actual trinkets, medals, busts, and collectables to pick up — stash a few more of those into the wardrobes, drawers, and cupboards, and we've got a nice and easy compromise... Unless Eidos was trying to make their "Master Thief" a kleptomaniac. :|Anyway, I'm bad at ending essays and anything utilizing one or more paragraphs, so... tl;dr Thief was a fun time, though it's hindered by quite a few issues that, while relatively small, are very apparent in the game and level design. The biggest of which (in my opinion) being a problem in the narrative... Which most might not even give a damn about. I still recommend it, though. I like the new voice actor better than the old one (don't kill me, pls), the graphics are stellar, the immersion is stellar, and if you can look through some of its issues and past the fog of nostalgia, it's not a bad game at all.In terms of a score (for ease of use), we could say it's an 8/10 who slipped, fell, and landed on the 6.5/10 step.I'm eager to see what they do with the second game, when they inevitably release a second one.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												The newest Thief game can be compared to a reboot/remake of a beloved Hollywood franchise. It's nowhere near as good as the originals, but it's not terrible, and it's updated.I've played Thief for roughly 7 hours, the city sucks to travel through and the map is completely horrible and there is never a clear direction. Thief shines when you're in a mission through a building or house, and stealing things under someones nose is really rewarding. Outsmarting guards never gets old either. So if you're a fan of stealth games, than Thief is a no brainer. But if you're fairly new to the genre, play Dishonored as it is a much more polished, fun, rewarding and realized experience. In my opinion Dishonored did Thief better than the new Thief did.I hope there is some kind of fast travel option implemented into Thief, because if I have to traverse through that map every time I need to get somewhere far away I'm simply going to stop playing, it's that bad.

number of helpful: 23 of 43 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Eidos Montreal had all the experience they needed for developing Thief through the making of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Although the new Thief was a bit harder to create since the last game of the series was released in 2004 and they had to keep the new game's atmosphere as close to the older ones as possible.Starting with the story it's not what you will remember after you have finished Thief. You will be expecting most of the plot twists and towards the end the story seems a bit far fetched. The City is divided in different areas or districts. The problem is that those districts are divided into smaller areas as well so there are frequent loading screens. Also the city offers an illusion of an open-world environment but the truth is that you can't go everywhere you want to. But even in a smaller area there are many paths you can follow to your destination whether it is on the rooftops or the roads.The biggest problem of the game is it's AI. It may be easy for enemies to spot you but it is really easy to escape and hide. Just hiding in some shadows or climbing on a roof does the trick. Also their reactions to noises, torches of fires going off or when finding bodies are really bad. They may look around for a while and then go on with their patrols as if nothing happened.Leaving the games problems behind, the stealth mechanisms are really great. Garrett has a lot of tools and his trusted bow at his disposal which he can use to avoid his enemies or dispose of them. The City is filled with loot to steal and a lot of them (especially unique loot and collectibles) are really hard to find so that offers a good challenge. You will have to find safe combinations, secret passages behind bookcases and items hidden behind paintings. Sneaking around the city and searching every corner and every house for loot is really fun.If it's hard for you to find loot you can use the Focus ability which highlights objects you can take or use and enemies. The thing is that Focus makes the game a lot easier so try to avoid using it as much as you can. Garret's abilities can be upgraded by buying (or findind) Focus points and you can also buy new tools or equipment upgrades from merchants around the city. The game's graphics are great. Especially the character's faces which are really epxressive. The animations are smooth. As for the music, it gets a little annoying at times. For example when you are trying to sneak around somewhere and you hear music pounding in your ears. The voice-acting is good as well with Garrett's voice standing out.If the bad AI is not a really big problem for you then Thief can give you a really great time. There are a lot of secrets to discover and finding them using Thief's stealth mechanincs is a real pleasure.75%

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												(At the time that this review is released, I will have NOT beaten Thief yet. I may change my feelings/opinions on it as I progress the game)Thief is a good game for any of you stealth gaming enthusiasts.Although it's story is NOT very interactive, and you don't get the same sort of emotion you would get if you played any games such as, The Walking Dead by Telltale, it is still an overall good game.In a graphic perspective, the game itself is very nice when it comes down to details, shadows, and lighting, but other than that the gameplay feels at points either too jumpy, or too slow paced. At some areas it feels like you have no idea what is going on, and you just want to 'beat' the chapter.As of playing this game, I can't help but feel the way I did when I first tried to get into the game, 'Dishonored'. I kept feeling like I couldn't comprehend what was happening no matter how much the story progressed, and in the end I just got tired of it and had to stop playing it. Thief feels relatively similar to Dishonored's gameplay, but are not nearly the same in a matter of combat, or storyline. The stealth in Thief, which is what is made out to be it's "core gameplay mechanic", works very well if you try to play as a thief who must hide in the shadows and stay hidden. This can make the game feel VERY slow after a while, and eventually I gave up on hiding, as it proved useless when no guards where around. In the aftermath of all that, this game does have some pretty bad AI. The AI which ussually consists of guards or at some points, just average townspeople, which seem to have a pretty mental way of thinking. If you throw a bottle directly at them, they either start getting confused, or walk in the complete opposite direction of where the sound percieved of the bottle smashing was heard. You may be thinking at this point, why am I not stating any real positive outlooks on Thief? Well, that is simply because their isn't many. Like I stated either this game more or less a lighting showcase with some stealth and parkour.After defeating the first Chapter/Tutorial stage, you seem to notice a severe lack of things you could steal. At this point, it's more or less a parkour simulator with a few confusing stories and characters that I just don't seem to get attached to, or relate to at all. In fact, as of playing this game the only emotion I have felt is anger towards the AI for somehow not being able to spot you less than 2 inches away, while standing INFRONT of them... If your one of those people who want to look for a cool game that has action, "parkour" or stunts, and an interactive story, than this game is not for you. However, if you are looking for a linear game that focuses on one main topic and task, than this game is for you.Overall, I would say this game would get 6.5. Although I put a some-what negative look on Thief, this game could be fun for anyone who may have enjoyed games such as, Dishonored and Metal Gear Solid, and I would recommend it to any new-commers to stealthy gaming industry. However, if you are a fan of the original Thief series, and not this decently okay reboot, then I suggest not getting this game. Although I have never played any of the original Thief games, I have heard from many fans of them that this game misses out on some of the key elements used in the original games, which leads many original fans to dislike the way this games story and gameplay was delievered. Well that is it for my review of the game Thief, I hope you enjoyed reading this, and if you were wondering whether or not you wanetd to purchase this game I hope I helped you in making that decision.--Kv321 (Part of the E3D Network)

Finished review below.I can't play the game - after trying and trying I had to give up due to the non-mappable controls and my physical limitatrions. Thats the reason why a lot of people with physical issues play PC instead of consoles, the extreme customizability of inputs. For you to not take the extra time to make the controller maps customizable is just stupid. Now I have to go spend time screwing with JoytoKey/all the other key-to-controller progs and that never works as well as native controller support and is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I'm not going to let it influence my review because for most people its a minor issue, but if you are like me and need the customizability of a fully mappable controller, you might take this into consideration.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Depending on how you like to play, Thief is either a quick sprint to the finish that will test your reflexes and make you think on your feet or a grueling marathon that will require all your powers of deduction, observation, and a walkthrough or two to complete. Grabbing all the achievements in Thief took me about 47 hours total over the course of a few playthroughs, even with help finding the seven secret areas I overlooked.Taking on the role of the eponymous main character you'll have to make your way through the city you call home, old forgotten ruins beneath it, a mental institution on the other side of the river, and even your own mind. Parts of Thief play like something directly out of a horror game and manage to do it better than most games that make horror their focus. Speaking of Garrett, the man's got a great sense of humor. His zippy one-liners never disappoint.The art direction in Thief is drab, but appropriate. The game is set in an authoritarian citystate on the verge of societal collapse. The colors of any given scene are gray and brown, with a bit of blue and white thrown in for lighting. Interspersed with the dull scenery are carefully placed spots of shadow that you'll need to take advantage of if you want to remain unseen and/or not die, and thousands of shinies you'll need to collect if you want to complete the game.One final note on appearances: I've never liked the "steampunk" aesthetic, so watching the grungy patchwork technology in some parts of the game fall to pieces the way it would in the real world brought me no small amount of secret vindictive pleasure.While each chapter is fairly linear there are usually multiple ways of progressing and different ways of approaching each situation. Very rarely does the main game restrict your options- if you want to muscle your way past the guards and take what you're after by force, you usually can if you're good enough with your blackjack. Just don't try that with the Freaks in the lower levels of the old city; it won't end well. You can also replay each chapter to try something different by revisiting the chapter's starting location. You will need to memorize them or look them up, though, they're not marked on your map.I was a little disappointed that there were only two boss fights in the game. I know not every chapter of a game should have a final encounter, but only two? There's so much you can do with stealth games like this one to build entertaining showdowns so Thief loses a few points here by my reckoning. A word of caution about the final boss... on the hardest difficulty possible (custom settings only, I think) the final boss is a game of breakneck hide-and-seek where being found means you die. Instantly. I'm never doing that again and if achievements are your cup of tea I wish you luck. Hint: move clockwise.Flaws notwithstanding, Thief would make a great Christmas gift- nothing says "holiday spirit" like breaking into other people's homes, taking their things, and dispensing wanton vandalism and violence along the way. Deck the halls.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												I personally found this game brilliant. I'd recommend it to most people, because of the variety of methods of going about the game. It doesn't matter if you're a sneaky thief who doesn't even knock anyone out, who is never even known to be there. Or if you're the more violent thief who kills everything in sight and is feared by the contending factions.Gameplay - 8/10 Well, this can be a bit of a controversial subject, I thought the story was fairly good (about a 6/10) but the other gameplay (I.E sidemissions) also offer a chance for a different type of fun). Graphics - 8/10 The graphics are pretty good. sometimes you get a slight drop in frame rate (I did, but all the settings were set to absolute max, and I'm playing on a laptop.Sound - 7/10 The sound is pretty good, better in combat scenarios, however you have a good ambiance created through everything combined, which results in a decent atmosphere to coincide with the game play.Overall - 7.5/10. I enjoyed this game, there are several options to make the game harder, including in mission challenges and other fun things. Should take about 13 hours to complete everything on medium difficulty, and 15 on the hardest. Recommended. 10/10 would steal everything from a person and then knock them out again.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Thief, a stealth based composed of multiple settings and scenes that conflict in the point of interest for the player. Thief's time is set to be in both medieval / modern century with electricity and fire with alot of sword play. This game will keep you on your toes most of the time and has an interest in horror. Characters and AI: You are Garret, the master thief, king of rats. Master of stealth and loves to steal things. Yet you have a heart for the city in which you live in, making your actions duable in the sence that you are the good guy.Eren: A young woman who partners up with Garret and ♥♥♥♥s everything up in the begining.AI: The AI are ok and someare scary, never the less they have a specific pattern in which they move and can't seem to see♥♥♥♥♥♥in the dark unless they are really close.The game is very detailed to the biggest of buildings to the finest crack in a piece of wood. It looks beautiful. But it's always dark. This game also likes to jump around in the story, linking things from the past to the future, which is really cool and all, but lacks interest and a sence of excitement. Only a few scenes in the game were actually really good, but other than that it's a very slow game. After a few missions, instead of sneaking passed the gaurd, you start to kill them in glorious fashions, reducing the amount of time, but killing the experience and atmousphere. Combat and movement: The moevment is fine the there are issues with the combat and climbing. When it comes to seriously climbing stough, the character can't seem to do what you want him to do even though the objective is right infront of you. It's frustrating. And the combat sucks, whenever you dodge, you get hit, making it even more frustrating. So for those who want to play this game, make sure you have a good computer! This game will lag alot if you don't and get ready to take things slow, don't rush them.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												I would recommend this game, but only to those who did not play the previous games in the series.First I will discuss the pros of this game.  This game is mostly about sneaking carefully from place to place, stealing everything of value you can lay your hands on, and this game does a good job of ramping up the tension when you risk detection.  The sense of atmosphere this game creates is strong, but very different from its predecessors.  For those more accustomed to action games, there are a few more active scenes in which you must make a hasty escape, but fighting is usually not an option.  The game has an almost movie-like style to it, although this is very common in commercially produced games.  There are plenty of unique, collectible treasures to gather, which you can keep and admire after returning to your hideout, and a lot of secrets to find.  The focus ability is useful, not only enhancing your abilities for a time, but also making it easier to navigate and spot important objects, such as traps, switches and ropes.Now we come to the cons.  For fans of the previous games, Thief is likely to be something of a disapointment.  Many of the fantasy elements of the game have been removed.  Hammerites and Pagans are nowhere to be seen, although some signs of their former presence can be seen here and there.  Elemental crystals are no longer used on Garret's arrows and have been replaced with mechanical or alchemical alternatives.  Rope arrows can now only be used in very specific locations, as they can no longer lodge in the scenery.  Even the word "taffer" has fallen out of common use among the city people, replaced with more familiar swear words.  Although this is probably meant to give the game a more mature style, it actually has the opposite effect and makes the characters seem somewhat juvenile.The cinematic style of the game, as I have already noted, is very similar to most other modern games and doesn't really seem to fit.  The hand-drawn animations of the previous games are gone.  Even the upgrade system is somewhat generic and seems like a half-hearted attempt to imitate other games.  The storyline is also very different in style to the previous games.  While not exactly bad, it often attempts to depict Garret as vulnerable and insecure, as if to draw attention to his softer side.  Although some may find this intriguing, I thought it seemed somewhat contrived.  The game's ending is abrupt and leaves a lot of loose ends, giving the impression that the final cinematic was abandoned half-finished.All in all, this is a decent stealth game in its own right, but for fans of the previous instalments, like myself, Thief marks the death of the series and the beginning of a long line of dull, generic, mass-produced sequels.  If you love stealth games, treasure hunting and a strong dark atmosphere, this game is for you.  However, if you liked the previous games, avoid it.  Unless you are prepared for the drastic change in style, this game will leave you feeling empty and unfulfilled.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This is a flawed gem of a game, but in my own opinion one with more positives than negatives.Tight controls, detailed environments, and atmosphere you could cut with a knife, sadly held back by a rather weak story.It also sadly but understandably, buckles a bit under the shear weight of the legacy it is trying to uphold, but as a fan of the old series I enjoyed this one. Ones experience aside with the old Thief series, this is one of those real 'love it, or hate it' type deals, and although I recommend this game for any fans of stealth, I would still argue you to if possible, try the game first before investing in your own copy.I personally found it interesting and neat in a way that reinforces that Garath (the main character) is actually a physical presence in the world... but for the record I’ve heard a lot of people that find the frequent, if short, animations were he opens and picks up things, to be utterly infuriating. Just to name one example on the ‘love, hate’ thing.In short, I would recommend this for stealth fans, and fans of the Thief series; the later if with the caveat and warning of the game being quite different from the rest of the series.For all others: For good or ill, this really feels like a larceny simulator with a fantasy twist. If that sounds interesting to you, you might enjoy it, but Gareth is very, very weak, and even a single guard may kill you if you are unprepared.Unlike this studious previous outing, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, combat is usually not an equal option unless you are really good at it, or spend a lot of money, time and upgrades on making it so; something that will eat up resources that could have been much better spent elsewhere.So if you have some patience this can be a very rewarding game you will lose dozen if not hundreds of hours to... but gamers aimed more at the action side of things need not apply.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												(At the time that this review is released, I will have NOT beaten Thief yet. I may change my feelings/opinions on it as I progress the game)Thief is a good game for any of you stealth gaming enthusiasts.Although it's story is NOT very interactive, and you don't get the same sort of emotion you would get if you played any games such as, The Walking Dead by Telltale, it is still an overall good game.In a graphic perspective, the game itself is very nice when it comes down to details, shadows, and lighting, but other than that the gameplay feels at points either too jumpy, or too slow paced. At some areas it feels like you have no idea what is going on, and you just want to 'beat' the chapter.As of playing this game, I can't help but feel the way I did when I first tried to get into the game, 'Dishonored'. I kept feeling like I couldn't comprehend what was happening no matter how much the story progressed, and in the end I just got tired of it and had to stop playing it. Thief feels relatively similar to Dishonored's gameplay, but are not nearly the same in a matter of combat, or storyline. The stealth in Thief, which is what is made out to be it's "core gameplay mechanic", works very well if you try to play as a thief who must hide in the shadows and stay hidden. This can make the game feel VERY slow after a while, and eventually I gave up on hiding, as it proved useless when no guards where around. In the aftermath of all that, this game does have some pretty bad AI. The AI which ussually consists of guards or at some points, just average townspeople, which seem to have a pretty mental way of thinking. If you throw a bottle directly at them, they either start getting confused, or walk in the complete opposite direction of where the sound percieved of the bottle smashing was heard. You may be thinking at this point, why am I not stating any real positive outlooks on Thief? Well, that is simply because their isn't many. Like I stated either this game more or less a lighting showcase with some stealth and parkour.After defeating the first Chapter/Tutorial stage, you seem to notice a severe lack of things you could steal. At this point, it's more or less a parkour simulator with a few confusing stories and characters that I just don't seem to get attached to, or relate to at all. In fact, as of playing this game the only emotion I have felt is anger towards the AI for somehow not being able to spot you less than 2 inches away, while standing INFRONT of them... If your one of those people who want to look for a cool game that has action, "parkour" or stunts, and an interactive story, than this game is not for you. However, if you are looking for a linear game that focuses on one main topic and task, than this game is for you.Overall, I would say this game would get 6.5. Although I put a some-what negative look on Thief, this game could be fun for anyone who may have enjoyed games such as, Dishonored and Metal Gear Solid, and I would recommend it to any new-commers to stealthy gaming industry. However, if you are a fan of the original Thief series, and not this decently okay reboot, then I suggest not getting this game. Although I have never played any of the original Thief games, I have heard from many fans of them that this game misses out on some of the key elements used in the original games, which leads many original fans to dislike the way this games story and gameplay was delievered. Well that is it for my review of the game Thief, I hope you enjoyed reading this, and if you were wondering whether or not you wanetd to purchase this game I hope I helped you in making that decision.--Kv321 (Part of the E3D Network)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												I had heard some things about this game before I got it. I heard some good things and some bad things, but the majority of the things I heard made this game sound more mediocre and disappointing than anything. Many people played this game expecting to get the original Thief game, which caused disappointment for them. I haven't gotten around to playing the original Thief games, so I can't make the comparison, but I wouldn't say that this game is bad. In fact, I actually found it to be quite good. Sure it has it's issues, but I definitely got my money's worth considering I bought it on sale for just over $10, put in 50+ hours and felt thoroughly entertained throughout the game.Story:The game begins as you take on the role of Garrett, a thief-for-hire as he is in pursuit of the Primal Stone, a gem that his contact Basso has asked of him to acquire. Garrett is joined by Erin, his young and naïve apprentice. Garrett and Erin are on their way to Baron Northcrest's manor in hopes of stealing the stone. When they arrive on the roof of the manor and gaze through the rooftop window, they see Baron Northcrest performing some sort of ritual with the stone. Feeling uneasy, Garrett calls off the job. Erin objects and a brief altercation ensues before Erin falls through the glass window and into the ritual. As Garrett jumps through the roof in an attempt to save her, a part of the building collapses onto him and knocks him unconscious. Garrett awakens one year later to find the city is plagued by The Gloom, a plague that causes it's victims to hear voices and kill themselves. Garrett himself has started to have visions of Erin and learns that she may still be alive. Garrett is now in pursuit of finding her. Meanwhile, Orion, one of Garrett's new clients is leading a rebellion against the Baron and Garrett is stuck in the middle of it all.Gameplay:The gameplay can be really addictive and immersive. It's so fun hiding, sneaking around and collecting loot. You can spend your loot on upgrades for Garrett's abilities and weapons. The game is fairly big. At times, I felt overwhelmed at how much there was to explore as I'm a completionist and want to get as much out of the game as possible and explore every corner of every map. I would describe this game as pseudo-open-world. The game is centered around The City, which is divided into different districts. You can roam The City as you please if you're not in the middle of a chapter. You'll come across a loading screen when you go from one district to another. In order to progress through the story, you'll have to complete the main story chapters. The story chapters are a bit more linear. Each main story chapter is found in different parts of The City and will be replayable once you complete them by revisiting their respective areas. I guess you could compare this game's open-worldness to Super Mario 64. In Super Mario 64, you could roam throughout the castle and access each level by jumping through the paintings. This is kind of like that, except The City is much larger and has more to do. On top of the main story, there are side missions to do and different collectibles to find, which are displayed in Garrett's hideout for you to admire when you're not in the middle of a chapter. There are three different playstyles in the game – Ghost, Opportunist and Predator. You can play the game trying to remain completely undetected and unseen under the ghost playstyle, use the environment to distract enemies and get what you need under the opportunist playstyle or knockout anyone in your way under the predator playstyle. There are various thieving challenges to complete depending on which playstyle you choose. The Negatives:I've come across a couple of glitches in this game. I've noticed the AI spinning in circles at high speeds or just standing there without moving to the point where you could literally walk through them as if they didn't even exist. I've also noticed points in the game where Garrett would get stuck in a corner and I'd have to reload my most recent save so I could continue playing. This could be frustrating at times and made me glad that I saved the game as often as I did. Granted, these glitches weren't incredibly frequent, but they did happen on more than one occasion. Also, Garrett doesn't have the strongest character. The stoic voice acting is fitting, yet makes him come across as rather dull. I didn't think it was bad, but I just thought he could have used a bit more charm. There are some people that complain about the story. I wouldn't call it bad, but it wasn't anything groundbreaking either. It was decent and was enough to keep my interest. My problem was the ending. I don't want to spoil anything, but I'll just say that it left me with the same feeling of confusion that Bioshock Infinite's ending did. Perhaps some people like that sort of thing, but I wasn't a huge fan of it or the confusion it left me with. I mentioned the game's size earlier and how overwhelming it felt at times. I meant that in a good way. However, the downside to that is the map navigation. Navigating the map in the linear chapter missions were fine, but navigating The City could be very confusing if you didn't remember how to get from one district to another. As much as I love freeroaming The City, it  can feel very clunky and easy to get lost in even if you're using the map.Conclusion:Overall, if you like stealth games, I'd recommend picking this one up when it's on sale. While there are people like me who enjoy the game, there are many who don't. I think it depends on each person individually and what it is they expect from the game. If you haven't played a Thief game before or if you're able to put your personal bias for the older games in the series aside and treat this as it's own entity, I think you'll find it has a lot of content to offer for the sale price to keep you busy and entertained.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
In short: 7/10 - Recommended to patient, stealth-obsessed gamers not looking for a great story.For a good challenge, turn off all UI and hints, make use of the great custom difficulty settings (no weapons, no KOs allowed, no damage allowed, etc.), and play non-lethal ghost style.  This makes for a much more immersive and intense experience.  Move slowly; allow yourself some time to learn to navigate the city.  The map is not extremely helpful (seemingly an intentional choice), and those short on patience may quickly become frustrated attempting to find side missions, in particular.Level design is not brilliant, but it is not 100% linear, either.  Contrary to the beliefs of those who rushed through, there are multiple paths to most objectives, but those paths may take a bit of exploration to discover.  That said, the game would certainly benefit from a more open, expansive touch, as being met with repeated denial upon attempted door, window, and ledge traversal is not exactly fun.  "Uh oh!  That guard may spot me.  Better scurry up this ledge...nope, game designers didn't want me to scurry up that ledge.  Loading quicksave..."  Also, loading screens when crawling through windows?  Let's nix that from the next game, please.Dialogue mixing is terrible.  The localization of voices is so poor it seems unfinished (voices through a wall often sound like they're six inches from your ear), and vocal levels are all over the place (dialogue buried to the point of unintelligibility during some cut scenes).  Also, the extreme repetition of guard dialogue is inexcusable for a AAA game.  Pure laziness.  I laughed really hard when the Golden Joysticks Awards nominated Thief for Best Audio.  Anyhow, all other aspects of audio fare much better.  General atmosphere is certainly strong and enjoyable in its dark ambience.Stealth mechanics are good, and sneaking around, distracting guards with bottles, navigating around noise-prone caged birds and dogs, creating shadow with water arrows, finding and disabling traps, and pick-pocketing are among the simple joys Thief presents.  The game truly shines when theft is the sole focus (this isn't always the case).  Do not skip the side missions, as they offer some of the best thieving and stealth opportunities.  AI is fair and as relaxed or challenging as the difficulty selected.  Failure always feels like your own fault rather than, "How'd that guard just see through a wall?!"  That said, you are underpowered against guards as an incentive to remain stealthy.The story is something to skip through on subsequent replays.  As the supernatural stuff creeps in, you may find yourself saying, "But...I just want to be a thief and sneak around and steal things."  Or not.  This certainly depends on your expectations, or lack there-of, from a game titled "Thief".  With that said, the Outlast-style level, out-of-left-field and non-Thief as it may be, is genuinely creepy.Replay value is high, particularly for obsessive completionists and speed-run attemptees.  The game does make this unnecessarily difficult in that each mission must be found in the city in order to replay, and none of these are marked on the map, so those short on time may spend the entirety of that time searching.  This may be a fun extra challenge for those with lots of time, patience, and practice navigating the city, but the additional option to quickly select and replay levels would certainly be welcome.Comparison time...many compare Thief to Dishonored.  Both are basically first person stealth.  Dishonored is clearly the better game as far as level design and story.  But for me, Thief is stronger in the shadow/darkness department, and I actually much prefer sneaking and being stealthy in Thief.  Though I opt to play Dishonored non-lethal, no KOs, and without "blink", I almost feel like the game would be more fun if played the opposite way.  How about Styx: Master of Shadows?  It's a fantastic hardcore stealth game with insane level design (but lower visual production values), and a clear winner as long as third person floats your boat.  If I found a game with the dark atmosphere of Thief, the art direction of Dishonored, and the level design of Styx, I wouldn't play anything else.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												First impression: Not total garbage. I'm surprised! You and I both expected me to flat-out dislike this game because I'm a long-time fan of the franchise, didn't we? But it really is not total crap.As far as I'm concerned, all references to "classic Thief" elements such as the Hammerite symbol, the Keeper statuette, Garrett's mechanical eye, guards mentioning the word "taffer, etc., they are all just nods and easter eggs paying homage to the original trilogy. There's some clumsy attempts to dovetail the rebooted universe with the old but it's too nonsensical to take seriously. And why use the name Basso for new-Garrett's fence? Why not use Cutty? Old-Basso was just a boxman (expert lockpicker).The city hub makes a return in Thief 4. I know some people who didn't mind it in Thief 3, but I know *nobody* who LIKED it. Its reuse here only served to pad gameplay time with tedious walking back and forth. Thief 2's "Life Of the Party" mission had Garrett traversing the city rooftops from his home all the way to Angelwatch. In that single mission alone, the world-building achieved by the things you witness and the conversations you overhear on the way to the actual mission area gave that Thief-universe more heart and soul than this entire game did for its own universe. I'll never forget the pejorative 'taffer' or the battle between the guards of Lady van Vernon's house and Master Willey's castle. A few weeks from now all I'll remember about Thief 4 is "sloop" and "Garrett, I'm slipping!"Analogy time: This game is about as classic Thief as the movie "World War Z" was a faithful adaptation of the book, i.e. not even a little bit. Now, now, this is a reboot, sure, sure. I'm already accounting for that and I'm still making this statement! The thing they've created here does not inherit enough Thief-y essence to rightfully call itself a reimagination of the original intellectual property. This game and that movie should have no right to affiliate themselves with those respective IPs. The only reason they have each done so is because their creators did not have faith in their products to stand alone on their own merits.

												Beautiful, this game is just beautiful, the PC Port is fonominal, the lighting effects were better then real life. This may be the only game other then octodad where i have practically fell in love with the storyline. The cutscenes were really nicely done, props to the voice actors, their voices were just so realistic and it really managed to get you into the story. You really feel like your inside of the game, stealing, hiding from guards, knocking random people out with aerial takedowns. This is my favourite game to ever be released on the steam store. Also I only had it since last night (9th March) and I already played more then 12 and a half hours. You can tell i like this game.The only negative I have is the texutre of windows, they look a bit, how you would say, smudgy and it kind of looks like something you would make in nursery.Other then that brilliant game! 9.5/10

I can get bored doing stealth so at least headshots are an option when you get frustrated. Mostly I found myself doing a mixture of the three techniques to get through the game. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Thief mixes really excellent gameplay with really terrible story telling, and in that sense it's pretty classic. The whole story feels very cobbled together, and none of it comes together very well, however it's a blast to play through for die hard stealth fans. The world is wonderfully put together with a large variety of environment puzzles to sneak through. There are many approaches to almost every situation. There are a few points in the game where you get bottlenecked into a single solution and they feel pretty glaring when you reach them because of how large the variety of options is almost everywhere else, but these moments are few and far between and many players may not even notice them.Over all, Thief is a solid entry into the series if you value gameplay over story telling. However if you feel that the characterization and story telling of the series to date has been your primary motivation for playing, then you may want to give this one a pass.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												This game wanted to be Thief. Its developers wanted it to be Thief. I wanted it to be Thief. Unfortunately, it is not Thief. It is a game that wishes it could hang out with Thief's friends. To those that loved the original game it is not like the original in all the wrong ways, except in the thieving. If you want something more modern that is closer to Thief then play Dishonored otherwise, just play the original ThiefThe good about the game is that the stealing is fun and challenging. The building designs are pretty.The meh about the game is the story. It is truly meh. It didn't really make me want to finish the main story or learn any of the lore that was created for this new game.The bad was first and foremost Garrett. He was a dumb character and looked really stupid when he had his mask pulled down to the edge of his chin. Who does that? In the game it made him look like he had extra chins. I don't mind that they wanted to make him different than the original Garrett, but at least make him interesting. He could have been any character and it wouldn't have changed the story at all.The other bad is that because the story was meh I didn't care about any of the characters that I was supposed to. They could have all died and I would have just looted the corpes and moved on. And that is what I feel they should do with this title.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												The city is beyond beautiful but it felt empty and was frustrating to navigate. Its largely dark and rainy atmosphere made it strangely relaxing. Garret's movement (running, sneaking, swooping, vaulting) felt perfectly polished. Bow shots and takedowns felt great; melee combat was just ok...I missed having a blade. The main story was a bit of a mess in my opinion, it seemed to have a lot of holes, left a lot of unanswered questions, and generally was just hard to follow... the writing however I thought was rather good, almost movie-like... only fragmented. The main missions were interesting enough but generally linear, simple, and scripted; a notably different feeling experience from the previous Thief games. Basso's jobs were unfortunately forgettable, very often you'd be tasked to break into someones house to steal something only to arrive there and find no resistance at all; this attributed to the lifeless feeling of the city. Client jobs on the other hand were much more interesting, but the questgivers themselves were often inconveniently located and required the player to constantly backtrack through the labyrinth-like city. Backtracking to the Queen of Beggars and the main merchants similarly felt unnecessarily frustrating. The item and focus upgrade systems I think were commendable ideas but they ultimately felt inconsequential and left my itch for progression unscratched. I missed the Hammerites, Pagans, and Keepers... as The Watch, while cool, didn't feel justly elaborated upon. In truth I had fun with the game, I was impressed with its masterfully polished controls and gorgeous graphics, but the overall gameplay, pace, and story missed their marks and left it forgettable.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Being an old-school Thief fan, I was ecstatic to get my hands on this game. I wasn't the biggest fan of Deadly Shadows because of the third-person change so I'm glad they kept it first-person and I really like Garrett's modelling. Very cool. The whole game is very 'Thief-esque' which I'm glad to see and I love the amount of things you can steal, since I'm a human magpie. The graphics are beautiful, the city is dark but when you go inside, there's lots of colour and character in each place you visit. The story is fine, I enjoyed playing it out but the ending felt a little quick and anti-climactic, mostly the last scenes. There are only a few problems that I found with the game, and unfortunately some affect the game quite drastically - especially if you're playing the second time around to get every shiny you missed. Firstly, the mapping system is quite badly done, there's no names at all for any of the areas which is highly frustrating and would have probably made the fact that to get to most areas, you have to jump through people's windows and go through loading screens each time, a LOT less frustrating. It would be nice to know WHERE you are going. They probably would have been better off keeping a similar mapping system to the old Thief, they had labels and also showed you which parts of the level you've been to and which is undiscovered. Another problem is that to replay chapters, you have to find the place where you began that chapter - impossible since there's no labelling and quite a lot of chapters! Also, a minor issue really, but I would have really loved the word 'taffer' to make it back into Thief and maybe make the NPCs say a wider range of lines, they seem to be repeating the same ones over and over and it gets really frustrating. Despite the flaws, it's defintely a must-play, if you keep in mind that a lot of things are different. Including the lack of dagger/sword and a prompted blackjack instead of real-time. I'm not saying they affect the game much, they're just different. THe first-time playthrough is very interesting and I was engrossed in it for days, I enjoyed it that much. I just wouldn't replay it, even though I wanted to, because the mapping system made it a lot less fun than it could have been. As you can tell, I'm writing a mixed review here, which is sad for me since I am a huge fan of the Thief games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												First, an important point: I only recommend buying this game if it's cheap.Once I disabled SSAA from the start-up graphics menu, the game actually became playable on my stupidly high-spec computer and oversized widescreen monitor. I don't understand why a computer that is above and beyond the recommended specs is unable to run this game out-of-the-box. Anyhoo.Once the game got working properly, the graphics are very pretty. I feel that the facial animations were a bit messed up, particularly in cutscenes, but besides that, the game looked nice.The sound mechanics of the game are STUFFED UP. Someone might be two floors below you, with masses of stone separating you from them, yet you hear them like they're right next to you.You're in a silent room. You peep through a keyhole, and you can see a couple people talking. Suddenly, you can hear their voices blaring at you, even though you backed away from the keyhole and (closed) door. Same goes for peeping through a hole in a thick stone wall. At first you can't hear a thing, then after you establish their presence, it's as though they're shouting in the same room with you.Trying to listen in on a conversation? You get close enough to hear a couple of people having a conversation. Except, one of the two people drop out to a barely audible murmur. But the person they're speaking to has their voice blaring as though speaking through a loudspeaker. This problem lead me to enable subtitles, just so I could read what they were saying. But do this, and you will be constantly bombarded with repetitious "background chatter" in the city. There were, like, 3 dialogue strings on repeat.The story is abysmal. There are other reviews that go into detail plenty well enough that I won't repeat the problems here.But, if you want a game that isn't a standard shooter, that has some creepy moments, pretty graphics, and lots of random loot to steal, give this game a go IF it's on special.

												Well, I haven't played any Thief game before, but I've played Dishonoured. While Dishonoured has got this steampunk atmosphere and you've got 20 ways to behead anyone, I find Thief quite pleasant game. I know there are many reviews claiming "this is the worst stealth game known to man since forever", but it depends on what you mean as "stealth", if you consider stealth to move around killing people in 20,000 ways, this is not your game, indeed. But if you rather fancy a slow paced game, with a great atmosphere and brilliant reproduction of the City of London, watching an OLED 42" telly at 23Hz with a glass of wine, this is your game, to be yours for the small fortune of $4.99... your glass of wine is dearer, indeed. And no, this is not "the worst stealth game known to man", not even at that price... 9/10

Posted: June 9, 2015
												I haven't played the other titles of this franchise game so i went into this with an open mind.  Honestly, i tried to like it.  I really did.  This game seriously is "go from point A to point B" on a grossly obvious linear path.  Whats the point of sneaking around if i can't even kill anyone? Maybe i havent got that far yet but, dang...i dont feel like a bad*** thief with supposed super-powers.  I feel this is a rip-off of Dishonored without all the coolness that embodies dishonored. However artistically speaking, this game is pretty gorgeous.  There are upgrades that make your useless abilities slightly better yet not enough where you would actually use them differently.  You can seriously run through this game bashing people in the face with your club and probably don't need to buy a single upgrade.  Im severely disappointed and won't be playing anymore of this.. :-(

Yes , If you wanna know more about the game read the following review!First of all , im a veteran of old thief games finished them all on hardestDid finish this on hardest on ps4and now its time to play it on pc In this review i cover the mechanics and suchI will not disscuss the story in this game because its really not worth it. Introduction	For a start this a really good rebot ,Probly the best Thief could ever get , i remember when i was gonna play this and my throat just went berzerk with a throat abscess. So i never got around to play it on pc until now start of 2016 when there is nothing to play on steamSo you start out in a mission to basicly steal items thats really all that thief is and thats why i love thiefthe feeling of "I was in this XX and stole this XX from these ppl who had atlest 30 guards in the area and they didnt notice me at all.Thats why i just freaking love thief.Gonna point out some Pros and Cons  Pros  The AI is perfect in my opinion (Do not play on hardest if you want releastic guards) Good World/Open world-kind of  Stealth system is perfect! The Difficulty system is really well made Charactars are intressting Main missions have really nice "Map design" Side Missions Unique loot Collectible Npc discussion Three different path of gameplay (will talk about it later on in this review) Shadows (You can use shadows to locate where the npc are not many ppl use it) Focus System Clean UI  Lots of looting Shadow Gem (Shwoing when you guards can spot you or not) Upgradable gear (Will talk about this later on)  Lamp Switches (both good and bad depends on you as a person) Arrow Technics (will talk about this later on) Charactars are intressting  Cons  The Voice actors are awefull (Sometimes the voice acting plays twice on npc's not sure why) to small main mission maps   Combat is just awfull Story is awfull Small Size of mission  Map (In my opinion) Bad Hardest Diffuclty "Sightings by guards"  Difficulty SystemOkay here is why Thief appeal to both veteran players and new players.It makes you make you'r own difficulty, if you wanna remove focus system go on do it.If you wanna have iron man mod go on do it.Its so good well made!CharactarsOkay i will not cover all Characters just cuz it could be spoiler to you!I will only cover the start Characters you find at the start of the game. Garrett The Master Thief Erin City Watch aka Guards Citizens Basso  Barron Voice Actors - Really that awfull?Erin = In my opinion i feelt that her voice actor wasn't "Commited" to the role and as a result it didnt go home for me, There is so much i could write about when it comes to thief but i wanna keep it short.Garrett The Master Thief= Im so sad about his new voice actor but still he does a fine jobThe old game had the best voice actor for Garrett the master thief.the new one does the job fine but thats all, some cutscenes are just "ehm...okay i guess"City Watch = God damn i love those voice actors , some of these city watch are doing the job really really well and as a result i end up listing to the disscusions.Citizens = I am suprised that they managed to get some decent voice actors for this role , i mean its not a requirement to have good voice actors for some random npc that just walk around, maybe talk to some other npc, they make the role really really wellBasso: Im not sure yet what my opinion is yet on this charactar , all i can say is "He's fine i guess"Barron: This man, this charactar really make the role very very well, Really like it!In some missions where he screams it feelt like he meant it!Some more information: Sometimes when you run around in the city from mission to mission , you maybe find some npc in houses talking about YOU! this made me just smile!thats a plus on my side! This is all i will cover for voice actors! content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												I would recommend this game, but only to those who did not play the previous games in the series.First I will discuss the pros of this game.  This game is mostly about sneaking carefully from place to place, stealing everything of value you can lay your hands on, and this game does a good job of ramping up the tension when you risk detection.  The sense of atmosphere this game creates is strong, but very different from its predecessors.  For those more accustomed to action games, there are a few more active scenes in which you must make a hasty escape, but fighting is usually not an option.  The game has an almost movie-like style to it, although this is very common in commercially produced games.  There are plenty of unique, collectible treasures to gather, which you can keep and admire after returning to your hideout, and a lot of secrets to find.  The focus ability is useful, not only enhancing your abilities for a time, but also making it easier to navigate and spot important objects, such as traps, switches and ropes.Now we come to the cons.  For fans of the previous games, Thief is likely to be something of a disapointment.  Many of the fantasy elements of the game have been removed.  Hammerites and Pagans are nowhere to be seen, although some signs of their former presence can be seen here and there.  Elemental crystals are no longer used on Garret's arrows and have been replaced with mechanical or alchemical alternatives.  Rope arrows can now only be used in very specific locations, as they can no longer lodge in the scenery.  Even the word "taffer" has fallen out of common use among the city people, replaced with more familiar swear words.  Although this is probably meant to give the game a more mature style, it actually has the opposite effect and makes the characters seem somewhat juvenile.The cinematic style of the game, as I have already noted, is very similar to most other modern games and doesn't really seem to fit.  The hand-drawn animations of the previous games are gone.  Even the upgrade system is somewhat generic and seems like a half-hearted attempt to imitate other games.  The storyline is also very different in style to the previous games.  While not exactly bad, it often attempts to depict Garret as vulnerable and insecure, as if to draw attention to his softer side.  Although some may find this intriguing, I thought it seemed somewhat contrived.  The game's ending is abrupt and leaves a lot of loose ends, giving the impression that the final cinematic was abandoned half-finished.All in all, this is a decent stealth game in its own right, but for fans of the previous instalments, like myself, Thief marks the death of the series and the beginning of a long line of dull, generic, mass-produced sequels.  If you love stealth games, treasure hunting and a strong dark atmosphere, this game is for you.  However, if you liked the previous games, avoid it.  Unless you are prepared for the drastic change in style, this game will leave you feeling empty and unfulfilled.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I personally found this game brilliant. I'd recommend it to most people, because of the variety of methods of going about the game. It doesn't matter if you're a sneaky thief who doesn't even knock anyone out, who is never even known to be there. Or if you're the more violent thief who kills everything in sight and is feared by the contending factions.Gameplay - 8/10 Well, this can be a bit of a controversial subject, I thought the story was fairly good (about a 6/10) but the other gameplay (I.E sidemissions) also offer a chance for a different type of fun). Graphics - 8/10 The graphics are pretty good. sometimes you get a slight drop in frame rate (I did, but all the settings were set to absolute max, and I'm playing on a laptop.Sound - 7/10 The sound is pretty good, better in combat scenarios, however you have a good ambiance created through everything combined, which results in a decent atmosphere to coincide with the game play.Overall - 7.5/10. I enjoyed this game, there are several options to make the game harder, including in mission challenges and other fun things. Should take about 13 hours to complete everything on medium difficulty, and 15 on the hardest. Recommended. 10/10 would steal everything from a person and then knock them out again.

Posted: July 6, 2015
												Thief is both one of the best stealth games I've ever played and a game I couldn't wait get rid of.+ Cool Lore: Interesting universe. A sort of alternative dark medieval world with some intriguing magic and beings.+ Lighting manipulation: Light fires or put out torches with flame and water arrows.+ Arrow types: On top of fire and water, use stun arrows, poison gas arrows, or just the normal lethal arrows.+ Smooth moves: Sneak, slide, climb, crawl. Nice parkour-ish skills, fluid movement.+ Feel like a real thief: Pickpocket people, rob small houses or big mansions, run on rooftops, hide in closets.+ No mad rampages: Fighting a single dude face to face is very hard. This is a true stealth game. Sneak or die.- Crap story: Weak protagonist, weak mcguffin, weak side-characters, weak villain.- The ending: The game just ends.- Repetitive: Sneak into place, rob place, return to quest giver, get another job, repeat until story advances, repeat again.- Small, linear hub-world: You always end up running up and down the same few streets getting to and from NPCs and objectives.Without a nice story to keep you going through the repetitive gameplay, it almost falls short of decency, but actually ends up being a pretty good stealth game. Some of the best sneaking around in a game ever... Just beware of the asylum level, you might be led to think you accidentally switched to playing Outlast.Simolius - July 2015

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Thief is a reboot of the classic FPS stealth game series "Thief".The medieval/steampunk setting is immersive, thanks to a great shadow usage, skilful design and gloomy colors.The main story is quite short and "unsalted" but always great in places and background happenings. The severely intricated city, which is the mission hub, is the soul of the game.Optional client jobs, secondary missions and break-ins are the way to actually feel the thief essence: this is a game to be explored, as every corner can hide a lever or a secret passage, and information gathering is crucial.Game mechanics are not perfectly refined as in Dishonored, and the sound (which is of good quality) is affected by some bugs, but the sense of realism and immersion in the atmosphere of Thief is deep and catching.88/100For a more faithful stealth gaming experience I suggest to switch on the no-kill and no-detection modes, as the game provides unlimited quicksaves.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, having enjoyed previous Thief titles, but sadly it wasn't to be. Although the game looks great and does play quite well, I never really felt like I was the Master Thief, fleet of foot and all but invisible amongst the shadows. No, for the most part I felt clumsy and lacking the dexterity necessary to remain undetected; ledges and boxes that I'm sure had been reachable and climbable in previous areas, suddenly seemed to become impossible obstacles, for one of such talent, and running, climbing, traversing the rooftops and skulking in shadows never seemed to flow as smoothly as intended.Bothersome game mechanics can often be overlooked for the sake of a good storyline but sadly Thief let me down in this area too. From the intriguing, via the confusing, to the ridiculous, I have been left thinking "I'm still not sure if I even know what just happened there".So, why the recommendation? Well, Thief isn't a bad game, and for a fair, low coinage can potentially provide good value hours of distraction for many, even enjoyment for some, just not for me.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I heard a lot about the new thief before buying it but thought I should make up my own mind and played it myself.I played about 10 hours to beat the games main storyline including a few sightseeing trips and sidequest. So 50 bucks for 10 hours is not really worth it for me.Why did I recommend it? Scroll down to the bold text. :D-Spoilers up ahead-I like the thief franchise but I would not really put it under that name. Playing the first few chapters you get the feeling this might become an okay game but around the third chapter you kind of start giving up on it. Specially when Zombie/Falmer/Weeper guys start appearing with a super lame and poor explanation of how they came to be.It was really confusing for me since it feld like they didn't quite know what type of game they wanted it to be. Sometimes I felt like it wanted to be a stealth type game then it felt like it wanted to be pure action..suddenly it tries to be a really weird horror game with mentioned above Falmer type creatures that might have been taken from Skyrim. I do know that people who developed Dishonored also worked with Thief before and I don't know if the storylines from both games were created simultaneously but I got to be honest..Thief has Gloom and Dishonored had the rat plagueThief has Freaks and Dishonored had the WeepersThief has the Blind Begger Queen and Dishonored had Granny RagsThief had Erin taken away but guiding you through the world Dishonored had the Empress and later the heartThief takes you to the Primal World in Dishonored you were taken into the VoidThief has the Thief Taker General and Dishonored had Slackjaw - both resembling Bill the Butcher from Gangs of New York.Its not always entirely the same in the way they act of function but it is quite close.I have to say I played Dishonored for hours and hours and I could continue doing so but with Thief that is not the case.The chapters were fast, linear and the guards had a really bad AI.Non the less it was an okay game just not worth that amount of money. So I will give it recommendation if you:- Get it when its on sale - and don't expect a game that feels like one of the Thief ones. If you don't expect that and you only pay..let's say 20 bucks.. it's a game you can enjoy for a little bit while you have a few hours time(edit: did some formatting)

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												This was a tough one for me. As a long running fan of the Thief series I was very excited for this game, and it left me feeling a little mixed. The game seems to take place several years after Deadly Shadows and while that isn't a bad thing, they seem to use it as an excuse to discard a LOT of the Thief series staples...pagans, keepers, hammerites only got the subtlest of nods, nobody uses Taffer anymore, though it is mentioned oddly, elemental crystals are gone for seemingly no reason and Garret isn't quite the cynical anti-hero he originally was; he openly elects to be the hero this time around which is stupid; all to save his new spunky girl sidekick!....it actually hurt me to type that. The plot is ehhh.. at best and they forgot Garret's mechanical eye. Just as weird they went about bringing up a lot of other things..Basso from Thief 2 returns, they even recall his marriage, you actually stumble into Keeper ruins once or twice they even give a nod to insane widow Moira in the form of a chapter Moira's Asylym. In short from a Lore standpoint, they wrecked this game in the most puzzling of manners.Gameplay is another issue however. Disregarding the mauled lore, the game is actually a lot of fun to play. The levels are of good size, not nearly as sprawling as classic Thief levels but certainly a dramatic improvement over Deadly Shadows small spaces, with multiple points of entry and progression such as the game demands. The downside is this game actually features points of no return; which is baffling. A game that is heavily about exploration actually has points where you can't backtrack from....really at a loss for words there other the quick-save is your friend. The City itself is open to exploration again like in Deadly Shadows, but unlike Deadly Shadows it's actually awesome! The City is large, gloomy, tightly-knit with a plethora of doors and windows you can break into, rooftops to explore, and all sorts of hidden nooks and crannies. Inbetween chapters you can pick up simple thief missions that take you around the city to find and steal various trinkets as well as whole, albeit small, individual chapters in the form of client jobs. A nice touch as well is you're able to go back and replay any chapter you just played without needing to load an old save to do so in case you want to try again or missed some loot. They did this aspect at least very well.In the end if you're new to the Thief series and looking to try your hand at stealth games, I imagine you'll find this one a lot of fun. If you're a Thief veteran you'll be very disappointed in the butchering of the lore, almost as if they basically said they don't care, but you'll still find a lot of enjoyment in the gameplay despite it's few hiccups in that regard. It's fun but it's no Metal Age.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												If you're a thief fan, you probably already own this game. If you're new to the FPS(tealth) or played a different game in such genre you should play this game too. Just don't compare any other games with this. Here is my forum post about the game ;"...At last, after 29,5 hours of play, i also have managed to finish this awesome game. As a hardcore fan of Thief series, i wanted to share my opinions/experiences about the game shortly. Brief info; i've played all of the series (Thief, Thief Gold, Thief II, Thief 2x-unofficial, lots of fan made missions, Thief 3) in "expert" mode and i always play as a "ghost".This time i set the dificulty settings to "master" and enabled all customs dificulty settings except the save game limitation and iron man. So I didn't use any "focus" ability therefor i dont know about them "yet". And i will not promote the game, it doesn't need it anyway, i just want to point somethings to - maybe- make this game even more awesome.Pros;Ambience is excellent, most of the times it felt the exact same as the other thief games.Gameplay is excellent, i found this even more controll-able than the other thief games. BUT leaning without "peek"ing would be more useful.AI is very good, really liked the "birds/dogs" addition and npc's reaction to open doors/chests etc. although i'd say excellent as well but there's a flaw mentioned below.Story is almost very good. i really wanted to see some connection between Thief (4) and the older ones (this is a personal choice ofcourse) (but we saw hammerite cathedral right?) Until the end (no, even after we finished) we don't exactly know what has happened to Erin or what has happened to us on that "The Drop" night that made us "sleep" for a year? And for god's sake did we rescue her or not!? Side quests and little details about almost anything like notes, speeches completely awesome. Scary moments in Chapter 5 were superb!! (i knew someone would look back to us thru that key hole)Cons;After we took an arrow, we play rest of the game "bandaged". On my laptop; there s always a string hanging and sometimes it strecthes to somewhere infinitive on my screen (though this is reported) and this adds even more scary-ness to the game sometimes.As a ghost player, some side missions and last 2 chapters are impossible to play as ghost. Because of the custom dificulty settings i've made, i couldn't finish 1 Basso mission (had to ignore the mission). And i could finish the last 2 chapter as "oportunist". It would be more awesome if there was another ways to play as ghost.With "Slow movement speed" custom difficulty enabled; the mission where we escape Baron's tower became ridiculous. Restarted that "event" like 20 times maybe.. If you "sprint" then dogs will catch; had to "swoop" whole the way which makes you pull out of the mood and then you will be exhausted after 3rd swoop so will be shot by invisible something. I'm really not sure how did i finish that event. RNG i guess.Some speeches of npc's can be heard from some distance. It's normal but some others' , you can hear from anywhere in the map with exact same volume if you were near the npc. Think of a repeatedly said sentece!! Made me hate some maps!Flaw in the AI; 3 times (these are when i felt that i had to; but i wonder if i could do even more) i took something infront of an npc and that one didn't be alarmed because line of sight blocked by glass, vase or something insignificant. Even in the last chapter i did this (stripped a painting from the wall) when stealth crystall bursting light!Swoop/Peek; Sometimes, when i want to get close to -lets say a crate- with swoop and then i peek; birds dont be alarmed.. no problem. When i stop "peeking" birds start to sing... normally they should be alarmed when i swoop if i'm in line of sight though.. weird..as a result, i want to thank the team. i've doubts before but after waiting for YEARS for another part of the series, this one hit the spot imo..."

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												I've always been a huge Thief fan. It was the first heavy 3D game my brother and I actually saved money to buy a new video card for. It's no surprise that when a new reboot to the original series came out, I had to have it. I was pretty surprised as just how stealth heavy this game really was. With that said, if you don't enjoy slow sneaking, then don't bother with Thief. My playthrough was done with no HUD and almost all the difficulty multipliers. The game features 8 chapters in all with multiple side missions you can accept in between the story levels. The games hub world is compartmentalized into large areas of the aptly name, City. Guards patrol the streets which can hamper travelling from one side to another. The game rewards those that take things slow and study their surroundings. There are plenty of ways to reach the rooftops and rope arrow "anchor points" to reach open windows. The game excels when it presents some pretty difficult puzzles blocking the way to hidden loot. I found myself stumped a few times only to find that hidden switch or read a note with clues. Just trying to reach some areas in The City can be a puzzle in itself. The hub world feels like it recieved a lot of love in designing hours and hours of areas to pillage. The audio in this game seems like it was completely undone. NPCs will sometimes trigger audio loops saying the same thing over and over. Had I not had the difficulty cranked up, I would've put an arrow into every annoying NPC that was rambling about coffee or being cold. Some NPCs will also stop in the tracks, seemingly forgetting their programmed walking path. I also found the AI to be a bit unpredictable. Sometimes they would freak the hell out over an unlit torch and other times they were more concerned with how they could smell the river. Birds andd guard dogs will also alert enemies of your presence. The game didn't convey this but if a crow or dog is alerted, then you are considered detected even though you were able to slip away unseen. Overall the guards dont seem to be an improvement over the original series. They'll chase you for a while and then give up. Garrett isn't an exceptional fighter as he only has a blackjack (blunt weapon) to fight with. Unlike the original where he had a sword and later a dagger. The main story line is an overall disappointment. The first half of the game explains very little and it seems like you're solving a full blown mystery. This isn't at all a bad thing. A lot of the original game's story is absorbed simply through gameplay with the cutscenes just setting up the next heist. There were multiple times in the first half of the story where I thought there may be an introduction to the Hammerites, Pagans, or even the zombies of the original series. The story is mostly grounded in reality and goes into a really strange mysticism  route toward the end. It makes the last act of the game so incredibly disappointing that I wish I had stopped playing it at that point. Besides that, many of the levels feel like true, modern successors to the original series. In terms of sneaking and thieving, this game does a lot of things right. Its just a shame the storytelling was lackluster along with a few rough edges in audio design.
