content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Can I be blunt here? I played the original Thief games years ago. I liked them, though I never finished them. I played Thief 2014 a couple of months after it came out. I liked it and actually completed it. I won't be recommending though, due to the unavoidable issues that the game has, especially in the narrative, characterisation and level design department.It may be an unpopular opinion, but Thief 2014 is at least better than Thief Deadly Shadows. Of course, it isn't in the same league or plane of existence as the originals by Looking Glass but honestly, it isn't the worst Thief game. What I found playing it back in 2014 was that it felt like an upgrade to Deadly Shadows, improving on that game's shoddy performance issues which make it downright awful to even be able to play today. But lets get down to the nitty gritty review of this, quite frankly, utterly conventional reboot of a classic franchise. The large swathes of hate for this game came from, once again, unrealistic expectations being piled upon it. My only expectation was for it to be better than Thief 3 and I got that... by the fact that Thief 2014 is practically just a graphical update and can actually run on most PCs. It looks fairly nice for a console port from the new generation of consoles, though since the colour scheme is, well, nonexistent save grey, darker grey and pitch black, it isn't much of a marvel to look at by any means. The story and characters are so bland I can't even remember their names or any of their motivations. The rebooted version of Garrett is, quite simply, insulting to even the most passing of Thief fans. I kinda liked him in as the smug sarky social pariah he was portrayed as in the originals (and to a certain extent in Deadly Shadows) but I wasn't going to parade him through the streets as an shining exemplar to being a great game character. However, in Thief 2014, he's been boiled down to the barest minimum; gruff, unimaginative semi-violent white-guy no.2million. A Batman figure, pratically, dragging along the spunky sidekick girl apprentice for missions, who overplays the 'I don't need you around anymore, Gramps' vibe far too much.Thankfully, she is ditched from gameplay after the tutorial mission, thank God. However, the only real story thread revolves around Garrett sneaking into places to find out where she might be. That's it. She's embroiled in some kind of hilariously cliche McGuffin conspiracy plot that makes other hilariously cliche McGuffin conspiracy plots laugh out loud at it's sheer mundaneity. Overall, the plot is merely a framing device for the all the things the game feels it needs to rip off from other, better games, notably Dishonored. Moving on from the awfully poor narrative, the game revolves around an incredibly laborious hub world to navigate around, find collectibles and engage in burglary side missions. The map given to you for navigation is horrendously unintutive to use, as from it you are not able to piece together where exactly you are in terms of elevation or whether you are inside or outside. Interior and exterior mapping isn't layered, it's it own flipping layer! It calls for some of the worst map design I've seen in years, if not ever. Gameplay wise, it isn't all that bad. By playing the game as it's meant to be played (i.e. focus on staying in the shadows and getting to objectives by avoiding guards rather than taking them all out) is quite fun. Hardcore stealth is the best way to play and the game gives you a decent degree of customisation in order for it to feel just right as a hardcore stealth experience. There's an Iron Mode difficulty level (which doesn't allow for quicksave spamming/save scumming tactics at all) and the dumb 'Focus' ability ripped straight from AssCreed's Eagle vision, can be turned off in the options with no impact on story/level progression or collectible hunting. The wide amount of customisation options, accessed any time in either a mission or in the hub world. is welcome indeed. Garrett has the practically the same standard yet functional equipment he had in the last games. The water arrows extinguishes torches, the moss arrows grant him a quiet floor to traverse and the noisemaker arrow distracts guards. The rope arrows this time, are used entirely contextually in only a certain place, which sucks but isn't a dealbreaker. If the levels were as open as the original levels and this feature was included, then I'd be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥but as it stands the game Level design is strictly middle of the road. It's gone the Splinter Cell route of basically amounting to nothing more than either a corridor or a courtyard setup, together with having no more than a duo of guards to about 7 wandering around in any given areas. The cramped levels tightens the element of tension and, unlike Splinter Cell, doesn't feel quite as random when you are spotted. This game knows when Garrett is out in the open or huddled in a dark corner, and the AI respond appropriately. I'd have been ready to have gone far enough as write an angry letter to the developers or maybe held one of their kids to ransom had this been buggered up. The challenge comes from finding the right moment to move when guards aren't looking, which to me has always been the very essence of Thief as a series, it's signature element. Despite the ability to use different, un-Thief like playstyles, at its core the level design is built to highly encourage ghosting. My big gripe about the level design is by far the fact that points-of-no-return exist. It's baffling as to why they have included these, but it's no doubt a huge downer on allowing any of the missions to be enjoyable. With them, the game propels itself another 70million miles from the original games. I'm suprised I got so many hours out of this game. It was probably because, unlike Thief 3, I was so shocked to find out it didn't just crash on startup or loop the intro cutscene half a hundred times then crash, that I kept playing not noticing the sense of shock I was feeling. Yet of course, in the grand scheme of things with the franchise, 25 hours is probably enough time to see/steal everything in just one LEVEL in the original games. I was suprised I actually finished the god-awful story. Maybe it was the promise of the game delivering a pretty good horror segment around 2/3rds of the way through and a pretty sweet race across a burning bridge of buildings close to the finale. These certainly stand out among the highlights of the story and, for the most part they were nothing but 'set dressing'.Despite a good amount of things that it does quite decently (the ability to customise gameplay mechanics, the essense of Thief not totally lost but only hidden between the usual modern game standard ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, a really good horror level...), Thief 2014 is still a mostly unneccessary game, delivered to mostly newer gamers only to remind them that this series once existed back in the dawn of PC gaming and publishers be damned if they can't attempt to wease some life out of it yet for the new gaming generation. It's bland hubworld, lazy map design, uninspired colour palette, merely serviceable level design and truly horrible plot outweigh it's few yet significant strengths.To sum up, Thief 2014 is only slightly better than medicore. It pales in comparison to the original games and, while the stories of the originals and Deadly Shadows weren't that brilliant, the one in the reboot drags it down to bargain bin realms of quality. However, it isn't as bad as people have said. There are far worse games out of there obviously, and worse games which ruined their franchises. To me, Thief 2014 didn't ruin the Thief series as Deadly Shadows beat it to the punch. Though I'd be a fool to deny it didn't come bloody close.5/10

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This might have been such a good game.  As a long-time fan of the Thief franchise, I really, really wanted to like it. Unfortunately, the longer I played, the more the game's faults started to irk me, up to the point that I couldn't in good conscience recommend it unless the price goes down dramatically.Initially, my opinion was quite favourable. The game certainly looks pretty. Light effects and dynamic shadows are very realistic, and the first-person camera works better here than in almost any other game I can think of. Garrett's hands are just gorgeous and there's a strong sense of being physically present in the world. I didn't even mind the much-maligned context specific movement. Some of the missions were quite enjoyable. The story might be utterly forgettable and both the protagonist & the City have been given an unnecessary makeover (what's with the eyeshadow, Garrett?) but nevermind, it's a reboot and I can live with change... as long as the stealth gameplay itself offers the thrilling and robust experience I remember from previous Thief games.Unfortunately, this is where the game falters. Previous reviews have pointed out the outrageous flaws in Thief's audio design so I won't go there except to say that yes, it really *is* bad. NPC awareness seems to fluctuate wildly: guards often won't react to loud noises like breaking glass and knocking stuff over, but on other times they seem to magically detect the player even when crouching well clear and in dark shadow. The game's light gem is really inconsistent and visually it's difficult to see the dark spots the designers have meant for you to hide in, as opposed to darkish-looking places that are only there for show and offer no cover whatsoever.I played the game on Master difficulty, and about half-way through I started hoping I didn't - not because the game was too hard (it really wasn't), but because it made moving around the City hub an exercise in tedium. The City is a hopeless, frustrating mess of constricted pathways that at first promises freedom of exploration but quickly reveals itself to be just a claustrophobic maze with only few ways to pass through. There are certain choke points in the City that you end up crossing dozens of times as you track side quests and missions, and slowly sneaking around the same set of guards for the umpteenth time quickly grows old. By mid-game, I really wanted to play on an easier difficulty so I could just snipe the city guards full of arrows, or simply run past them. These choke points are made even more maddening by a terrible audio glitch that replays snippets of NPC dialogue over and over in an endless loop for as long as you stay in that area. An example: 


YouTube™ Video: Jebediah Chokes is a right prick! 

			Views: 462		

			A couple of of guys in Thief voicing their opinion. Repetedly		

 Should you resort to blackjacking the guards to shut them up, well... bad news,  every time you go through a loading screen the guards are reset and back in action. And there's a lot of loading screens, even entering one-room random apartments often results in one.So, moving around the City is time-consuming and frustrating, and the maps are no help at all. They're confusing, badly executed and glitchy: at one point, the minimap went crazy and reversed north, south, Garrett's direction and the location of the quest markers completely. The most frustrating thing, however, is the lack of freedom in missions and the City hub. Instead of free-form exploration and clever tactics that made the first two Thief games (and the third, to a lesser degree) so exhilaratingly immersive, the game wants you to follow pretty narrow pre-designed paths. What's worse, sometimes in missions you open a door or a window, and without warning the game will transition you to a new area... with no way back. No matter that you still had half a manor to explore and loot to grab - the designers think that the plot has moved on and so should you! Adding insult to injury, there are several scripted points when you are detected and need to flee, following an exact path decided by the designers. Trying to be creative by attempting to climb a wrong wall or taking a wrong turn results in a quick scripted death. There are weird platform jumper sections and puzzles that are so insulting to the player's intelligence that it begs the question why they were included in the first place. Most times there simply is no way to get the puzzle wrong: you just need to press the buttons the game tells you to press, in the order that the game tells you. Thief is not an absolute disaster of a game. I certainly enjoyed some of it. It's just an unpolished, awkward mess that tries to include every trick the designers learned from recent games like Assassin's Creed and Dishonored, while getting wrong the core experience of original Thief classics.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												I'm torn on the recommendation and here is why.Environment, atmosphere, graphics, gameplay was all outstanding. Map design was hit and miss, some places far too linear but some were great. Sound was an afterthought in this game. Tons of sound issues, looping, double sounds playing over each other, volume issues, hit & miss voice acting. Unlike previous games, sound really is not an integral part of gameplay. Lots of AI issues during gameplay, especially with guards not moving. Usually a save game or checkpoint reload will fix the issue. As a stealth game I felt I got my $60 and would recommend it to the average player. 6/10. Would be 7 or 8 if it didn't have all the bugs, sound and performance issues. They should be able to eventually patch this.As a long time taffer, I'd have to give this "Thief" game a 3/10. I've been playing Thief since release in 1998, and still play to this day. The System shock series and Thief are still in my top 5 games list. I believe most hardcore Thief fans like myself, are going to be very dissapointed with this title. If a company is going to retain all the IP and legal rights to a game, why waste it by throwing it out the window? There are some references in the game, and items which you might consider easter eggs that pay omage to the old games. They should have left this a stealth game in the Thief universe and left it at that.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Unfinished and unpolished. These two words spring to mind after playing this game. Don't get me wrong, it's far from a horrible game....it's just not a very good one. Thief tricks you into thinking it's a well made AAA title in the first few play sessions but with every hour more spent on the game, the cracks really begin to show. Thief for the first half of the game is a really fun and clever game with a true sense of immersion that most games fail to achieve. I felt like I really had control of Garett and his every movement had a true sense of weight to it. I liked the integration of stealth, it felt fresh and original to me. The graphics and art style really stood out to me and praise really has to go to the art team behind this game; Thief truly does look incredible with it's excellent lighting and slick model animations.Once the second half of the game approached, I started to grow tired of Thief's poor design choices throughout. 'The city' main hub is clearly intended to act as a sort of sandbox style of area where you are encouraged to explore however the poor layout, constant alerts by poorly placed guards, unecessary loading screens, invisible walls, and lack of freedom make it more of a chore to play in. The story also started to get a few too many loose ends which wasn't helped by some poor voice acting and weak script. Where Thief really shines is when it doesn't try to hard and simply sticks to the core stealth elements. The development team really nailed these sections. It's unfortunatly overshadowed by far too many action sequences that try to be cleverly inserted simply to "beef up" the game, when in reality they simply are not needed and certainly detract from the overall experience. Again, Thief is a fun game for the first few hours and does propose some very clever and original game mechanics....it just never realises it's true potential. Worth getting if it's cheap or a free game but not worth full price unfortunatly. Hopefully if ever a sequel emerges, these serious issues are ironed out and we truly get the game this one could have and should have been.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												If you're trying to play this game as a previous fan of the series, stop right there. You don't need to waste your time with this "reboot" of the Thief franchise. It's sloppy, unpolished, and generally uninteresting.      As a huge fan of the Thief series, this reboot was the last thing any one of the fans wanted. With massive talents quitting the studio during Theif's development, it should have been a fairly good sign that things were turning to the dark side.      Gameplay. Hoo boy, that's a doozy. First off, contextual jumping NEVER works the way players expect. In previous Thief titles, you could freely jump, peek around corners, and generally feel like a theif with more dexterity than a drunk burrick. This reboot throws all of that out the window. Too many times I've fallen from the roofs and narrow walkways of this horrible reincarnation of The City because I simply wasn't in the right place at the right time to press the space bar.     Instead of using Q and E for leaning (or whatever your preference), you have to first be near a corner to press E, the main function button to start a locked player stance of peering around corners. It's blocky, non-intuitive, and it takes immersion out of the game. Why you may ask? Because having to go through extra steps to make sure you're actually on a surface deemed acceptable to the engine to be peeked around is pretty awful when you could normally just press a button to peek.     Story. Another damn doozy. Take what was awesome from the Thief series and throw it out the window. If you know how Garrett got his mechanical eye, that is no longer present here. Instead you get some mystical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t crystal stuck in your eye, which has no great effect for you. The mechanical eye allowed players to zoom in on distant targets, and it was crafted by a chaotic good type faction: The Hammerites. They are all but missing from Thief. (Don't even start with the cathedral, that was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.) Voice acting was dull, and the story just felt lifeless and not quite as interesting as the earlier games. You don't feel for the other characters since they just seem too over the top, or too lifeless.     Graphics, ehhh. Okay, it's not a horrible looking game by any stretch...but thats because most of the maps are smaller than your most recent FPS levels. I'm not kidding. You have to sit through annoying window opening, or crawlspace animations before meeting a loading screen that lasts far too long for each small area. How did level size suddenly disintigrate from earlier games, when this game totes the famous line of being the "next gen."     In summary, if you're a fan of the game, you're better off pocketing the money and finding another title to spend your money on.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												So I got thief on a special deal and decided, before i play it, to play Thief Gold. Thief Gold is the original and features many great things. It has a range of arrows that the player can use to do a lot of things from putting out torches to causing distractions on the other side of the room. It is older than me so my hopes were not that high but it is still a very challenging game. But anyway, to the game in question. The first thing I noticed was the fantastic PC port. I was not expecting this but you can change almost everything including controls, audio, graphics etc. Jumping into the game I found myself in a world of grim beauty. The artwork creates a very good atmosphere along with the eary music that keeps you on edge. Those are all nice things but after completing a couple missions I realised the city/hub world was an "always on". The guards will always want to kill you and that makes getting around to the shops quite annoying. I read some reviews of people saying they liked this as it was good for practising but I found it more of a nuisance. Another unneeded nuisance is that, as far as I know, the only way to increase arrow holding capacity is to buy three extra DLCs all 79p each. It seems cheap but I do not want to pay money for something they could neatly add as the player gains more focus points. That leads me on to the skill points in thief called focus points. They are gained from completing certain missions and by paying in game gold to "The Queen of Beggars" for an ever increasing price. This is fine. I am perfectly happy with the gaining of focus points but not so happy with the usage. The skill "Trees", even though they are barely branches, consist of two perks; one will read something along the lines of "Slightly encrease your ability to..." the second one will be along the lines of "Majorly encrease your ability to...". I do not see a point in having them if they barely do anything. Even the first branch gets given a point already allocated to it before you get given an open map, leaving one space left for upgrade that early on in the game.The puzzles were another thing that stood out to me. They all seemed so forced like a cry of attension reminding everyone you bought a game with more than stealth. THey never really fit into place and delay the proper gameplay. At the end of each level you are "rewarded" for how you played. I say "Rewarded" because I have yet to see what it does besides XP. The three wins you can get are Opportunist, Predator and Ghost. I put them in order of how good it feels to get them, Opportunist being last. Opportunist is where you steal a lot of things and put out the most light sources but doesn't feel as rewarding as the others. In the first mission it teels the that the main character, Garrett, is against killing people then lets you get rewarded for killing as many people as possible. The game should strive towards making people want Ghost or Opportunist, not just Ghost.Another thing that made me want to steal less was the fact houses had around 2 things to loot in them and some even had really oddly placed traps that make their houses unsusable and just dumb thief killing machines.The combat was actually quite clever. In the original you were given a sword and blackjack, but in this game you do not get a sword. This makes people want to do more stealth than if they could just complete the game with stabing everyone under the sun. The blackjack is still used for takedowns ,although in an animation format instead a 'Click to hit' way, but you can press 'r' (by default) to hit with your blackjack. One verse one battles are easy enough with correct dodging along with one verse two battles, but any more and you are certain to loose life.Overall Thief was still a good game, it has an immaculate stealth system and an atmosphere that keeps you on edge with the chance of guards always being around the corner. I will compare it to the original and say it clung to it like it should. So I will give this game 7/10 as it seems completely finished just could be better in all the above stated reasons. :3

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												I never played the previous Thief games, so I had no predetermined expectations about what the franchise should be. My only hope was for a good game, but unfortunately for every part of the game that I enjoyed, there was something else that I didn't like.The player takes on the role of Garrett who, as the title suggests, earns his living as a thief. When one job goes wrong, Garrett stumbles into a conspiracy involving high society and a touch of the supernatural. The following story is okay, but it never really excited me, and I didn't find any of the characters interesting.Thief's gameplay is primarily focused on stealth. You'll want to stick to the shadows and either avoid guards/civilians entirely, or sneak up behind and perform silent takedowns. One very good design decision is that the player decides how forgiving the stealth system is, in the difficulty options. If you want detection to mean instant failure, go for it. If, like me, you prefer to have the ability to fight through your mistakes, you can do that too.However, the combat is terrible, so you should avoid it unless you have no choice. Both the bow and the melee weapon are slow and weak, and Garrett's armour is paper thin, even when you've bought their upgrades. Taking on more than two enemies simultaneously is almost certain death. This may be realistic, but its not fun.There are three types of missions. Story and client missions are mostly enjoyable. These require you to break into a unique building and steal a special item which will advance either Garrett's story, or a smaller arc for one of two friendly NPCs. The buildings tend to be quite large, have multiple entrance points and hidden paths to reach your goal while providing excellent stealth opportunities.Side missions don't have a purpose beyond earning extra coin, which you can also get by stealing from random houses along your path. These all take place in the City hub areas, which is the weakest part of the game. The level design here is very narrow, full of dead ends and only one or two paths through. Even if you ignore these minor missions, you still have to travel through the City to reach the story missions. There's no fast travel option, so the amount of times you have to bypass the same respawning guards, while listening to their one line of repeated dialogue, quickly becomes tedious. You'll also notice that most houses are empty, which makes the City feel lifeless.It wouldn't be fair for me to comment on graphics because I'm currently below recommended spec for gfx card, so I had to do some tweaking to get a reasonable framerate. Controls are fully rebindable and work fine with mouse and keyboard. Most elements of the HUD can be customised to find your desired balance between functionality and immersion. It took me 17 hours to finish the main quest, and I skipped some side quests, so value for money is good.Overall I don't think Thief deserves a thumbs down, but I also wouldn't view it as an essential purchase.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Well, Thief is a game that makes me contradict myself a lot. Personally, how I feel about this game is split in half after I have finished half of the game play. I understand people when they say that they have cherished the old Thief games more than they do this, however, as much as it has flaws I found this game pretty entertaining so far.First of all, I am against comparing the latest game of the series to the previous ones because Thief on its own is a game that makes you feel as if you are playing a completely different game, as if it does not belong to the series and such games should be reviewed seperately from the rest. Here are the things that have caught my attention so far:+ The gameplay may either be fast paced or very slow. It totally depends on how you wanna roll. The fact that game offers you an aggressive approach even though you should not be playing a stealth game aggressively, is quite appealing imho. ( I am the aggressive type, what can I say ?) There are many options to how you may finish a chapter in this game and that is a huge advantage for Thief, pretty much since gameplay is the biggest entertainment source that a game like Thief may have. + Despite all the frame rate issues that I have pretty often, the visuals are outstanding to be honest. The dark, gloomy city is amazing and definitely makes you feel the atmosphere. I find this to be an important fact too since the game has to cover up for the lack of story coherence at some point, which is an aspect that I will talk about next.+ Controls are a huuuuge thing in this game. Everything is sooo responsive that Garrett immediately responds to every bit of control. After all, this is how a stealth game should be anyways. Considering how the responsiveness has improved the quality gameplay time, I am really glad they have paid attention to this. The moment the game tells you to walk in the water, you will start appreciating the flawlessness of the control design of the game.- I really love open world games, and I was really happy to see that this one is also one of that kind however the worst point that an open world game could get to would probably be not having any side quests. Luckily Thief does a little bit better than that ! But unfortunately sidequests are extremely linear and all about going somewhere and stealing something. That is it. If it had more versatility, the fact that it had some nice sidequests could have made me review this game much more positively. (Even tho I already am reviewing it positively, so imagine.)- Story sucks. Literally. Well I get that they have wanted to change it, tune it a bit but seriously it is really annoying to see even after you finish half of the game and yet do not understand a thing because of the lack of details and the cutscenes that feel like they do not belong or fit anywhere in the story. At the beginning it makes you feel like it has a great potential however I promise you, you never get to see that potential and it is just sad.- Music may get annoying after a while, at least it did for me so turning it down a bit helped a lot while trying to get into the game. With all these advantages, disadvantages and flaws, I really enjoyed Thief. I agree that it may not be the most memorable game neither of the series nor of the last year however it has some great potential with that gameplay. I also do not understand the hate pointed at it because people tend to bash something quite easily just because it does not look like the previous versions. So try it out and you may really enjoy it even though it is not perfect.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												For a game trying so hard to be Dishonored, you'd think it take some of the things people liked about Dishonored. The level design was the standout part of Dishonored, with open, expansive levels with plenty of paths and secrets. At first glance, Thief's levels look like they have a taken a page from the same playbook Dishonored copy-pasted from, but once you explore a little, you'll realize that there is never more than two paths on each level. There is a level where you have to sneak into a mansion. There were two obvious paths into the mansion: one through the front door, surrounded by about six guards with the intelligence of a Michael Bay fan; and another path leading to a vent, which was completely unguarded. I first went through the vent but, upon realizing that the vent just put me behind the front door, I reloaded and played the other path. Another bonus of Dishonored were the abilities, each of which had their own use for exploring the levels. Thief's abilities are almost all boring passives, that I didn't upgrade at all after the initial level. Thief's abilities have no use in the levels, they open no new paths. There is almost no point to stealing things after the first few levels, as once you have the wrench and the wirecutters, the upgrades are almost completely useless. The focus is lifted right out of Hitman: Absolution because originality is hard. The game pretends to encourage different playstyles but anything other than pure stealth is completely unreasonable. The only way to kill guards is the bow and all of the lethal arrows are absurdly expensive. I'm alright with a game being a stealth game, Square Enix, you don't need to cater to the ritalin popping droolers who get bored when their fellow man isn't being exterminated at a rapid pace. Have some backbone and stick to your guns: If you want to make a stealth game, make a stealth game.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Having never played the original thief games I was not sure what to expect from this game. I did like dishonored, which I thought was a decent game, nothing amazing. Do I think this is a better game than dishonored? Yes and no.Technically the game is nice looking, I'm running 1600p with a 290x and it runs nice. The typical unreal engine stuttering and texture loading is an annoyance, but not a game breaker. What the MAJOR pain for me is the layout of cities with loading sections  littered all over the place when going through windows.The button bashing when opening a window is an obvious attempt to mask loading times. The objective markers are vague and had me trying to find ways into some places which were not on the current map, I needed to go through a loading window and go around behind. These are the flaws in my opinion which stop this from being a great game. Last gen cross platform games are still hurting people with PCs and new consoles.I'm not going to bother discussing the plot, because it's about as interesting as watching paint dry.With all the above flaws the game is enjoyable. Gameplay is more enjoyable than dishonored while technically dishonored is more accomplished.+Graphical lighting effects+Dark and dank, but always looking pretty+Gameplay is satisfying and sucks you in+Nice sound effects-Crap story-Technical limitations of engine breakup the fun-Boring charactersOverall a good game which does great in some areas and falls flat on it's♥♥♥♥♥in other.8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												So I got thief on a special deal and decided, before i play it, to play Thief Gold. Thief Gold is the original and features many great things. It has a range of arrows that the player can use to do a lot of things from putting out torches to causing distractions on the other side of the room. It is older than me so my hopes were not that high but it is still a very challenging game. But anyway, to the game in question. The first thing I noticed was the fantastic PC port. I was not expecting this but you can change almost everything including controls, audio, graphics etc. Jumping into the game I found myself in a world of grim beauty. The artwork creates a very good atmosphere along with the eary music that keeps you on edge. Those are all nice things but after completing a couple missions I realised the city/hub world was an "always on". The guards will always want to kill you and that makes getting around to the shops quite annoying. I read some reviews of people saying they liked this as it was good for practising but I found it more of a nuisance. Another unneeded nuisance is that, as far as I know, the only way to increase arrow holding capacity is to buy three extra DLCs all 79p each. It seems cheap but I do not want to pay money for something they could neatly add as the player gains more focus points. That leads me on to the skill points in thief called focus points. They are gained from completing certain missions and by paying in game gold to "The Queen of Beggars" for an ever increasing price. This is fine. I am perfectly happy with the gaining of focus points but not so happy with the usage. The skill "Trees", even though they are barely branches, consist of two perks; one will read something along the lines of "Slightly encrease your ability to..." the second one will be along the lines of "Majorly encrease your ability to...". I do not see a point in having them if they barely do anything. Even the first branch gets given a point already allocated to it before you get given an open map, leaving one space left for upgrade that early on in the game.The puzzles were another thing that stood out to me. They all seemed so forced like a cry of attension reminding everyone you bought a game with more than stealth. THey never really fit into place and delay the proper gameplay. At the end of each level you are "rewarded" for how you played. I say "Rewarded" because I have yet to see what it does besides XP. The three wins you can get are Opportunist, Predator and Ghost. I put them in order of how good it feels to get them, Opportunist being last. Opportunist is where you steal a lot of things and put out the most light sources but doesn't feel as rewarding as the others. In the first mission it teels the that the main character, Garrett, is against killing people then lets you get rewarded for killing as many people as possible. The game should strive towards making people want Ghost or Opportunist, not just Ghost.Another thing that made me want to steal less was the fact houses had around 2 things to loot in them and some even had really oddly placed traps that make their houses unsusable and just dumb thief killing machines.The combat was actually quite clever. In the original you were given a sword and blackjack, but in this game you do not get a sword. This makes people want to do more stealth than if they could just complete the game with stabing everyone under the sun. The blackjack is still used for takedowns ,although in an animation format instead a 'Click to hit' way, but you can press 'r' (by default) to hit with your blackjack. One verse one battles are easy enough with correct dodging along with one verse two battles, but any more and you are certain to loose life.Overall Thief was still a good game, it has an immaculate stealth system and an atmosphere that keeps you on edge with the chance of guards always being around the corner. I will compare it to the original and say it clung to it like it should. So I will give this game 7/10 as it seems completely finished just could be better in all the above stated reasons. :3

Posted: February 20, 2015
												The screenshots and video clips looked promising. The reviews sounded promising as well. I was fairly pumped to get the game.Boy was I disappointed.While this game looks fantastic, and parts of the gameplay are fantastic as well, I felt that the game went off down a really strange path with the storyline by introducing ghosts and whatnot that, for the lack of a better explanation, simply felt weird. I wasn't sure that I was playing the same game after a few chapters or that I was a thief. After all the game is called Thief, not ghost hunter.The controls fell short as well. The characters movements felt extremely unnatural and even lacks the ability to jump. Yes, you can't jump. What a basic movement. Crouching and running felt awkward and I died several times because of this.They only weapons you get are arrows, and those are far and few between. Good luck actually fighting anyone. There's tons of swords, why can't you use them? Sure, the game is about stealth but even ninjas have knifes and swords.I don't even think I'd recommend this game if it was free. The headache and frustration simply aren't worth it. Spare your sanity and find something better.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												I never played the previous Thief games, so I had no predetermined expectations about what the franchise should be. My only hope was for a good game, but unfortunately for every part of the game that I enjoyed, there was something else that I didn't like.The player takes on the role of Garrett who, as the title suggests, earns his living as a thief. When one job goes wrong, Garrett stumbles into a conspiracy involving high society and a touch of the supernatural. The following story is okay, but it never really excited me, and I didn't find any of the characters interesting.Thief's gameplay is primarily focused on stealth. You'll want to stick to the shadows and either avoid guards/civilians entirely, or sneak up behind and perform silent takedowns. One very good design decision is that the player decides how forgiving the stealth system is, in the difficulty options. If you want detection to mean instant failure, go for it. If, like me, you prefer to have the ability to fight through your mistakes, you can do that too.However, the combat is terrible, so you should avoid it unless you have no choice. Both the bow and the melee weapon are slow and weak, and Garrett's armour is paper thin, even when you've bought their upgrades. Taking on more than two enemies simultaneously is almost certain death. This may be realistic, but its not fun.There are three types of missions. Story and client missions are mostly enjoyable. These require you to break into a unique building and steal a special item which will advance either Garrett's story, or a smaller arc for one of two friendly NPCs. The buildings tend to be quite large, have multiple entrance points and hidden paths to reach your goal while providing excellent stealth opportunities.Side missions don't have a purpose beyond earning extra coin, which you can also get by stealing from random houses along your path. These all take place in the City hub areas, which is the weakest part of the game. The level design here is very narrow, full of dead ends and only one or two paths through. Even if you ignore these minor missions, you still have to travel through the City to reach the story missions. There's no fast travel option, so the amount of times you have to bypass the same respawning guards, while listening to their one line of repeated dialogue, quickly becomes tedious. You'll also notice that most houses are empty, which makes the City feel lifeless.It wouldn't be fair for me to comment on graphics because I'm currently below recommended spec for gfx card, so I had to do some tweaking to get a reasonable framerate. Controls are fully rebindable and work fine with mouse and keyboard. Most elements of the HUD can be customised to find your desired balance between functionality and immersion. It took me 17 hours to finish the main quest, and I skipped some side quests, so value for money is good.Overall I don't think Thief deserves a thumbs down, but I also wouldn't view it as an essential purchase.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												This has nothing to do with the original series and is much worse than the first three Thieves. Admittedly, that's a high bar to clear. But even judged on its own merit, this is not a good game. The level design is linear, your tools of the trade only work on designated spots (jump included!), the writing is bad, the sound design very flawed (the volume is all over the place). Moreover this screams "consolitis" unashamedly: For example if you play with keyboard and mouse, you must not turn off the frame-search helper, otherwise you won't know where a hidden button behind a picture frame is. Players with a gamepad get a vibration, for kb+m there is no alternative apart from a UI signal.Everyone forgot about this game, its price fell and there were no cry for more.Do yourself a favor and buy the first three Thieves. Or play them again. Or play the Dark Mod. Nothing to see here, just a butchered series.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
What to pay to be happy with the purchase : < $20, < €17TLDR : Incredibly dissapointing. Dishonoured is a far superior game overall. THEIF is a dumbed down console game through and through. Simplistic maps and a shoddily implemented story really let down the artists/animators/coders that worked on the game. Compared to other titles, the initial price tag of 60 euro is insane. So much more could have been done with the components and IP they have here, but ultimately the oddly mismatching visual art and gameplay make sense when you did deeper. Reading up on the tumultuous developement history THEIF which dares take the name of the original franchise, is nothing more than an admirable last ditched revenue recovery, however as a title, it's mediocre.------------------------------------------------------------The BAD :The plot is disjointed and jarring, giving the impression they've hacked great chunks out with a blunt axe at the last minute. Important chunks. Like hearts and livers, not little fingers or toes.You have to spam E to open windows, which you can't cancel out of. Going through a window often causes a load screen, even if the "house" you're going into is a single small room. The entire game is extremely sectionalized, and there are many, many, many load screens. It wouldn't be so bad if you didn't have to go through several screens just to go upgrade your gear or buy new arrows.The stealth system, one of the main parts of the game, seems little more advanced than Skyrims.You're funneled down paths. Choice is an poor illusion here. Cool toys like the rope arrow have their potential wasted, given they can only be used at set locations. You can't even swing on ropes. Often you'll be a short distance from a hand hold, but garret will clutch the rope, unmoving, like a scared child.You have a claw with a rope on it, which you use in maybe two "press X" contextual locations, Even although you can rappel with it, at no point are you allowed to manually rappel or use the rope-claw.If you die, several locations will respawn you in the light, right in view of a guard.The upgrades aren't explained well at all, and have little to no effect.Every time someone swings at you for the first time in combat, a dialogue box pops up telling you to press V to dodge. (see my Thief video for an example.)The noises you make in mele combat seem to come from a completely diffent voice actor than Garret, almost sounding female at times.Trying to get GHOST rankings is infuriating, and not fun. Apparently picking a pocket is not ghostly.Side missions would be much more cool if the city were open world once you completed the game or something, but it's not, so doing them becomes a slog of load screens.Reloading the the clock tower area a few times seems to cause a memory leak or something.Stealing things doesn't make you feel good. Most of the stuff you steal that you can use for cash is very low value, making going out of your way to lift shiny things somewhat pointless. The biggest steals are cosmetic, and even then they aren't very ... "cosmetical" ... some of them are even just a tickbox inside a chest in your hideout.The GOODLockpicking has been done far better than assassins creed 3, but that isn't hard. In fact it's probably the most tollerable lock picking I've seen in a game to date. It actually feels quite good.I really like how you need to shoot people in an exposed area of the face to headshot them. If they so much as tilt their head at the wrong moment and your arrow hits the brim of their helmet, you're screwed.The game is admittedly very pretty in places.The game for the most part makes good use of resources. Even on highest graphics you wont notice much frame drop with a good, but 3 year old PC.Camera work is near flawless.

I loved the other Thief games, and i even still play them sometimes, but after just 3 hours of gameplay, i became bored and tired of the constant 7 FPS, the unlogical stealth system, no nostalgic enemies, stealing knives, headshotting enemies without killing them and the story. I dont recommend this game, but if you really want it, wait until theres a sale. 4/10 from me.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This game broke me. I haven't played a game to bore me this much since... actually, as a matter of fact any game that I buy and bores me under 2 hours I decide to refund it. I bought this back in 2014, at about 2 months after its launch. Haven't installed it for 2 weeks, like the total fagot that I am, started playing, and I was bored to death, uninstall it, hide it in my library forever. Now, it's summer time and I decide to come back to some of the older games to get some avg completion rate for my 'chievos.And now we come to the actual game, and let me start right off the bat that the game isn't fffffFFF♥♥♥♥ING HORRIBLE, ALRIGHT?? There is no need to melodramatise this review for no reason, just as pretty much the rest of the negative reviews are doing it. And before you start downvoting this review for actually being positive, keep in mind this is one man's opinion AND I'm trying to understand the loyal fans of the series. Believe me, I do. For a fact I haven't played any of the previous Thief games myself, however I DID see speedruns and let's plays and I have to agree that the games sure are awesome, even for this time. But now, not as a fan but just as a guy that decided to play this game, let's get riiiiiiiiiiiight into the- nah, not doing the Keemstar thing. This is Thief.Actual review:If you haven't already guessed the premise by the title alone, God, I just don't know what a Thief does in this world, he surely doesn't, you know... STEAL people's belongings by any chance, does he? No, he actually just gives random foot rubs to all civilian he encounters and kisses them on the cheek to say "Good night".And yes, you steal stuff. Lots of it.What is the actual story behind this game? Well, imagine Dishonored without all of the cool powers. Then you got Thief, ez pz. The long version is that the city you live in with the name of... "city", has caught a disease called "the gloom". In the game, we don't get to see anything of what the gloom does, so we'll call it dibs and say it's just death. Or black plague the becoming/part 2/whatever. In this dark age, quite formerly and literally, as we'll see about that in a bit, the world, or more like, the "city" is being ruled only by royal blood and the rich, which gets the time period just right. Well, that and the fact that there is an unnatural power that apparently touching you turns you to Superman and the rest get transformed into big scary african monsters. WE ALL LEARNED THAT AT THE HISTORY CLASS, DON'T DENY IT!That was the overall of the world, by my understanding anyway. And I think by devs standards, too. The other half of the coin consists of the protagonist of the franchise, Garret, following through his new adventure of stealing♥♥♥♥♥♥/span> saving his sidekick from becoming a godess of destruction and stopping a crazy man of injecting 'juana into people to make them the big scary african monsters. That's not what I had in mind. Especially since we're talking about a game where your main goal is to, you know, steal things. Let's just say you rob the levels in the process, so that counts. Now, onto the gameplay!Since we're talking about thieving people of their belongings, the whole idea of the game is to stealth your way through everything, using your well-acquired gear as well as your Superman powers. Before getting to these subjects, the first is the light and dark mechanics from the previous games. This is your stealth folks: stay in the dark, remain hidden, stay in the light and everyone sees you. Even a 1st year student on game developing can make this happen, how can a big company such as Eidos could ♥♥♥♥ this up? Oh wait, THEY DID ♥♥♥♥ IT UP!A lot, and I mean it, a LOT of the ♥♥♥♥ing areas, both in the hub and the chapters have these places where you can stay right under the lamp post in the middle of the crowd and stay unseen OR stay in a corner covered in darkness but there is this one particle of light and you're given away, just like that. Mates, if you couldn't get the one thing right about a stealth game, that being your actual stealth, you blew it day-♥♥♥♥ing-one. GOD!Ugh, I feel bored already. Giving to its credit, there are multiple ways of making your way in or out of a place and the whole game can be beaten as a ghost main. You can access these ways with your gear, which may include a wrench for opening up vents, a prybar for windows, rope arrows(self explanatory), and my favourite: the claw, for reaching higher ground places. Now there aren't that many ways of going your way around(about 2 or 3 per mission), and I think that hurts the game quite a bit, mostly in replayability. Instead, if you want to replay the whole damn thing, you will have to go for all of the loot and collectibles, as well as completing the mission objectives, which aren't that special, but they're there and give extra money at the end of it, which never hurts. On the other hand, the collectibles are looking fantastic, always feels so NICE to get one expensive piece of jewelry made out of gold and all sorts of precious stones and gems with all sorts of meanings behind them. There are also plaques you will find across the city, as well as paintings, which whoever designed them has a mind beyond our plane of existence. He makes furry porn. That's about it.Now to the chapters and the hub said earlier, that's your game. There are a total of 8 chapters and a couple of side-quests and jobs. The hub itself is pretty big, with a lot of areas to explore and collect all of the possible loot. Too bad you can't keep exploring without stumbling on a loading screen. No seriously, what's up with that? I swear that I have waited through more loading screens than my entire Fallout New Vegas career. Hell, Fallout 4 at that. What, did the devs had a problem making the hub actually... OPEN TO EXPLORE?! Not only that, some aparments have thein own loading screens. And they bear nothing. Maybe a collectible and some loot, but no life, no guards, no extra hidden room, no NOTHING. So just a huge waste of time of yet another loading screen. I swear they have a fetish for this. One last thing about the hub is that it actually changes while progressing the storyline, but not by a lot. A few more npcs are added, some guards are removed, some added, nothing particularly noticable, but they are there. Also, from the earlier "dark ages point", I'm surprised how there is no single crack of sunlight to be seen anywhere in the game. Guess they took the dark part a bit too literal.The chapters themselves... oh god. Let me tell you that the first half is BORING. It feels like all of those levels are part of the tutorial, and that is simply a bad move, as I never felt like I had any of the liberty the game gives you in the the second half. And if you managed to get to chapter 5, that, my friends, is finally the point where the game is starting to feel alive, which is ironic for anyone knowing this chapter. Anyway, from this point I started to see the ways around, use my water arrows to extinguish fire, create mayhem through the guards by simply throwing one bottle and there are so SO many things I was able to do here that I couldn't do previously. Truth be told, I had a lot of fun in these chapters! To the point where I said this game is worth the damn purchase! But it just takes so long until then you'll most likely die of the boredom more than anything else. That and fall damage loltl;dr To recap, the stealth is broken, the first half is painfully boring and the upgrades are questionable. But beyond that, in the other half the game is playable it I felt like it was worth spending my time there. The final verdict for Thief is a 6.5/10. I'd say that if you catch this under 10 bucks, it's good. If you find it at 5, you're golden. Steam can't let me write anymore, so I say this has been one man's review, the decision is all up to you.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Felt Like I Was Playing an Unfinished GameThe long and the short of it is this: Thief is, quite simply, not a game I would ever recommend playing. To anyone. Do I regret playing it? Not exactly; some parts of the game were fun and enjoyable. But on a whole, I could have spent that time on a better, more worthwhile game. Dishonored and the original Thief games come to mind, and I've heard good things about Deus Ex. I have a few main reasons for disliking it this game: bad gameplay, poor level design, and low quality writing.GameplayI found the gameplay to be severely underdeveloped, counter-intuitive, and choppy. There is no "lean" control as there is in Dishonored and Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Not only can you not perform this simple motion wherever and whenever you like in Thief, but if you're going to look around a corner you have to approach the corner and press E. Which is the action button for everything. So while you are searching a desk, you may find that Garrett gets in one of his jumpy moods and suddenly huddles behind it, peeking cautiously around the corner at...nothing. All because this feature was poorly designed. Also, counter-intuitive actions. You hold E to peek through a keyhole and press right-mouse to stop? Who thought of that awful idea? It makes sense to me that you press one button to start an action and the same button to stop it.Also, whose idea was it to have the player spend gold on upgrades that make a task harder? I spent some good money on upgrading Dexterity. Does the upgrade make lockpicking easier? NO. It is more tedious, it takes longer, and it uses Focus. Bad, bad idea.Level DesignOn several occasions while I played the game, I found myself unclear on what I was supposed to be doing and how I was supposed to do it. The tasks and how to accomplish them just weren't always clear, and it's not because I'm an inexperienced gamer or don't know what I'm doing, it's because the level and the sequence of events/objectives was not thoroughly developed.Also, was anyone else frustrated by an apparent inability to use rich text in the documents? It's really not that hard, guys. Couldn't you just write an italicized word like this rather than *like this*? Nothing interferes with a game's immersion like seeing that kind of notation to remind you that you're not, in fact, a thief in The City during a time period similar to the 19th century; you are in fact in the 21st century, playing a disappointing game.A note on graphics: it was excessive. I turned all of the settings all the way down on my computer, and it still crashed a good 20 times or so. I've played games with great graphics on my computer (all 3 Bioshock games, Portal 2, The Talos Principle, etc) that never made it crash; Thief could have easily been a good-looking game that didn't have a seizure every hour or so.Writing...Do I even need to say much on this? So much drama. The dialogue was sub-par, and Erin is the most annoying, angst-filled teenage girl I've ever seen in a game. The story of the game just felt...dry.ConclusionThief was a game that tried to be everything that Dishonored was, and fell miserably short. Dishonored benefited from a rich and immersive story, fluid and intuitive gameplay, and well-designed levels that gave the player options without confusing them; Thief had none of these in its favor. Eidos missed a great opportunity to make Thief into a fantastic reboot, and they could have done it if they had held themselves to a higher standard and taken the time to produce a quality game. Unfortunately, they didn't, and this is the result.

												I only beat this game because I paid $60 for it at release. It's worth maybe $10 at most. I'd pay $10 just to play the Asylum level once, but other than that, the rest of the game is horrifically linear and rather boring. It's just not worth full price at any time. Wait for a <$10 sale, play past the asylum level, as it's the high point of the game, and then go back and play the other Thief games, which are actually good stealth games.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												I had high hopes for this game and honestly im pretty satisfied. Graphically this game is dark gritty and beautiful. I run this at max setting in 1920x1080 with no issues at all save the cutscenes which seem to lag a bit with the voice.The game play isnt much diffrent from the other thief games. They have added new tools and a nice upgrade system. The focus abilities to me seem a bit overkill for most of the options but do add some thing for new and old players. I dont use focus at all. I wanted the orignal thief experience. So i removed many of the new features by playing a custom game.Its like the old Thief games as long as you customize your gameplay experience. Make the game your own based off your play style. The option for added rewards by removing the new features from the game really makes it fun for me. If you were expecting somthing totally groundbreaking and new this game isnt it. That being said this is a good installment to the thief franchise and im happy to be able to play Garrett once again. If your new to Thief or a old school player give it a shot.(FYI: I'm glad rope arrow's are back i missed them alot in deadly shadows the gloves didnt do it for me lol)

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												I have a somewhat old gaming rig that plays current titles resonably well on high or very high settings. It's running an Intel Core 2 Duo 3.3 GHz, two nVidia GeForce 9800 GTX+ GPUs in SLI and 6 GBs of RAM. Thief lists in its minimum requirements a "high-performance dual core CPU or quad core CPU." Apparently the highest performance Core 2 Duo manufactured does not make the cut. Granted this is a legacy LGA775 chip, but I wish the system reqs were a bit more specific. The game's benchmark averages 6.3 FPS on the absolute lowest settings while my CPU is maxed out just running the menu screen. I pre-purchased at full price and now I have to sit on it until I have a new rig, which I wasn't planning on building anytime soon. From what I hear I'm not missing much, anyway. Damn shame.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												A worthy reboot.If you've played the original then the changes may upset you. The originals had a steampunk shade to them before steampunk was even a thing, but this one does not. There will also be inevitable comparisons between the voice actors. Though if you let it stand on its own, Thief is solid. The gamplay is very reminiscent of the originals. The story is pretty good. The more open world exploration from Thief III is present and thriving more than before. There's a tinge of weirdness,  but not the same dose as the originals. Overall, solid and we'll see where it goes with the reboot.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Custom difficulty is ABSOLUTELY the way to play this game. Put it on the Master setting, turn off focus, and set options that make it a 0 kill, 0 knockout, 0 detection scenario. This may sound like it would be too hard, frustrating, or even boring, but it's far from the truth. THIS is why Thief has been getting less-than-good reviews: the reviewers are ploughing through on the normal difficulty setting to get their ♥♥♥♥ing review out the door, and with all the helpful options enabled, a lot of what makes this game great gets screwed up.What you quickly realize playing a Custom setting of over 700 (there is an achievement for this) is that the maps were expertly crafted to accommodate this play style. There is always a solution that does not require any sort of confrontation, and it is this type of solution, whether it be quick-dashing from small shadow to small shadow, putting out lights, or creating distractions, that keeps the game thrilling in every engagement. In this way, every piece of loot is a challenge, whether it be attempting a quick lockpick while a patrolling guard is approaching or stealing a jewel from a tabletop right underneath somebody's nose.Meticulously blackjacking enemies and reducing the level's population one-by-one is much easier and robs the game of that constant sense of tension that works so well. When the enemies are a CONSTANT threat and you give yourself no ways to engage them, Thief is pure gold.It may be harder this way, and it will certainly be a longer game, but Thief is meant to be taken slowly, one area at a time, each room like a puzzle to be worked out.Perhaps Eidos Montreal's biggest mistake was not having enough confidence in their own gameplay and dumbing Thief down for the masses, hoping for a universal appeal. A hardcore, old-school type game might have gotten more attention in the press and more praise from the people who devoted some time to it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												This isn't terrible, and there are some genuinely good missions in it, but ultimately it becomes less fun the more you play it. I'm quite close to the end, but I don't care about finishing the game anymore. I have been doing a fair number of side missions, but still: 20 hours in, and I don't care about what's going on. It's full of clichés, such as the empty wheelchair rolling towards you in the corridor of the haunted mental asylum (seriously), and other games do everything here better. Get Dishonored and its Brigmore Witches DLC instead. A big problem is the city that connects everything. Familiarity breeds contempt, and you often have a lot of ground to cover to get from NPC to NPC which leaves the big feeling both big and small at the same time. You start to wish that some of the side mission characters might reward you with a fast travel option to other points on the map, given that you can't earn useful items from that work. Instead, we are forced to walk everywhere through a city that's bizarrely lacking interconnection. Often, you need to find an exact window to let you through into another city section. It is torturously stubborn when you're trying to get from A to B, and worse because of the completely unnecessary amount of loading points. Even with an SSD, this is still irritating. You'll quickly learn to hate the identical animations for squeezing through a tight space and the QTE to move the same fallen beam, and the "Hold X, now tap X repeatedly" thing for windows (which I could forgive if it was ever about a subtle movement to avoid being heard, but you will never be heard).This tediousness feeds into everything. I was playing for a long time wondering when I'd finally get a razor to steal paintings, or a wirecutter to disable traps, when Googling the problem finally told me that only one trader in the entire city sells those. This is one of many things in this dreary game that just makes you think, "♥♥♥♥ you, Eidos".Many reviews allege that the graphics are great, a viewpoint with which I strongly disagree. Animations, modelling and textures are pretty basic and old-fashioned. Swinging censers wreathed in smoke simply move their smoke field with them. Graphics settings appear to do very little to help or hurt the framerate, which is bizarrely low considering the lack of demand here (I have a 4GB Nvidia card, and it cannot keep the rate above 60fps at 1080p).

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Most of the things I wanted to say have already been said in the review section, but after two playthroughs (one for the story and challenge, one for assorted achievements) I feel like giving my two cents nonetheless. In the very likely case you don't want to read the wall of text below, my overall opinion is that while this game doesn't suck, it's also very much “meh”.If you want to play a Thief game, go play the old ones! I recommend the second :)If you want a modern, triple A spiritual successor to the Thief series that also allows for some really fun action gameplay, go play Dishonored.Thief 2014 is not wasted money, but definitely money that could have been spent better.My opinions on some major gameplay-related elements:Gameplay.The stealth gameplay is there and it's not bad. Sure, now you can see the alert status of enemies, but on the other hand I feel like their AI has been slightly improved: for example, they react to doors being opened\closed. The parkour stuff is really fun in theory, but you're limited to the places that the game decides for you (and conveniently color-codes for you). As a lot of other people pointed out, Thief I and II did this in a much more fun and creative way with the old rope arrows, fifteen years ago.There's a lot of potential for action gameplay and lots of upgrades, if you're into that; although it's kinda dull.Focus mode is basically Batman detective mode and conveniently highlights all the important things for you. It feels like cheating and it's kinda sad it was put in to begin with, but it can be safely ignored.There are also several action sequences and even QTEs. You can close your eyes when they come up, I guess.Level design.You could easily get lost in the old Thief games. The levels were huge and in order to figure out where your objective(s) was you could only rely on a minimalistic map, plus whatever hints you could find. In this game, on the other hand, you have an objective marker and a real-time minimap. The streamlining is also pretty noticeable: there's always a direction that's the correct one and in order to progress you have to keep moving in that direction; often times the game is even so kind as to close off parts of the level once you've reached a certain point. Since I'm on the topic of level design, this might be a good moment to mention how dark this game is. Not dark as in “it's night”, dark as in “there is no concept of brightness in this universe”: most things are black, grey or brown, any other color is actually a bleak shade of whatever that color is supposed to be. This has the double effect of making every level look the same and being pretty tiring on the eyes (in my experience, at least).Enemies.There are quite literally two enemies in this game. The standard human guard, and the freaks. The freaks are... the freaks. They all look the same and only appear a bunch of times, but at least they're pretty creepy and sneaking around them is slightly different. On the other hand, officers of the City Watch, Graven mob and random thugs are visually undistinguishable from each other unless you're actually in their face, and their “personalities” are the same: they all repeat the same lines constantly, relentlessly, until you know them by heart. In a game like Thief you need a decently varied array of enemies, both for gameplay purposes and to make the universe more engaging. Open world.Thief is an open world game. There's a (supposedly) sprawling city which you need to move through in order to reach the starting points of the game's chapters; and which you can explore to discover all its secrets. At first you're going to be awestruck by how big it is: so full of alternate routes, so full of secrets to find... but all that excitement is going to quickly disappear around the second time you're sneaking through the long path you're forced to take in order to get where you need to get, while you're trying to make sense of the map (spoiler: you'll never be able to make sense of the map). And you'll have to do this again, and again, and again.If all of this sounds familiar, congratulations, you've played Thief III! Except the City in the previous game wasn't as confusing, if I recall correctly.More ramblings of a salty fanboyThese are mostly minor nitpicks. You can safely stop reading here.The plot.In the old games the plot was some kind of creepy big conspiracy that Garrett stumbles upon because he's always where he isn't supposed to be; and it slowly built up level by level. Here they try really hard to make it extremely personal from the very beginning, but they do so using a character that's barely introduced and a world whose only inhabitants are idiot clones who spend their time wondering what's in the sloop. The plot is also at the same time predictably clichè and ridiculously vague. “Oh no, the bad guy wants to use the vaguely defined plot device to do... something! Oh no, now a new bad guy wants to use the vaguely defined plot device to do something else!”. ContinuityI can tell they decided to ignore all the series' lore because they thought burricks, treebeasts, haunts , automatons etc... weren't bleak enough for this modern triple A masterpiece of bleakness. The Pagans with their hilarious broken English and their creepy wood witch vibe are gone. The holier-than-thou, priests-turned-engineers Hammerites are gone. The Builder and the Trickster are gone. So how do you deal with making a sequel\reboot to a series while at the same time not wanting to use that series' lore, but wanting to keep the main character? Simple: you set it sometime in the future and make it so Garrett isn't actually Garrett, but another guy named Garrett who looks very similar to Garrett and is also an incredibly skilled thief, also has a fence who is coincidentally named Basso... you get the idea. And this is not a complete reboot, mind you, it's officially a future version of the old Thief world. You can check the wiki[thiefgame.wikia.com] to read more about it, because you sure as hell won't get more info by playing the game. Long story short, you can probably guess that I'm very salty about the complicated stupidity of this game's continuity and lore.Audio bugsThe in-game meThe in-game mechanism The in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.chaThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the vThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.ery least questionable.nism that triggers dThe in-game meThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.chanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.ialogues is at the vThe in-game mThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the verymechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.ery least questionable.BleaknessI've already talked a bit about how hard this game tries to be bleak, but I feel the best way to convey what it's like and also why I can't take it seriously is to write some sample dialogue, the kind that you'll hear constantly through the game.Guy #1: “My shift of♥♥♥♥♥♥shoveling is over. Wanna go get drunk?”Guy#2:“Yes, I might forget about how I just threw my own mother's body in a mass grave”Guy#1“I'll have to bury my six kids soon, they have the plague and I lost all my money when the rotting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I was with robbed me. At least some street thugs killed her immediately after”Enter guard.Guard:“Did someone say... thugs? And kill?”Violent noises, Guy#1 and #2 screamGuard:”I have the plague.”

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												I have been a fan of the Thief series since it was first released over 10 years ago. That being said, myself along with many others, have a certain level of standard that needs to be upheld to really give the game a fair chance. Technology has improved by leaps and bounds even over such a short period of time, so it would be foolish to think it could be anything like the original in such a way that wouldn't already put a bit of a handicap on the view of the game. Mind you, that's not all true, as several aspects of the original series could have made and improved return and didn't, but I don't think that you should let that deter you from giving this game a fair shot.First off, if you were a fan of Deus Ex: Human Revolution (I certainly was), then right off the bat, you might like this game (it was developed using the same technology by the same company). The game has that Human Revolution feel plus some aspects you might have found in Splinter Cell: Blacklist. At first, It feels very cover-based, but it does allow you the freedom to approach situations in any way you see fit (though it still may be pretty limited). The original Thief games were all about plopping you in the mission with a "good luck" and no idea what to do, without some deal of exploration. This game doesn't quite offer that level of challenge, as they will make objectives known to you, highlight items of importance, and allow you the use of the Focus ability (which basically shows you all the stuff you might be able to interact with), though it's up to you if you want to use it or not. This level of hand-holding in the various missions throughout the game may be what you aren't looking for, and if so, it's probably not for you. Granted, it's not idiot proof, so there's that.The original games gave you the choice of how to outfit yourself before each mission, depending on your playstyle, and this game does that too, albeit through the use of the hideout. You can store items in your stash for later use, though unless you like to stockpile items, I don't find it much use, as you can carry quite a bit. The game does let you begin certain missions without tools that would otherwise make it easier, encouraging you to scout around a bit. There is an "open world" feel to the game, as the major "hub" of the city enables you to roam around looking for extra secrets and loot to pay for your gadgets.The game does have an upgrade point system as well, which you can obtain by donating money to the Queen of Beggars or finding them in secret areas. You can also visit various people around the city who will sell you tools and trinkets for use on your missions. There are side quests, nooks and crannies, and a good deal of things to keep you busy in addition to the main story, which some people might find enjoyable. Depending on how you choose to play each mission, you are awarded points and loot based on how you acted (ie, did you kill everyone, avoid everyone, or use the environment to sneak around?) and if you completed other thieving objectives (such as not killing anyone, pickpocketing people, not being detected, and stealing all possible loot). These are unique to each mission, and the game doesn't tell you what you need to do, so you have to get in the habit of checking before each mission to see what you have to do.The map is handy, but it's also quite primitive. You can see major points of interest such as shops and objectives, but you can't set waypoints and you aren't always given a clear idea of what areas are dead-ends and what areas are transition points.The controls are very good, the graphics are great, and the music is fitting. The AI isn't too bad, and as you increase the difficulty, they get smarter, so it will keep you on your toes. The voice acting is pretty mediocre, but it's definitely not horrible. The story is not bad either.If you can overlook the fact that it's got some flaws and isn't the original game, give it a shot. It holds its own simply based on  the fact it's a Thief game.

												The whole game feels very clunky. If you're climbing around there's a good chance you'll get stuck because you're not in the exact right position for the game to register you need to jump to the next ledge.The stealth elements are not much better. If you're discovered you may have little choice but to restart the area because you have no escape options at least not early on and combat only works 1v1 anything else and it's not worth the effort.When you're not being detected everything feels like a very linear path even when it looks like it may be more open. Sometimes there's a second way to go about doing things but it's rare and sometimes you'll require a special tool you'll only get later on. Had the combat been more fun or the game was more forgiving when you were caught it may have been better. It's not like it's a rewarding challange either. It's missing a bunch of little things that would have really made it a decent game.

There are random invisible obstacles, ragdolls get launch into space when you put them down, NPCs sometimes get stuck while walking and start spinning around madly, HUD disappears completely. Somewhat entertaining, but annoying nevertheless.There's a lot of filler. Exploring dressers, bedside tables and picture frames is slow (due to animations and minigames) and unexciting. Nice touch: when guards rush to attack you, they just keep repeating their last phrase like a battlecry.
