content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												So it's been 30 hours so far, and even though I'm having such a blast, the collecting of EVERY SINGLE LOOT (OCD) is starting to get to me. I just had to get that out of the way, here and now! Surely Garret is content by now?! Moving on...This reboot of the original Thief will not be suited to all, in fact I wouldn't be surprised if only 1 in 10 people actually will enjoy it, as the taste is a rather specialized one. If you are a diehard fan of the original series you may or may not enjoy this one, since while it still captures the essence behind Thief, the whole openworld experience is quite hampered with long loading times, awkwardly placed transitional zones and poor openworld map layout, other than that it is everything you could want from a Thief game!If you're used to running around and killing everything without repercussions then I suggest you look elsewhere. As the original games, Thief is very unforgiving in all but stealth actions. And rightly so, for this is a fully stealth based game, and thieves are no match in combat. Thief, not Rogue, there is a difference. They're light footed, they get in and out, that's all there is to it.A lot of people seem to want to compare this game to Dishonoured, and while the two may share similarities I can honestly say from playing both that Thief is the one to go for a complete stealth experience and a very dark storyline whereas Dishonoured you can get away with pretty much anything you do, without a real challenge (unless you impose one on yourself).All looting and thieving aside, Thief has one of those rare atmospheres that manages to draw you into the game world, and that is thanks to the talented developers at Square Enix, the driving force behind Deux Ex: Human Revolution which also had such an amazing atmosphere to get absorbed into. The story in itself is quite an interesting one, and later on towards the end the game starts taking a turn for the horror/paranormal reminiscence of Outlast which both terrified and excited me since at least in Thief you have a chance (emphasis on YOU, not me, as playing on Master difficulty with instant fail on taking damage/being seen is what I've condemned myself to).While the graphics in Thief never was an issue since it's such an old game, I can't help but feel that they limited themselves quite a bit by using the Unreal Engine (though I've seen much better looking games with the same engine). But to be honest, it's not about realism (though it does get that across), but about the dark noir/steampunk feel which goes hand in hand with its rugged graphics display. The audio is what really makes the game come to life though, with footsteps perfectly positioned and the rest of the sounds matched correctly more often than not you'll feel like you're really in the game until you're stuck humping a wall because it's not a predefined climb spot.Take all this and add the ability to start a custom difficulty game where YOU get to decide how the game will play out, if you can use healing items, if you are allowed to take damage or use specific items amongst many other modifiers makes for a completely unique experience tailored to your own playstyle! Think you're a Master Thief? Prove it!For those who haven't played any of the Thief games and are looking for something new which doesn't heavily rely on combat (though it is available) a la Metal Gear Solid/Splinter Cell then I'm sure you'll find something of value in Thief.For those of you who are Thief fans, or have played any of the older Thief games then for nostalgia sake you will enjoy being a Taffer once more, causing mayhem for the guards, racking up loot, finding the secrets and generally just being a badass.

												I played all the Thief games and I enjoy them all.This one the graphics are decent and a nice step up from the originals.The controls are simple to get used.The audio is nice and clear with no problems.The missions so far are decent and offer a nice wide range to power through and have fun. This is a singleplayer campaign fun game with lots to do, and you actually get the feeling that it is open world.  I was walking around and had multiple routes to find and do something, and I really thought it was open world, when I know it is not.There are multiple ways to approach a mission or a person, with secrets, hiding spots and different things around.Overal this game is very much worth the time and effort you put into it, for a fun experience make sure you watch ALL the video's, they are really really nice to watch, and I am a person who skips them but a friend of mine made me sit and watch them all, and I did and thankfully I did because they are good video's.Anyway, worth the time, money and effort you put into it.Well done Thief.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												This is not Thief. It's the hollywood cash-in version of Thief. It's every stealth game except the one it was named after, (and they just don't gel together). The thing just doesn't tick the right boxes for me - moving round in the game I feel like some unfit wannabe nut who thinks they're in batman/tomb raider (but lacks the skills). Other times it just feels like some Dishonoured rip-off; less-polished, with a mediocre story. Aeriel knockouts, ffs. I just quit out when I started clambering around on pipes like Sam FIsher and I started getting flashbacks to the last Splinter Cell. It's like they don't know why Thief was great, so they just tried robbing all the other stealth games since.Garret is just not the man he was. The sneering cynicism is gone. And so are his stealth skills, apparently. Guards have spotted me from (relatively) miles away when I'm perfectly still and in total darkness. I snuck up to a nice bit of loot, hit the 'e' key to kick-off the looting animation, and the sound I made when looting attracted guards. WTF?Back to The Dark Mod, I guess.

												I was really excited for this remake when it was annouced but it has proved to be one of the most uninspired remakes/redos / whatever this is trying to be. I loved the original Thief games and Dishonored because of the connections, but Thief 4 is neither of those in character or style.NPC's are boring and flat, world design is drab (there's no color like there was in the originals), and for some reason they tried to pull like a reverse borrow by giving Garrett supernatural powers similar to Corvo's and a plague. Also Garrett is now some kind antihero and lacks any of the character of Stephen Russell's version. I want to compare the level design to the Dark Project, but thats an insult even to that game, it's just so linear and boring and I can't focus on any of it for more than 5 minutes. There's no keepers no pagans no Hammerites, there's nothing here but tiny sneaky boring thief man.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I know at the time of writing this I only have a few hours of gameplay into Thief, and I will probably add more over the next few days, but there are things about this game that I find let down lovers of the original Thief series.To be honest, I'm not even sure why this title was "rebooted" another time after Thief: Deadly Shadows.  The answer is probably out there, but I'm just too lazy (and I honestly don't care) to find it.The first thing I noticed when even starting this game is that it feels very much more like a reboot... far from the roots of the originals.The world, although they would like you to think it's "open" leads you by the hand down the garden path.  Practically every Thief game prior to this one is very much more "open" to exploration than this one.  In those prior installments, you could at least wander around a bit... find other marks, find other points of interest, find little nooks and secrets that you can explore and loot to your heart's content.  This game seems very restrictive by comparison.  You can't even jump up on walls or buildings.  For a minute there, I was wondering why the game would practically highlight everything that could be climbed or held onto, but now I guess I know why.... because you can't jump up on, climb, or hold onto just anything anymore.  It even tells you to "find a way into <insert building here>" but then puts a freakin' marker on your screen to point out exactly where to go.The next thing is the dialog.  I honestly can't explain why developers think that adding profanity will somehow lead to a better game.  The originals managed to do excellent without it.  Personally, I find it a sign of a weak script if the developers think they have to sprinkle curse words throughout just to give it some body (which curse words alone can't do).  It's getting that I have to ditch my computer speaker system and start using headphones because NOTHING is able to be played around my family anymore.That said, one of the tiny nitpicky things I found was that the lipsyncing sorta was hit and miss at times.  There were a few points where the dialog was done but the character kept flappin' their gums.  Other times, the character would speak but their mouth would not move at all.However, even having said all that, I'm still finding the gameplay OK... yes, merely OK... not stellar, not horrible... just OK.  I do have to admit that the environments and texturing are well done and they actually are one thing that shines in this game.  At least it still LOOKS like a Thief game.  But even then, it doesn't fix what's wrong with the game.I wish Steam had a sideways thumb... I don't really want to recommend this game for anyone who came from the original Thief series, but it's not entirely a bad game as such.  It's just not as immersive as the previous games.  So, that being said I will still give it a thumbs up, but it should actually be pointing sideways.

												Initial Thief — The Dark Project — once taught us to hide in shadows and to avoid battles, to listen to each sneeze and to make plans on the fly. Continuations, including in many respects disputable Deadly Shadows, all this picked up and developed, but now there was a restart, and a lot of things were for some reason forgotten. Thief of 2014 really refused everything that occurred in the previous parts of a series. Here never existed the stimpankovskikh tekhnofilov-hammeritov, neither sorcerers pagans worshipping to god Trikster, nor secret order of the Keepers, undertaken to store balance between these two extremes. The city in which the thief Garret bosses, too changed: if earlier in it the rough medieval architecture, now in a course elaborate constructions of the Renaissance and the Victorian era prevailed, and magics in it remained less than nothing. "Stealth of new generation" which was praised highly actively by developers, in Thief difficultly to see. It isn't known, unfortunately it or fortunately, but the new generation differs from old only existence of the indicator of uneasiness over enemies. For the rest the scheme old — we hide in dark corners, we try not to catch sight to enemies and if got — we are washed away at the fifth speed. The policeman попсихует, will shout: "Leave, the coward! ", will come to a conclusion: "I ran away, the swine" — and will return on the post, is exact as in Deadly Shadows. And this algorithm doesn't depend on complexity level almost — simply at easy level security guards are blind, deaf and will forget about Garret, it should drop for a second out of sight, and on the heavy will sound alarm at the slightest pretext and then still the solid hour to shudder from the slightest rustle. Praised settings of complexity which in the theory have to allow to adjust game to any taste and to any player — only a set of sticks which can insert into wheels. For example, we can force game to set off defeat after the first given alarm. It is possible to forbid Garret to kill and even to deafen policemen. But with the same success it is possible to play one hand or, say, sitting a back to the screen — sense from such "weighting compounds" slightly. Unless it is worth turning off "the concentration mode" to feel the thief of old school. (This my opinion and it can not coincide with yours).

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Garret is the thief in the game whom the player controls, he is a righteous man who refuses to kill a guard, but will gladly pick their pockets stealing their wages, and rob their homes, thus starving them to death.  If you cant tell Garret is a jerk, all this is visible from the start of the game where you are with another thief whose a female, go girl power!  Garret wont be shown up by her badassery and thiefs away her weapon which kills her thus reinforcing the fact that Garret is a jerk.  That is what should be on the box not "Theif", but in BIG letters the word JERK!The graphics are terribad, yet somehow they require very high specs, figure that out?  The graphics are so bad you cant see much on screen EVER!  Everything is grey, black, light grey, there is an entire rainbow of grey in this game.  For lovers of the color grey this would be a great game, because Garret is color blind to every color under the sun it seems.  Any colors that do appear are washed out.  The devs realizing how poor their choice was to use 5 colors to make an entire game, gave you thief vision.  Thats right as a super hero thief due to bad graphics you just hit a button and know where all the treasures are.  However instead of feeling like a thief you feel more like a garbage man.  There are bracelets in rain gutters, valuable goblets just lying in bushes, so instead of finding treasure your picking up scraps of garbage nobody wants.  Ever seen in movies where some homeless guy collects crazy trinkets like socks or other baubles and keeps them as trophies in his sewer domain?  Well now you can  live the dream of being a shiftless hobo picking up trash, you even get an abandoned clocktower to show off your shinies.Poor Garret, what did these developers do to the beloved Garret of the practically holy trinity of gaming called the Thief series.  With his eyeliner and deep voice he sounds more like he should be writing in his diary of woe, as an emo kid recounts their life memoirs about missing out on sales at Hot Topic while hanging out at the mall being all edgy.  These guys had a bajillion dollars to make this game and just wasted it, this game is a waste.  They had so much money they made a REAL LIFE version of Garret's bow, had it commissioned by some machinists and custom made for who knows why or how much money.  They even remade the ENTIRE foundation of the games XP system replacing it with some kind of force system where instead of earning xp for upgrades, you just buy them from a blind hag!  That is not made up, it sounds like something a crazy person would do, but yes, in this game you go and become better at combat or better at seeing things from a blind hag.  Ugh, when they made this game, were they even trying, its like trolling.  This is a first person stealth game which is an odd choice which the game suffers for.  There is only one FPS platformer that ever really worked called Mirrors Edge.  All of those gamers who to this day have nightmares of old games that were plaatformers with terrible controls, can relive those vietnam flashbacks playing Thief because the controls are awful.  Garret the thief gets no armor running around in his underwear, the reason for this is your a thief, you get no armor because it makes noise.  But every guard you see has armor, chain mail, swords clattering about and none of them make a sound!  The guards in their full armor are as stealthy as ninjas, sometimes you go around a corner and BAM a knight is walking around, completely silent.  Since this game has no radar your left guessing where enemies are NEVER feeling like your in the game.  The combat is awful, if you get injured dont worry, just bring up your inventory and enjoy some food, then go back to combat, stopping to eat food in the middle of combat?  For how much "realism" the devs proclaimed about how this game would revolutionize stealth, these guys got it wrong, all wrong, everything is wrong, and nothing is right.  Thief even managed to botch movement, thats right the simple act of traversing through the physical plane is mind boggling in Thief, you cant even jump, there is no jump button.  A platforming game with no jump button, Thief is a confusing mess of playstyles that cant make up its mind what it wants to be.  There are times you will move around and all the sudden your stuck, if you look down there is some small pipe you walked into or box that is below your line of sight.  Well, here is how to stop the "Thief" in "Thief"  leave some garbage on the ground making it so poor Garret cant climb over it.  Garret will most likely abandon the mission since he cant climb over the garbage.  Becoming bedazzled by the pile of trash, rummaging through it like a homeless person looking for tin cans finding forks, spoons. and perhaps, even the holiest of holies a "PEN".  Thats right in this game a PEN is treasure, all Actuarial undergrads using mechanical pencils should be on the lookout for a thief named Garret.  All those lost writing utensils are probably due to a world class thieves guild hell bent on cornering the worlds supply of writing implements or maybe they just hate math, could be a little bit of both.Sitting trying to think of any redeeming qualities just gives a migraine.  The levels are all small like in Hitman Absolution which is also made by Square Enix, you walk from one end of a level to the other, thats it.  Thats the whole game.  Its horrible, even trying to force myself to play it is brutal.  Who let this game get made?  Why does it exist?  With all that money and this is what they create?  Indie games can be bad, usually its due to lack of budget, and even then the games dont suck at what they try to do.  In Thief the lockpicking mechanic is an empty circle, when it lights up you pick the lock its a downright insult to lockpicking in gaming.  As proof indie games can do it better, check out Motte Island which has a better lockpicking mechanic than multimillion dollar Thief.  Things like that are what make alot of indie games rule, leaving the AAA studios to drool.This game had it all, and threw it all away.  Every second spent playing it, anyone who owns skyrim will think, hey I can run around pick pockets and steel spoons and forks in Skyrim.  "Thief" with its AAA name, and AAA developers comes off like a crappy mod for skyrim, but of course skyrim does this without modding, so dont buy Thief, just buy Skyrim.  When this game came out and all the pro reviewers were drooling, how could NOT ONE of them say.... Oh hey Skyrim has a Thieves guild, with an open world of in depth quests, lockpick mechanics and stealth... because those reviewers suck, someone should make a list of any reviewer who liked this game and blacklist them for the good of gamer kind...   TLDR:  Like most modern games there are segments where you go through HVAC ducts in air vents.  Yes the middle ages suddenly has central air... The only thing thief will do is steal your time, literally its a time burglar, making doing anything better than playing this game.Buy Skyrim instead or buy any elder scrolls game even old morrowind is better than this.Rating:  0/10  Value:  $0.00

												Genre - Fantasy first person Stealth/RPGI have played through all the other Thief games to date and I was worried that this one wouldn't stay true to its roots, being too console friendly. Thank F*** I was wrong! I have only played through the first chapter and am freely exploring the second. However, I think I know enough to pass on a positive review. The fighting is balanced so that you might die if you get into a scrap against the odds, this means you will have to use stealth and the environment to succeed. The arrows are back to distract, put out torches and kill. You can sneak up and cosh unsuspecting enemies from behind or rob them. The story seems to fit in with the world created in the other games and the characters are lovable rogues. Also you can freely move around the enviroment, to a point, robbing random dwellings and finding secrets. You can buy upgrades to give you advantages in certain situations such as picking locks (this has also been done well) and healing. Also when detected there seems a fair time and situation to when aggro is reduced. Be careful as citizens will run and get the Watch when you beat up their mates.A game that encourages you to use the darkness as an advantage and be a sneaky thieving git!

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Please note that I am reviewing this reboot as its own game. I have never played any of the original "Thief" games so you will not find a comparison here. My review will be based solely on my experience with this version of Thief.Ever since I first heard of Thief I was excited. I am a huge stealth-fan and I never got around to playing the original Thief-games, so this was a great opportunity for me and other newcomers to jump right into this iconic stealth series... and I am very glad that I did. Thief is a beautiful game and a unique stealth experience with smooth gameplay and lots of variety in your approach on things. Simply a superb game that is unfortunately brought down by critics and die-hards fan who expected something that would have stuck more to the "original recipe".The Good:· Smooth controls: climbing low obstacles, peeking around corners to get a better look at your environment, swooping from shadow to shadow... It all feels incredibly smooth, especially for a stealth game. If you have ever played Dishonored, just imagine something like that without magic and a more realistic approach.· Money money money: getting your gold-greedy paws around precious items such as common goblets and letter openers among countless others and more unique collectable items is incredibly fun and satisfying. This loot is generally realistically spread, meaning no golden goblets will be found on the streets and that jewelry will mostly be found in stores or houses. I personally think this encouraged me to explore different area's to find different kind of loot.· Phenomenal stealth gameplay: there are no stealth games this well-crafted in my recent memory. Your approach may depend on the situation, your goal or the difficulty (which is geniously customizable to enjoy the game as hard or as simple as you'd like). You can sneak past every guard, knock them all out, just steal all their money (heheh), or you can distract guards by firing arrows, putting out fires, throwing empty bottles etc. It feels fresh and addictive and completely different with every level or replay.The Bad:· AI: there's dumb AI and there's blind AI. I'd say the AI isn't necessarily dumb (birds and dogs will alert guards and guard frequently and correctly patrol the area) but the AI is blind as f*ck. Alright, you're in the shadows, but at times you can literally walk in front of guards and they'll keep their eyes fixed on you, but they won't react. This idiocy encouraged me to stay as far away from guars as possible, but I'd prefer my AI a little bit more alert and responsive.· Pure stealth may not be for everyone: in games like Splinter Cell or Hitman you can either go in pure stealth without ever being noticed of going in a bit more fierce, killing every enemy in sight. You can obviously kill enemies with an arrow in between the enemy's eyes, but real action is avoided. The more stealthy you play, the more rewarding (both in-game and personally) and immersive the game will be, but poor in-game combat will put off almost everyone looking to cause some fuss.The Ugly:· Man this game is gorgeous. Amazing textures, immersive lighting, stunning character models, an atmospheric city and espacially Garrett's hands are detailed beyond belief. One of the most beautiful games in recent memory.Final Verdict:· Thief is not for everyone due to its imperfections, but for stealth-fans like myself this game is a must. It's the very best stealth has to offer and undoubtedly a game that will stick with you for a long time. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 25 of 48 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Thief is a great instalment to the series and as kind of a reboot it's does a great job paving the way for what will hopefully be the first of many more 'next-gen' Thief games.The game it's self is aestically very pleasing, the graphics are second to few and overall gameplay is smooth and relatively uninterrupted. The mechanics are well enough for sneaking around and looting etc, but don't expect to be going toe-toe with more than 1 enemy at a time. Basically, if you're discovered by more than one guard, it's a death sentence and you will learn how quickly you can load last save. Whilst I wasn't expecting much of a combat system from the game, I was hoping for sneak damage perk when using the bow and perhaps some minor melee combat, or the ability to counter (non-lethal) attacks so I could make my escape route with a sense of panic and urgency. That said, you can purchase/find poison cloud arrows that incapacitate the enemy – just don’t miss as the game is more unforgiving than getting the drunken wrong end of a cigarette. I would have like to have seen more of an awareness indication on guards and enemies – this would aid the swooping between shadows and give better aid to timing of attacks/takedowns as well as increasing the difference between similar games, cough, Dishonored, cough. It’s awfully frustrating drawing an arrow on your bow to maximum tension only to have it stick in a guards head and then him be fully aware and alert of his assailant. What the game does do well is the stealth and sneak ability, far superior to the likes of dishonoured and much less clunky than say for instance Skyrim. It’s impossible not to compare the game to Dishonoured with all the similarities but Thief is not smothered by the steampunk, futuristic, often hard to follow alternative universe. Instead, the immersion is founded on a gritty late 1800’s era where plague (the gloom) is run rampant through the city streets. You’re free to run the streets and break into houses via rooftops plundering all the fancy cutlery and golden microscopes you can fit in your endless wizard pockets. The game turns these delightful items immediately into an equivalent gold value you can spend on tools for more felonies. There’s an unmistakable satisfaction gathering up all the collectables to a set of rare items and where the game falls short of combat more than makes up for it with blatant burglary and theft. Thief doesn’t benefit from a completely free roam environment (like Assassins Creed series) unfortunately. This really brought the points down for me as Garett can easily scale most things then be completely unable climb or jump others that seem remedial in comparison. Perhaps if there was more of an assassins agenda going on in the game this could have been a reality for the game but ultimately it comes off as laziness or lowered expectations for the game. Fortunately, it doesn’t ruin the game but would have given it that additional dimension that could have made it a triple A title or worthy of a higher RRP. That said, I think the game is worth the money and is a good bang for the buck.I recommend this game if you get a kick out of sneaking around, outwitting your opponents and solving puzzles to progress the story. The story it’s self-unravels as you play through the game and combined with the incentive of stealing some fancy pants items, well makes the game worth playing. If you are looking for more of a brawling experience though, I cannot recommend it, you will be sorely disappointed and likely frustrated that your kick♥♥♥♥♥reflexes and ability to strike multiple keys in quick succession will do you no good here. On top of requiring a decent spec machine this game will also require patience, attention to detail i.e. don’t knock over cups, tread on broken glass etc and an appreciation for stealth & thievery. So far, I can’t really knock the game given what I spent on it. It has been worth every dollar and I’m sure it will continue to be so while I uncover more loot and more story.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												The Bad: Awkward, unneeded 3rd person moments of climbing. The story feels flat and the characters aren't fleshed out at all.  When exploring the open world hub called "The City" there are loading screens everywhere. That being said, they go by pretty quickly or are hidden via a QTE event. Audio problems ranging from guards repeating their lines immediately after speaking, being able to hear them from a great distance away as if they are right next to you, or absolutely no audio at all during cut scenes (each of these things happened randomly at some point).  Removal of the dagger is a turn off for some but as I normally ghost anyway it was not a problem. The size of the levels vary from linear to nonlinear at times. The Good: The stealth is amazing and it's exhilarating to dash from one shadow to the next as you sneak around. The game itself looks beautiful and, in my opinion, really captures a steam punk Victorian London feel. The game mechanics steer you towards the stealth route (as it should) by removing the dagger (though really you can still use arrows if you wish to kill). The guards are not stupid and while you can take one on no problem, alerting several generally results in a death. That being said, an extremely patient player can take down all guards or slip past them entirely. The light and shadows look fantastic and work wonderfully as a stealth mechanic, though don't expect to be invisible in the shadows on harder difficulties when a guard walks right up to where you are. Speaking of difficulties, there are a ton of customizable options for tailoring your game to your desired difficulty. The game itself has a solid length and lasts even longer if you do all the side missions, which are probably the best part of the game. A ton of loot is hidden in the hub world as well as every story and side mission, including special collectables like paintings, rings, and plaques (can you complete all the sets?). The new focus mechanic is a welcome addition allowing you to view interactable objects such as loot, traps, and things that can be opened. That being said this new mechanic is not necessary to complete the game and can be turned off entirely. While the levels are not as big as in previous Thief games they still offer multiple ways of reaching objectives. Lastly there are upgrades you can purchase throughout the game for your focus abilities and trinkets that increase things like max health or decrease resource costs. While this may not be the classic Thief game many were hoping for, it is still a great game in it's own right. Aside from the audio problems (which may be fixed with future patches) the game gave me no problems and was enjoyable from start to finish. Though it may not be a perfect game, any fan of the stealth genre should enjoy Thief. I personally give it a 7/10. If you are on the fence I hope this helps!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												THIEF. You probably expect the oldschool THIEF, you go through the reviews, they say "IT'S NO OLD THIEF, WHY.".. It was probably the last time i listened to any reviewsites, except the game has an overall of <35. However.You are Garrett, the masterthief and you start with a girl named Erin, going through the city, moving on many roofs, but already arguing. The objective was, to get something. It wasn't really clear. They were on the roof of a cathedral and looked down to people summoning something. Well, THIEF is obviously not a straightup middleage game without any fantasyelements. To keep it short. They start a fight because Garrett doesn't like how it works, she is loosing her claw and she tries to catch it, falls down and you have absoluetly no idea what happened. Except that you were one year unconscious. Enough of that.The game is welldetailed, every building is different so far, well some are just for some letters or documents, but still exciting.The atmosphere is awesome in a dark city with a terrible plague that keeps everyone small, except for guards and the rich ones and has great soundeffects, steps (blood, glass, books, leaves, etc.)There is tons of small loot to pick up, so you can buy different arrows that can help you through the game or upgrading your armor and different goodies which are permanent, like 25% lesser to pay for arrows. Also collectives, from a picture with a naked female body and a goathead. Rings, necklaces, signs and so on.The most important thing is the gameplay. You can play in different ways. Go full stealthy. Go and knock everyone out. Or go  aggressive and kill everyone. Focus is your friend of bluemarking loot, which can be very helpful, use it. But you don't have permanent focus, and it doesn't refill, unless you use flowers. The enemies aren't that smart sometimes, but smart enough to recognize steps if you are too loud or if they see you in the light. Even if you hide in the dark, they can see you if they're near enough. The controls are flawless, i actually expected a terrible port.The only annoying thing is to press [E] for pressing a bar or to open windows. Like it or not, it might be no oldschool THIEF, but it's still a pretty nice game and i didn't regret to spend my time on it.

												OVERVIEWThis game is reboot of a awesome stealth game back in the late 90s-00s you are Garrett, A thief idk how he got into the thiefing biznus but he is. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												This rendition of Thief is remeniscent of the original games in some ways, but probably not  enough  ways. While I enjoyed playing the game for awhile, I found myself becoming bored. Travel throughout the city felt tedious, and the loading screens every few feet are annoying and break immersion. The in-game map is borderline useless for actual navigation. The actual mechanics of the gameplay left me feeling as if they developed the game to appeal to a newer generation of gamers. I miss the excitement of sneaking up on someone and actually having to pull out a blackjack and knock them over the head. It takes away from my agency as a player when all I have to do to quietly take out a guard is hit Q. During development, Focus was a hot button issue for the hardcore fans of the series. I didn't mind it. I usually just let it run out, and I'd use it to temporarilly highlight things in the environment so it was easier to find stuff. The game is dark, as it should be, but sometimes its nice to not have to walk around in the dark forever looking for a switch. There are other applications of Focus for combat, but I mostly ignored that. The selection of arrows was nice and probably the aspect of the game most true to the original games. The story wasn't great, wasn't bad. It was a vehicle for gettting you from one place to another while you looked for stuff to steal. This review seems pretty negative; nevertheless, if you enjoyed the original Thief games, I still think you should give this a shot. It's a nice looking game and if you're okay with setting aside thoughts about how it should have been, you can probably manage to enjoy it for what it is.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												i7 2600k @3.48GB memory64 bit OS7870 graphic card.Everything is either high or maxed.No bugs or stuttering issues. Runs smooth 99% of the time, a bit of slow down/stuttering on chapter/area starts for about 5 seconds while stuff loads, but other than that smooth as silk.I'm first gen of gamers, and played all Thief games on release, and bought them all again on Steam recently while waiting for this to be available, just to get back into it. Yes it has some minor issues, such as guards repeating phrases (same happened in the first 3 games by the way now and again) Yes it is more linear than the originals, but still quite open, depending on how far your in to the game and what mission you are doing, and it is a different background and story to the originals. The story isn't as good as the first 3 games, in my opinion, but it isn't bad at all, it's just average for a story/plot in games these days. I quite enjoyed it. As usual these days…crap ending to an enjoyable game.The voice acting is good, I laugh at people freaking out just because they changed the voice actor from the originals. This new guy is good and does a good job. The quality of voices throughout the entire game is of high standard.The hub is a pain to navigate, but no more so than in Thief 3.The mature themes are ok for me but they are definitely mature with lots of bad language used throughout the game and some graphical sexual images and scenes. For me it was a little bit over the top and not really needed, but it does kind of fit into the setting so I can say it was ok in context of the setting and game. 18+ for sure.The AI is just as good as in all previous Thief games, and on Master/Custom settings, better, and harder. Those who think otherwise are recalling with nostalgia, not fact. Go play the first 3 games which are very cheap to get on Steam and you will see what I mean. The guards and their patrols in all 3 previous games were just as dumb as in this game, probably more so.Thief 4 guards actually react harsher and help each other better than the originals in most circumstances, and unlike the original 3 games, you can't really fight your way out of things and take them on at harder difficulties you will be dead pretty fast. You’re a Thief, not Chuck Norris, throw a flashbang and run is the idea, or kill them with arrows, silently, from a safe and hidden distance.There are so many custom options in this game that you can tinker with it to make it into a game of your style than just about any other game available, and this is a massive plus and a nod to those of us who played the originals first time around. If you don't like some of the new effects, switch them off, simple as that.This reboot is well worth the money, they have done overall an excellent job with it, and you’re just spiting yourself not buying it due listening to people who are a combination of uber fussy, where nothing will ever be good enough for them, the mentally idiotic who think it is some form of ninja game and try and kill everything that moves then complain about combat not being good enough (duh) or simply having never played this new game, but still slag it off anyway, such as the journos on a bandwagon of slagging it off, just the same way they pump up games all saying the same thing together like a herd of sheep when that game is terrible. Play it for yourself, play it like a Thief, not an Assassin and start on Master difficulty, and it is a very good game. This is one "older generation" who enjoys playing it very much and will soon be playing it through again, and trying to do better and closer to 100% for each mission. Which is VERY hard to do. This is one of those games with a ton of stuff to do and find, lots of nice touches, if you play it as it was meant and designed to be played you will have a great time. There are LOADS of side missions to do as well. A lot more than you might first think! Go back to Basso after you finish the main story line just for starters, I got an extra 19 missions just from him, and add on the other 2 sources of missions and there are tons of them.Overall I would give it 85% and recommend it as a not perfect, but a very good reboot of a dearly loved game, and well worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												After a huge amount of speculation and suspicion about the title before it's release, it has finally got out after long periods of delays.  I got to thank Eidos Montreal for not rushing with THIEF and listening to the fans and making changes to the game they desired.First off; the PC port is superb. You can adjust the difficulty settings and basically anything related to either the UI, interfaces or just general game experience and playstyle. Not to mention all those fancy graphics options out there aswell.The game looks and sound very good. The city takes a very dark and moody grip on you and the athmosphere is amazing. The City itself is a fully explorable Hub area, much like in Thief: Deadly Shadows or Deus Ex: Human Revolution.I think  the biggest thing that really made me love this game, were all the detail and little things around the City, including tons of secret areas, environments to exploit, dark corners and streets, hideouts, passages and the list goes on. This can also turn in to a real OCD hell, if you aim to hunt as many items as there is to be seen (or not to be seen) :D.The story is actually quite good in my opinion, yet icluding a bit typical theme of a dystopic/depressing world. Also do remember that this is a reboot: Not everything can be the same like in the good ol 90's.Garrett is not voice acted by Stephen Russell anymore, but the voice actor is no joke. He really reflects Garrett's materialistic, kleptomanic and cynical personality really well and gives a good immersion to the game.I like how the game doesn't hold your hand if played on master custom options. You have to find those switches yourself, figure out the puzzles alone and plan your movements when doing housecleaning and anything in stealth.  I highly recommend Master difficulty for the best and longest game experience. (this game hasn't got a 12h linear story like in Bioshock Infinite.)THIEF can be played with more aggressive gamestyle, but it's not regarded to be the most original way to play the game and it is not so fun compared to all the sneaking, lurking around and running on the shadowy rooftops. Also kinda funny when you think about Garrett's negativity about killing and positivity about stealing :).Compared to Skyrim, I didn't find almost any bugs or glitches, apart from repeating conversations and AI NPCs that sometimes just decide to stand all night long at the same place. Even with those, the AI is extremely intelligent when it comes to sneaking.  ---->You will use load/save alot.I did NOT like:                     - Some ridicilous obstacle restrictions that even an eight year-old could climb.                      - Getting stuck on finding a way to rare loot or avoiding randomly patrolling guardsmen.THIEF is a reboot done well, even with all the negativity amongst some of the oldest fans and people with too spesific expectations.

												Pros:Visuals are great, leveldesign very nice, epic loot is hidden, so you have to take your time to enjoy.The new Focus ability is neat as well, although no real game changer. Cons:The story could'nt be much worse. Someone really tried to get over the cancel of his favorite soup opera. A lot of unessessary drama, no real thought was put in the motivion of the protagonist. Also, there are a lot of achievements for a very agressive and offensive playstile, that doesn't really fit the sneaky Masterthief, but I ignored that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												The bad reviews were mostly right. Just finished the game as a fan from Thief since the first game. Hated the stealth in AC4 (although is a great game) and hoped that this game would show how a stealth game should be.CONS: almost no freedom, poor AI, anoying bugs (specially the sound), and for me, VERY repetitive. Enemies have only 2 types, respawn of guards in the city, a lot of loading screens, and the lack of chars to interact. Lazy difficulty system (on/off hud itens).PROS: playing w/ Garret again is like meeting an old friend. Graphics and atmosphere are great. Some chapters are memorable and beautifuly designed. The first hours were really good to play. The optional focus system is a great idea for newbies.The AI is the more disappointing part. Scripted, dumb and lifeless. They should look real, go ask for help, surround, reinforce the protection (a more complex script at least). Instead, they act like an game from the 90's. Things shoud look really difficult to steal. Killing a guard should always be the last option.I was hoping an open stealth sand box, challenging AI and next gen graphics. Got only the last one. This game will be forgotten in some months, result of the poor experience, little replay factor and no innovation in the genre. Don't pay the full price if you're not a fan of the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Side quests are where this game really shines - environments are small, but this is the only part where at least you have some sort of freedom of exploration. Main missions, on the other hand, are too linear for my taste and story is pretty forgettable. There's a lot fun to be had in Thief, mostly due to heavy emphasis on stealthy, non-confrontational approach to all adversity, but all too often you get the feeling that something's missing here, and it ain't all that sh!t you just nicked.Also, can't go wrong with those fabulous first person animations. I wish more games were able to give you this uncanny feeling of controlling an acual human being, instead of floating cameras with gun props attached on front.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												I can't say enough good about Thief!  It is so immersive and I love how they actually force you to play the game, there are no shortcuts and the in game "help" (focus) feels right.  I love that there is no fast travel, so you constantly have to move about the world.  I love how many hidden treasures there are to find, and the variety of collectable items there are.  I love the challenges that each client job and chapter give you, and the custom difficulty levels mean endless replay ability.My only complaints would be the occasional pathing glitches that the AI experiences, and some occasional Audio bugs which make some voices much softer than the normal volume of the ambient voices.9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Dishonored is anoth...wait...this isn't Dishonored? Hmmm.Yes I realize this is part of an old series and not a Dishonored clone...in fact Dishonored is more of a Thief clone than anything else, but due to the fact that this is the first game in the series for probably a decade most people will shove out the Dishonored comparisons.I have to say I am a bit unhappy with the "challenge" aspect of each chapter of the game (given that's what games give you now...there's no more playing games for fun or entertainment, achievements and beating other people is far more important)...it can be interesting to have the challenges in the game but I don't really care for a rating system when I'm playing the campaign of the game, if I want to be insulted for a crappy performance I would specifically pick "Challenge mode".The game itself looks nice although it was made for previous gen consoles and received the "upgrade" for newer ones and the PC...the PC version feels more like a console port in regards to the graphics than a game that was tailored to each system (IE: Dragon Age Origins and other types of games that weren't just hastily ported to make money)...if it was upgraded properly for the PC I'm not seeing it (and yes, I have my settings turned all the way up).I do enjoy playing stealth games of this type despite not being all that great at the stealth aspect (patience is for losers).I'm now bored with reviewing this so my point is; buy the game if you enjoy stealth games. kthxbai

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Side quests are where this game really shines - environments are small, but this is the only part where at least you have some sort of freedom of exploration. Main missions, on the other hand, are too linear for my taste and story is pretty forgettable. There's a lot fun to be had in Thief, mostly due to heavy emphasis on stealthy, non-confrontational approach to all adversity, but all too often you get the feeling that something's missing here, and it ain't all that sh!t you just nicked.Also, can't go wrong with those fabulous first person animations. I wish more games were able to give you this uncanny feeling of controlling an acual human being, instead of floating cameras with gun props attached on front.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Solid reboot of a classic series. While its issues are well-publicized (annoying button mashing, linear segments, iffy AI, poor writing, etc), most of said issues have been completely overblown by most critics. Yes, there are linear segments in the game but they comprise a tiny portion of the overall experience. Of the 40+ hours I spent playing the game, maybe an hour of that consisted of linear segments. The vast majority of game takes place in large, open-ended areas that promote exploration. AI can bug out on occasion and get stuck on the environment or loop VO indefinitely but these cases are the minority. On Master difficulty, the AI is pretty decent and will definitely offer a challenge. The game's writing isn't great but it's not the abomination some reviewers make it out to be. It's pretty standard videogame writing. If you're solely motivated by story, that may be a problem for you but if you play stealth games because you actually enjoy stealth gameplay, it won't be. Combat is clunky and unsatisfying but that was the case in the previous games as well. And really, if you're fighting in a Thief game, you're playing it wrong.Ultimately, when played properly (stealing all the loot without touching any NPCs) on Master difficulty, the overall experience is faithful to the series. You still get the same satisfaction from stealing without being detected. Make no mistake, the new Thief is very much a pure stealth game. Unlike the recent Splinter Cell and Hitman games, combat is not a viable playstyle. If the idea of sneaking around and stealing stuff isn't inherently appealing to you, you will not enjoy this game. However, if you're looking for a solid stealth game that retains most of the strengths of the Thief franchise, you will likely enjoy this entry in the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Thief 4 isn't so much imagined and designed as it is churned out by a giant game-making computer in the service of Square Enix's finance department. Everything is entirely as expected. Scripting awful, cut-scenes awful, voice-acting painful, plot unintelligible, graphics brown, textures popping in over a period of minutes (shoddy Unreal3 engine) etc. etc. The main city is not so much a real place as a more or less random copying and pasting of building parts. 75% of the door are just background and cannot be opened. All of the rooms contain the same things. That's not to say there isn't some fun in trying to steal all the trinkets on the side-quests, but the money you get for them doesn't buy anything useful, so there's not much incentive: the three main gadgets can all be purchased for peanuts early in the game. Main quest levels are abysmal until level 5, when the programmers finally decided to try their hand at level design, rather than just linear paths or maps no bigger than my house. After this, it gets a bit better, but then you have the plot to compete with (such as it is). Halfway through the game the obligatory zombies appear that can also see behind them, apparently, which is just cheating. Other misfires include some shadows which don't quite work properly, some light areas which shade you just fine, a sneak button AND a sneaky-sneak button, and the ability to climb up and fall down only when the game says you can. There are also some third-person climby bits like Uncharted and a level running away from things, like a fifth-rate Uncharted. To sum up: it's not terrible, but you're better off spending a few pounds on Dishonored, a game created with some degree of imagination, invention and passion, or playing Thief 1 and 2 (costing pennies), or playing The Dark Project (costing nothing) or even playing Thief 3, or perhaps just pressing your thumbs in your eyes until it hurts. 5/10.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Despite a variety of bugs that signal the game was probably released too early, Thief is a title to recommend to people who like sneaking through the shadows.  DIRECT combat really isn't much of an option - sneaking around your opponents or distracting them usually works better. If the guards see you, run like hell (or reload a save). The story writing probably could have been a bit more fluid as the dialogue in particular is a bit cheesy at times. There are a few bugs, like the treasure map hunt that currently has no end, that need to be patched. The controls take some getting used to (such as the "drop down" button not typical in PC games), but once mastered, the game is genuinely fun to play. For anyone moderately serious about gaming and worried the game is too casual, I recommend playing on the hardest difficulty setting and turning a lot of the unnecessary bits off (such as the Focus ability). Eidos did allow for relatively nice modding in that way. Would I recommend to a friend? Depends on what sort of game they like, but I enjoyed my time in Thief thoroughly (college work did not get done).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Pros: patiently sneaking through this is fun, tense and challenging. Caters to many challenge levels. Lots of stealth tools and options. Captures a lot of major elements of the first three games. Memorable missions that flesh out the world. Focused plot. Disturbing, dark atmosphere. Playstyles, collectibles and Thieving Challenges add replayability.Cons: buggy, albeit I didn't encounter any that did more than break the immersion. Bad dialog with ok-to-bad voice acting, and obvious repetition of lines. Slow start, and not all will find it engaging even once it does get going. Plot revolves around the obnoxious, snarky, angsty Erin, and can be hard to follow. As a reboot, does indeed drop most major elements of the lore and world of the first three.My recommendation: lower your expectations, know not to expect something that lives up to the first three or to modern stealth games, steel yourself whenever Erin speaks... and this can actually be quite enjoyable through almost all of it. If that doesn't sound appealing to you, the game itself is unlikely to win you over.And whatever you do, don't pay full price.The four comics are decent. The first two provide backstory for the game, the last two explain more about events during it. They make up a 20 minute read. There The soundtrack is great, fits the gloomy mood of the game. It has a running time of 26 and a half minutes. The digital artbook is a fairly interesting look into the design work. It has 22 pages.Overall, if it looks to you like you'll love the game itself, and only in that case, it's worth spending a little extra on this edition.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												I played the Thief demo when it came out in the late 90's. I bought it as soon as it came out. I bought Thief 2. I bought the third "Thief". I bought Thief Gold when it came out. Then I repurchased all three on Steam. Suffice to say, I really REALLY like Thief. Needless to say, I had high expectations for this game.It didn't disappoint! This iteration is addicting, despite some issues. To avoid a tl;dr, I'll summarize:The good:Love the bow. LOVE the bow. Ambient sound and music is spot on (a cornerstone of the originals)Rich environments and some "feels real" settingsAt least one level that will make you want to curl up into a fetal position and weep in shame at your fearThe bad:Can't jump, except for under certain circumstancesSome levels feel small-ish, some feel abnormally large (i.e. a wooden ship that seems to have acres of square footage)The map. It's nigh useless, especially if you're trying to track down the level entrances once you've beat the game. The ugly (spoilers?):The story. That's not to say it's a bad story, because it really isn't, in my humble opinion. It's just incomplete. Garrett was out for a year, and there's loud hints dropped that he was in an asylum. Why? How did he get out? The Gloom is gutting The City. Why? What is it? Where did it come from? Is it even connected with the plot? What happened to Erin? Who IS Erin, anyway? And oh my! Garrett's eye is part of a mysterious crystal! Yet nothing comes of that. His eye remains intact and the crystal seems to get put back together without it. So why bring it up? Square Enix and Eidos Montreal have created a great platform that could see some very epic gameplay, it's just a shame they didn't spend a wee bit longer on fleshing out the main story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Perhaps it's been a long time since I played the original series but I'm actually enjoying the game.  I admit the first 5-10h I was pretty frustrated and thought about giving it up but I went ahead and gave it a chance because I wanted to like it.First, I decided to play on Master and I turned off most of the help that the game offers like mini-map, waypoints, etc.  This certainly made it much more difficult and using some of the moves like swoop took me a bit to really use effectively.  Once I figured out how to use it became much more useful.As others have said, this is a stealth game. If you don't want to take your time, move slowly and sneak around then this isn't the game for you.I also wasn't overly fond of the look of Garrett and the rest of the world but the more I played the more it grew on me. Perhaps it's me not buying into the hype and just wanted a game where stealth actually matters and takes a bit of skill to manuever without being  seen.Note: To the guy who said all the ground sounds like carpet obviously hasn't played much.  Wood planks sound just like wood planks, stone sounds like stone, etc.  In fact just looking around with the mouse causes you to make noise that guards can pick up on.Overall for me I give it an 8/10 and I'm enjoying it and I'm looking forward to playing again on the next higher difficulty to earn more of the achievements.It boils down to what your expectations are and what type of game for which you're looking.The 2 things I don't like is combat, it's tough to melee effectively but I know that's by design and the lockpicking is designed for a controller.  I wanted to turn off the visual assist but it requires the rumble of a controller.  Otherwise I enjoy it and have played quite a lot.

Posted: June 16, 2014
												I think a lot of the reviews for this game are a bit harsh. I mean it's not going to win game of the year or anything but for the money it's pretty much all there. It's got a half decent story, it's not exactly challenging but it's fun enough. It's just an easy play, you don't have to think about it to much and it's entertaining. The graphics are beautiful and the voice acting is good, it plays a bit like dishonoured which is definatly a plus in my book. Overall if you have a bit of spare cash it 's worth it if you are into stealth and stuff like that, however there isn't as much combat as i thought there would be and frankly the combat sytem sucks, because there isn't really one there to be honest. combat, on the rare occasion that you actually get into it consists of mashing r and holding down q... not the greatest but it's not a big deal because it's a very small part of the game. If you are not sure wait untill it goes on sale (like i did). but honestly it is really not as bad as the reviews and metascore make out.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Perhaps it's been a long time since I played the original series but I'm actually enjoying the game.  I admit the first 5-10h I was pretty frustrated and thought about giving it up but I went ahead and gave it a chance because I wanted to like it.First, I decided to play on Master and I turned off most of the help that the game offers like mini-map, waypoints, etc.  This certainly made it much more difficult and using some of the moves like swoop took me a bit to really use effectively.  Once I figured out how to use it became much more useful.As others have said, this is a stealth game. If you don't want to take your time, move slowly and sneak around then this isn't the game for you.I also wasn't overly fond of the look of Garrett and the rest of the world but the more I played the more it grew on me. Perhaps it's me not buying into the hype and just wanted a game where stealth actually matters and takes a bit of skill to manuever without being  seen.Note: To the guy who said all the ground sounds like carpet obviously hasn't played much.  Wood planks sound just like wood planks, stone sounds like stone, etc.  In fact just looking around with the mouse causes you to make noise that guards can pick up on.Overall for me I give it an 8/10 and I'm enjoying it and I'm looking forward to playing again on the next higher difficulty to earn more of the achievements.It boils down to what your expectations are and what type of game for which you're looking.The 2 things I don't like is combat, it's tough to melee effectively but I know that's by design and the lockpicking is designed for a controller.  I wanted to turn off the visual assist but it requires the rumble of a controller.  Otherwise I enjoy it and have played quite a lot.

												I think a lot of the reviews for this game are a bit harsh. I mean it's not going to win game of the year or anything but for the money it's pretty much all there. If you are not sure wait untill it goes on sale (like i did). but honestly it is really not as bad as the reviews and metascore make out.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Some nice mechanics and good stealth game massively let down by a some what bizzare plot, missing (basic and necessary) features and a scoring system for the main game that makes no sense. *SPOILERS*The open world thing is great but you can't place your own map markers which makes getting round really hard, there are some Assassin's Creedy pipe and wall climb bits in the missions that don't appear anywhere else in the game and give you a really obvious "go this way its easier than sneaking past the guards" path. The bank heist mission is interesting and adds some slight depth to the city, but is really just a way of getting cash and using the new mechanic of avoiding the cameras. The city felt alive and chaotic, people living on top of people and it gave some great areas to explore, but after a while I found them more and more like a labyrinth. Many of the areas look the same or similar enough to be confusing, and the map was less than useless at solving this problem when it came to finding the way into a window or to the start of a mission. I often walked around trying to find my way into an area only to find myself compleetly lost. The gameplay is fantasticly fun, sneaking up behind guards and cracking them in the back of the head was brilliant. The environment often allowed me to trick the guards, triggering a guard dog to get them to huddle in one area so I could explore the opposite side. I regularly got caught out by traps and guards not being where I expected them to be (like behind a door facing it so when you open it they see you) but they where all scenarios I could believe would happen if you thought someone was going to break in. It makes sense that people guarding something will be looking at the obvious way in....Allthough magic is a core part of the story it doesn't have to be part of the gameplay if you don't want it too. I prefered to play using it as little as possible and trying to work it all out on the fly unaided but that isn't always possible. There are two upgrade trees, one magical (exchanging loot for skill points that can also be found by exploring the story missions) and one bought from vendors (loot for upgrades and tools). I found myself using the tools more partly because there are multiple places you can get upgrades but only one (irritatingly far away) place to buy skill points.I beat the game in about 12 hours on medium, I didn't do all the side missions but I was satisfied with the level of quality for the price I payed, the custom mission system gives the game some real replayability and once you get past the story you can just have some fun with it. There's even a mission in a brothel where you can nock everyone out with, what appears to be, heroin. The graphics are stable even on my older machine, some of the fabrics have artefacts in the rendering that I can't get rid of even after messing with the settings but I expect this is a driver issue and will be sorted soon (it in no way affects the gameplay). At the time of writing the benchmark tool is not brilliant, it hovers around the 20-25 FPS mark regardles of changing the setting so I assume that this again is a driver issue (not being optimised for the benchmark tool) but the game itself runs much higher than that.*REALLY STORY VITAL SPOILERS*The ending was odd, why did he put his hand on the book? What did that achieve?I never really understood the deal with the android people, and when I completed Ectors missions he says the man is working but we never get to see it which would have been a nice reward for doing his missions. The final 'boss battle' for want of a better word was good fun, it took me a few goes to work out where the shards had gone and to collect them. The shadows mechanic used was intelligent and fits well with the stealth aspects of the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Delving into the past is always a risky move and may not always win a company the encore that they desired. There is a very thin line between changing to much and changing too little in these sorts of games. Change too little and you will be branded as lazy, but change too much and people will start writing death threats to you. To be able to stand on that line takes skill, which unfortunately isn't always there.Thief, by Eidos Montreal is the reinvention of a classic franchise that has players take on the role of Garrett, THE master thief. When the city that created and defines him is threatened, Garrett must step from the shadows and uncover the truth before his world is torn apart forever.You begin the game in the middle of a job. Trailing along with you is your young, rash and slightly over confident protégéé Erin. In a nutshell you are tasked with stealing a special stone, you get caught up in the middle of a cult's ritual, Erin dies and you fall asleep for a year.It is when you wake up that the story truly begins, if you can call it a story. Throughout the 8 main missions it is really quite difficult to keep track of the storyline. All of the major events and characters that are meant to invoke an emotional response in the player just feel dull and boring, and the story elements just feel like a puzzle that's had all the pieces thrown in in the hope they will fit together. The story has to main ideas, the city is in peril and Garret just doesn't care and a revolution has begun but Garret just want's to find Erin. Your quest to find answers will unfortunately be quite boring and mundane, in many cases will only be half answered. "How the hell did Garrett get super thief powers?" is just one example. If you're looking for an enticing story to keep you hooked, the predictable betrayals and confusing plot points aren't enough to carry you through to the unsatisfying ending.However even with a whitewash for a story there is a silver lining, however thin. The stealth and thievery in this game is tremendously enjoyable, addictive even. Thief has abandoned the action loaded gameplay for a slow and stealthy style, and they have done this to good effect. As you will find as you play the game a majority of the missions require you to steal everything in your path. This will involve; lifting valuables, breaking into safes, and disappearing into the shadows. To help you with this you are given an arsenal of different gadgets, that will allow you to access new areas so that you can steal even more. Fire, Water and Gas arrows are also invaluable in distracting your enemies.Different arrows available to you in ThiefUsing all your gadgets and equipment effectively is extremely rewarding in a way that is hard to describe. It's as if you are a real thief, sneaking around in the shadows, disabling traps with your wire cutters, opening vents with your wrench or dousing flaming torches with your water. It is this feeling that probably kept me playing through even the worst moments of the game.The thieving in itself is an artform that will take many an hour to master. In every draw or cabinet there could be valuable treasure, on every desk there could be a clue to help you find a valuable treasure. It is up to you to find which draws actually do contain valuables and which on which desktops there are clues, but one thing is for certain. The thieving aspect can be dangerous, a guard could spot you at any moment so you must be very careful. The fact that it is so easy for a guard to spot you whilst you are opening a draw and the fact that you are very vulnerable whilst doing so creates an extremely addictive tension, and one must experience it in order to truly understand. It also allows one to become distracted so that they no longer have to concentrate on the many pitfalls of the game.Nice Golden Wine Bottle you can steal in ThiefSide jobs, as in any game, are optional. But if you truly want to understand what drives this dark and gloomy city it is strongly recommended. These jobs will allow you to meet citizens offering high risk jobs that can earn you some serious gold and some interesting experiences. Challenge mode is also recommended if you want to test your sneaking skills in well designed, timed scenarios. There are enough of these little hidden jobs and missions to keep you occupied and exploring the dark and mysterious city of Thief.Surprisingly enough this game often feels too dark. Yes as a Thief it would make sense that most of the things you do occur in darkness but it seems that, no matter where you go the lighting never changes. You could be in a house, castle or out on the streets and it still feels like you are just in a dark room trying to steal stuff. This doesn't make the game any better or worse, and it does create some atmosphere but I think it would have been more interesting if the lighting had have varied more throughout the game.Dark City of ThiefThe game is sometimes surprisingly too dark.Unfortunately when you start looking to aspects other than stealth to keep you entertained you will find that you are very limited. The combat for example, feels like it was thrown in as an after thought. Yes it is a stealth game and the aim is not to get caught but occasionally you will run into the odd guard. All you have to defend yourself is a high tech metal club and a weak dodge move and when you are coming up against fully armoured men with crossbows and swords, theres not much you can do to stop them from running you through.Armoured City Guard in ThiefThief Combat isn't great.On this gloomy note we shall move to the sound glitches. On multiple occasions I experienced looping guard dialogue, that continued until I got annoyed and shot the guard. There was also some inaudible speech during in-game cutscenes. It annoyed me even more that these occurred more often towards the end of the game, which means that I missed out on something that could have been vital to the storyline, but anyway. While there were too many sound glitches for a AAA game like Thief the experience wasn't completely ruined and I was able to push on.To sum up, if you are looking for a stealth based experience then Thief will probably fit the bill, although Dishonored may be more to your liking. Despite it's terrible storyline and multiple glitches it was enjoyable and I feel I got enough out of it for it to be worth the money.Thief Official SiteOur YouTube Channel

												Excellent game. Love the city design which has lots of twists, turns and nooks and crannies and multiple levels. There are a lot of hidden areas and secrets and much to explore. I miss Stephen Russell as Garrets voice but the new voice actor is okay and the game is still worth it. Some very interesting missions. Mutliple ways to play. Graphically this game is absolutely stunning and will blow you away. I haven't finished yet but up to now the storyline is very strong. Definitely rewards patient and thorough players. If you like stealth games like Deus Ex then you will love this.

												This is the first time that I played a game from the Thief franchise, so I can't say anything in comparing to those. But overall I like Thief. The main story sometimes is a bit dull, and I find it very boring to keep running after a girl who can't stop whining. Sometimes this bothters me immensely when she pops up on my screen. Also, I didn't really like chapter 5, but that just because I found it really dark & scary. And truth be told, those kind of stuff just ain't for me. But the 'bad' things didn't spoil it for me, because it's so rewarding when you can sneak around stealing stuff and nobody knows you're there. If you like sneaking around, this game is for you! :)

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Solid reboot of a classic series. While its issues are well-publicized (annoying button mashing, linear segments, iffy AI, poor writing, etc), most of said issues have been completely overblown by most critics. Yes, there are linear segments in the game but they comprise a tiny portion of the overall experience. Of the 40+ hours I spent playing the game, maybe an hour of that consisted of linear segments. The vast majority of game takes place in large, open-ended areas that promote exploration. AI can bug out on occasion and get stuck on the environment or loop VO indefinitely but these cases are the minority. On Master difficulty, the AI is pretty decent and will definitely offer a challenge. The game's writing isn't great but it's not the abomination some reviewers make it out to be. It's pretty standard videogame writing. If you're solely motivated by story, that may be a problem for you but if you play stealth games because you actually enjoy stealth gameplay, it won't be. Combat is clunky and unsatisfying but that was the case in the previous games as well. And really, if you're fighting in a Thief game, you're playing it wrong.Ultimately, when played properly (stealing all the loot without touching any NPCs) on Master difficulty, the overall experience is faithful to the series. You still get the same satisfaction from stealing without being detected. Make no mistake, the new Thief is very much a pure stealth game. Unlike the recent Splinter Cell and Hitman games, combat is not a viable playstyle. If the idea of sneaking around and stealing stuff isn't inherently appealing to you, you will not enjoy this game. However, if you're looking for a solid stealth game that retains most of the strengths of the Thief franchise, you will likely enjoy this entry in the series.
