number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												"Do you recommend this game?"  Barely.  Despite a bevy of complaints, I still find it hard to pick either way.  I did enjoy playing it for a solid 40 hours.  On the other hand, I came away from it very disappointed.  It plays like a Thief game.  It sounds like a Thief game.  It doesn't FEEL like a Thief game, though.  I'll explain why in a moment but let me get to the good points first.  Oh and by the way this will be full of spoilers.  The sneaking and actual gameplay is great.  Most levels were actually surprisingly tricky to sneak through unnoticed.  But there was always a way.  I must've replayed most sections at least a few times trying to get it just right.  Figuring out those situations was quite satisfying.  Two levels in particular (one in an abandoned asylum, the other in some fantastic buried ruins) affected me quite a lot.  One was marvelously creepy and scary with tons of great moments.  The other was just a joy to wander through and wonder at the mystery of it all.  And it helped that both levels were quite nostalgic of great moments/themes in past Thief games.And one more good thing I can say is that, taken on its own merits, I think the story in this game wasn't terrible.  I almost cared about it at times.  And it definately had me wondering where it would go next... I kept playing just to see if the great potential of it all would pan out.  Their were certainly some fantastic opportunities for some really classic revalations to be made......which the writers/devs completely failed to take advantage of.  That's the first of my complaints.  The story overall does fall flat in the end.  And speaking of the ending, it's one of the worst I've seen in a while.  They tried to make it artsy, which some may appreciate.  However.... it comes way too fast, is way, way too short, resolves the story only as much as it absolutely has to, and leaves to rot all that glorious potential for tie-ins back to past games.  There is absolutely no attempt to continue to hook the player.  Nothing at all to leave you saying, "Ooooh I can't wait to see where the next game goes!" Looking back at the game in general, none of the interesting personality of past Thief games is there.  This I believe is probably because they decided to completely leave out all the great factions from previous games.  No Hammerites.  No Mechanists.  No Pagans.  In fact they're never even mentioned aloud.  There's guards, but they're not anywhere near as interesting to listen to.  And they repeat their lines way way way too often for how dull they are.  I miss the oafish buffoon guard complaining that he'd rather be at a bear baiting.  The side missions are mostly useless time-fillers that are there just to let you earn some money without actually providing any interesting content.  The environments look beautiful but nothing feels lived in.  There's plenty of books to pick up and read, but doing so opens an extremely basic, minimal text menu.  With all the beautiful modelling, texturing and animation in the game... why not show me reading an actual book?  Immerse me in the world more!  Don't remind me I'm playing a video game by showing me a menu unless I'm trying to change video settings or something.  I very nearly didn't recommend this game, for all these reasons.  Particularly for the horrendous ending.  You never want to end a game like this with a, "WTF, that's it?!?"  Honestly, I think that kinda ruined the game for me.  But the more I think back on it, the more I can see that I did enjoy the majority of the time I spent actually playing it.  Particularly because the missions were challenging to perfect.  Given some time I could see myself going back and having a bit of fun knocking out the few achievements and secrets I missed.  But I'd also be disappointed again by all the wasted potential and lost opportunities for a game that could've been truely great.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Pros: patiently sneaking through this is fun, tense and challenging. Caters to many challenge levels. Lots of stealth tools and options. Captures a lot of major elements of the first three games. Memorable missions that flesh out the world. Focused plot. Disturbing, dark atmosphere. Playstyles, collectibles and Thieving Challenges add replayability.Cons: buggy, albeit I didn't encounter any that did more than break the immersion. Bad dialog with ok-to-bad voice acting, and obvious repetition of lines. Slow start, and not all will find it engaging even once it does get going. Plot revolves around the obnoxious, snarky, angsty Erin, and can be hard to follow. As a reboot, does indeed drop most major elements of the lore and world of the first three.My recommendation: lower your expectations, know not to expect something that lives up to the first three or to modern stealth games, steel yourself whenever Erin speaks... and this can actually be quite enjoyable through almost all of it. If that doesn't sound appealing to you, the game itself is unlikely to win you over.And whatever you do, don't pay full price.The four comics are decent. The first two provide backstory for the game, the last two explain more about events during it. They make up a 20 minute read. There The soundtrack is great, fits the gloomy mood of the game. It has a running time of 26 and a half minutes. The digital artbook is a fairly interesting look into the design work. It has 22 pages.Overall, if it looks to you like you'll love the game itself, and only in that case, it's worth spending a little extra on this edition.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Fun game, but not great however.Don't get me wrong, I definitely think my money was well spent buying it, but there is a lot of room for improvement. The bad:-As I never played the original thief games, the nostaglia factor was completely lost on me.- You need to mash "E" to do literally anything in the game, but once you get over that, its not that big of a deal.-The story doesn't really pick up for a while. -The puzzles are an insult to my intelegence, the take about 30 seconds to solve.-The sound is really messed up; sometimes there is someone talking in the next room and you will have no idea. Conversly, someone could be on the other side of the road and sound like they are right next to you. (this gets really anoying)-The supernatural skills, akin to those found is Dishonored, are next to useless. Combined with their cost to use ingame, they are a complete waste.-The guard AI should be totally scrapped, no redeeming qualities about it.-Character models look really weird-No character developementOn the bright side:-The game was able to introduce a supernatural element without coming across as hoaky-The art style and graphics quality are both beautiful in a very dark way. A powerful GPU is strongly recommended.-The game, like most other stealth titles actually requires some degree of skill.-Stealing things never gets old. My sum up:-mechanics 7.5/10-art style 9.5/10-graphics quality 9/10-story 6.7/10-character design 6.5/10-character develepement 4/10-guard AI 3/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Now that I have calmed down from my "nostalgic" rage, I have to admit: Thief (2014) is a decent game. I wouldn't go call it a master piece or very good, but it's fairly good and a nice experience on its own. If you start comparing it to the original versions or even Dishonored you are very likely to find a ton of things to nitpick and cry about. This was the mistake I did the first time, and although it was somewhat justified, it was in the end a bit unfair since I have to judge the game as ITSELF, not as a recreation of bygone glory days or as a rival to something else.With that said, I personally have enjoyed this new installment. There are, like mentioned, TONS of little and bigger things to complain about, namely the very restricted movement around the small sandbox environment you dwell in, and buggy A.I. (I just love the dialogue audio problem where the guards keep repeating the same things all the time... not). I also found the new way of peeking around the corners absolutely stupid (whatever happened to good ol' Q and E?), and the cinematic cutscenes look dámn weird at times - from cinematic view, that is. The story I couldn't care less about, and the chance to roam yourself from mission to mission in the city, although cool at first, is just tedious in the long run and I find myself getting lost half the time, thanks to the pretty useless map. I just wanted to get the mission started, not to trying to navigate through the confusing city layout and pondering which rope or ladder would lead me to a window that'd took me to the right place!And with THAT all said... I still like the game. The missions are fun to play when you adjust yourself to the game mechanics and the overall philosophy (meaning, the less you kill the more you enjoy the challenge), and some of the maps are just brilliant when it comes to gameplay, almost bringing memories from the Thieves of yore. Do I recommend this rebirth? Meh... on sale, definetely. If you loved Dishonored and unchristianly worshipped the original ones as your Lords and Saviors, I see no reason why you wouldn't enjoy this one as well... provided you play it with open mind. So, I might even recommend it. I think I will.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												I have played Thief since it originally came out, back when dirt was still new :) This version is quite different from the original series, Garrett is still the main character of the game, but I don't care too much for his "look", I think he's too skinny, though that is probably because back in those days he would be skinny like that, especially living the kind of life he would have led as a thief. I don't care for his overall look, but his voice is still Garrett all the way. Most of the time you don't "see" Garrett because you are playing in a first person perspective, it's only in the cut scenes that you see Garrett.The game play isn't really like the original game either, but I can't complain, it's interesting and playable.I have been playing the game for a few days now and have a pretty good feel for the gameplay, you are given tasks to complete, so far I have been able to figure out most of what has been asked of me, I have only had to look up a few things online. I like the save game feature so I can try out things without losing my place.Now to the stats, I wasn't sure if I would be able to play this game on my system, and honestly it's barely playable, BUT I can play it, hardcore gamers wouldn't like playing on my laptop, but for me it's just fine. My laptop is under the minimum specs they say this game can be played on (barely), it wasn't until I saw a video on YouTube of another player with the same specs I have, actually I had double the ram of his, other than that, the specs were the same and it looked playable, couple that with the fact that they had it on for half price last weekend, I figured if I couldn't play it at all, I wouldn't have lost too much money.SPECSThe specs of my laptop are: Acer Aspire V5-571P-6698, 15.6 inch screen, Intel Core i3-2377M 1.5 GHz (3 MB Cache), 8 GB DDR3 RAM, 750 GB 5400 rpm Hard Drive, Graphics Coprocessor Intel HD Graphics, Graphics Card Ram Size	128 MB, Win 8.1 64 bitAs I said, it doesn't even have the required minimum specs to play, but it does play, on the lowest settings. The only setting I don't have at the bottom is the resolution, I have it set to the same resolution of my screen, I believe it's 1280x768 or something close to that.I do get the black screen when I first start the game, I have tried the various fixes and so far none of them have worked, BUT the game does start after 4-5 minutes, fortunately I am able to alt-tab out of the game and surf the internet while I wait for the music to start on the game, then I go back into the game, that's the worst part for me is waiting for it to start, I also don't exit the game if I think I might play it a short time later, I just hit esc to pause the game, then alt-tab out of it....I have a rather slow internet, 3MBPS at best, so it took me 2 days to download it, if I would have left my computer on overnight, it would have been even sooner, but it was worth the wait. I would give it 7 out of 10 stars, the reason I don't give it 10 stars is because the game, as good as it is, isn't really a major match with the previous versions, it's close, but no cigar.I use my keyboard and mouse to play, it works for me, I did reverse the mouse up/down movement, I have always preferred the airplane style of moves where when you pull back on the mouse, you look up and when you push forward, you look down. The keyboard and mouse settings are pretty intuitive, I haven't remapped any of the keys, yet...I would recommend it for anyone who likes first person shooters, you don't have to have played the previous versions to enjoy this game, it can stand on its own, though if you know the history it will make for a richer story experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Now that I have calmed down from my "nostalgic" rage, I have to admit: Thief (2014) is a decent game. I wouldn't go call it a master piece or very good, but it's fairly good and a nice experience on its own. If you start comparing it to the original versions or even Dishonored you are very likely to find a ton of things to nitpick and cry about. This was the mistake I did the first time, and although it was somewhat justified, it was in the end a bit unfair since I have to judge the game as ITSELF, not as a recreation of bygone glory days or as a rival to something else.With that said, I personally have enjoyed this new installment. There are, like mentioned, TONS of little and bigger things to complain about, namely the very restricted movement around the small sandbox environment you dwell in, and buggy A.I. (I just love the dialogue audio problem where the guards keep repeating the same things all the time... not). I also found the new way of peeking around the corners absolutely stupid (whatever happened to good ol' Q and E?), and the cinematic cutscenes look dámn weird at times - from cinematic view, that is. The story I couldn't care less about, and the chance to roam yourself from mission to mission in the city, although cool at first, is just tedious in the long run and I find myself getting lost half the time, thanks to the pretty useless map. I just wanted to get the mission started, not to trying to navigate through the confusing city layout and pondering which rope or ladder would lead me to a window that'd took me to the right place!And with THAT all said... I still like the game. The missions are fun to play when you adjust yourself to the game mechanics and the overall philosophy (meaning, the less you kill the more you enjoy the challenge), and some of the maps are just brilliant when it comes to gameplay, almost bringing memories from the Thieves of yore. Do I recommend this rebirth? Meh... on sale, definetely. If you loved Dishonored and unchristianly worshipped the original ones as your Lords and Saviors, I see no reason why you wouldn't enjoy this one as well... provided you play it with open mind. So, I might even recommend it. I think I will.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Solid reboot of a classic series. While its issues are well-publicized (annoying button mashing, linear segments, iffy AI, poor writing, etc), most of said issues have been completely overblown by most critics. Yes, there are linear segments in the game but they comprise a tiny portion of the overall experience. Of the 40+ hours I spent playing the game, maybe an hour of that consisted of linear segments. The vast majority of game takes place in large, open-ended areas that promote exploration. AI can bug out on occasion and get stuck on the environment or loop VO indefinitely but these cases are the minority. On Master difficulty, the AI is pretty decent and will definitely offer a challenge. The game's writing isn't great but it's not the abomination some reviewers make it out to be. It's pretty standard videogame writing. If you're solely motivated by story, that may be a problem for you but if you play stealth games because you actually enjoy stealth gameplay, it won't be. Combat is clunky and unsatisfying but that was the case in the previous games as well. And really, if you're fighting in a Thief game, you're playing it wrong.Ultimately, when played properly (stealing all the loot without touching any NPCs) on Master difficulty, the overall experience is faithful to the series. You still get the same satisfaction from stealing without being detected. Make no mistake, the new Thief is very much a pure stealth game. Unlike the recent Splinter Cell and Hitman games, combat is not a viable playstyle. If the idea of sneaking around and stealing stuff isn't inherently appealing to you, you will not enjoy this game. However, if you're looking for a solid stealth game that retains most of the strengths of the Thief franchise, you will likely enjoy this entry in the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												After seeing the Gamespot feature of this title pitted against Bethesda's Dishonored, one would have an uneasy feeling of having invested on the title. I was a bit conflicted to say the least - I loved the time I spent being Corvo, and honestly speaking it was one of the few stealth titles that I got really immersed in. On the other end, Garrett, the master thief is also an icon to be recognized - he is the hero of the game series that built the foundations of the stealth genre. How could a reboot of the classic title for the the current generations gaming not stay faithful to the original? A bleak picture was already painted for me before even getting a chance play it. But we play on. Maybe at this point, what I really want to say is: take everything you read and hear about with a grain of salt. I know Gamespot is an authority when it comes to games but the best judge is still yourself. (Or putting it more humorously, I already bought the damn game, what other choice do I have but playing it?)Lo and behold, some of the things I watched and read were dispelled once I started playing. Let me first tackle the four points where Gamespot compared this title to Dishonored:1) Authentic World: Both worlds are beautiful. While Dishonored does a great job of utilizing the Steam Punk overlay on a Victorian inspired city, I wouldn't really say that Thief doesn't do an equally good job by creating the The City more realistically. The gloom-stricken city of Thief is as beautiful in its own foggy London town way. The shadows around the corners and the residents' whispers are both functional and gripping, if you care to listen intently. Details were worked on well and this is coming from a player using a low setting laptop, as the GPU capability is quite gimped. The only losing points of Thief is the loading time and the navigation aspect. Continuity, which is technically the end product of both is not as preserved as Dishonored. 2) Creative Choice: Ah this one is a pickle. Dishonored really packed the title with a lot of choice from freedom of movement to the tools and magic the character can make use of. Thief doesn't have this full luxury of this but if you think about it really, being a thief with a limited set of tools and somewhat contract driven, I would have to say the limitation is the very challenge the game offers. The game obviously is single minded as a thief should be - you have something to steal, and too much freedom of choice can become the master thief's undoing. 3) A City Under Chaos: Gamespot says that Thief's City is somewhat under populated for you to feel the Chaos ensuing. I can't really say much for this point as I've only reached the fourth chapter. I haven't seen the full extent of any riots or street fights, if the narrative turns to those events. But the lack of population save for the patrols of the City Watch and underworld gangs should actually serve as reminder to the player that you are a sore thumb in all that is happening. Here is a city under lockdown - and save for the occasional hanging, a ♥♥♥♥♥ displaying her goods, gloom victims, and bystanders - the streets should really be empty. The emptiness of the streets evokes loneliness and a certain level of dread.4) First Person Immersion: Garrett's gloves look really fetching, don't you think? Kidding aside, Thief manages to do an excellent experience in my opinion. The stealth aspect is laid out more in detailed compared to Dishonored. And the way Garrett interacts with objects like Windows and Frames make for an authentic experience. However, it can be overdone, and I would have to agree with Gamespot, as it makes for a redundant experience in some cases. (How different will be this window to the one on the next rooftop really?) The Swoop is a really neat move for the character as it makes you feel really sneaky. Aside from the physical hindrances I've mentioned in Creative choices, I really can't complain much about the way the first-person design was developed for this game.To me, the game is really beautiful in its own respect. While I haven't completed it, I would have to say that still offers the kick that it should for a stealth title. Dishonored, to me, is a slightly different animal. The things Gamespot mentioned that are the losing points of Thief should be inspected in a more positive view, as the lack or absence of some freedoms and features offer the challenge or flavor the title needs. I can't say much for the story yet but so far the journey has been immersing. One of the best features, I think, would be the custom difficulty setting of the game. You can pump the highest difficulty setting of the game with truckloads of additional restrictions to really test your skills. I believe that limitations drive your creativity further, and in a sense creates an atmosphere that being an infamous master thief is a hard life underneath all that stolen glitter and gold.

												Fun game, but not great however.Don't get me wrong, I definitely think my money was well spent buying it, but there is a lot of room for improvement. The bad:-As I never played the original thief games, the nostaglia factor was completely lost on me.- You need to mash "E" to do literally anything in the game, but once you get over that, its not that big of a deal.-The story doesn't really pick up for a while. -The puzzles are an insult to my intelegence, the take about 30 seconds to solve.-The sound is really messed up; sometimes there is someone talking in the next room and you will have no idea. Conversly, someone could be on the other side of the road and sound like they are right next to you. (this gets really anoying)-The supernatural skills, akin to those found is Dishonored, are next to useless. Combined with their cost to use ingame, they are a complete waste.-The guard AI should be totally scrapped, no redeeming qualities about it.-Character models look really weird-No character developementOn the bright side:-The game was able to introduce a supernatural element without coming across as hoaky-The art style and graphics quality are both beautiful in a very dark way. A powerful GPU is strongly recommended.-The game, like most other stealth titles actually requires some degree of skill.-Stealing things never gets old. My sum up:-mechanics 7.5/10-art style 9.5/10-graphics quality 9/10-story 6.7/10-character design 6.5/10-character develepement 4/10-guard AI 3/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Now that I have calmed down from my "nostalgic" rage, I have to admit: Thief (2014) is a decent game. I wouldn't go call it a master piece or very good, but it's fairly good and a nice experience on its own. If you start comparing it to the original versions or even Dishonored you are very likely to find a ton of things to nitpick and cry about. This was the mistake I did the first time, and although it was somewhat justified, it was in the end a bit unfair since I have to judge the game as ITSELF, not as a recreation of bygone glory days or as a rival to something else.With that said, I personally have enjoyed this new installment. There are, like mentioned, TONS of little and bigger things to complain about, namely the very restricted movement around the small sandbox environment you dwell in, and buggy A.I. (I just love the dialogue audio problem where the guards keep repeating the same things all the time... not). I also found the new way of peeking around the corners absolutely stupid (whatever happened to good ol' Q and E?), and the cinematic cutscenes look dámn weird at times - from cinematic view, that is. The story I couldn't care less about, and the chance to roam yourself from mission to mission in the city, although cool at first, is just tedious in the long run and I find myself getting lost half the time, thanks to the pretty useless map. I just wanted to get the mission started, not to trying to navigate through the confusing city layout and pondering which rope or ladder would lead me to a window that'd took me to the right place!And with THAT all said... I still like the game. The missions are fun to play when you adjust yourself to the game mechanics and the overall philosophy (meaning, the less you kill the more you enjoy the challenge), and some of the maps are just brilliant when it comes to gameplay, almost bringing memories from the Thieves of yore. Do I recommend this rebirth? Meh... on sale, definetely. If you loved Dishonored and unchristianly worshipped the original ones as your Lords and Saviors, I see no reason why you wouldn't enjoy this one as well... provided you play it with open mind. So, I might even recommend it. I think I will.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Very good game overall. A bit different to previous Thief games. More liner in terms of mission space but much more open between missions than other versions of thief. Map is awful, sound is buggy. The main character is really well executed, previous versions of him were much more interesting and better portrayed. Graphics are really good, a set up over human revolution but they seem to have come at a design cost in the form of loading screens. Combat was done much better in previous games. The interactivity of the world is a big improvement over past games. In comparison to Dishonoured, Thief is much darker, even though it draws on similar themes. Garret is a much more interesting character than Corvo but the voice artist in this game does not give the best performance. Gone is the world weary Garret and he is now a bit too smug.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												There are lots of conflicting opinions of this game. That's probably because some of the elements of this game are put together quite well while others seem like they were rushed through. Everything about Garret's sneaking around is flawless. The levels are also done well. Everything about his bow is great to. Also Garret has all these modified arrows that are so awesome.On the other hand it feels like the story line and the cut-scenes were an afterthought. If you are impatient you will not like this game. The next gen graphics take a while to load in between levels. Also you can't rush in and overpower your enemies. If you try that you will always die. That sounds bad, but it's not. This game makes the player plan my every move carefully providing them with a good challenge. It plays like a stealth game, because it's a stealth game (what a concept). If you played a previous thief game and enjoyed it you will probably enjoy this one. Over all it was a lot of fun and I that's the most important thing. I definitely recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												The game is absolutely tremendous, and is a great addition to the Thief franchise. However, there is only one fatal flaw in the game that is making me write this review, and it is that one flaw that ruins the game completely. (NOTE: THIS HAS BEEN FIXED BUT READ ANYWAY)There is a bug in the game, and how it got past the QA team, it is a mystery. The bug consists of me trying to leave the clock tower after beating the 4th chapter. However, when I go to leave the clock tower, I am placed right smack dab in the middle of it, furthermore unable to leave or even proceed with the game. It is because of this fatal error that I simply cannot recommend this game. The game was working absolutely flawless up until this point, and up until then the game was just ruined for me.EDIT: Apparently Square Enix moderators aren't taking this seriously at all on the Thief forums (http://forums.eidosgames.com/showpost.php?p=1999513&postcount=7), as opposed to them quickly answering a gaming magazine about the issue (http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2014/04/01/users-report-date-related-thief-save-data-corruption-square-enix-responds-.aspx). I've tried doing the suggested action of reverting my computer time to April 8th, but that hasn't worked.Due to the irresponsibility of the company's staff and their lack of response to customers in place of the hasty response to public magazines, This game has earned an indefinite 1/10. EDIT EDIT: The bug has been fixed but the way the staff handled it was still unprofessional. The game is now playable just fine, but who knows what else could happen that could make the game unenjoyable? Only time will tell. The game's great, the techincal support, however, is not. For now, my final verdict is a 6/10, and is reccomended, as opposed to me earlier not reccomending it.

												Now that I have calmed down from my "nostalgic" rage, I have to admit: Thief (2014) is a decent game. I wouldn't go call it a master piece or very good, but it's fairly good and a nice experience on its own. If you start comparing it to the original versions or even Dishonored you are very likely to find a ton of things to nitpick and cry about. This was the mistake I did the first time, and although it was somewhat justified, it was in the end a bit unfair since I have to judge the game as ITSELF, not as a recreation of bygone glory days or as a rival to something else.With that said, I personally have enjoyed this new installment. There are, like mentioned, TONS of little and bigger things to complain about, namely the very restricted movement around the small sandbox environment you dwell in, and buggy A.I. (I just love the dialogue audio problem where the guards keep repeating the same things all the time... not). I also found the new way of peeking around the corners absolutely stupid (whatever happened to good ol' Q and E?), and the cinematic cutscenes look dámn weird at times - from cinematic view, that is. The story I couldn't care less about, and the chance to roam yourself from mission to mission in the city, although cool at first, is just tedious in the long run and I find myself getting lost half the time, thanks to the pretty useless map. I just wanted to get the mission started, not to trying to navigate through the confusing city layout and pondering which rope or ladder would lead me to a window that'd took me to the right place!And with THAT all said... I still like the game. The missions are fun to play when you adjust yourself to the game mechanics and the overall philosophy (meaning, the less you kill the more you enjoy the challenge), and some of the maps are just brilliant when it comes to gameplay, almost bringing memories from the Thieves of yore. Do I recommend this rebirth? Meh... on sale, definetely. If you loved Dishonored and unchristianly worshipped the original ones as your Lords and Saviors, I see no reason why you wouldn't enjoy this one as well... provided you play it with open mind. So, I might even recommend it. I think I will.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												I'll admit, when I first started playing Thief I felt like the game would require a lot of patience and eventually things would become mundane and boring. I decided to restart the game on MASTER difficulty and  I certainly made the right decision.The game really picks up after the first half and the enemies you face act realisticly and most environments are incredibly large and complete. There are almost always multiple ways to progress and the game allows for many different playstyles. The story is really what keeps me playing though. Each new situation is like a game of chess, you need to move this way as a guard moves that way. As I am about to complete my first playthrough I realize how much fun this game when it's challenging. I turned off most of my HUD (except lock-pick indicator and waypoint marker)  and I highly recommend it if you want the advertised feeling of true immersion. To conclude, this game can be great or bad depending on how YOU want to play it. Want to play on normal difficulty? Prepare for a mundane, short, less rewarding experience. Want to challenge yourself on Master and turn off a lot of the HUD? Then you'll have a dangerous environment filled with scares and strategies each time you open a door or turn a corner. This being said, I encourage those who enjoy a challenging, first-person singleplayer to check out Thief!!! 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												I think of this game a lot like Portal.  "But they're nothing alike", you say, and you're completely and indisputably right.  But they share similarities and we'll start there.  Each main quest mission in this game is like a Portal chapter, at its core focusing on solving puzzles, avoiding environmental hazards, and using various devices, equipment, and well, stuff (portal gun, bow, gel, arrows, cubes, lockpicks).  But imagine Portal with the additional element of survival, more ways to play, extra objectives, better graphics, combat, more environments, and just overall more content.  That's what Thief is and that's why Thief is different from Portal - because it has all those things.There definitely was a lot of puzzle-solving in Thief.  Guards patrol the same scripted routes and the objectives remain the same regardless of which door you come in from to get there.  Perhaps some would prefer something more organic, but the way they've done it definitely impacts the gameplay, making it much more cinematic, dramatic, and rewarding.  It's the same feeling I got from completing a hard trial in a Portal game, and that's why Thief reminded me of it.  And it's not easy by any means to emulate that kind of feeling.So yes; Thief is, in a very important sense, kind of like Portal, but a lot better.  And Portal was a darn good game.  This game gets my recommendation.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												All around a great game.Definitely some annoying bugs, like conversion loops between guards that are the same (not even 2 varying ones, just the same ones over and over and over). Regardless, I was surprised at the low metacritic score, which I'm guessing is largely due to its attempt to stay within the Thief series.I'm a big fan of the original series and this one really failed in its story to keep on track with that... it's like they ignored much of the series' story. The female character in this one had the personality of a rebelious teenage girl - obviously something that gets pretty dang annoying.No real magical lure as existed as you got near the ends of Thief 1 and 2. Other annoyances, like the rope arrows not being able to attach to anything wooden, but instead only available at select locations (and there aren't that many really).Despite all that I still really enjoyed the game. You "stole" way more in this game, which makes since if you're a thief. The city was huge and full of secrets and places to explore.Whether you are a fan or not of the original series doesn't matter. It didn't ruin the series for me, but I'm sure hoping someone can follow this with another one that recovers it from that massive failure of this ones story... which I think is do-able, but no small task.

												If you're a fan of the original Thief games then you'll have fun with this reboot of the franchise. It adds enough new features on the original games to make it interesting, and its fun to have another adventure hiding in the shadows as a master thief once again.As a newcomer, this game wouldn't feel much more than an average. 												Good game, but there are a coupble of things I need to point out. The soundtrack for the game was bland, like it was put together in a couple of days. The music was extremely loud especially in the parts where concentration is a big thing. It's hard to sneak about when rock music is drowning out every other sound in the game. You are a thief, of course.Being a some-what "hardcore" gamer for the Thief series, I enjoyed the game nevertheless. Although this game should have been an improvement, I consider the previous games superior.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I thought this game would be good. I was wrong. It's fantastic.After acquiring the claw from Erin (Aaron?) traversing the world becomes almost infinitely easier - utilizing grates and hooks to get around and disappear in a flash. The sound design is fantastic, the graphics are beautiful, and the game itself is possibly one of the easiest to stick with that I've played in a long time. The story flows effortlessly and keeps your attention 100% of the time.I think my favourite part of the game is the extensive AI. Guards don't patrol a set path, they don't have specific orders from the game, they look everywhere and randomly -- and are even aware of hiding places that you might try to take advantage of. Don't rush through doors just because a moment ago nobody was there -- and don't expect him to stay asleep forever.Thief is easily one of the most exciting games I've ever played. It's rekindled my love for video games.Thanks, Steam.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Consolized version of a PC classic.  Thief takes away much of the freedom seen in the superior predecessors, and slaps on contextualized console gameplay mechanics to further limit the game.  Remember how you could climb almost anywhere?  Gone.  Remember how many different types of terrain would make a different amount of noise?  Pretty much gone.  Being able to interact with/pick up most objects you come across was also removed, and no longer can you use your rope arrows in many different places.Remember how detailed, unique, and interactive the world was in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, which is from the same studio?  Thief doesn't even come close.  In addition, level design is much more linear and much less intelligent than that of the first two Thief games.This reboot also fails to capture the same mystical, creepy feeling present in the first two Thief games.  Instead, it has a very generic steampunk setting, rather than the distinct and eerie one seen in the classics.  They attempt to turn the franchise into a more story-driven one, but the cutscenes and dialogue are laughable and have signs of poor production value (with near-broken audio as well).  Mediocre sound effects and stupid, predictable AI don't help its case either.Fans of the original Thief games (the first two specifically) will be disappointed by this game.  Fans of Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Dishonored will also be disappointed by Thief's more linear, limited, and more casual gameplay.  They'll also be disappointed by its lack of detail and more generic setting.  Thief does nothing to stand out, it's just a reduction of the greatness seen in the first two games and it's worse in just about every way.  This is the result of console focus; it's dumbed down and just a fraction of the original, because a game as complex and challenging as Thief Gold for example would overwhelm most gamers.  Its gameplay is not quite as limited as, say, the Metal Gear Solid franchise, but that's not saying much.  Don't even bother getting this on a sale.

												Side quests are where this game really shines - environments are small, but this is the only part where at least you have some sort of freedom of exploration. Main missions, on the other hand, are too linear for my taste and story is pretty forgettable. There's a lot fun to be had in Thief, mostly due to heavy emphasis on stealthy, non-confrontational approach to all adversity, but all too often you get the feeling that something's missing here, and it ain't all that sh!t you just nicked.Also, can't go wrong with those fabulous first person animations. I wish more games were able to give you this uncanny feeling of controlling an acual human being, instead of floating cameras with gun props attached on front.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												The bad reviews were mostly right. Just finished the game as a fan from Thief since the first game. Hated the stealth in AC4 (although is a great game) and hoped that this game would show how a stealth game should be.CONS: almost no freedom, poor AI, anoying bugs (specially the sound), and for me, VERY repetitive. Enemies have only 2 types, respawn of guards in the city, a lot of loading screens, and the lack of chars to interact. Lazy difficulty system (on/off hud itens).PROS: playing w/ Garret again is like meeting an old friend. Graphics and atmosphere are great. Some chapters are memorable and beautifuly designed. The first hours were really good to play. The optional focus system is a great idea for newbies.The AI is the more disappointing part. Scripted, dumb and lifeless. They should look real, go ask for help, surround, reinforce the protection (a more complex script at least). Instead, they act like an game from the 90's. Things shoud look really difficult to steal. Killing a guard should always be the last option.I was hoping an open stealth sand box, challenging AI and next gen graphics. Got only the last one. This game will be forgotten in some months, result of the poor experience, little replay factor and no innovation in the genre. Don't pay the full price if you're not a fan of the series.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												When it comes to the new Thief game, it's impossible to avoid comparing it to the now-classic predecessor Deadly Shadows. It also makes sense to rank it against the recent stealth/action hit Dishonored. In my opinion, Thief 2014 loses to both these games by a different margin. It's not nearly as deep and engaging as Deadly Shadows. At the same time it delivers the experience similar to Dishonored though I still find the latter to be the better game by design.However, comparisons aside, I still think we have a pretty solid game here. While it failed to deliver the constantly engaging experience, it still had enough moments to keep me going for almost 50 hours. Here are a few things to mention:- The game looks great. The graphics are impressive and the pre-rendered cutscenes do look really nice.- The level design is rather mediocre. There are a few cool moments in the game like the asylum (a neat tribute to Shalebridge Cradle) or the Northcrest Mansion escape. But some levels are definitely a failures with my biggest disappointment being the brothel level where in reality you have to spend 75% of the time exploring the dull catacombs. - The storyline is nothing but a glue to stick the missions together but it comes with a cast of rather believable characters.- The City itself is pretty interesting to explore and the client missions are definitely worth their time.- Finally, the overall game mechanics are subpar - the game is not really challenging on the regular Thief difficulty and most of the arsenal is barely used at all. A few trick will easily get you through all of the levels and there's no need to be inventive 99% of the time. Yes, there are tougher difficulty settings - but I expect every game to deliver the optimal experience on the regular difficulty.With all that said, I still can recommend Thief 2014 to the younger players who are new to the genre as well as the ones who have already enjoyed Dishonored. As for the veteran players of the series - there's a high chance of walking away disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												It's a grudging "Yes I recommend this game", but not as a Thief game. I didn't think the game was awesome (or even great), but at least it's playable. I suspected I wouldn't like this reboot so I deliberately played at the hardest level I could without perma death and made it as good a "Old School" Thief experience as I could. I wish they had created a new franchise for this, because this isn't really a Thief game. It's the same city, and the main character is called Garrett, but that's about it. I really didn't like the voice acting, Stephen Russell did a million times better job. But that's sort of OK, it's a different Garrett. The events of this Thief seem to take place some time after the original Thief games, but everything familiar is gone. No pagans, no Hammers (or Mechanists), no Keepers... nothing. On level 3 I briefly got excited when Keeper symbology showed up, then some pagan/trickster glyphs, but that was pretty much it. The old cathedral at the end of the game was a disappointment.The story was meh, but it kept me going. The ending was absolute utter beyond belief♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Graphically, it's pretty nice. Of course, it's light years ahead of it's predecessors, although of course those games are nigh on 20 years old. But I did enjoy the graphics.Audio was disappointing. There were times where conversations would go silent, and environmental effects like fires would stop – even when I was standing right next to a fire. Move a bit, and it would all come back.I play with sub titles enabled, and these were buggy as hell. Conversations would start that I couldn’t hear, and the subtitles would be printed on the screen. The silent conversations would then magically reset halfway through, and the subtitles would restart. On one occasion where I was poking around part of the city hub, the same conversation about Polly’s perfume/activities were played 7 times in a row, without fully completing the conversation.To complement this, some conversations would play twice audibly – there was a conversation about bear pits, and each time I heard this conversation, it would start, then as soon as the second sentence was spoken, it would restart and both would play at the same time.More ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.Worse, conversations could be lost – on numerous occasions when playing a chapter level, a conversation would start as I was following people. As I was playing the hardest difficulty level, it meant instant fail if I was ever spotted. On reloading after a fail, the conversation would not start again, including the person not moving about as they had been originally. This happen half a dozen times that I was fully aware of, who knows how many times it happened when I didn’t notice.One final audio issue, I was poking around the edge of the city at one point and could hear massive fires, the sort of fires you’d expect if you were in a burning city. Later in the game that section of the city opens up – and it’s on fire. Even though the setting on fire bit doesn’t actually occur at the point I started hearing the flames. Overall, the audio was poor. Levels seemed well designed, I always had a few routes, and managed to finish the whole game without knocking out or killing anything. Hell, even Deus Ex made you kill the bosses even if you were playing stealth, this Thief on the other hand didn’t require you too – something I appreciated in a stealth game. So a bonus point or two for that.While the environments tried to be varied, the creatures which inhabit this city were another let down. You had guards and civilians. An invisible ghost. And some strange human like things. Again, think back to the older games - guards, ghosts, undead, mages, elementals, civilians, pages, hammerites, mechanists, bots, rat men, mantises, monkey men, do I have to go on? Sheesh.And don’t get me started on the “Lets turn Thief into Assassins Creed” with the utter wank action sequences. Fortunately they were few and far between, until they got to the end of the game then realized they’d wrote code which they weren’t using and so tossed in a few more. So many better things you could have done instead off that.I didn’t really like the city hub in Thief: Deadly Shadows, and I don’t really like the one in Thief – although admittedly it’s much larger and better with plenty to do. Although when you think of games like Grand Theft Auto, HUGE worlds which you can run around in without being stopped by loading screens, why they decided to make you load the next section every other street was a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ In fact, while I’m complaining lets mention the pointless “Spam E to open windows” or “Spam E to move this amazing log that somehow manages to appear in every single ♥♥♥♥ing gap between a ‘S’ shaped crap”. Sigh.Can’t comment on the focus gimmick as I couldn’t use it due to the play settings, but my description of it as a gimmick should suffice to sum up my feelings on that score.Oh. And one last rant. HEY, GAME DESIGNERS. Since just after true 3D games were created, you've been able to jump whenever you wanted. In fact, I remember jumping on noisy surfaces in the old Thief games deliberately to draw attention to myself. So why the ♥♥♥♥ do you take away such freedoms in modern titles? Is it really so goddam hard to put in the basics like jumping.And something else - Thief 2 has a bank level. So does the new Thief. One of these is ♥♥♥♥ing HUGE with all sorts of fun♥♥♥♥♥♥ One is barely bigger than a shoebox. Guess which is which.I still replay the old Thief games every so often. I don't think I'll be replying this one.The Tomb Raider reboot returned to the origins of the story and retold it in a new way, and although I found fault with that game too, I enjoyed it greatly. This Thief root sets the old story on fire, pisses on its bones, buries it in♥♥♥♥♥♥and then dumps its own turgid story on top of that to make something unrecognizable. I really hope that this lacklustre game hasn’t killed the series for good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												This is a great game.  The graphics are terrific and the gameplay is very intriguing.  Now diehard Thief fans may not enjoy the changes from the older style Thief games, but for those folks who are willing to keep an open mind or who are new to the Thief genre, this game is a winner.  For one thing, there are multiple ways to approach almost any situation.  If you want to get through the game completely unseen, it is possible...not easy, but possible.  If you are the aggressive type and want to go through killing everyone in sight, well...ravage away.  It is a long enough game with a large world so you feel like you have definitely gotten your money's worth if you play all the side missions.  The storyline is interesting and the dialogue is very witty in many places.  It all depends on how you play the game and what your actions are.  This Thief is not as 'dark' as some of the earlier ones and differs in mood from say Thief Gold.  I didn't see this as a negative as some other reviewers did.  This game was a breath of fresh air after playing some of the earlier games.  This is not a criticism of the earlier games...just telling you that they shouldn't be compared directly.  This version of Thief is very good on it's own.  To believe it should be a direct descendant of the earlier games is to do all of the games a disservice.  Evaluate this Thief on its own and I believe you will agree.  There is a place for the old ones and the new both in the Thief world.  Enjoy...

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Yet another example of how "video game reviews" drag down a good game where many hours of blood and sweat went into. The tendency of reviewers to go mad as soon as a game does not reflect the reviewers expectation a 100%, is tiresome. This unprofessional babbling has nothing to do with reviewing objectively any longer. Every one can do it. It is mostly just the expression of a very biased opinion but disguised as a review. One article even rated Thief as alow as 40%....  come on, really? 40%??  This is a highly polished game, with a lot of atmosphere. Even the view of the scenes alone makes it worthwhile to play. How can one seriously rate it as low as a broken game (which 40% would imply - Yet the game is all but broken.)If you expect the freedom of previous Thief games, you will be disappointed. However, if you take the game for what it is, it is still a lot of fun. The tone it sets, and the mood it creates is very dark, distopian and gritty. Its first person movement immerse you well into the actions, and there are a ton of options to customize your difficulty. You can even switch off entire UI elements to immerse yourself even deeper.At times you struggle with the controls, but it is nothing game breaking and I got used to handle it as time passed. Thief's only big mistake is it's rather linear gameplay in the main missions, which is really the only downside of an otherwise great game.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												"Those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it...poorly"* Thief 1,2 = Coke* Thief 3 = Diet Coke* Thief (4) = New CokeFan reaction is same.Overall, I think it's a good game in its own right, just as I thought Dishonored was a good game. However, Dishonored wasn't called "Thief" with a pedigree to uphold. If this was released as a stand-alone game with a new universe and lead character (or even just a spin-off in the same universe with differe lead character) it would have had a much better reception.Reboot kerfuffle aside, this game reminds me a lot of Thief 3 ... in a bad way.* There's a City hub you spend most of your time retracing steps through* Level design is small and cramped* Missions are very short, even in the main quest* Your use of tools & abilities is often limited or contextual~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~* Unlike T3, The City Hub is the "meat" of the game, b/c you'll spend half your time exploring it or hoofing from point A to B in it. (Seriously, half my play time is just City Hub...*sigh*) It feels like a single "go loot the city!" Thief 1 / 2 fan mission (albeit a good one) with no over-reaching plot. Basso's "fetch" side missions increase the times you annoyingly retrace your steps in it. The addition of difficult-to-find "trophy room" loots eventually turns it from a fun "let's see where I can go and what I can nab" to a frustrating "where are the last 3 items in the collection? I feel so stupid!" Of major annoyance is how The City resets people. Knock a guard or citizen out, come back later, he's there again doing the same thing. It makes you feel like your actions have no impact due to lack of permanance. So, don't bother wasting arrows killing guards in The City. They just come back, and it's a waste of an arrow.* Ector and Vittori give side missions that involve going to separate maps, but they are small and short; probably 10-15 mins with a few guards and puzzles. They leave you unsatisfied and wanting for more. The main plot has the largest missions, but are still short, taking ~30 mins. Again, felt like T3 all over again. All of these leave you wanting for the days of Thief 1 / 2 where missions would take hours to accomplish on huge maps.* Folks complained about the spelunking in Thief 1 / 2 (eg: Horn of Quintus in T1), so T3 and T4 avoided it. You rummage through some old ruins in T4, but Garrett is no longer the Indiana Jones he used to be. Sad, because I loved those missions. Instead, you get "asylum" missions trying to creep you out. T3 had one (The Cradle), and it's like they rehashed it for T4. It's probably the best level, but it's been done before. The DLC provides a Bank Heist, but "been there done that" in T2.* The stink of X-box / PS port lingers as there's a crazy number of level transitions. They try to make them interactive (eg: opening a window, sliding through cramped boxes). What starts off as a novelty  turns into an annoyance. Why do I have to keep hitting the "use" key to finish doing this? Silly goose, that's so it feels like you're actually doing something instead of wasting your time on a transition. It  reminds you of how T4, like T3, was under tight build contraints, because it wasn't PC-exclusive. Hence the cramped, short levels and constant transitions.* Thieving is entertaining, but the constant petty larceny eventually turns into an insulting chore. You're a master thief, but you're lifting things that are worth pocket change.* Everything seems contextual. You can only jump & climb at designated spots. It helps to ensure you land properly every time, but it also reminds you of the lack of freedom you have. Likewise, I got stuck in a room looking for an item. I check a cheat guide... turns out I didn't try to climb the one specific bookcase in the room that allowed climbing while everything else did not. There's even an upturned table right next to the bookcase, but you can't climb that. I tried, hence I thought I couldn't go that way. But, I just didn't click on the correct object. Silly me. *rolls eyes** Same with your blackjack. You have to use the contextual "take down" button to knock folks out. You can't just whack them on the head with your melee attack button. * Same with the rope arrow. Did you honestly think you could just shoot it into any old wooden beam? No, silly. You can only shoot them at the specific beams that have specific rope-bound spots on them. That way you can't just go exploring whereever you please. silly goose.* Being "leet" and "edgy", there's now mandatory action sequences and parkour in some missions. This helps push urgency sometimes, but you're thrown into it abruptly and can die from a cheap kill if you don't react soon enough. It basically punishes patient gamers that play Garrett as a slow,  methodical thief by a) tossing them into situations they themselves wouldn't have let their Garrett get into, b) tossing them into twitch-gaming play-style situations they may not like playing. They also zoom out to 3rd person to show you doing some leet climbing parts. This just ruins the immersion of the game, making you feel like you're watching someone else perform the awesomeness instead of you doing it. Likewise, you can only do this awesome climbing on designated pipes and beams, not all of them. Why on earth should you be able to do it whenever you please? That's just silly talk, silly goose. (Again... lack of freedom).* When looting furniture, you have to open and check each drawer seperately. I know this lets folks pace themselves on it as guard patrols come by, but it just turns into a trudge. It would have been better to just have it automate the whole thing. Have Garrett quickly open and shuffle through all the drawers in like 10 seconds while the player looks on.* Lock picking "mini game" is still annoying. It was annoying in Thief 3, new version here is just as annoying. However, the "mini game" to search for hidden switches around books and pictures is really ingenious. It's actually immersive and intriguing. However, you get rewarded for Ghost-style playing, but there's no way to close some objects to make it really look like you weren't there. What kind of Ghost leaves a hidden floor compartment opened or a painting slid up with the safe exposed? Two steps forward, one step back?* "Focus" jedi skill and upgrades to equipment are a slap in the face catering to the "everyone's a winner" gamer. Your focus is basically a legitimate cheat that lets you no-brainer Batman detective your way through problems instead of exploring and thinking for yourself. I recommend playing the game the first time through with the "can't use Focus" handicap turned on in order to get a more Thief-like experience.* Like Dishonored, the difficulty modes are a joke, because the game is easy regardless (dumbed-down to the lowest common denominator). There's extra difficulty modifiers to disable aspects of the game, but some are a joke. "Can only use utility arrows". Really? I only used those as it was. "Can't use Focus." Really? Focus should be off by default. But, then they jump to Ironman modes or auto-fail missions if spotted. After a few cheap kills or guards spotting you while hidden you realize how abusive that can be.* Some missions have one-way doors/slides, and there's no warning. You're exploring, getting loot, oh, what's this button do? One-way door. But, I need to go back and explore that other area. Oh, silly goose. Just play the entire mission over again later, because you're stuck now. Once again, it gives you the feeling that you have no freedom.Overall, I like the game, I had fun, but it could have been more in it's own right.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												When it comes to the new Thief game, it's impossible to avoid comparing it to the now-classic predecessor Deadly Shadows. It also makes sense to rank it against the recent stealth/action hit Dishonored. In my opinion, Thief 2014 loses to both these games by a different margin. It's not nearly as deep and engaging as Deadly Shadows. At the same time it delivers the experience similar to Dishonored though I still find the latter to be the better game by design.However, comparisons aside, I still think we have a pretty solid game here. While it failed to deliver the constantly engaging experience, it still had enough moments to keep me going for almost 50 hours. Here are a few things to mention:- The game looks great. The graphics are impressive and the pre-rendered cutscenes do look really nice.- The level design is rather mediocre. There are a few cool moments in the game like the asylum (a neat tribute to Shalebridge Cradle) or the Northcrest Mansion escape. But some levels are definitely a failures with my biggest disappointment being the brothel level where in reality you have to spend 75% of the time exploring the dull catacombs. - The storyline is nothing but a glue to stick the missions together but it comes with a cast of rather believable characters.- The City itself is pretty interesting to explore and the client missions are definitely worth their time.- Finally, the overall game mechanics are subpar - the game is not really challenging on the regular Thief difficulty and most of the arsenal is barely used at all. A few trick will easily get you through all of the levels and there's no need to be inventive 99% of the time. Yes, there are tougher difficulty settings - but I expect every game to deliver the optimal experience on the regular difficulty.With all that said, I still can recommend Thief 2014 to the younger players who are new to the genre as well as the ones who have already enjoyed Dishonored. As for the veteran players of the series - there's a high chance of walking away disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												This game is a mixed bag of quality; on the one hand, the main storyline is plagued by under-developed characters and an overall forgettable narrative (not to mention the presence of Erin, the most annoyingly pretentious character to ever grace a Thief game). In fact the only character that I personally remember from the main storyline is a corrupt Watch officer named the Thief-Taker General, mainly because he was just so much fun to watch in the cutscenes (everyone else is either mopey or bland). Furthermore, certain levels in the main storyline feel annoyingly streamlined and linear, which hurts the overall experience greatly (at least for this player). On the other hand, the gameplay itself is solid and the visuals are stunning. While certain levels do follow a specific path, others allow you to approach them in your own way. And some of them are even memorable, like the "Dirty Secrets" mission where Garrett infiltrates a brothel. I especially like how immersive Thief feels; the way Garrett interacts with the environment really feels natural, as if we're really seeing through his eyes. The game's setting, simply dubbed "The City", is a joy to explore -- especially with the new gadgets introduced in the game, which allow you to access places and trinkets that are otherwise unreachable. The atmosphere in The City is thick and gloomy, with sickness and doom as far as the eye can see. And for this reviewer, it was downright beautiful in its own twisted way.Furthermore, the "custom difficulty" options are superb and really let the player customize his or her gameplay experience as desired. This was a spectacular idea by Eidos-Montreal, and is something we could stand to see more of in future triple-A titles. However, the difficulty interface is also hindered by Eidos-Montreal's bizarre decision to prevent the player from changing the difficulty mid-game, instead forcing players to start a whole new save file to experience higher or lower difficulty.Overall, the matter of whether you'll like this game or not really depends on what you want from it; if you want a good story with interesting characters and a satisfying conclusion, don't bother. But if you want an immersive and atmospheric addition to your gaming library, or if you're just curious about Thief 2014 in general, I'd say give this one a go at least once (but it's not likely you'll care to go through the main storyline again). For a better overall experience, though, check out the original Thief trilogy -- all three games are dirt-cheap here on Steam, and this humble gamer recommends each and every one of them.

												Fun enough game i guess, is quite slow, didnt get story at beggining since i have never played the original thief games. Maps are cool although constant loading in main city sucks and maps dont allow much back tracking which sucks when there are bonus objectives e.g find all loot and you cant find all loot because you cant go back to areas to look for it also collectibles and notes there are way to many of them and they are kinda boring, game does offer more than just stealth you can go full combat if you wanted but you will probably run out of arrows to quickly and not have the gold to replace them so best to stick with your batton and stealth until you complete the game atleast. Graphics are good, sounds are good, sound in cutscenes on surround sound is horrible at barely works but in game its perfect. very short game maybe 10 hours to complete all chapters and side quests, possibly longer if you want all collectibles and achievements but if your just playing through for the gameplay 10 hours indeed. Sidequests are boring and take like 1-5 minutes each, there are 8 main chapters for the main storyline (take 20-40mins each) and about 26 side quests (1-5mins each). 6/10

												Thief is a good and entertaining game. If you like sneaky games, you'll find plenty to like here and its difficulty customization is great. The graphics, sound, etc are also good - not perfect, but they do their job fine. As far as "Thief" goes, though, it has little to nothing to do with its predecessors and if you are looking for a proper Thief game you will be disappointed. This is not a genre defining game. But as long as you are not expecting such a game, you will have fun.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												There are two problematic trends at play here:The first is to rush games out before they're ready; this is bad enough with respect to downloadable content, but with critical crashes and bugs, this is a betrayal to the consumer.  I have abandoned the attempt to finish this game after two times, as this game will erase your savegames the moment it inevitably crashes.  Do not trust the reports that the savegame bug is resolved; twice I lost my progress just before the last level and resolved the plotline on Youtube.The second is to take a beloved saga from a time of dedication and innovcation and continue it with today's negligent simplifications.  Thief began with a terrifying ideal:  what would you do if a run-of-the-mill guard could kill you and your only recourse was to evade detection?  What if you were less powerful than everything else in your world?  NOW save the world.  The fanbase, one of the Internet's first gaming fanbases, has disbanded.  You've one chance to bring them back.  Make another game, and make it Thief.  Oh--and please release it when it's ready.

												I hated this game at first, at second and at third.But in the end, I've managed to squeeze some good fun out of it.To do this I had to:1. Actually rename it to Viscera Cleanup Detail Dishonored.2. Make a keyboard macro for the obnoxious "Hold E, Mash E" sequences.3. Turn off Garret's voice and subtitles and skip all the cutscenes. Play it for collectibles and powerups.4. Switch difficulty to Normal, play messy and loud, use lots of consumables.5. Turn all interaction and navigation prompts on. It is useful to know what your deranged movement autocorrect is planning.6. Throw bottles at people's heads. All the time. Of all the fun this game has to offer, this is THE fun. There's a guard on the watch tower? Bottle him. It's either he falls down like a rock, or screams and curses, unable to get down.That's it. This how you play it to have fun. Forget that it is a Thief game. Fight, kill, use superpowers and pick up rubbish. Be a Janitor Batman.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												The Thief franchize has been a very unique one over the years. The whole purpose of the game was to steal, remain undetected and discover things that should've remain hidden.Now, 10 years after Deadly Shadows a reboot of the game has been made. It's not a sequel of any kind or does it share all of it's previous characterisitcs. The developers stated once: "we made the game thinking about what Thief would be like in our times and not as a sequel to the previous games".Leaving the fact that this is indeed not a sequel of the game aside, there are a couple of changes within the game that seem to cause hardcore fans to not like that much and casual players to be more attracted to it. First off, the story has been changed quite a bit; while it still keeps its mysteries and whatnot interesting conversations, the story is now full of action, enemies, allies and sometimes not as stealthy as one might want. Despite that it has stayed strong, while it might seem cliche at some points it still has it's Thief touch in it.Another aspect that has changed is the gameplay. It's now possible to complete missions in various ways, but don't get me wrong, anything un-stealthy might sound easier than it is. The mechanics of the game work properly and while thingls like opening drawers and closets while crouching might not be possible (as it will utomatically make you stand up), there is no reason to think the game fails at any of it's gamelay aspects. Focus is another great aspect of the game, some, such as myself, dont think of it as a necessary thing to use in-game but it certainly gives the game a new way of going about missions, in fact it's implementation in-game has been more than justified and it's not just a simple over the top ability you'll get out of nowhere.Finally there are some interesting aspects I have yet to talk about. The various maps/scenarios are a thing that caught my eye, they certainly are quite the thing and all in all I think the whole exploration and just taking your time to look arround your environment really pays off as you'll find yourself with more loot and a personally amazing level design. To follow that up is the audio, one of the strongest aspects of the previous Thief games and that might've not quite gotten there this time, with a couple of bugs and some reapeating conversations, however it still stays strong and manages to immerse you into the game. As a final note there is a bit of a Horror/spooky part to the game I, as a sassy, found pretty scary, to the point where I had to stop myself from playing many times, I think this part of the game was interesting enough and it surely adds a first in  experiences for me, and despite my struggles I think it was nice for the game to have this many sudden changes of pace.PS: I didnt mention Dishonored because I believe that's a different First Person Stealth game and wouldnt like to compare it to Thief despite them sharing a couple of characteristics.TL;DR:- Good solid story- Good gameplay mechanics and options (including customizable difficulty)- Amazing level design- Ok audio and sound effeectsLooking at the game from a objective point of view and forgetting about the rest of games I'd say it's a amazing game that easily stands up to other games with it's story and gameplay. As a Thief fan I can still recommend the game, because it's still as unique as it's predecessors and I for one think the reboot was a success.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I almost feel guilty with how much I've enjoyed this entry to the Thief series. Folks have chewed the game up for not being very devout to the series and that it's another case of a cherished franchise getting screwed by corporate repackaging. While this game is far from perfect, I really don't think that's warranted at all. It's rare I have this much genuine fun with a game.First, I'll mention the bad. This game was optimized by a twelve year old. I had some stuttering on my system even on lower graphical settings, a number of crashes, and the occasional sound-glitch that cut half the game's sound. The dialog and story can be really corny (I mean, someone literally uses the line "we're not so different, you and I" without joking. Seriously?), and there's a huge detriment to the fact that you can't jump. Yes, that's right, you can't jump. You need to go to ledges to jump down or to jump onto something, but you can't leap whenever you want.So, with all that said, why do I like it? Well, I'm the kind of gamer who really, really likes stealth games, particularly in the case of FPS. I played a stick-to-the-shadows rogue in Skyrim, I snuck around throughout the Metro series, and I couldn't get enough of the earlier Thief titles. One of the most satisfying feelings I get is looting a room blind, slipping past guards just as they're about to catch me, and solving some tricky puzzles to get to a safe. This game is flooded with secrets, and between missions, you travel a huge city with a number of nooks and crannies waiting to be explored. There's also the stealth roll, which allows you to very smoothly leap from shadow to shadow, which is tremendously satisfying. One of the best aspects, though, is the environment. There's so much great atmosphere in this game, from a creepy abandoned asylum (with jump scares, be warned), to a burning bridge, to a lavish mansion. I got lost trying to look for so many secrets, and the rewards for finding them were pretty satisfying on their own. I even like the fact that Garrett is total crap in a fight. Makes it that much more terrifying when you're caught, because you can't defend yourself nearly as easy as other games.All in all, I'd definitely say buy this beauty, even if you're a diehard fan of the earlier titles. Once you get over some of the more glaring aspects, this is a real diamond in the rough.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												I have to give this title a 8/10. All in all it's a great game and proves to be very fun, especially with the sneaking aspect .So, here is my personal breakdown of the game.GRAPHICS- Absolutely freaking beautiful. Very gloomy setting to the game. With graphical settings on high, this game is most definitely eye candy. Only one issue with this and it just involves video quality and rendering at one of the cutscenes towards the end of the game. It appears to me that it is just the result of rushing the scene for whatever reason. It caught my eye and I'm betting I'm not alone. Otherwise flawless and fantastic experience.GAMEPLAY- Very responsive controls with a gamepad, no problems whatsoever. Engaging combat system which allows you to map inventory as you like, small upgrade system, just enough to keep you out of any customization menus for too long  and allows you to focus more on your creeping skills.STORYLINE- Interesting story that kept me grinding to see what was next( a good 20 hours even without secondary quests, no complaints here (although I cannot compare this with previous Thief titles as this is the first I've played). Regardless, i thought the game in itself did an extremely good job of morphing many story cutscenes directly into gaps of gameplay. UPDATES/SUPPORT- I know there was a save game problem due to a technical problem with time zones a little while back but the devs were quick to fix this problem and that is the mark of a good team. No problems I am aware of since that.OVERALL- To wrap it up, this game is definitely one to check out and not let slip through your fingers. I would recommend to everyone who loves: a good story, beautiful graphics, sneaking around, killing things, sneaking around, shooting arrows, blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up, burning♥♥♥♥♥♥ sneaking around, putting out candles, peeping through keyholes, picking locks, lifting loot while being sneaky, the dark, breaking bottles, and ummm...sneaking around ;)  Great Game, highly suggest checking it out.
