content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Despite a lot of negative reviews, I gave this game a shot.  I think a lot of the problems people had with the game have to do with focus and their difficulty setting. I did a custom playthrough on master difficulty with focus, knockouts, kills, food, waypoints, and button prompts all turned off. I went through the game with the majority as a ghost and somewhat as an opportunist.  And while some problems still persisted, I think the game was really fun.Some of the missions in the game were not very fun, and linear. Mission 1, the end of 4, the end of 6, and part of 8 were not very fun, but the rest were pretty great.Pros:Extremely fun stealth and gameplay, lots of different routes to take the majority of the game, lots of difficult loot to get, great side missions, majority of missions are fun, guards see you pretty easily (good thing). great atmosphere.  The city (will discuss below)Cons:bugs in sound, guard pathfinding, and a few other things.  Awful soundtrack with dubstep when detected.  Pretty bad chase sequences and climbing sequences.  bad storyOther than the gameplay, the best thing in the game, in my opinion, is the city or hub area.  It's huge and open, and with plenty of secret areas to discover.  It has very good atmosphere, with a lot of side missions and mini missions to do.  It has this feeling of despair which really helps the atmosphere out.Overall I liked the game a lot more than other people did. The last few missions were very tough and fun, and mission 5 is pretty creepy.Given a score I'd say 7/10 good game (real 10 scale, not ign 9/10 it's garbage)

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												  So I just beat Thief (not the Bank Heist dlc) and I have to say I love the game. Not sure what to make of the ending but if it means what I think it means then I don't like it (the ending that is). The ending aside there are a multitude of ways to complete objectives (you can go pure stealth-no knockouts/kills/being spotted, hybrid-knockouts and not being seen and/or Predator-killing and taking names) and to find loot. Just keep in mind that this isn't a fighting game so if you get 3+ enemies attacking you at once..you may not survive. You can replay missions over and over again building up money (or that perfect score) so you can afford the most useful/expensive items. New items from the merchant are released as you complete missions/chapters so don't bother hoping a good one will show up randomly.  At times killing/knocking enemies out is...broken. Some instances you can knock someone out and everyone nearby will hear it while other times they can be easily within ear shot and no one notices. You'll have to experiment (save a lot in this game so if/when you mess up you aren't screwed) to find a way that works for you. Some enemies are supposed to patrol certain areas but end up bugging and not moving which can mess up a perfect run (you'll have to log-out/back-in to fix this). If you do decide to kill with bow/arrows (your blackjack(melee weapon) is also an option) make sure you're accurate because certain ammo doesn't grow on trees if you know what I mean.  Although you don't need it to play/beat the game I suggest buying the players(strategy) guide because it will show you were 98% of the loot is (yes it still misses some here and there). It does show you were ALL of the "collectibles" are (I found all of them in one run during my playthrough).  If you really want a challenge you can turn off a lot of the help thats offered in the game and add more difficulty to the game. I won't bother listing all of the options just know theres a lot you can alter.  All in all I recommend this game to those who like stealth/stealing/puzzle-solving/action and a decent story. You will enjoy yourself.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												While I would reccomend this game, I only do so for the avid stealth game fans out there. For anyone else I'd reccomend something much less unforgiving. While it may look nice, the toughest part of Thief actually comes from the unified button for every acrobatic action you can do. The spacebar jumps, ducks, drops from ledges, dashes, and ultimately does way too much for a single key. Too many times I wanted to jump and fell to my death because the camera wasn't tilted upward enough. Additionally if you plan to not kill anyone and never get caught like I did then you'll be reloading your quick save quite a lot, making the game longer than I would have liked.Again if you're seriously into stealth games I'd reccomend it if only to get your fix, but otherwise I'd suggest you get something that's easier to play, or even just the prior Thief games.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												6/10I got this game at Media Markt for 4,00 EUR which was a great find. This game has a storyline very similar to Dishonored (sneaking, plague in the city) however, unlike Dishonored, the plot lacks in consistency and the game play is very linear. At one point I just got sick of opening and closing drawers and basically steal everything because it felt like it was the only point of the game.  The first part is very similar to Dishonored but then it's like the writers decided to change course halfway and instead of a plague infected city you have a thing called primal that got into a girl's body and made her create the gloom and blind faceless naked monster (wtf?). Then there was a scene at an asylum totally out of character for this game and that aspect could have been better explored because it was the most interesting part for me (phantoms, loonies, hidden cashes, and an overral good story). But then it was over and back we go to stealling all the things.  I also have to complain about the map, it's horrid, takes 20m to get to a place. Honestly there were parts I enjoyed like the client jobs but it was a bother to go an get them because of the stupid map. I could have given this game a higher rating if it wasn't for the ending - absurd as it was not to mention rushed as hell.Anyway, wasn't expecting more from a 4,00 EUR game. Good Buy,

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Thief's reboot came as a huge disappointment to me. Though the basic core mechanics are somehow functional, everything feels extremely artificial, constricted and predictable. The level design is both linear and uninspired, with obvious solutions to every single problem that's encountered. In addition to this, it is also highly inconsistent, and simple patterns are repeated way too often.The game isn't so much about observation and decision making anymore, it's more about dexterity and following the path that was carefully crafted for the player. Which is a real shame, considering that player movement is again very clumsy and restricted. I ended up getting spotted or falling to my death a few times only because Garett didn't perform the contextual action one would expect.Note that the linear structure is not necessarly a deal breaker for stealth games. Dishonored and Splinter Cell: Blacklist have the same level structure at their core, but individual action bubbles offer much more interesting challenges. Their AI is much more agressive, but the player is also granted additional options, meaning that playing as a ghost in those games require a fair amount of planning before jumping in the action. Thief doesn't have this anymore.Secondary game mechanics also feel very tedious. Lockpicking really only is a chore, and one you'll have to do pretty often moreover. Even stealing loot is painful because of the stupidly long animations which get triggered for every single action you perform. They're nice to watch the firt couple of times, but it just feels completely silly and boring when you pick up a bunch coins literally one at a time. Finally, the main city hub is also completely uninteresting. There's absolutely no challenge in exploring it, and I very quickly got bored of breaking into completely random windows (with once again a ridiculously long animation) only to slavage a couple of pointless items.After only 4 hours of gameplay, I'm already at the stage where I have absolutely no desire to get back to Thief, and think I will just stop there. I've only played the first 4 chapters (master difficulty), and so far there hasn't been one single moment where I felt that the game rewarded careful observation, planning or creative problem solving. It's only been about mindlessly crawling in the shadows, which should be one element of steal gameplay, but definitely not the whole thing. If you haven't played them yet, I would much rather recomment trying Dishonored, Splinter Cell: Blacklist, or the older Thief and Project: IGI games.

(i.e.: no Jump button, no built-in ironsights on the bow, no sword or dagger WTF?, rope arrows very limited, original Garrett voice actor was awesome, world-lore from 1st three games is gone). This is a good game, but if you've never played Thief 1 & 2...maybe 3 (all on Steam!) then you should try those first.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												6/10I got this game at Media Markt for 4,00 EUR which was a great find. This game has a storyline very similar to Dishonored (sneaking, plague in the city) however, unlike Dishonored, the plot lacks in consistency and the game play is very linear. At one point I just got sick of opening and closing drawers and basically steal everything because it felt like it was the only point of the game.  The first part is very similar to Dishonored but then it's like the writers decided to change course halfway and instead of a plague infected city you have a thing called primal that got into a girl's body and made her create the gloom and blind faceless naked monster (wtf?). Then there was a scene at an asylum totally out of character for this game and that aspect could have been better explored because it was the most interesting part for me (phantoms, loonies, hidden cashes, and an overral good story). But then it was over and back we go to stealling all the things.  I also have to complain about the map, it's horrid, takes 20m to get to a place. Honestly there were parts I enjoyed like the client jobs but it was a bother to go an get them because of the stupid map. I could have given this game a higher rating if it wasn't for the ending - absurd as it was not to mention rushed as hell.Anyway, wasn't expecting more from a 4,00 EUR game. Good Buy,

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I don't know why this game has such low scores and so many people bad mouthing it.  I have been a fan of stealth games since the original Thief: The Dark Project and of all the stealth games out there, the Thief series and the Splinter Cell series has been my favorite.  This game is a pure thief game, bringing back great memories of cleptomania and the terror induced with nearly being caught.  I loved routng around in every cubby I could find trying to get the maximum amount of gold or trying to pickpocket everyone in a level.  And this game rewards you for doing just that.  If you want to sneak through every level without being seen, the more you do that, the more skills you get that help you do just that.  If you want to stealth assassinate everyone in the game like a ninja, you can and the more you do it, the more skills you get to help you do it.  Really, my only complaints are that it has a linear story and no open world, which in today's video game world, it should have been just the opposite.  Overall, a great entry to the Thief series and I foresee myself playing this one through several times, despite its linear story.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												I have to give this title a 8/10. All in all it's a great game and proves to be very fun, especially with the sneaking aspect .So, here is my personal breakdown of the game.GRAPHICS- Absolutely freaking beautiful. Very gloomy setting to the game. With graphical settings on high, this game is most definitely eye candy. Only one issue with this and it just involves video quality and rendering at one of the cutscenes towards the end of the game. It appears to me that it is just the result of rushing the scene for whatever reason. It caught my eye and I'm betting I'm not alone. Otherwise flawless and fantastic experience.GAMEPLAY- Very responsive controls with a gamepad, no problems whatsoever. Engaging combat system which allows you to map inventory as you like, small upgrade system, just enough to keep you out of any customization menus for too long  and allows you to focus more on your creeping skills.STORYLINE- Interesting story that kept me grinding to see what was next( a good 20 hours even without secondary quests, no complaints here (although I cannot compare this with previous Thief titles as this is the first I've played). Regardless, i thought the game in itself did an extremely good job of morphing many story cutscenes directly into gaps of gameplay. UPDATES/SUPPORT- I know there was a save game problem due to a technical problem with time zones a little while back but the devs were quick to fix this problem and that is the mark of a good team. No problems I am aware of since that.OVERALL- To wrap it up, this game is definitely one to check out and not let slip through your fingers. I would recommend to everyone who loves: a good story, beautiful graphics, sneaking around, killing things, sneaking around, shooting arrows, blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up, burning♥♥♥♥♥♥ sneaking around, putting out candles, peeping through keyholes, picking locks, lifting loot while being sneaky, the dark, breaking bottles, and ummm...sneaking around ;)  Great Game, highly suggest checking it out.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I almost feel guilty with how much I've enjoyed this entry to the Thief series. Folks have chewed the game up for not being very devout to the series and that it's another case of a cherished franchise getting screwed by corporate repackaging. While this game is far from perfect, I really don't think that's warranted at all. It's rare I have this much genuine fun with a game.First, I'll mention the bad. This game was optimized by a twelve year old. I had some stuttering on my system even on lower graphical settings, a number of crashes, and the occasional sound-glitch that cut half the game's sound. The dialog and story can be really corny (I mean, someone literally uses the line "we're not so different, you and I" without joking. Seriously?), and there's a huge detriment to the fact that you can't jump. Yes, that's right, you can't jump. You need to go to ledges to jump down or to jump onto something, but you can't leap whenever you want.So, with all that said, why do I like it? Well, I'm the kind of gamer who really, really likes stealth games, particularly in the case of FPS. I played a stick-to-the-shadows rogue in Skyrim, I snuck around throughout the Metro series, and I couldn't get enough of the earlier Thief titles. One of the most satisfying feelings I get is looting a room blind, slipping past guards just as they're about to catch me, and solving some tricky puzzles to get to a safe. This game is flooded with secrets, and between missions, you travel a huge city with a number of nooks and crannies waiting to be explored. There's also the stealth roll, which allows you to very smoothly leap from shadow to shadow, which is tremendously satisfying. One of the best aspects, though, is the environment. There's so much great atmosphere in this game, from a creepy abandoned asylum (with jump scares, be warned), to a burning bridge, to a lavish mansion. I got lost trying to look for so many secrets, and the rewards for finding them were pretty satisfying on their own. I even like the fact that Garrett is total crap in a fight. Makes it that much more terrifying when you're caught, because you can't defend yourself nearly as easy as other games.All in all, I'd definitely say buy this beauty, even if you're a diehard fan of the earlier titles. Once you get over some of the more glaring aspects, this is a real diamond in the rough.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Despite a lot of negative reviews, I gave this game a shot.  I think a lot of the problems people had with the game have to do with focus and their difficulty setting. I did a custom playthrough on master difficulty with focus, knockouts, kills, food, waypoints, and button prompts all turned off. I went through the game with the majority as a ghost and somewhat as an opportunist.  And while some problems still persisted, I think the game was really fun.Some of the missions in the game were not very fun, and linear. Mission 1, the end of 4, the end of 6, and part of 8 were not very fun, but the rest were pretty great.Pros:Extremely fun stealth and gameplay, lots of different routes to take the majority of the game, lots of difficult loot to get, great side missions, majority of missions are fun, guards see you pretty easily (good thing). great atmosphere.  The city (will discuss below)Cons:bugs in sound, guard pathfinding, and a few other things.  Awful soundtrack with dubstep when detected.  Pretty bad chase sequences and climbing sequences.  bad storyOther than the gameplay, the best thing in the game, in my opinion, is the city or hub area.  It's huge and open, and with plenty of secret areas to discover.  It has very good atmosphere, with a lot of side missions and mini missions to do.  It has this feeling of despair which really helps the atmosphere out.Overall I liked the game a lot more than other people did. The last few missions were very tough and fun, and mission 5 is pretty creepy.Given a score I'd say 7/10 good game (real 10 scale, not ign 9/10 it's garbage)

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												For any fan of the Thief franchise wondering whether or not to get this game, my advice is to grab it. While there are several aspects of this game that frustrate me, overall the missions are extremely well made, visually stunning, and the sounds/music create a very immersive atmosphere. I'm a huge Thief fan, I've played Thief and Thief 2 about a million times, not to mention tons of fan missions (some of which are almost better than the original missions), and this game doesn't disappoint me. Could it be better? Yes. Here are the cons:Less freedom: Frequently during the game you will get the sense that you are being too heavily directed especially in the city going to and from missions. Loading screens/busy work: The city area (where you buy supplies, go to and from missions, etc) is the worst part of the game. It's easy to get lost because it's too full of dead ends, and the "gates" to get to the next area aren't marked. There are windows you pry open, most just lead to homes, some are the "gates" that take you into a new region of the city. Unfortunately the map doesn't tell you which is which so finding your way around can take a while and be annoying. Hand animations: This one doesn't bother me that much but I still wish it wasn't there. Whenever you grab loot or open a drawer/door there is a short animation of your hands grabbing/opening. Some people may not notice, I just think the game would flow better without the animations. Those are my biggest gripes, but the pros far outweigh them. The pros:The freaking missions: The missions (especially starting at chapter 5) are extremely well made and fun to play. Chapter 5 was very well done and managed to freak me out several times. The music and sounds are excellent, and missions are large, beautiful, and difficult just like Thief should be. Upgrades/Swoop: The upgrade system fits great with this type of game, and the new swoop move where you quickly and silently...well...swoop adds a great dynamic to your stealth movement. Overall this is a really fun game and a great addition to the Thief franchise (I like it a lot better than Deadly Shadows), and while the city area can be a headache, the actual missions more than make up for it.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												I highly recommend this game for any gamer who is into excellent, top notch, stealth games. Where many people state that Thief doesnt provides ways through to an objectives as advertized and that it is only a point A to point B game; yes, thats what it is however, there are MULTIPLE ways to get through to something and it is how you get from point A to point B that matters. You are armed with a bow, and the environment around you, you have the ability to buy upgrades for your gear and obtain Focus points (Perk points to enhance your skills and make the game slightly easier) So it is a stealth game with limits, but you can still play how you see fit.I will note to anyone wanting to buy this game though, the setting is very similar to that of Dishonored in terms of, there is a plauge ravaging the city but where in Dishonored that was the primary reason for doing things. In Thief a plauge is there as a reason to why there are limitations in the city, it holds little to no focus. The story (plot) is about people fighting for power, how it affects the lower classes, and that greed for power is ultimatley what plauges the city. So for story wise, I also reccomend it, if you keep in mind the irony that you are a Thief and what everyone else does around you. Also, it is a FIRST PERSON game, but one of the best I have played.If you liked Dishonored, you will like Thief, if you enjoyed the original Thief games, you will greatly enjoy this. Take my advice,  in purchasing this game though; wait until it goes on sale. Square Enix will undoubtedly create more DLC so save money where you can!Also note, this is a Reboot, people complain that it is not like the original Thief, and it isn't. But don't let that knock you out of giving this Reboot of a series a good shot. This game was released in a different generation and is very good for what it is. Do not let the metacritic scores trick you into not buying this game.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												This game is good and bad.  The world created is impeccable.  The gameplay is likewise well crafted and fun, particularly if you turn off all the visual aids and assists.  The original was ground-breaking where stealth gameplay was concerned, this game honors its roots for the most part, while gently bringing the genre forward.  After Splinter Cell and Dishonored took what Thief began and honed it, rebooting Thief required some tweaking.  This is one of the areas the game suceeds in; most the missions and sidequests are fun to play with a fair amount of choice and diversity.  The world is not entirely open, but open enough to allow exploration without moving too far away from the story.  Story, unfortunately is where the game falls on its face.  It is clumsy, leaves numerous loose ends and often pulls you out of the action to rush you through a thrown together cinematic.  Voice acting is mediocre and audio bugs repeat the same line constantly or layer them over other lines.  The City layout can be very confusing, which does not sooth the frustration of the repetitive running back and forth the game puts you through.  The game contains profanity that seems awkwardly out of place for the time period it tries to mimic and falls into the same childish trend of "there must be boobs!  And sex!!" that seems to be gripping so many Developers anymore.  Personally I thought Disnonored handled its "seedy grit" more professionally.  Maybe I'm just tried of cheap thrills replacing creative content.  Don't get me wrong, as a whole the game is enjoyable with several shining moments.  It's no Human Revolution, but it's entertaining enough for a playthrough or two.  A filler until the next Deus Ex comes out.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Well, I just finished the game now and I can confidently give it a solid rating of MEH/10.I didn't dislike it, and I still think it's better than Thief 3 by a long shot, but this modern update is to Thief what the Bioshock games are to System Shock.I think this game felt a lot closer to the originals. Yeah, it's missing direct references to the Hammerites, and the Trickster is mentioned once or twice. Yeah, it's a new voice actor, and yeah, there's a bunch of crap added to make the game easier. But taking into account that they have to make a sellable product, AND the fact that most of the hand holding can be turned off (most, but sadly not all), and I'm willing to be a lot more forgiving than I was towards Thief 3.Touching on the new voice acting and stylistic elements, Thief needed to be rebooted. There's no way they could have continued from 3 narratively, and a prequel would've been crap. On top of this, the game is coming out so long after the originals it would be very difficult to access a new market. So yeah, it had to go the way of the reboot. I would've preferred it if they'd kept closer to the original setting but they didn't and I think the game suffered for not doing so in the eyes of original Thief fans like myself. As far as the voice acting goes, I think the new guy did a good job trying to read like the old Garrett, but it didn't help that the lines he was reading were so dull.Story-wise, I think this is where the game REALLY drops the ball. You CANNOT tell a player they care about a character, then expect them to get emotionally attached from the start of the story. You DEFINITELY can't do this if the character the player is supposed to care about represents the exact opposite of the character you want to play in the game. I kept hoping the story was going to escalate to something bigger than Erin and, even though the city was at risk, I was disappointed that this was the motivation for Garrett throughout. When Erin fell in the prologue I rubbed my hands in anticiapation of the real story starting. Instead, it went no where fast and finished with one of the bigger WTF endings I've ever played. SO disappointing.Graphically, the game was incredible. I have no qualms with anything they did visually, except for the overblown effects used for gameplay purposes (peek through the tiny hole in the wall here! for example). The visuals were let down by the bland, somewhat imagination free designs of the environments though. Myabe I just didn't find them all, but I was hoping for secret passages, interesting ways into buildings, etc. Very little of that to be seen. Then, of course, there's the critical error of making points of no return for no good reason. Just for the hell of it, you've gone through this gate and you can't go back now. Why?! Is this some kind of forced replayability trick? Because it's just intensely frustrating.I almost switched the game off during the prologue when I saw "rope arrow points." Sadly, this was a reflection of most of the gameplay; trying to match the original, but falling short for who knows what reason. This just leads back into the unimaginative design of the levels again as the whole thing seems to have been made to tell this story rather than allowing players to make their own. This is nowhere near as bad of a problem as with other modern games forcing their story on you, but it still feels like a string of linear arenas within which I have a small selection of methods I can use to get by. I kind of liked the swoop mechanic, and the way I felt like I was IN the environment, but these were both kind of ruined by the way the NPCs DIDN'T seem to be in the environment. Being detected seemed utterly random sometimes, as were their reactions to things that happened around them.As a jumping point for future Thief games, I'd definitely say this is a good start, but there's a list of Dos and Don'ts that come with that.Do:Build levels as real working environments, then give the player an objective and a set of skills and let them go wild in it. - These games should be about exploration, not forced routes and limited paths. Sometimes this'll allow the players to break the game (stacking crates to get onto parts of levels I wasn't supposed to in the original games, for example) but that's all part of the playing experience and doesn't take away anywhere near as much as boxing a player in with invisible walls and limited choices.ADD PROPER ROPE ARROWS - Seriously, there's no excuse for this.Embrace the diversity of the original source material and write smarter, not artier. - What the hell happened at the end of the game?! I have no idea, and to be honest I don't really care. You forced a relationship on me that I had no interest in and now the game is over I don't care enough to replay any of it. For an example of good plat twists, see Thief 2 when you go to pay the Sherrif a visit.Let me jump where and when I want to. - Because when I have to go through a convoluted Rube Goldberg style method to reach a platform I could blatantly leap to, your game looks dumb. In fact I'll expand on this and suggest your artists and level designers communicate more because when there's a chunk of wall with enough handholds in it to practically walk up the wall, but I can't because there isn't a "climbing grill" there, it looks dumb.Don't:Add pointless third person sections for no good damn reason. - Or at all for that matter. It ripped me so far out of the game I physically recoiled. Suddenly, instead of swooping and lurking in shadows, I'm prancing around on the pipe using a grappling hook to jump to grills and... WAIT A MOMENT, a freaking grappling hook?! The claw has a damn rope on it? Then why the hell can't I use this in about 99% of the rest of the game?! There's so many ways that would be useful! Seriously, it's like the Deus Ex: HR boss battles; a completely alien, different game that had no place being there at all.Points of no return. - Ever. Seriously, there's barely ever a good enough reason for this. Ever.There's no need for a city between levels. - This just bloats the game with running back and forth through the same damn environments for no good reason. If the time spent making the city had been spent on the levels, the game could've been far more focused and probably more enjoyable. On top of this, running through a city apparently populated by a dozen guards and half as many random drunks/beggars/civillians inexplicably walking up and down the same street is WEIRD. Maybe the rest of the cities population are all sleeping through this eternal night? NOPE. Having broken into a vast number of buildings and homes, the player will realise that the gloom has been far more devestating than previously imagined and anyone with enough money to live off the streets has already perished! Apparently being homeless, or a thug for hire, is a cure for the debilitating disease!This game could've been great, but instead it just leaves a bitter taste. Again, I'm not saying I diliked it. Despite everything I've said, there was still some entertainment to be had, but it was shallow and mostly a let down. It was like scoring a date with the hottest girl in town, just to spend the whole night listening to her talking about her recent trip to the toilet. Lovely to look at and spend time with, but not what you expected or hoped for and kind of unpleasant to sit through for too long.I'm glad this game was made, and I hope there are more like it, because even though it was far from the Thief game I wanted to play it's even further from the mindless rail-shooters/multiplayer shoot-fests that seem to be driving the games industry today. At least there are studios out there who are TRYING to make games more interesting. Yeah, they missed the mark, maybe they even missed the target, but at least they were aiming for it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Really good game if you have the patience, Thief is a game you can't take is you want to rush things. Here you play as a thief (see the name), you're not an assassin, you're not a ninja neither a warrior. You play as a thief, it means you have to steal things and stay in the shadows if you want to live, fighting nearly always means dying.If you can take that, this is for you.Thief is a sequel to an excellent serie which was thought to be dead. A lot of fans will tell you it's not the same, that all the atmosphere is gone. Well it's only half true. Thief HAD to get rid of some gameplay elements to become more manageable but still, it does not betray the spirit of its predecessors. When you look at the story, it's true that some things should have been preserved, there were lots of elements linked to the cults taking place in this universe and most of them were cut in the end which is quite sad.You might be discouraged by the repetitive loading screen when you visit the HUB but it is quite rare during most of the game since you're almost always on a mission.In the end, I would say that Thief is a good game, it's not excellent but still you might be surprised and like it. It is now quite affordable if you are concerned about the price so if you want to try a new experience or you simply are a fan of infiltration: do not hesitate, it is worth it.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I never played the original Thief games on PC. My first Thief game was the excellent (well I thought so!) Deadly Shadows on the original Xbox, which I mostly played in third-person.This reboot is first-person only but I really enjoyed it despite the mixed reviews it got. It has a good setting, sadly broken up into areas separated by loading screens, and each of the missions have different routes through them and they can be tackled in different ways so it doesn't feel linear. Graphically the game is terrific, making good use of the aging Unreal Engine 3, and the overall story is good. Voice-acting and dialogue is fine but music is sparse.Unfortunately for this version of Thief, Dishonored came out first and was overall the better and more interesting game (particularly in terms of abilities) but this is still an entertaining stealth romp if lurking around in shadows is your thing.

Items for collection don’t tell a story or have any importance. The game just really feels rushed and disappointing that they couldn’t capture any of the original magic from the series. Saying that it runs well, didn’t crash and gives value for money in length.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Considering the fact that I suck at stealth games, you should probably take what I say below with a grain of salt.Pros: Visuals and gameplay. When playing the game, I found myself really enjoying the movements and the design of almost everything. The graphics are beautiful (and I have never been so fascinated by the hand movements of a character in my entire life until I played this game....). As for the gameplay: again, it's a stealth game so confrontation with enemies are not recommended or encouraged and, while the option is available, the tools and abilites you're provided within the game support this. One of the better reviews for this game points out the limited range of weapons/tools you're given to use, and makes a good point that that makes it difficult to kill someone when you're discovered via beating them to death with a blackjack (I honestly laughed out loud when I read that section of the review). And adding to that (or would this be pointing against?), you have to remember that you're a thief not an assassin, the limited range of weapons you have support stealth and distraction. Plus you have a number of actions to do when caught: attempt to run and hide (with varying results) or beat the crap out of the guard with the risk of catching the attention of others (if there are any). Also, the only way you'd possibly kill someone in this game is if you've missed the takedown option while you were beating them within an inch of their life, you're shooting arrows at them, or setting nearby things on fire (I don't know if piling their unconscious bodies on top of each other count, but the loud cracking sounds they make when you do makes me wonder...)Cons: Storyline and characters development and narration are okay. Could it be better? Probably (but you probably know something's wrong when you're more heartbroken about Jenivere the bird than that one girl you're trying to save). While traveling the city, you're still liable to be lost and confused even while using the map, because it's that useless unless you're tracking an objective or you remember the general places of things (but then that's what online guides are for I guess). Also: disembodied voices (but I guess you've already heard of that one haven't you?)I don't know if that's all I have to say about the game (I feel like if I try to think of anymore right now I'm probably nitpicking).But all in all, I think this is a game that's worth playing if you enjoy stealth games, and is the type of game you can play again and again, if not for the storyline and characters then definitely for the gameplay and visuals.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Reading all the negative reviews, apparently this game isn't for everyone. However, based on the aesthetic aspects of the game (the atmosphere, detailed graphics, and artistic loading screens), and the fact that the stealth mechanics were pretty much just what I look for in a game, I would give this an 8.5/10 stars.Pros:-Smooth gameplay with few exceptions-Beautiful atmosphere with a soundtrack that matches -Great stealth mechanics; cannot rely on combat-Very well done suspense in the asylum level-Decent storylineCons:-I don't mind the loading screens (they go by fast on my system), but I guess other players do-AI could be more challenging (played Master difficulty, and though it was a bit challenging, I expected it to be harder.) The game does allow customized difficulty, though.-Stupid ropesOther:-Definite deviations from the Thief canon, though this game obviously takes place in a later era. History has repeated itself and a new Garrett (perhaps a descendant of the original), with many similar abilities and allies, takes the center stage. It makes perfect sense as you play the game (there are hints and references everywhere), and it helped me, as a fan of the original games, deal with the many changes to the Thief lore that took place in this new game.-People compare this to Dishonored, which I've also played and love. I say it's like comparing apples to oranges.-Remove 1/2 star if you don't like your games to end with a little ambiguity.

												6/10I got this game at Media Markt for 4,00 EUR which was a great find. This game has a storyline very similar to Dishonored (sneaking, plague in the city) however, unlike Dishonored, the plot lacks in consistency and the game play is very linear. At one point I just got sick of opening and closing drawers and basically steal everything because it felt like it was the only point of the game.  The first part is very similar to Dishonored but then it's like the writers decided to change course halfway and instead of a plague infected city you have a thing called primal that got into a girl's body and made her create the gloom and blind faceless naked monster (wtf?). Then there was a scene at an asylum totally out of character for this game and that aspect could have been better explored because it was the most interesting part for me (phantoms, loonies, hidden cashes, and an overral good story). But then it was over and back we go to stealling all the things.  I also have to complain about the map, it's horrid, takes 20m to get to a place. Honestly there were parts I enjoyed like the client jobs but it was a bother to go an get them because of the stupid map. I could have given this game a higher rating if it wasn't for the ending - absurd as it was not to mention rushed as hell.Anyway, wasn't expecting more from a 4,00 EUR game. Good Buy,

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Not a bad game. Not as good as it could be. The primary character can't do simple things (like jump) except in certain occasions, which means they had to put ramps in areas to allow access.  Seriously, what kinda crap is that? Can't even hop up in the air to look at something? Console-like key functions get boring and frustrating (to open windows, hold a key, then hit it over and over until the window opens), wasting 10 seconds on some windows, while others open after the initial space bar. Plus, why keep locking drawers Ive already unlocked if there's nothing in them the 2nd time around?  Can't skip some of the long mandatory "watch this to see how great the story is"  scenes, like the elevator ride up. Can't skip the "look how scary we can (not) be" scenes. Watching them during the first playthrough was barely tolerable. I didnt buy the game expecting Oscar-winning actors, and after the first, somewhat disappointing, disjointed ending, IDGAF about the "story line". Fine, have mandatory crapscenes the first play-through, then allow them to be skipped. Also, if I wanted to play a 2-D side shooter where I'm locked in to one course of action, I WOULDNT, because I don't. Running through collapsing buildings trying to get loot before I burn to death, dying , then trying again and again until I make it through by trial and error. Not enjoyable, no benefit to the game, I'd say someone's girlfriend or boyfriend wanted to show off his/her arcade style design skills. Also didn't enjoy wandering around trying to figure out how to get where I needed to go . Surely it wouldn't have been too hard to have a map with freaking location names on it. I'd bet that was left out so that the total  time spent searching for a way to get to a portion of the city could be counted as play time, when it's  not really. The end of-mission rewards for goals didn't make sense. Ok fine, let's have a goal like don't be detected, and then have one for 10 combat takedowns, which pretty much means one of them isn't achievable. At least if I DO 3 or 4  of the goals, why are only 2 of them shown at the end? Are the goals based on play style?  Also, have one AUTOSAVE slot of you must, but if I hit quick load, allow it to load MY last save,. On the topic of saving, what moron came up with the idea that we can't save if anyone is looking for us? Sneaking through an area for 10 minutes, get spotted by one guard and we can't save while anyone is alerted even if we're hiding and there's no way they can reach us? That's a CROCK!. Next, the restrictions on passing through the transitions where we need to move a board. Dash to an exit , get spotted by a guard, try to move through the exit and get told,no , you have to stay, wait for the guard to come up and fight him. Again, BS. On the topic of fighting, yeah, I get it, we're not supposed to fight. I guess the same moron designed the fight limitations. Hit someone with a sword, try to hit them again, nope! can't do it, gotta pause until they hit you back. Can't block, and dodging wont work if youre in a narrow area. Same thing with trying to blackjack someone to initiate a combat takedown. Sitting for 5 seconds mashing the blackjack key while the screen is prompting me to do a regular takedown, then the guard turns around and I get nailed by 3 other guards when he yells because I couldnt initiate a combat takedown. Just crappy crappy coding. Now that I've listed (most) of the irritating and pointless parts of this game that had the potential to be great, but missed, here are the good parts.  Not many FPS games are worth a crap anymore. This one wasnt great, suffered from an attempt to make it more than it was, but it was fun when I wasn't trying to figure out how to get to a certain portion of the city if I didn't want to go on a prescribed mission. I did like being able to see what the goals were for each mission, but I and many others figured out how to by accident. I like the ability to jump from target to target in mid-air without falling. I like the bow, but it's underpowered until after it's leveled up. Shoot someone in the head or face with a bow, they should be down for the count, period. Over all, did I like the game, despite the many shortcomings? Yes. Was it worth $59? HELL NO!! Would I spent $59 on another game from the same developer? Nope, sorry. $50 and up should be reserved for top of the line, well-written games. No longer does just being New mean a game should be priced that high. I do recommend the game, but with reservations. I'd give it a 6 on a scale of 1 to 10. That might seem like a low score, but a lot of the games coming out are only 3 to 5. The main benefit is this game CAN be played for hours and hours.

												This is a game I really wanted to enjoy but found myself struggling to the whole way through the game. I am a new thief player and have always enjoyed stealth games and was looking forward to see this reboot of the franchise that started it all. And all this game had me saying was I should really be playing dishonored instead. It felt almost exactly the same in every aspect. This would be fine by me if it they had been released close to each other but dishonored came out over 2 years prior which is a standard development cycle.The main story can get schizophrenic at times and several times I was lost having to look at recaps online of what was actually going on. The game liked to switch between 3 main storylines and not really explain when or why they were doing this. I think this was to make the game seem more mysterious and edgy, which I just found to be irritating. It seemed like the story was mashed together when square needed to stretch out this 7 hour main story.Now there are some points that I fail to grasp between game play mechanics and the story. The main one being that there is a huge point in this game to say that he doesn't kill people, only the ones who need it. This is brought up at least 4 times in the first 5 minutes of gameplay. Even saying that it was wrong of Erin to kill a guard  Yet one of the first things you get is broadhead arrows allowing you to just headshot your way through the game if you wanted. It even gives you slow-motion kill cams, Garrett you hate killing as much as I hate Lord Gaben.  I assume this was implemented to help out newer players but it just kind of makes his moral high ground that is referred to countless times fall flat.This games stealth feels fantastic 95% of the time. Getting to hide in the shadows and climb your way across the rooftops and hiding in the alleys to make it through complex puzzles of guards. In almost ever encounter in this game I found a way to get through it without having to knockout or kill guards. Another thing that I really enjoyed were the weapon upgrades and trinkets. It seemed like a fair amount of thought went into creating the names for them and what they do each of them made sense and were well thought out that level of immersion added a nice touch when upgrading my health of focus. I would say that my main gripes from this game didn't come from anything related to the game play but rather that the story was cliche and bland. I feel like if that I had put more time creating a fleshed out story that didn't quite feel so linear and run of the mill I would have enjoyed this game much more. But with nice stealth mechanics and thought put into gameplay I have to say this game works for someone who wants to take their time and not marathon through it and for someone playing on a console.Final vote console gamer and a 6 out of 10.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												While I did not play any other thief game before this I find Thief 4 very interesting and fun. The stealth mechanic is nothing special but still a lot of fun when you mange to get away with something just before an enemy spots you. Combat is close to non existant in this game and im not so sure thats a bad thing, the game is based around stealth. If people want combat they should play Dishonored instead.The city even if not huge like in somegames, it provides a fun way to get around and jump from mission to mission while offering a few side quests and interesting places to loot along the way.I was amazed at the amount of detail put in the light effects but the textures could be better.Overall this game is awesome and if you have a spare 50$ you should try it.8.5/10 on gameplay7/10 on story7/10 on graphics10/10 for originality and fetures8/10 overall

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												In short… Based on the amazing originals this game is disappointing. The game feels simply rushed, it would have been so much better had it been polished and re-worked. However, I bought it on sale and found it worth the money in the long run; it wasn’t as terrible as some would suggest, just not great. You do occasionally get a glimpse or feeling reminiscent of the originals but never quite hits the spot.The graphics look good but still way too much copying of models, once you’ve seen one cabinet, chest etc. you’ve seen them all. The story is not that interesting and just confusingly unimportant. Annoying repeat animations for certain actions that are just not needed and waste time. Items for collection don’t tell a story or have any importance. The game just really feels rushed and disappointing that they couldn’t capture any of the original magic from the series. Saying that it runs well, didn’t crash and gives value for money in length.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Im not an oldschool gamer, so i havent beat the other thief games (but i own them). I really want to play this game, but there is a level in this that i am about 20 seconds into the main building and i already quit the game. Keep in mind for those of you that hate horror, level 5 is about an asylum with gollum like creatures that has been abandon and overrun basicly. If you do not like horror, i would not sugjest this game (unless you can do horror for like an hour). The mojority of the game isnt scary, so its really just a mission of horror, but that stopped me. The game is fun, and i bought it because i owned the other 3 thief games, exept they seem to give very little instruction and expert you to do this thing. I got a couple of missions in on the last one but still couldnt figure anything out. This gamme (as i had hoped), is alot simpler. There is a map marker and a dot on your screen above the objective, but it is not like it is handing it to you. I often spend alot of time trying to get to it because there are buildings in the way. So, even though this review isnt very long, i must say it is a good game, even though i havent beat it. Remember, if you do not like horror games, i would think about if you want this or not because then you dont play the whole game, but still, it is an amazing game.
